But in generally, we try not to do the incompatible changes.

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1While this fixes the bug, it also unnecessarily lets operate all the following code on an empty string. The special case of empty string should be handled immediately instead. Note that such empty strings can not only occur during TextToColumns but also in CSV import, in which case it can be even performance relevant.

Patch Set 3:(1 comment)So I did an initial review of the patch and I think the general concept is ok but I'm still not sure about some of the details.Mainly the use of -1 as special column index and having special cases for it everywhere.I'm not sure if we should not instead switch to a solution that has a valid ScAttrArray for any ScColumn and if there is not yet a ScColumn inside of the ScTable we query the ScAttrArray stored in ScTable. I need to read more and talk to you, Eike and Kohei to see what is the best solution.

Patch Set 3:> (1 comment) >  > So I did an initial review of the patch and I think the general > concept is ok but I'm still not sure about some of the details. >  > Mainly the use of -1 as special column index and having special > cases for it everywhere. >  > I'm not sure if we should not instead switch to a solution that has > a valid ScAttrArray for any ScColumn and if there is not yet a > ScColumn inside of the ScTable we query the ScAttrArray stored in > ScTable. I need to read more and talk to you, Eike and Kohei to see > what is the best solution.Thanks for the review.The ScAttrArray object (aNextColAttrArray) in the ScTable has its nCol member set to -1 to indicate that it represents all unallocated columns. The check nCol == -1 in ScAttrArray methods is to prevent making calls to pDocument methods like InvalidateTextWidth() from aNextColAttrArray as it requires a valid/existing Column.The special cases in the ScAttrArray methods are in fact for the case of default formatting where nCount == 0 and pData == nullptr.
Patch Set 3:@Markus, @eike, could we have a better review/merge of this patch ? Dennis has other patches waiting on this.thanks in advance.

Patch Set 3:> > (1 comment) > > > > So I did an initial review of the patch and I think the general > > concept is ok but I'm still not sure about some of the details. > > > > Mainly the use of -1 as special column index and having special > > cases for it everywhere. > > > > I'm not sure if we should not instead switch to a solution that > has > > a valid ScAttrArray for any ScColumn and if there is not yet a > > ScColumn inside of the ScTable we query the ScAttrArray stored in > > ScTable. I need to read more and talk to you, Eike and Kohei to > see > > what is the best solution. >  > Thanks for the review. >  > The ScAttrArray object (aNextColAttrArray) in the ScTable has its > nCol member set to -1 to indicate that it represents all > unallocated columns. The check nCol == -1 in ScAttrArray methods is > to prevent making calls to pDocument methods like InvalidateTextWidth() > from aNextColAttrArray as it requires a valid/existing Column. >  > The special cases in the ScAttrArray methods are in fact for the > case of default formatting where nCount == 0 and pData == nullptr.But do we actually call these methods for the default formatting? As far as I read the code the default formatting is stored in the ScTable instance. If these methods are supposed to be never called for the default formatting I think an assert is the better solution.Sorry that it currently takes me a bit longer to review patches. I'm quite busy with my thesis and can not afford to spend too much time on LibreOffice.

Patch Set 3:> But do we actually call these methods for the default formatting? > As far as I read the code the default formatting is stored in the > ScTable instance. If these methods are supposed to be never called > for the default formatting I think an assert is the better > solution.As per the current patch the default formatting is not stored in any of the ScAttrArray objects (in ScTable and in ScColumn), it is used only when required, by callingpDocument->GetDefPattern(). When an ScAttrArray object is constructed, by default it is set empty that is,  pData <- nullptr and nCount <- 0which is indicative of the default format. If default formatting is stored inScTable instance, for a new document if user adds new content for say first N columnswithout any formatting, then the first N ScColumn instances of ScAttrArray will getcreated by copying the default formatting from the ScTable instance. This can be avoidedby making ScTable's ScAttrArray instance be empty by default indicating default formatting.But the penalty is we have to add special cases everywhere for ScAttrArray methods. But I am not sure if we want this. Should we revert to ScTable instance storing the def.formatting ? - it would make the code simpler.

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1(7 comments)So.. with the third attempt to review I finally managed to wrap my head around this.. ;-)I think having the aNextColAttrArray for unallocated columns at ScTable is a good approach. Same as Markus I'm not very fond of the spurious nCol!=-1 checks sprinkled over, but I also don't have a better solution. Calling any document content related functions for the unallocated column clearly must not happen.Overall I'm impressed, you seem to have dug deeply into this.I have some inline comments about some minor changes. Once these are done, do you think this would be ready to be added for 5.3?

Patch Set 3:> I think having the aNextColAttrArray for unallocated columns at > ScTable is a good approach. Same as Markus I'm not very fond of the > spurious nCol!=-1 checks sprinkled over, but I also don't have a > better solution. Calling any document content related functions for > the unallocated column clearly must not happen.Hi EikeThanks a lot for the review. Just to clarify regarding the nCol != -1 check, we need to let methods like Reset(), SetPatternArea(), ApplyStyleArea() to be called for the aNextColAttrArray but *without* changing any document content. An alternative to nCol != -1 checks is that we can have a default parameter or data member called bUnallocated with default value = false for all such methods and use that instead of (nCol != -1) when calling from aNextColAttrArray. Would that be better at least in terms of readability of the code ?In the meantime I will fix the other issues as per your comments. Thanks.

Patch Set 4:I have made changes as per Markus'/Eike's comments.Copypasting my previous comment so reviewers don't miss them : -Regarding the nCol != -1 check, we need to let methods like Reset(), SetPatternArea(), ApplyStyleArea() to be called for the aNextColAttrArray but *without* changing any document content. An alternative to nCol != -1 checks is that we can have a default parameter or data member called bUnallocated with default value = false for all such methods and use that instead of (nCol != -1) when calling from aNextColAttrArray. Would that be better at least in terms of readability of the code ?

Patch Set 4:> An > alternative to nCol != -1 checks is that we can have a default > parameter or data member called bUnallocated with default value = > false for all such methods and use that instead of (nCol != -1) > when calling from aNextColAttrArray. Would that be better at least > in terms of readability of the code ?I don't think so. To the contrary, it would mean to have to keep yet one more variable in sync.

Patch Set 5:> (5 comments) >  > Starts to look good. Confirm you have tested it and it works well > now?Not perfect yet. It works well for a pre-defined table created with direct sql like:CREATE TABLE "myTable" ("id" INTEGER NOT NULL,"decNumber" DECIMAL(9,3), PRIMARY KEY  ("id"))But in the Table Design GUI I still cannot change the field properties "Decimal places" and "Length". The sql statement generated after creating a table with a decimal in it looks like:CREATE TABLE "myTable" ("id" INTEGER NOT NULL,"decNum" DECIMAL, PRIMARY KEY  ("id"))So (precision, scale) part is missing. I think this part is missing in Tables::createStandardColumnPart, and I can fix it.But I still don't know why are the property fields not editable. There may be some settings somewhere to enable it, and I could query those numbers through PROPERTY_ID_SCALE and PROPERTY_ID_PRECISION...

Patch Set 1:> Those vars are read without a mutex locked, > so dialogs can still be displayed multiple times.That's possible, but highly improbable (requires two UI (!) code paths to cross this in ~exactly same time), and I suppose that reading bool without lock is safe to prefer faster implementation to the one that has mutex overhead. > no, not unconditionally; each instance of JavaContext creates at > most one instance of JavaInteractionHandlerSorry, missed that. Will look further.

Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1Although a big change, I think it is safe. Only documents created outside of LibreOffice should currently be able to create document like this.  Plus, the ODF spec says it should be honoured anyway, if it is defined.The downside is that now the document will display properly, but if someone tries to edit those settings (and perhaps only GO to any format dialog, and then hit OK instead of cancel), the layout will reset to zero padding. Basically, we get read-only compatibility in 5.3, where before we had no compatibility at all.

Patch Set 3:vmiklos: I was planning to re-enable that code once the flip switches for the default to be true, and not false.  That's why I left in that line of code. I thought it would be better to leave all of this compat code in than to rip it all out just to find out that compat is needed for some reason.  There is a TON of code that could be removed if one really wants to strip all of this "require a border" code.  But that sounds like a LO5.6 task.The first patch in 5.4 will be one with this comment:tdf41542 globally allow padding without borders: UIThis is the primary fix for tdf#41542 - enabling the UI to adjust thepadding without requiring an enabled border line.  This effectively changesALLOW_PADDING_WITHOUT_BORDERS into a preventative compatibility settinginstead of an enabling one.If an AllowPaddingWithoutBorders=false case is ever found, additional codewill be needed to send the SID_ALLOW_PADDING_WITHOUT_BORDERS setting foreach type of border (page, paragraph, image etc). It currently is only setupfor frames. see commit f013d4a1f4073cda735befd6e446bee35f3db65cThat patch will remove out the comment and add back in the commented out code.

Patch Set 1:Urk - using virtual inheritance for all of the OutputDevice ref and unref calls ... like this:class VCL_DLLPUBLIC OutputDevice : public virtual VclReferenceBaseI assume that this will then put all those nice previously in-lined, and optimize-able out mnRefCnt++ and -- pairs behind virtual function calls. But of course - we could look at the generated code to see if it in fact it is that awful ;-)What's the stripped binary size increase would be a good question.

Patch Set 3:I did notice the #N/A error in xls, but saw that as unavoidable as xls does not support LOGNORMDIST with 4 arguments.I could try to remove the 4th argument when not needed, but otherwise I see no solution; or should I convert to LOGNORM.DIST in these cases to preserve the formula?

Patch Set 3:> I did notice the #N/A error in xls, but saw that as unavoidable as > xls does not support LOGNORMDIST with 4 arguments. > I could try to remove the 4th argument when not needed, but > otherwise I see no solution; or should I convert to LOGNORM.DIST in > these cases to preserve the formula?Should be converted to LOGNORM.DIST, not removing arguments. Not sure at the moment how substituting with another function operator could be accomplished though, probably somewhere in sc/source/filter/excel/xeformula.cxx around XclExpFmlaCompImpl::ProcessFunction()

Patch Set 2:This I don't understand.A new document with LOGNORMDIST(a)LOGNORMDIST(a,b)LOGNORMDIST(a,b,c)LOGNORMDIST(a,b,c,d)is saved as ods asLOGNORMDIST(a,b,c)LOGNORMDIST(a,b,c)LOGNORMDIST(a,b,c)LOGNORMDIST(a,b,c,d)and saved as xlsx asLOGNORMDIST(a,b,c)LOGNORMDIST(a,b,c)LOGNORMDIST(a,b,c)LOGNORM.DIST(a,b,c,d), just as I intended.Opening these saved documents with Excel produces for the ods:LOGNORM.DIST(a,b,c,d)LOGNORM.DIST(a,b,c,d)LOGNORM.DIST(a,b,c,d)LOGNORM.DIST(a,b,c,d)and for the xlsx:LOGNORMDIST(a,b,c)LOGNORMDIST(a,b,c)LOGNORMDIST(a,b,c)LOGNORMDIST(a,b,c,d)which IMHO shows that the conversions done by Calc are OK and that Excel cannot handle ODF documents well.Could you explain what is not good yet with this patch set?To me the backward compatibility for LOGNORMDIST within Calc is preserved (concerning the now optional last 3 arguments) and the interoperability with Excel is taken care of.

Patch Set 1:Thank you for your review.> However I decided against it, since reading configuration on every repaint brings some performance penaltyI see, just wondered if the performance penalty is really severe or not.What we want then would be to derive utl::ConfigurationListener andprovide a suitable ConfigurationChanged( ::utl::ConfigurationBroadcaster*, sal_uInt32 ),as in Calc's ScModule (ScModule::ConfigurationChanged() in sc/source/ui/app/scmod.cxx)and Writer's SwModule (SwModule::ConfigurationChanged in sw/source/uibase/app/apphdl.cxx), etc.Right?

Patch Set 1:> > However I decided against it, since reading configuration on > every repaint brings some performance penalty >  > I see, just wondered if the performance penalty is really severe or > not. I didn't observe any slowdown myself, but that doesn't mean that other people wouldn't, who knows what they do with their office :) e.g. this blogpost explains why are frequent configuration readings a bad idea: https://mmohrhard.wordpress.com/2015/10/07/short-update-about-the-performance-testing/ > What we want then would be to derive utl::ConfigurationListener and > provide a suitable ConfigurationChanged( ::utl::ConfigurationBroadcaster*, > sal_uInt32 ), > as in Calc's ScModule (ScModule::ConfigurationChanged() in > sc/source/ui/app/scmod.cxx) > and Writer's SwModule (SwModule::ConfigurationChanged in > sw/source/uibase/app/apphdl.cxx), etc. > Right?Aye, that's exactly what I meant :)

Patch Set 1:Some explanation.Stressing the WebDAV provider a bit, I found some new problem, specifically when trying to use LO in a 'multi LO user; way.By 'multi LO user' I mean working on the same WebDAV file two or more users, with only one at a time working.Seems that framework changed a bit in the behaviour, some new problem popped up, probably one of the cause is the XCommandEnvironment missing, specifically to enable authentication.The first patch set of this series is a possible simplified solution to obtain a default XComandEnvironment whenever a default ucbhelper::Content is instantiated.The other patch set in this series is the way to use it.This is an implementation stemming from <https://gerrit.libreoffice.org/gitweb?p=core.git;a=commitdiff;h=3b26a2a403ca5e99b0dd07d042d47501c091af16>.The comment in the code added in the first patch set of this series should explain the rationale behind the change.Should I open a bug as a matter of explanation and use (the bug) as anchor point for the commits?What do you think?Thanks.

Patch Set 1:* If you feel that a bugzilla issue would be useful to add more information, then by all means create one.* I wouldn't split this into two changes; it's easier to understand new functionality together with a use case of it, so I'd (almost) always combine in a single change the newly introduced functionality with the use case that motivated its introduction.

Patch Set 1:Module sd is curious in that it's source is split into sd/source/core/ and sd/source/ui/, yet much of sd/source/ui/ is actually included in the core sd/Library_sd.mk, not the UI sd/Library_sdui.mk.  That means that .cxx from sd/source/core/ routinely include .hxx from sd/source/ui/inc/.  I'm not sure what the best overall fix is for that, maybe it asks for a reorganization of the the files?  Thorsten or Armin may have an opinion.  (And if nobody has a good opinion, it's probably fine to include this as-is, as the sd/soruce/ui/inc/ include directory is apparently already made visible when compiling sd/source/core/.)

Patch Set 1:> I'm not sure what > the best overall fix is for that, maybe it asks for a > reorganization of the the files?  Thorsten or Armin may have an > opinion.  (And if nobody has a good opinion, it's probably fine to > include this as-is, as the sd/soruce/ui/inc/ include directory is > apparently already made visible when compiling sd/source/core/.)Yes, this change is useful regardless - a reorg sounds good, and getting rid of relative include paths even helps with that.

Patch Set 5:(2 comments)So I'm not going to remove my -2 from this patch, until this is implemented better from the architecture POV.Suggested implementation would contain a struct or class holding pointers to the buttons and some operations on them, such as i) pressing buttons on/off ii) making sure only one buttons is pressed at time iii) containing some mapping of buttons (pointers to them respectively) and pointers to functions to call when the button is pressed See for example sc/source/ui/cctrl/checklistmenu.cxx, ScTabStops therein is example of such structureHaving 5+ if-else's to controlling the workflow is simply not acceptable (well, maybe it is in some freshman university C++ introductory course, but not here)

Patch Set 1:not in both places?  Ideally eventually it can be fixed...I don't take reverting a unit test lightly, but this one has always been a complete thorn and I'm convinced that keeping in the code that allows it to currently pass is detrimental.  Thus the slightly modified unit test which looks terrible on released versions of 5.x, and mostly correct with all the changes in 5.3.  It certainly is WRONG before this patch hits, so it is a toss-up of one unit test verses another.With the regular page-break, it would be possible to switch to the follow style at that point (which in some cases would be too late, but better than nothing), but doing so has given me round-trip problems that I haven't been able to solve yet.  So one step at a time, and at least get this in before 5.3 releases.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1Your patch is basically right. But note that this is introducing new feature,because so far '%' is a reserved keyword only to mark up line comments (started with "%%")and to encode greek symbols such as %alpha. And a single '%' is an empty token.Now we are making a single '%' represent itself. I would like to see- fix calculation of m_aCurToken.nCol at line 660 in case of a single '%', and- a unit test.Thanks.

Patch Set 2:FWIW, given enough time, I would like to get rid of these MS-DOC style end-of-cell and end-of-row markers in dmapper, let dmapper work with the OOXML table model with its explicit starts and ends (instead of gluing similar rows together), and move all the create-table-from-similar-rows heuristics from dmapper to rtftok, which still needs it.It bothers me a bit that in the OOXML case we drop this table start/end information in the tokenizer, then in dmapper we spend time reconstructing it again. But it's not a trivial change, and it has been always like this, so not urgent... :-)The fact that in RTF it's OK to specify table properties after the contents of the table, while OOXML specifies it before (and because of this, the RTF tokenizer has to buffer the table contents) is just a cherry on the "cake".

Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2Yes, the code that makes a selection by indices looks unreachable to me. dbaccess seems to assume that "by bookmark" and "by indices" are two possibilities and to pass a selection along with a boolean flag to document which one it is. Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1(4 comments)Looks good so far, but there is small problem with default creation:As soon as you override the CreateDefaultObject method, what happens is that SwFEShell::CreateDefaultShape is never called for all SIDs that use ConstRectangle. So:1. SwFEShell::CreateDefaultShape has code that previously handled line creation (OBJ_LINE case), and now it becomes unused.2. Some SIDs aren't properly handled in the new CreateDefaultObject, so e.g. if you create a textbox, it created outside the page, then "jumps" into its place.We have now 2 options:1. Implement support for all ConstRectangle based SIDs into CreateDefaultObject, and remove the unused code from SwFEShell::CreateDefaultShape.2. Not override CreateDefaultObject, and instead implement everything in SwFEShell::CreateDefaultShape.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1(2 comments)> This is for initial comments. I've just inserted a placeholder for > media file path. It reads "Insert Media Path Here". I, or may be > someone else, might pass actual Media Path there.Come on, you can do it ;-) it is trivial by now, when you got this farImplement a new method of MediaControl class, e.g. implUpdateURLField (it could take OUString as an argument). It should do mpMediaPath->SetText($some_url), where $some_url you're going to obtain from maItem (avmedia::MediaItem) member variable, by simply calling its getURL() method. Call this method from MediaControl::setState(). That's it.

Patch Set 2:I'm unable to get the resize function to work. Other mentioned things can be quite easily implemented. The problem is that the media URL is not set the time when we setText() mpMediaPath to "Insert Media Path Here". Although media URL is set by the time setState() is called, but I'm only able to update the text of mpMediaPath from there but not the width, which results in cutoff text/overlapping elements. I had implemented this taking into consideration, the example of <TextEdit>mpTimeEdit, which seemed similar in function that it displayed some text. But, it never needs to change it's width, when set once. Not so with mpMediaPath. If there is any example of a <TextEdit>/<FixedText> that updates it's width during runtime, I might be able to do this in a similar way.

Patch Set 5:Looks great, but there were some bugs and tweaks that are needed.Default should be the first entry in the submenu menu.If set to notebookbar, restarting LO wont show notebookbar and changing it to another mode and then back to notebookbar wont make it appear.If notebookbar is enabled, .uno:AvailableToolbars should be disabled.If notebookbar isnt enabled, .uno:Notebookbar should be disabled.For default mode, if the sidebar is opened/closed/only showing the 'show' arrow button, it should be opened only showing the tab bars (what it looks like when you open writer with a cleared profile).For single toolbar mode, the sidebar should be enabled but collapsed only showing the 'show' arrow button, the toolbar icons need to be changed to small if they are set to automatic and the icon style should be changed to sifr if set to automatic. this means that before the activation of single toolbar mode, the icon size and style needs to be preserved in the user profile for non-single toolbar mode, as well as saving it for when exiting single toolbar mode so it can be restored when returning to single toolbar mode. In this mode, all contextual toolbar should be disabled (https://bugs.documentfoundation.org/show_bug.cgi?id=92218#c13).For sidebar mode, the sidbear should be fully opened whatever state it is in and set to the properties tab.For notebookbar mode, the sidebar should be collapsed to show the 'show' arrrow button, similar to single toolbar mode.

Patch Set 5: Code-Review-2(1 comment)I advise against hardcoding specific services. Especially when they are only available in a small subset of languages.Letting special cases creep in like the one in flagged in the comment is even worse.Instead of hardcoding the ask site, make it a generic "find help online" or similar, that links to the domain specifically created for those kind of links: http://hub.libreoffice.org/something.That in turn can then redirect to language specific resources. (either redirect directly to askbot or show a overview page, depending on language. That then can be maintained/updated independently from LO (you cannot change the hardcoded URLs in a released version of LO after all)so again:* make it a generic page instead (not "Questions and Answers" but something like "Get help online" or something similar)* all URLs in LibreOffice itself should be http://hub.libreoffice.org/something ones.definite -2 because of the special handling of locales, without it it would still be a fat -1 from me

Patch Set 12:the problem is that there is that something invokes the copy ctor of unique_ptr<Palette>MSVC doesn't tell you where this is but it must be somewhere affected by this patchin contrast with other compilers MSVC creates default members like copy constructors of classes even if nothing calls them, so most likely a unique_ptr<Palette> member was added to a class that has no "Foo(Foo const&) = delete" yet to suppress the copy ctor - add that and it should work.

Patch Set 2:> perhaps the use of AsyncEventNotifier should be replaced by > dispatching to the default thread-pool? I think that is already > properly cleared on shutdown.oops, didn't notice your comment...what does "properly cleared" mean here? the problem why this crashed was that the SolarMutex was never released by the main thread until after DeInitVCL started killing VCL widgetry that the events in the AsyncEventNotifier thread had VclPtrs to, so the important aspect of the fix is that the Joining happens in a SolarMutexReleaser.this sounds quite scary but there is already a SolarMutexReleaser in DeInitVCL so i thought it shouldn't be any worse than before :)

Patch Set 3:(2 comments)Removal of the binary table autoformat load/save code sounds a bit brave to me. Sure, table autoformat will be mostly useless for new users when the table styles UI is ready, but we have to take care of old users as well, possibly having valuable data in their user profile.
Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1(1 comment)I agree. I'll revert then to two table styles containers (document one and autoformat window one). The document one will be populated upon document creation.

Patch Set 3:I think in the long run it'll be OK to deprecate and then remove the table autoformat UI (and the binary table autoformat configuration in the user profile), but not before the table style UI is ready, and we're not there yet. So we need some kind of compromise to allow you continuing towards a complete table style UI while not breaking existing users of the table autoformat.As far as I see the root of this conflict is that on one hand you want to use the autoformat dialog for the purposes of applying a table style (and displaying table style previews), while existing users want to display their existing table autoformats there.How about this:- add a new non-optional bool parameter to the SwAutoFormatDlg ctor (right after pShell, so the compiler will point out all call sites for you) named e.g. bTableStyle, and if it's true, then let it behave the way you need it; if it's false, then let it behave it did in the past- when creating the dialog via Table -> AutoFormat, then set the new flag to false, i.e. load and save the binary thing from/to the user profile, as before. if a table autoformat would be applied, first copy (and overwrite if necessary) the autoformat from the dialog's container to the document's container, so the style preview and actual document rendering matches- when creating the dialog from a future "click on the table style name in the table style list in the sidebar, and right click -> 'new' or 'modify'", then set the new flag to true: the user profile would be ignored in this case, and it would behave the way you want it.Does this make sense?And again, in the long run, that would mean getting rid of the table -> autostyle menu entry, when all style functionality is available via the styles and formatting thing already.

Patch Set 5:it looks like we still owe you some answers to your questions :)the only way to build with python 2 is to use --enable-python=system and set PYTHON, PYTHON_CFLAGS and PYTHON_LIBS variables manually to the right values, i.e. PYTHON_CFLAGS=`pkg-config --cflags python` PYTHON_LIBS=`pkg-config --libs python` before running autogen.sh(this is deliberately inconvenient so that newbies don't do it by accident)the only easy way to run all python tests is "make check" but that will run all tests, the faster way is to run every PythonTest_foo that exists manually via "make PythonTest_foo".unfortunately it often happens that broken commits are pushed to master and that will break your jenkins build here too if your change is based on the broken master, probably that's what happened here in some cases.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1Hmm - so - I would be rather happier to have some much deeper unit tests here. We have hit a problem in the parsing, we are trying to fix it - and I don't see a unit test for this behaviour - which is a red flag.First I'd like to see an example of a new file with assertion code that mis-uses defined namespaces without resolving them; eg. checking "office:foo" for any value of the office namespace.How we propagage unknown namespaces properly - is an open question - but I see only one path (of a rather complex function) in FastSaxParserImpl::callbackStartElement with a method added to it - I would like to see test files, and assertions that exercise all of the paths here - so we can check we have a good, comprehensive solution.Thanks ! =)

Patch Set 1:IMHO I think there still is something wrong with FV:PartType value of -2 is evaluated in the function as FALSE, seehttps://bugs.documentfoundation.org/show_bug.cgi?id=100646#c0Please tell me if I'm right or wrong. In the first case I will amend my patch set to a better fix, in the second case I will abandon this submission and try to learn from your explanation.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1> IMHO I think there still is something wrong with FV: > PartType value of -2 is evaluated in the function as FALSE, see > https://bugs.documentfoundation.org/show_bug.cgi?id=100646#c0 >  > Please tell me if I'm right or wrong. In the first case I will > amend my patch set to a better fix, in the second case I will > abandon this submission and try to learn from your explanation.Bah, you're right, the "boolean" is evaluated completely strange in ScGetZw() where we have if(fF > 0.0){}else{} so actually all values <=0 act as FALSE. What a nonsense..So that should be changed from double fF to bool bF and all functions calling ScGetZw() should obtain the argument value using GetBool() instead of GetDouble().We probably will have to mention that change in the release notes, because it may alter calculation results, even if from wrong to right ...

Patch Set 2:> sadly the bug report of the original commit 78775f1ad9b3f394896179898db984e139d5b5cc > is hidden. > https://bugzilla.novell.com/show_bug.cgi?id=821795Odd stuff, but yeah, apparently it was about that Excel saves literal single characters to be displayed in format codes always with a \ prefix, even if not visible in its UI, so a fraction format {# ?/?} is saved as {#\ ?/?}, then when loading that as is we'd end up with two format codes for the same thing, the predefined {# ?/?} and the loaded {#\ ?/?}, which might had been confusing some folks.. We do display the blank literally anyway, so removing the \ in that case is ok, in others it's not, as can be seen from the bug report.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1one can get quite creative when it comes to number formats.here some valid, not always useful examples for fraction formats# #/#? ?/?0 0/0$ #/#000 000/000 # "plus" "the fraction "#/## $2/3imo escape chars are there for a reason and should not be removed carelessly.sadly the bug report of the original commit 78775f1ad9b3f394896179898db984e139d5b5cc is hidden.https://bugzilla.novell.com/show_bug.cgi?id=821795

Patch Set 1:Hmm... I'm not convinced that misusing a toolbox controller as a way to place a control inside a .ui file is a good approach in general. It might be fine for simple controls like comboboxes, because those can be placed on a "classic" toolbar too, but using it for a whole panel seems like overkill. Why not register SlideTransitionPane as a proper glade control, and use it directly?About the late init problem: You can try some kind of event notification. If none of the existing notifications proves to be useful - you can use the dispatch status updates mechanism. (And of course making the whole notebookbar init much later is an option too, but I have no idea how hard it would be.)

Patch Set 29:Hello Thorsten,My initial approach was to set all setters to constant and use a const_cast inside them so we could get rid of ImplGetData() in jobset.hxx and only use ImplGetConstData() along the code. Don't you think this would work?

Patch Set 29:> Hello Thorsten, > My initial approach was to set all setters to constant and use a > const_cast inside them so we could get rid of ImplGetData() in > jobset.hxx and only use ImplGetConstData() along the code. Don't > you think this would work?Not really, since the entire point with the copy on write semantics is to un-share the object the moment you write into it - so we need the non-const ImplGetData() to signal that event.

Patch Set 1:It is the aforementioned Scottish Gaelic Spellchecker, prior LibreOffice versions were shipping with v2.8, but license file was missing, so the extension wasn't working. I added the license file, and updated to the current version (3.1), future updates will come from this extension as well.For me this is a bit stressful, as it was my first commit meddling with dictionaries, and I made a few mistakes as well when I was trying to figure out how this was working. Therefore for the sake of future updates, I'd like to have the absolute minimal modifications compared to the original, so you can just overwrite the whole thing, and see right away if anything was changed apart from the dictionary files (likely not, but you never know). These are the only reasons why I'm not eager to modify the directory structure and description.xml.However, as I said, if this is important, I'm fine with making the changes, and then I'll ask the dictionary/extension maintainers to update theirs.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1I understand fully making your first patch is stressing, but there are a couple of points you need to be aware of:- this is the 5.2 branch, so there will probably not be "later" changes (we get more restrictive with the 5.2.x releases). On master things are different- Maintaining different structures is a real PITA (you only do it once, we work with the structures for every release).- removing the extra "dictionary" directory, seems very simple, and is really preferred.Why do you need to talk with other extension maintainers ? this is only about the dict-gd

Patch Set 1:Please consider these points:-I have nothing to do with the dictionary/extension itself, it's not up to me if it gets corrected or not, if it isn't, it's going to be a pain for the person who updates the dictionary in git based on a newer release (assuming the structure would be updated in the master branch as well),-the directory structure for dict-gd was the exact same in previous releases, as I wrote, I only updated the files, and added a missing reference in Dictionary_gd.mk,-I personally agree that it would be nice to have the same structure as other dictionaries.

Patch Set 1:May I also add that while this is a topic worth following up on, it is unrelated to the bugfix submitted here, and not releasing it makes no difference regarding the directory structure of this particular dictionary/extension, only prevents the bugfix (assuming my change is correct this time).Despite not being involved with the extension, I don't mind being the one to follow up on this with its maintainer, and have the directories fixed in the master branch when the extension is updated, but after some consideration I'm not comfortable addressing that change in this commit.Regardless of what your decision is in the end, thank you both for reviewing this update.

Patch Set 1:This fix is not about filtering of control characters.The problem is with exactly one bad glyph (containing 4 Unicode characters at once - that's why "uLen == 4" check is present in code).Concerning the presence of C0 control codes in PDF - I can't find what are you talking about in the PDF specification (maybe you can point to the exact page and line?).But what I was able to find - is this quote: "All other byte values between 0 and 255 may be used in a string object." (page 409, second line).Next I was tried to craft the PDF file with control character: and my attempt was succeded: https://bugs.documentfoundation.org/attachment.cgi?id=125720 . This file passes the validation at https://www.pdf-online.com/osa/validate.aspx .

Patch Set 1:> The problem is with exactly one bad glyph (containing 4 Unicode > characters at once - that's why "uLen == 4" check is present in > code).Which is four unicode points, i.e. four glyphs - one of them you wantto keep, three of them you drop; > Next I was tried to craft the PDF file with control character: and > my attempt was succeded: https://bugs.documentfoundation.org/attachment.cgi?id=125720 > . This file passes the validation at https://www.pdf-online.com/osa/validate.aspx > .Sure. But we definitely want to drop tab and line feed at otherplaces, too - or not?

Patch Set 1:> Which is four unicode points, i.e. four glyphs - one of them you want> to keep, three of them you drop;They needs to be dropped here not because they are 'tab' or 'line feed'.In this case, they are in fact alternative codes for one glyph.But poppler interpreted them as a sequence, likely because this feature is nonstandard.> Sure. But we definitely want to drop tab and line feed at other> places, too - or not?This is another question, not related to this problem.And I doubt if this removal is needed.If control codes embedding is a normal thing in PDF files, then some document may rely on it.And proposed change will probably corrupt it.To say for sure, real PDF test cases are needed, but they will be hard to find, I guess.

Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1Love it - thanks for the swamp draining Markus ! =) I guess my lingering concern is what happens when we have SEH enabled code that catches a SEGV vs. normal code - does that mean we get various exceptions thrown out of eg. OGL drivers that are compiled with this option (?) etc. anyhow - moving closer to the Linux case sounds like a good idea to me for window stability =)Thanks.

Patch Set 2:> Love it - thanks for the swamp draining Markus ! =) I guess my > lingering concern is what happens when we have SEH enabled code > that catches a SEGV vs. normal code - does that mean we get various > exceptions thrown out of eg. OGL drivers that are compiled with > this option (?) etc. anyhow - moving closer to the Linux case > sounds like a good idea to me for window stability =) >  > Thanks.So EHs only affects whether we catch the SEH or not. It does not affect how other code handles it. Of course if we get a lot of SEH excepions from outside of our control that are currently caught in one of the catch all handlers we are going to crash a lot.EHs has basically two effects on the code. catch(...) will not catch SEH exceptions and there is no stack nwinding and destructor calls going to be for SEH exceptions.I think both are fine in our code. The case that some external part is handling SEH with EHa should not concern us as if we get a SEH from that cod ewe will just crash and if that code handles it we are not going to see it anyway.

Patch Set 1:But AFAIS the window of time for the race already opens after  if (osl_atomic_decrement( &m_refCount ) == 0) {in OWeakObject::release, not only after  MutexGuard aGuard(getWeakMutex());in OWeakConnectionPoint::dispose.  I think the real problem is that WeakReferenceHelper::get must not call xAdp->queryAdapted() once its m_pImpl's OWeakRefListener::dispose has been called.

Patch Set 1:it looks safe to me:1. OWeakObject::release does atomic_decrement(m_refCount)2. ~OWeakObject calls disposeWeakConnectionPoint, then OWeakConnectionPoint::dispose, then OWeakRefListener::dispose3. OWeakRefListener::dispose locks the mutex4. OWeakRefListener::dispose clears m_pObject5. OWeakRefListener::dispose locks the mutex6. only after all listeners are disposed, m_refCount is *freed*so any access between 1. and 3. of OWeakConnectionPoint::m_pObject will observe m_pObject->m_refCount == 0 and do nothing,any access between 3. and 6. will observe m_pObject == nullptr and do nothing

Patch Set 1:> 5. OWeakRefListener::dispose locks the mutex"unlocks the mutex, of course... furthermore, can 2 separate threads cause trouble by calling OWeakConnectionPoint::queryAdapted() at the same time as the above?it appears they can't, the situation where both osl_atomic_increment run at the same time and the 2nd one returns "1" instead of "0" and therefore erroneously concludes that the m_pObject is still alive is prevented by the mutex-lock that ensures a osl_atomic_increment is always followed by osl_atomic_decrement before the next attempt.however that doesn't guarantee anything if subclasses of OWeakObject fiddle with m_refCount themselves...

Patch Set 1:there are 2 serious hazards from sub-classes of OWeakObject:1. incrementing m_refCount in their destructor2. overriding OWeakObject::release() without calling the base class impl, so that disposeWeakConnectionPoint is never called
Patch Set 1:> it looks safe to me:Yeah; I think I started to mix up the scenarios with and without the added clearing of m_pObject in OWeakConnectionPoint::dispose.

Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2Okay, rebase made it build. Congratulations ;-)You can trigger a rebase in that case, keep in mind that it may cost build time (for another build), so better is to first try to find out why it failed. Try to navigate the links in the 'build failed' data. Sometimes it it unclear, but if it fails it often is a include missing which is e.g. needed on linux build and not on win (or vice-versa). Your local build is only on one system, gerrit is exactly there for this purpose, to test if it builds on all three main platforms.

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1C:/cygwin/home/tdf/lode/jenkins/workspace/lo_gerrit_master/Gerrit/Gerrit/Platform/Windows/vcl/win/gdi/salgdi.cxx(625) : error C2259: 'WinSalGraphicsImpl' : cannot instantiate abstract classdue to following members:'void SalGraphicsImpl::SetXORMode(bool,bool)' : is abstractc:cygwinhometdflodejenkinsworkspacelo_gerrit_mastergerritgerritplatformwindowsvclincsalgdiimpl.hxx(80) : see declaration of 'SalGraphicsImpl::SetXORMode'you can't remove the parameter only in the Windows-specific derived class, if you want to remove it you have to remove it in SalGraphicsImpl and every class derived from that (there is at least one per platform).the bug says that the Mac OS X backend may or may not actually use the parameter, so the first thing to be done here is to clarify the situation on Mac OS X - if it turns out that the 2nd parameter is still in use there, it cannot be removed.

Patch Set 1:Well, I don't agree here:) My aim is not to satisfy complainers, but to show that LO has great configuration capabilities, even if they are not available in UI.Some thoughts:- The memory page seems to be appropriate for these information and one more paragraph does not make any harm there.- The warning at the Expert Configuration page is sufficient for me.- I really cannot say that no one in the world has use case for this - generally, this option is recommended to reduce memory consumption and I believe it can be still useful for some machines.- Maybe we should have some agreement how to reflect expert configurations in documentation (a topic for the documentation team?) - and then write them consistently (now I did it the same way as before).

Patch Set 1:> What is the actual purpose of this?The formula bar in LOK case is not tiled rendered, so we cannot interact with theformula bar directly. In this case, we need a way so that client applicationscan simulate a formula bar.> Why not update dependent formula cells, conditional formatting and so on?We do not want to update dependent formula cells with each keystroke when theuser is still writing his/her input into the formula bar because these areintermediate values. It could be an incomplete formula or an invalid value whichwould result in throwing error for all dependent cells. We only want to updatethese dependent cells in some particular condition, say pressing enter, informula bar. Hence the distinction in this UNO command now, so that when theuser is just typing, we don't commit the contents to the cell.I tried looking for other ways to accomplish this, but this approach made mostsense to me. Surely, if you have any suggestions, please let me know :-)> What should happen if one enters a numeric value / date / formula?The cell should go in edit mode with each keystroke in formula bar updating itscontents but not commit till we press enter(by not specifying DontCommit param).

Patch Set 2:> The formula bar in LOK case is not tiled rendered, so we cannot > interact with the > formula bar directly. In this case, we need a way so that client > applications > can simulate a formula bar. > We do not want to update dependent formula cells with each > keystroke when the > user is still writing his/her input into the formula bar because > these are > intermediate values.Thanks for explaining. Makes sense.

Patch Set 2:not sure about the UI-interaction here..All "please wait, I'm doing something"-indicators I've come across involve spinning things (hourglass in windows, beachball on Mac, various spinning circles in browsertabs, android apps)Flashing/pulsating items however stand for "new info available [click to show more]" - at most it stands for "almost there, click me to continue". So it represents the opposite, waiting for the user to do something, and not for a task that's running in the background.I initially wanted a circle spinner around the FAB, but gave up before I got it working...For stuff like this I see no problem using different animations depending on the android version, it is no critical thing, doesn't  involve program or makes it not work on other systems. (So I'd rename the amination xml to a generic fabanimation or something, then we can use different ones by using versioned resources)(ps: had to rewrite my comment, as gerrit did not remember)

Patch Set 2:As discussed on IRC:os_cib: Sweet5hark: I read it. The idea of the method you want to remove is to be able to redirect. The marked regression does that to provide a WESTERN/CJK/CTL state to the font attribute slots depending on the script type. To me this is a perfectly valid use case. If you remove this method all those places require the creation of an additional temporary object just to be able to 're-Which' it. Sweet5hark: os_cib: thats worth it, because what happens in the itemset right now is even worse: when you put s WESTERN font item in a itemset in the CJK slot, the item will still have the WESTERN which-id. so when you go to the itemset and ask it for a CJK item, you actually get one with a WESTERN which-id. and when you innocently put that somewhere else (assuming it is a CJK) with Put(item), it will end up setting over the WESTERN item, not the CJK one.Sweet5hark: os_cib: thats clearly insane and likely the source of quite a few bugs we ignore because CJK isnt too mainstream.Sweet5hark: os_cib: the temporaries are not nice, but likely can be resolved later. at least they not actively conspire against the reader of the code to do something nasty instead of the expected.Sweet5hark: os_cib: if you have an alternative that makes sure that if you do a pItemSet->Get(nWhichId) you get an item with rItem.GetWhich() == nWhichId feel free to suggest.Sweet5hark: os_cib: do you get what I was aiming for now? an alterntive would be for Put(item, nWhich) to punch over the which id of the item in the set -- but I wasnt sure if _that_ would have caused regressions, thus I wrote the original bug like that.os_cib: Sweet5hark: I'm actually surprised that 'my' use case puts items into the set that carry a differnt which id than the their position requires. It should not be hard to fix.s_cib: While at it I found another use case - not handled by the patch. InvalideItem() calls Put() with a VoidItem with which==0 and the ... then uses the other which id to find the right place.Sweet5hark: os_cib: well, invalid items should be an implementation detail of the set. it shouldnt need public functions for that.Sweet5hark: os_cib: if you want to make the itemset punching over the which-id of items stored in it, so that the which member in the item is the same as the position in the set, go for it. Back then I was afraid of possible regressions from that change, as some code might implicitly rely on that.Sweet5hark: os_cib: as long as the end result is "an item at a position in a set actually also has than nWhich", Im happy.Sweet5hark: s/it shouldnt need public functions for that./the implementation of invalidate shouldnt need to call public functions of set./So -- not objecting if Oliver prefers a different solution, if Noel is ok with that. (tdf#34465 should then be updated or closed)

Patch Set 1:I based my changes on https://bugs.documentfoundation.org/show_bug.cgi?id=97831#c43 and concluded that Excel handles the argument from left to right and quits at the first error encountered.With respect to jumps, I reverse the stack and only read the arguments I need. So I don't know how much advantage there is using jumps. I haven't started that yet. But I do know that I will have to change some things as the maximum count now is something like 30 and I may have up to 127 expressions/values to compare.

Patch Set 1:Note that the reason I removed some of the private default constructors, instead of marking them "= delete" is that they are redundant: if a class declares one or more constructors, then the compiler will not generate a default constructor.Possibly I should write a plugin for this and do it in a separate patch.

Patch Set 2:Hi Faruk,Thanks for working on this, it looks awesome, except I have few comments that I think should be taken care of before we merge this. What do you think ?1. tpstatus label is obscured; not clearly visible. Maybe better if we add a background below this label, or something to make it visible clearly ?2. It should be possible to close the dialog when user clicks somewhere else. Currently, only way to close the dialog is to hit again on the toolbar button.3. I think we should limit the dimensions of table user can create with this new toolbar button just like we do in desktop, because if we don't it would stick to the mouse movements and user will have a hard time to find an empty space to close the dialog button. This is pretty annoying from user POV, I think.4. I noticed that the state of this new toolbar button doesn't get reset whenever user manages to close the dialog. So for eg: if user closed the dialog with table dimensions 12 x 12 selected, the next time he opens it, it would still be at 12 x 12. The state should be reset everytime dialog is closed.5. Currently, user has to move his mouse slowly to select desired dimensions. If he moves the mouse little faster, the dialog doesn't notice that.6. You have limited the width of dialog unlike its height. I think you intend to limit the number of columns user can choose here (?), _but_ if user moves his mouse back and forth near the right edge, more number of columns gets added to the same width increasing the number of cells per row - density - which makes the grid a mess. Can we somehow avoid that ? Also as pointed out in (3) limiting number of rows makes sense here.Besides these, I found a missing '+' (see inline comments which makes me suspect this is not the version you have in your local box since this version doesn't work out of the box unless someone changes code himself - is it ?)

Patch Set 2:Hi pranav, Well actually this patch was my first interaction with toolbar, so i was planning to rewrite some parts of it better. (e.g. we have jQuery but as a habit i didn't use it often) I'm going to follow your suggestions while fixing it. > 1. tpstatus label is obscured; not clearly visible. Maybe better if > we add a background below this label, or something to make it > visible clearly ?An empty (white) background should take care of it. > 2. It should be possible to close the dialog when user clicks > somewhere else. Currently, only way to close the dialog is to hit > again on the toolbar button.Definitely, this is my first priority > 3. I think we should limit the dimensions of table user can create > with this new toolbar button just like we do in desktop, because if > we don't it would stick to the mouse movements and user will have a > hard time to find an empty space to close the dialog button. This > is pretty annoying from user POV, I think.I can limit it like 20x20. I guess it would be enough? > 4. I noticed that the state of this new toolbar button doesn't get > reset whenever user manages to close the dialog. So for eg: if user > closed the dialog with table dimensions 12 x 12 selected, the next > time he opens it, it would still be at 12 x 12. The state should be > reset everytime dialog is closed.I should add this to onClick and Close events. >  > 5. Currently, user has to move his mouse slowly to select desired > dimensions. If he moves the mouse little faster, the dialog doesn't > notice that.With combining (3) and this maybe we should consider adding a selectable fixed size 20x20 table, anyway I'll look into this and try to understand what's wrong with it.  >  > 6. You have limited the width of dialog unlike its height. I think > you intend to limit the number of columns user can choose here (?), > _but_ if user moves his mouse back and forth near the right edge, > more number of columns gets added to the same width increasing the > number of cells per row - density - which makes the grid a mess. > Can we somehow avoid that ? Also as pointed out in (3) limiting > number of rows makes sense here. > Hmm, weird. I think its related to `evo-pop` since i haven't limited the width of dialog :-) anyway solving (3) should fix this and using `evo-pop` wasn't a good choice. > Besides these, I found a missing '+' (see inline comments which > makes me suspect this is not the version you have in your local box > since this version doesn't work out of the box unless someone > changes code himself - is it ?)Ah, while writing this patch i was on a hack-fest with a computer with heat issues (can't compile LibreOffice before it shut itself down) and was working on a remote machine and had to hard-copy to commit to my own box, while fixing white-spaces etc. i have removed them by mistake probably.Thank you very much for your review.

Patch Set 11: Code-Review+2I'm still not happy with the whole approach as I think it is not something we want to do. I would have most likely only given a warning to the user that we had some problems fitting his text and not bothered with anything else. IMHO we are trying to be too clever for our own good with this algorithm.However I don't care enough to block this patch. This message should be enough encouragement for anyone who wants to revert that behavior.

Patch Set 8:(21 comments)So I have one general comment related to the concept and a few related to the actual implementation.I'm not sure if that is really a good approach. In general I think instead of trying to change the equation we should make it clear to the user that we could not layout his chart correctly and that he should look into fixing the layout. So a more make the user aware of the problems than trying to work around problems.I suggest that you contact the UX team and tell them about your idea and my concerns.Related to the code:I'm not happy with some of the special values, especially the use of 0 as formula length to signal that the formula length can be ignored. I think a cleaner solution is something like sal_Int32* pFormulaLength = NULL and require the caller to use a NULL pointer to signal that the parameter needs to be ignored. That makes IMHO the code cleaner as it is directly obvious that we are not talking about a zero length string.I'd also like to see a comment why the aValueString checks are necessary despite the earlier checks that this value is not handled in that place.I'm going to look into the localization issue that I saw as that looks like a serious problem.And finally I was unable to follow all corner cases in the new code. So if we are really going to merge this code, I'd like to see a unit test for nearly all special cases. Additionally a few comments explaining what we are doing would be helpful. Currently it is nearly impossible to figure out why some cases need special handling. An exmaple for that (which I have still no idea why it is correct) is that in one case we multiply nFormulaLength by 2 if aValueString is "1".This was a really review and I suggest that you start by talking to the UX guys. If they have more questions they can contact me.

Patch Set 8:I suppose the commit message should talk about OpenGLContext. E.g. EGL vs GLX on Unix like platforms.

Patch Set 3:Hi,I think you convert too much.When you add a method SdrGrafObj::getOriginalSize() it should return the size in the same units the SdrModel is defined in. This is not always 100thMM. In Draw/Impress/Calc it is, but in Writer it is Twips. So the method has to convert to the units of the SdrModel used, you can get that using GetModel()->GetScaleUnit() in/at the SdrObject which gives you the target MapUnit. Looks as if the original code you copied did not do that, but that is okay since it originally was only used in sd. With a method at SdrGrafObj it has to be done correct since e.g. it can be called in the future in Writer code and has to convert to Twips then.It is not needed to hand over the SdrObject again to the getOriginalSize() implementation as parameter, use the local C++ this ptr which is already the SdrGrafObj from which you need the size.In drviews7, the call to GetLogicRect() will already return the data in the model units, so I think the conversion there to 100thMM is not needed at all, just compare aRect.GetSize() with pSdrGrafObj->getOriginalSize, that should then compare both sizes in the same, correct model units.HTH!

Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2As Michael says the motivation behind this service is that in case an out-of-process UNO client registers a dispatch provider, then on startup the ~200 uno commands are queried a number of times -- and that's a lot of traffic, when the use case is that most of these commands are disabled, and only a few of them is forwarded to the salve dispatcher or handled directly. With this service, it's possible to handle most of the commands directly in core via cheap c++ virtual member function calls (vs. more expensive C++ <-> URP <-> external client ones, and the same marshaling + parsing back with the result). The configuration-based approach is great if you want to make these changes permanent -- this one doesn't touch the configuration, so the effect can be dynamic, and is automatically thrown away when the process ends.So to sum up, it seems to me the two are not conflicting, they rather complement each other.

Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1This approach of transporting a localized "wrong password" hint via the css.ucb.AuthenticationRequest.Diagnostic field is still problematic:  For one, it links the GUI-agnostic ucb code to GUI-specific, localized strings in svtools.  (The Diagnostic field is intended to pass through additional, protocol-dependent information from a server, which necessarily needs to be non-localized.)  For another, it only addresses the cmis UCP, not other UCPs using the AuthenticationRequest in a similar way, ftp and webdav.In f88554edd46d2dc8d6c8eaba74c89ccd3e537104 "Related tdf#98644: In login dialog, give a hint that the password was wrong" I have now extended the uui's (GUI) AuthenticationRequest handler, to give a better hint that a login dialog is presented to the user because the previously entered password was wrong.I would suggest to drop from this change those parts that set a localized "wrong password" hint in the AuthenticationRequest's Diagnostic field, and instead just make sure that the AuthenticationRequest's Password field is set when an old, wrong password from a previous, failed login attempt is already available.

Patch Set 1:To reproduce with a new certificate :mkdir -p dbopenssl req -new > cert.csropenssl rsa -in privkey.pem -out cert.keyopenssl x509 -in cert.csr -out cert.cert -req -signkey cert.key -days 99999openssl pkcs12 -export -out cert.p12 -inkey cert.key -in cert.cert -certfile cert.certcertutil -N -d dbpk12util -i cert.p12 -d dbIn LibreOffice -> Tools -> Options -> Security -> Certificate Path, choose the new directory "db" and valid the form.Restart LibreOffice.Create a new ods file.In Tools -> Macros -> Organize Macros ... -> LibreOffice Basic ..., Select the current file -> Standart and click on "New", close the window and save the document.In Tools -> Macros -> Digital Signature.. -> Click on "Sign Document ...", select the new certificate.Close the window and save.Close the document and re-open it.Save a copyof the document or wait for the autosave, edit the document and try to save.

Patch Set 6:I don't think this is a good change.  The default css.task.InteractionHandler service that is created here presents UI to the user.  It should be controllable by the UCP's client what kind of interaction shall happen; if no interaction handler is given, the UCP shall fail the client's request with an exception.

Patch Set 6:> I don't think this is a good change.  The default css.task.InteractionHandler > service that is created here presents UI to the user.  It should be > controllable by the UCP's client what kind of interaction shall > happen; if no interaction handler is given, the UCP shall fail the > client's request with an exception.it will still fail if it's the case, the hanlder it's only used in case of Web/DAV authentication needed, not in exception bypass.That is, if an exception is thrown, it will be reported back, cancelCommandExecution will still work using the original CommandEnv, the one set by the client.

Patch Set 6:> > I don't think this is a good change.  The default > css.task.InteractionHandler > > service that is created here presents UI to the user.  It should > be > > controllable by the UCP's client what kind of interaction shall > > happen; if no interaction handler is given, the UCP shall fail > the > > client's request with an exception. >  > it will still fail if it's the case, the hanlder it's only used in > case of Web/DAV authentication needed, not in exception bypass. >  > That is, if an exception is thrown, it will be reported back, > cancelCommandExecution will still work using the original > CommandEnv, the one set by the client.I think you misunderstood me.  If the client code (on purpose) passes in no interaction handler for some command to the UCP, and the UCP gets into a situation where it would want to consult a passed-in interaction handler, then the UCP must abort the command by throwing an exception back to the client, instead of creating its own interaction handler out of thin air.

Patch Set 6:> > > Tested and it solved the problem. > > > > which problem? >  > it provides a handler here: > http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/ucb/source/ucp/webdav-neon/NeonSession.cxx#455 >  > needed for certificate display/storing.But that doesn't answer my question:  What is the problem this change wants to solve?

Patch Set 6:> But that doesn't answer my question:  What is the problem this > change wants to solve?I'll try to give an explanation, by describing what happens.Please have a look at this gerrit already pushed (originally it was in the same series with this one):https://gerrit.libreoffice.org/gitweb?p=core.git;a=commitdiff;h=e1ae21889a214ea3b6f79018d3c710d75fc8fba6probably I should have kept both merged in a single gerrit patch set.Anyway, Kendy description I removed explained what this patch fixes.This is the callback Kenky is referring to in his comment (NeonSession_CertificationNotify):http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/ucb/source/ucp/webdav-neon/NeonSession.cxx#354in this callback, here:http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/ucb/source/ucp/webdav-neon/NeonSession.cxx#455the interaction handler is needed because it's the only way the user is notified that something went wrong during web connection because of SSL certificate problem.If a CommandEnv is available, the certificate is further checked, the real check is performed here:http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/uui/source/iahndl-ssl.cxx#248In handleCertificateValidationRequest_  the user is asked if the certificate can be trusted anyway, should some of the checks carried out there fails.Upon returning of a successfull interaction '0' is returned to neon, which go on processing the request.In the use case addressed with the patch (e.g. accessing a mozilla web site) the user interaction is not called, because the test Kendy reports as failing("In the case of services.addons.mozilla.com, the certificate is for versioncheck.addons.mozilla.com, but it also has...") is addressed inside handleCertificateValidationRequest_starting here:http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/uui/source/iahndl-ssl.cxx#276down to this last check:http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/uui/source/iahndl-ssl.cxx#300That can't be done if CommandEnv is missing.If this patch is not present, NeonSession_CertificationNotify always returns '1', returning '1' to neon, neon will stop the processing notifiying the caller 'Server certificate verification failed: issuer is not trusted',which in due time it's converted to a 'ucb::InteractiveNetworkReadException'.The root call to access file is this:http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/cui/source/options/personalization.cxx#582As you can see the catch clause doesn't deal with the exception mentioned above, and besides, nothing can be done by the UCB client if SSL certificates aresuspicious or wrong or in need of a deeper check.The missing CommandEnv is common in UCB client use of Web/WebDAV connection, what do we do when we end up with the same problem, about certificates?Or in another possibility, not yet addressed, if the remote web server challenges to obtain credentials and no interaction handler is available to serve them?

Patch Set 6:> > XSimpleFileAccess wrapper does have a method to set the > interaction > > handler >  > Ah, right, css.ucb.XSimpleFileAccess.setInteractionHandler.  The > code in cui/source/options/personalization.cxx can supposedly only > be triggered by GUI interaction, so it should be OK to call >  > xFileAccess->setInteractionHandler( > css::task::InteractionHandler::create(xContext)); >  > there to set the default (GUI) interaction handler.this is what I checked first.Works, but in case of errors (Internet connection, temporary DNS problem or anything such) there is a verbose error indication coming out of ucbhelper::cancelCommandExecution.Looking at the code in cui/source/options/personalization.cxx the original developer intended disabling it.I was thinking more on the line to implement something similar tocomphelper::StillReadWriteInteraction in order to interact with the user only when certificate problems are involved and have the other exception reported back, specifically thought to be used when a simple file access is needed.May came in handy on other occasions (some of them I already spotted for WebDAV).What do you think. ?

xresultset*) unclear to me where they usually come from#!/bin/bashIFS=$'\n'str_search=""^\s*using\s+[\w:]+::\w+;""for str_using in $( git grep -nP ""$str_search"" ); do        filename=$(echo $str_using | sed -r 's/^(.*\.\w+):.*;.*/\1/')        symbol=$(echo ""$str_using"" | perl -pe ""s|^.*using\s+(?:(?:::)?\w+)*::(\w+);.*|\1|"")        line=$(echo ""$str_using"" | perl -pe ""s|^.*:([0-9]+):.*;|\1|"")        lines=$(git grep -P ""([^\w""\""""/]|^)$symbol([^\w]|$)"" $filename| wc -l)        usages=$(($lines - 1))        echo 'in file '$filename': symbol: '$symbol' usages: '$usages        if [ $lines -eq 1 ]        then                echo 'in file '$filename':#'$line' declaration of '$symbol' is unused'                sed -i -r ""/[^[:alnum:]_]$symbol;/d"" ""$filename""        fidonenext step will be to check if removed declarations had a included header with the same name in the file and try to remove them.e.g. using ::com::sun::star::lang::XServiceInfo; got removed so remove#include <com/sun/star/lang/XServiceInfo.hpp> too."

Patch Set 2:> Note that some sub-menus are implemented as separate popup menu > controllers, and as such populated only upon menu activation. So if > you really need the full menu structure without executing the vcl > menu, you should at least do a fake call to the vcl menu activation > callback. (The other alternative would be to change > ResourceMenuController to create the MenuBarManager instance > earlier for this case, and then change also MenuBarManager::FillMenuManager > to create the controllers).I opted for the first one: doing a fake call, and that seemed to have done the trick. >  > But be aware that some popup menu controllers don't use standart > dispatch command for their items, as they implement them > internally. So the approach of "get the .uno command from the menu > structure, and later execute it" won't work for such cases.I guess we would deal with that later.Thanks for your pointers and suggestions. Saved me some time looking here and there and then realizing :-)

Patch Set 1:Note that some sub-menus are implemented as separate popup menu controllers, and as such populated only upon menu activation. So if you really need the full menu structure without executing the vcl menu, you should at least do a fake call to the vcl menu activation callback. (The other alternative would be to change ResourceMenuController to create the MenuBarManager instance earlier for this case, and then change also MenuBarManager::FillMenuManager to create the controllers).But be aware that some popup menu controllers don't use standart dispatch command for their items, as they implement them internally. So the approach of "get the .uno command from the menu structure, and later execute it" won't work for such cases.

Thanks :)Apologizes for the delay in answering.

Patch Set 2:Not providing a code review - don't feel qualified b/c I don't understand all of the logic.The fix worked for the test document on Mint 12.04.  (16.04 already worked before the fix.)  However, I'm afraid that too much may have been changed in the code - so that it works for this instance, but doesn't work in other situations.  In this case, nDstLocation was always 0, so nDstLocation<<1 (multiply by 2, right?) didn't do anything this time, but in other situations it might be critical. Also, if nOutDimention == 1, you will have a divide by zero exception.So perhaps your logic is fine (I don't know), but my gut feeling is that it fits the test case only and will break other situations.

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-2I've updated the patch slightly, most notably I've added a on/off switch to the Writer's menu, and removed the env. var (not needed when there is a switch in the menu).Unfortunately I fear we have to abandon this approach because the sfx2 childwindows appear only inside the shell; while here it is desirable to show the notebookbar outside of the shell (ideally between the menu and the toolbars).Szymon - unless Samuel has an idea how to actually use the sfx2 childwindow but a better way, I fear we should not merge this; but still, this for sure counts as an advanced Easy Hack for the GSoC (please do quote me on this should anybody ask).Not abandoning it yet, for the case Samuel has a way how to fix the concern, and yet still use the childwindow...

Patch Set 3:> Unfortunately I fear we have to abandon this approach because the sfx2 childwindows appear only inside the shell; while here it is desirable to show the notebookbar outside of the shell (ideally between the menu and the toolbars).Do we really need to have both the classic toolbars *and* the Notebookbar visible? I wouldn't have this as a requirement.Although it might become a problem that the Sidebar child window takes away width from the Notebookbar, but maybe there's a solution for that?

Patch Set 3:This picture discusses the toolbar docking areas, not the childwindow docking areas; the childwindows (and sidebar too) are inside the thing that is marked as "Document View" in the picture.Wrt. the toolbars + notebookbar visible at the same time - that's not a requirement for the tabbed notebookbar for sure, but I fear still necessary for the other use cases, like the simplebar or extendedbar :-( - at least for some transition period.To improve the positioning in this patch though, it's actually possible to do:-    SetAlignment(SfxChildAlignment::TOP);+    SetAlignment(SfxChildAlignment::HIGHESTTOP);that positions that over the sidebar, but still, it's all inside the "Document View".
Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1Actually, I'm about to experiment with a 'more interesting' parent window here - if we can get the SystemWindow to be the parent, maybe we'll get somewhere? ;-)

Patch Set 4:OK, so managed to plug it together; the core of the work still stays is the vcl (and has to, I'm afraid), but it is now created (and can be potentially managed) via the childwindow infrastructure.If we continue this way, I suppose we'll need to add some code to show / hide according to what the childwindow does, as we cannot just do a SetWindow(pNotebookBarWindow); but otherwise the approach looks usable - the buttons are clickable etc.I think I'll just remove .uno:Notebookbar from the menu.xml, and we can push this to master :-)

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1(5 comments)So there seem to be still a few merge errors in the patch (e.g. in configure.ac) as well as the handling of ENABLE_GLTF which of course depends on ENABLE_OPENGL.Now for the bigger question that I tried to discuss with thorsten once. As I think we will never advertise such a build configuration (IMHO the concept is completely broken (either OpenGL is an optional dependency and no mandatory feature may depend on it or there is no need to make anything optional based on OpenGL)) you should make sure that there is a big warning in the configure output that nobody using this configuration can expect any help or support from the project. In general I think that adding that many #if statements that are not localized is a bad idea but as far as I know I'm the only one with sub objections.

Patch Set 2:> (5 comments) >  > So there seem to be still a few merge errors in the patch (e.g. in > configure.ac) as well as the handling of ENABLE_GLTF which of > course depends on ENABLE_OPENGL. >  > Now for the bigger question that I tried to discuss with thorsten > once. As I think we will never advertise such a build configuration > (IMHO the concept is completely broken (either OpenGL is an > optional dependency and no mandatory feature may depend on it or > there is no need to make anything optional based on OpenGL)) you > should make sure that there is a big warning in the configure > output that nobody using this configuration can expect any help or > support from the project. In general I think that adding that many > #if statements that are not localized is a bad idea but as far as I > know I'm the only one with sub objections.The next upload will fix the problem you mentioned. This build configuration without dependencies to libraries not available on typical server installations has been around for ages. End users will of course not use them. But you are right that features that are needed to load/save/print/API-manipulate documents  should not depend on 'optional' libraries or should have a headless alternative.

Patch Set 2:>  > This build configuration without dependencies to libraries not > available on typical server installations has been around for ages. > End users will of course not use them. But you are right that > features that are needed to load/save/print/API-manipulate > documents  should not depend on 'optional' libraries or should have > a headless alternative.Actually my argumentation is the other way around. Currently OpenGL is accepted as a dependency of LibreOffice and we have been adding features based on OpenGL so we should not make it optional. Any change to this policy would need to go through the ESC.

Patch Set 3:> Yeah, I wanted to make it without classes too, but it looked more > difficult, because these functions call other functions that need > to be implemented for each platform (init/deInit/...) and so on. >  > I guess I should try it again =)Not having looked at your changes in detail yet, just a generic remark:If there is a common skeleton of code across the different platforms, and just some functions need to be implemented differently, it's IMO fine to* have the common skeleton source code in one place,* have a common include file that declares the functions that need to be implemented per platform,* have per-platform source files defining those functions.That works for both C and C++ code.  See bridges/inc/bridges/cpp_uno/shared/vtablefactory.hxx for an example of a (non-virtual) C++ class VtableFactory that leaves some of its member functions (that all happen to be static, but that's irrelevant here) to be implemented per-platform.

Patch Set 2:What do you mean about virtual methods / overrides? Patch Set 9:so do i see it right that CURL was actually shipping its own trusted CA database, and with this patch it uses (on linux) the NSS bundled CA database (nssckbi.so) instead?and this means that we can drop the nss-pem.patch too since that was some mystery stuff added for curl, presumably because curl's bundled CAs are stored as PEM ?

Patch Set 9:> so do i see it right that CURL was actually shipping its own > trusted CA database, and with this patch it uses (on linux) the NSS > bundled CA database (nssckbi.so) instead? >  > and this means that we can drop the nss-pem.patch too since that > was some mystery stuff added for curl, presumably because curl's > bundled CAs are stored as PEM ?What I found is that without the --without-ca-bundle --without-ca-path curl configure option curl was activating a hard coded path that differed from TDF's build baseline (CentOS) wrt mine. Actually disabling ssl+curl in a cross build situation (e.g. build on rpm pack distro, use in a deb pack distro).The bundle curl config options refers to are CA certificates.This <https://curl.haxx.se/docs/sslcerts.html>, topic 'Certificate Verification' - point 3. below may give some terse explanation.

Patch Set 9:oh now i find it in curl's acinclude.m4dnl regarding the paths this will scan:dnl /etc/ssl/certs/ca-certificates.crt Debian systemsdnl /etc/pki/tls/certs/ca-bundle.crt Redhat and Mandrivadnl /usr/share/ssl/certs/ca-bundle.crt old(er) Redhatdnl /usr/local/share/certs/ca-root.crt FreeBSDdnl /etc/ssl/cert.pem OpenBSDdnl /etc/ssl/certs/ (ca path) SUSE- so (as usual) there is a ridiculous nightmare of pointless distribution incompatibility and this would pick some random path depending on the build host, which is going to be pretty useless anyway
