Patch Set 3:Hi Bj鈹溍俽n,of course this is only an in-between step due to working with the (old) Rectangles. In the future this may all go to basegfx::B2DRange where these values may be valid input.The reason shit happens here is that Rectangle::GetWidth() substracts Right from Left, both are long. Thus, the source data has double the range of the result. It is questionable (and I thought about and decided against) to correct this in the Rectangle itself - what value to return then...?Also preventing correction is that in Rectangle, sometimes Right being smaller than Left is *used* to e.g. express that the object is mirrored - one of the rasons to base basegfx::B2DRange on Min/Max, so that can not happen by design.
Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2Taking in now, loop unfolding is unquestionable and the rest is for security

Patch Set 1:The problem in tdf#93124 is the following:1. The title text is aligned vertically to bottom, and its height is greater than its rectangle.2. In this case, when text isn't aligned to full width of the object, it ignores the vertical anchor setting (be it to middle or bottom), and aligns vertically to top. So, to retain correct position, the text must be aligned to full width.3. Full width alignment is only available when horisontal alignment is to center.4. All paragraphs in the text box are aligned to left, so LO "optimizes" the text object alignment to left bottom corner, thus disabling full width setting, and breaks the test position.Another approach could be to either allow full width for any horisontal alignment, or to fix incorrect anchoring in case when text height is greater than the rectangle (IMO, the latter is preferable). But that change is much more invasive, and I suppose that removing the optimization (lines 898-922 and 952-976) that uses word "sensible", i.e. it's not mandatory, just intended to be more performant (?) in some cases, may be more suitable here.Also, the line 1034 makes some kinds of text objects to auto-align its contents to the box. As may be seen in tdf#41245, that's not correct, so I removed it. If auto-fit is to be used on import, it must be enabled only when PPT specifies that explicitly.And even with the previous fix, some objects keep getting auto-fit flag just because the template specifies that, and that's why I needed to explicitly override it in 1093-1100. If later the auto-fit is to be enabled, it's the place where we should check for PPT (explicit) auto-fit setting, and enable it if set, and keep disabling otherwise.

Patch Set 3:> Let me explain in more detail... >  > It is common in code to use a clever trick to get more informative > text into the message from a failed assert(). For instance, one > could have (this a generic example, not from LibreOffice): >  > assert(nFoo > 0 && "We should have at least one foo widget"); >  > with the intent being that in case nFoo is <= 0, instead of the > message: >  > Assertion failed: nFoo > 0 >  > one would get this message, with a longer explanation: >  > Assertion failed: nFoo > 0 && "We should have at least one foo > widget" >  > In the code lines here, the string literal contains what is > essentially identical to the expression on the left side of the && > operator, so it does not give any additional information.ohh, now i understand. Actually i never used assert in any of my programming projects. I'm a 1-2 yr amatuer C++ programmer. Whatever the result may be, open source coding is always a great learning experience. Thanks for such a great explanation. I would update all of my patches tommorow morning.

Patch Set 1:Let me explain in more detail...It is common in code to use a clever trick to get more informative text into the message from a failed assert(). For instance, one could have (this a generic example, not from LibreOffice):assert(nFoo > 0 && "We should have at least one foo widget");with the intent being that in case nFoo is <= 0, instead of the message:Assertion failed: nFoo > 0one would get this message, with a longer explanation:Assertion failed: nFoo > 0 && "We should have at least one foo widget"In the code lines here, the string literal contains what is essentially identical to the expression on the left side of the && operator, so it does not give any additional information.

Patch Set 6:Thank you for your comments, I will look into them and correct the code where possible.In general:-I switched from vector< double > to array of doubles in an attempt to improve performance; but didn't try to measure the difference; I haven't looked into leaks and leak-protection, so I may switch them back to vector.-Some vectors were maintained as they are sorted or have to passed as vector to existing functions.-I now have 8 new functions, of which Excel doesn't have 3 (the multiplicative method, which is more realistic and IMHO of more use when forecasting). These 3 functions don't have an _xlfn prefix in OOXML as they don't exist there. I haven't fully checked yet if all entries in formulabase.cxx and xlformula.cxx are correct here.-My main efforts so far have been to get the functions working as they should (and changing constraints where MS Excel preaches them but does _not_ apply them).I want to change one last constraint (the time(X)-interval needs to be constant, but in case of dates an interval of months (28 to 31 days) is accepted by Excel. I have to find out how much deviation is accepted by Excel and how to incorporate this in the code, with interpolation in forecasts etc..Then I want to do a lot of numerical comparisons between Calc and Excel - where possible.Then I need to make a unit test; simple no-difference check with Excel is not possible as it is a forecast and the result depends on the exact method and sometimes random numbers.Then I want to go through the code again with a toothbrush.Then I want to prepare help-text (for someone else to put into the repository).And then my draft could become a real submission.We'll be in 2016 be then, it's a huge job - for me, at least ;)

Patch Set 6:(3 comments)Will upload new patch set -that should be mergeable too- with current changes.About the unittest: I prefer the test method as with the Excel2013 functions (no csv, but smart checking if no errors), but the problem is that Excel will almost always have different results than Calc. We're talking about forecasts, here. So should I create an ods file or should I create an xlsx and compare with verified Calc results?

Patch Set 6:A new delay:Testing with Excel2016 revealed that with argument 'Seasonality' having a value of 0 (meaning that no seasonal influence is to be taken into account), Excel uses exponential double smoothing, where it says that linear forecasting is used. So The Excel functions are exponential smoothing functions, not necessarily exponential triple smoothing.More code to make and I intend to rename the LO functions from ETS to ES, making clear what they do.So, you'll have to wait a bit longer for the next patch set.

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1While this may circumvent the crash it will likely cause regressions that formula cells will not be recalculated when cells in the sort range are changed after the sort. Reason is that SplitFormulaGroups() ends the listening on grouped formulas and moving that to a place before intersecting listeners are collected with aGrpListenerRanges after line 1193 may result in listeners been gone that otherwise would had been collected, so these listeners will not be reestablished at the end.I'd like to see some unit tests first that ensure we do not introduce regressions in various overlapping / non-overlapping grouped formula listener scenarios.

Patch Set 5:> Just curious, what's the benefit of genLang, compared to the > current l10ntools, after the kill-sdf branch was merged? >  > See http://libreoffice.hu/2012/11/27/featurekillsdf-branch-merged/ > for the background.the kill sdf was a very good thing, but it did not change the tools or the method. The "save" method in the old tools was rewritten to save .pot files.genLang "reinvents" the tools in a C++ fashion, making it more maintainable. You can however argue, that since the old tools work, why change it. The best reason for that is to move away from the central "make translations" that runs find over the source tree, and into adding the files to the local makefiles (e.g. define ui files like you define cxx files).

Patch Set 7:The main reason to wait for load acknowledgment and issue commands only after 'statusindicatorfinish' is received is also how we currently handle the docalreadyloaded, nodocloaded cases on the server side. Currently we have a very lame condition on the server side checking for docURL. If docURL != "" for the server, it means doc is loaded which is clearly not true since the load operation can fail.Hence, IMO, it is best to wait for the result of such an important command like 'load' to finish before we can issue commands from the front-end.

Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Verified+1We should rework commits with `git rebase -i @~X` where X is the number of commits pushed together. This allows us to iron out any issues that we fixed in later commits, such that it'd seem as though they were written perfectly from the start.
Patch Set 1:(4 comments)Thanks so much! :-)  I've added few comments - can you please have a look?

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1(4 comments)I've added a few comments, please see inline.But the biggest issue I have is with the design. We should avoid unnecessary complexity. When the user opens a password-protected document (without providing a password, or with wrong password) it will fail. Loading will fail. End of story.The UI should report the failure and prompt for password. Another load request should then be sent to the server, with the password, to try loading again.There is no need to have a password command, or remembering the jail url, or having a new callback (modify load callback to take the optional password) etc. All we need is for 'load' to have an optional password that is passed to the right API when provided.If 'load' fails, then everything fails and the user can try again. It's a fatal error to load a document and without a document there is no need to maintain anything at all (certainly no child). I'd even close the socket and cleanup everything. The UI should handle this case in a friendly fashion.Fail, return, prompt the user, and let them try again.Let's discuss if there are any design questions. Thanks!

Patch Set 3:Ashod: Hmm, the design concern is actually a good point; unfortunately on the LibreOffice side, it asks for the password interactively, so the LOK API was (naturally) extended so that we can interactively answer.Having said that, on the loolwsd level, it can be done as you suggest - return from load with "no password provided" error, ask the user for the password, and re-try the load completely (now with the password remembered).  That is safer (the load is not blocked), but OTOH more expensive (2x starting the load).Maybe we can even change the LOK API this way; but not sure what is best :-(Michael S.: Any view on this, please?

Patch Set 3:This should take care of the design concern mentioned above. In case of password protected documents, ToPrisoner is closed when no password is provided along with the 'load' command, but ToClient holds and keep listening for further 'load' requests. When another 'load' command comes (with or without a password), the flow goes all the way through broker finding appropriate child to host the new document URI.Additionally, this also prevents caching for password protected documents with the help newly introduced bunch of password related variables and successful document load acknowledgment to parent process.'statusindicatorfinish:' is now used as an acknowledgment of successful document load operation on server side, as well as client side. In case of password protected document, it will be sent only when correct password is provided (because it is triggered by LOK), hence preventing the client to send any additional messages unless document has been opened successfully by providing the correct password.

Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1(7 comments)Nice work! Almost there.I have made a few comments and raised a few questions.What stopped me from submitting is strdup :)I'll guess it was muscle memory :)Seriously, why not use std::string instead of the naked char*?Thanks again, good job.

Patch Set 4:> (7 comments) > What stopped me from submitting is strdup :) > I'll guess it was muscle memory :) >  > Seriously, why not use std::string instead of the naked char*?My only concern was documents having password as empty string, "", and std::string's default initialization to "". Also, LOK's setDocumentPassword function treats an empty string as a password attempt, and would get triggered again unless I pass a nullptr to it to abort the load operation, but of course that could easily be dealt with.If there are no empty strings passwords for documents, then yeah, we can change it to std::string, assuming "" to be no password provided

Patch Set 4:> > (7 comments) > > What stopped me from submitting is strdup :) > > I'll guess it was muscle memory :) > > > > Seriously, why not use std::string instead of the naked char*? >  > My only concern was documents having password as empty string, "", > and std::string's default initialization to "". > Reasonable. It's probably better to have a bool to track if we have a password (i.e. the user has provided a password) rather than track a pointer (and free). Btw, I don't think I noticed a call to free() anywhere.If we clean this part, I'm good to submit and your other comments are reasonable and can be dealt with later.

Patch Set 13:(5 comments)> I didn't notice ScTabViewShell::GetState() warning. But i don't > know how can i handle it.It has a switch where you can handle the commands similar to the Execute method, but this time for the command state. A state of a command is how the UI element (toolbar button, menu item etc.) that bound to this command presented to the user. It can be enabled/disabled, checked/unchecked, its text can dynamically change etc.wrt our case, I see that .uno:FreezePanes is enabled always, even in a read-only doc, and so should be the new commands, so this isn't an issue. What GetState currently does for .uno:FreezePanes is that it sets checked/unchecked state. But I wonder whether we want something similar for the new commands (i.e. detect if the first row/column is frozen and set checked state accordingly), or maybe such indication isn't that useful, and we can just drop the GetState part from tabvwsh.sdi as well.Eike: What do you think on this?

ScTabViewShell::GetState() ...] >  > wrt our case, I see that .uno:FreezePanes is enabled always, even > in a read-only doc, and so should be the new commands, so this > isn't an issue. Note that FreezePanes shouldalways be checked if at least one row or column is frozen, as it istoday.

Patch Set 1:> how could one remove such graphics?Well, that's an egg-or-chicken question.We should now answer it here. The problem is: the standard doesn't impose this restriction, and so documents with such graphics are legitimate. Moreover, they actually exist. Failing to import them is not a good option. There may be restriction at the UI level that doesn't allow e.g. creating those, and a UI may be developed to handle them if needed (e.g., like in AutoCAD that includes a tool to whipe zero-sized objects, or a navigator update that would include graphics list, including zero-sized). But that's a different task.Also, silently dropping those objects isn't good, too, because that would impair round-trip of documents.

Patch Set 4:The source is given, "[basic.lookup.unqual]/6", i.e., paragraph 6 of the [basic.lookup.unqual] section of the C++ Standard, e.g., <http://open-std.org/JTC1/SC22/WG21/docs/papers/2015/n4567.pdf>.

Patch Set 4:> The source is given, "[basic.lookup.unqual]/6", i.e., paragraph 6 > of the [basic.lookup.unqual] section of the C++ Standard, e.g., > <http://open-std.org/JTC1/SC22/WG21/docs/papers/2015/n4567.pdf>.Thanks. So the standard paper mentions exactly our test case:  namespace A {      namespace N {          void f();      }  }  void A::N::f() {      i = 5;      // The following scopes are searched for a declaration of i:      // 1) outermost block scope of A::N::f, before the use of i      // 2) scope of namespace N      // 3) scope of namespace A      // 4) global scope, before the definition of A::N::f  }where A::N is connectivity::mork. So according to the standard the declaration of i (ORowSetValue)) should be searched in connectivity namespace, where it's located. So this is clearly a MSVC bug.

Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1Have you read my comment in tdf#97383? I think it is a wrong approach to do direct manipulation in the else-part. If the image has no preserveAspectRatio set, then the variable rRatio has to be set to the default values, which are specified for this case. And then the part, which is now in the then-part, is valid in both cases and can be executed outside of if-then-else.

Patch Set 4:Hmm. That will most likely hurt us later but well we can deal with it then.I had chats with Kohei and Eike and I think the solution that seems to be acceptable to all of us is to use a std::vector<ScColumn*> or std::vector<std::unique_ptr<ScColumn>> with the additional requirement that there are no nullptr entries.This provides us with some benefits compared to the version without the additional requirement and the version based on std::vector<ScColumn>. We don't need to check every entry while iterating through columns (just compare once against std::vector::size) and we don't need to worry that pointers to ScColumn instances become invalid when we insert or remove a column. I hope this helps you for the rest of the work.

Patch Set 4:> I had chats with Kohei and Eike and I think the solution that seems > to be acceptable to all of us is to use a std::vector<ScColumn*> or > std::vector<std::unique_ptr<ScColumn>> with the additional > requirement that there are no nullptr entries. >  > This provides us with some benefits compared to the version without > the additional requirement and the version based on > std::vector<ScColumn>. Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1(14 comments)this is trickier than it appears :)some of these appear to be  obvious candidates for using assert(), which is much better at getting developer's attention because it exits the program if the condition is violated.assert() does not take a message, only a condition; in many cases the message is really superfluous, like when requiring that some pointer isn't null or some index is in obvious bounds, so the message can just be removed.but if you see a message that's worth keeping, you can use a trick and write assert(condition && "message); - that will evaluate to the same value as the condition since the string literal "message" converts to a boolean value of true.

Patch Set 1:oh that is clever, i didn't think of that - did you test that it actually works?basically the firebird build system does this the wrong way around, they should expect -j (or job server) by default on the top-level and then invoke the non parallel safe makefiles with "-j1".or even better fix their dependencies.

Patch Set 1:It works for me: top-level "PARALLELISM=0 make firebird" top-level "make firebird" (with implicit PARALLELISM value > 1) cd external/firebird && make -j2 cd external/firebird && make -j16 cd external/firebird && make -r -s # no -jIf I move my ccache cache out of the way, I see an appropriate number of parallel g++ processes in "ps -Af f"A previous version was filtering MAKEFLAGS to remove the problematic "-r" and leave all the rest, but in the end I thought it better to be more minimalistic. For future reference, here's the filtering code:if echo '$(MAKEFLAGS)' | egrep -q '^-'; then \  MAKEFLAGS='$(filter-out -r,$(MAKEFLAGS))'; \else \  MAKEFLAGS='$(subst r,,$(word 1,$(MAKEFLAGS))) $(wordlist 2,$(words $(MAKEFLAGS)),$(MAKEFLAGS))'; \fi; \

Patch Set 1:Thank you for your valuable feedback. As per my understanding, we cannot tell with certainty if the last entry is a cell name or not without invoking the formula engine. We cannot use a flag to keep track of the last entry because it could have been typed in, so there won't be a trigger for the flag.   The current solution does not cover all situations (for example, if the last letter is a space character), but I think it would cover the most common use cases, without having to invoke formula engine  with every change.If you think the formula is getting parsed with each change already, or if you think it won't be much of an overhead, then if you could give me some pointers, I could use that in the solution.Thanks

Patch Set 2:Oh yes. Sry. Just woke up.Had to fix it as it broke the build and forgot to leave a message.For the solution how to push such a patch to gerrit. You need to update to a git checkout that ncludes the pushed patch already. One solution to avoid long recompile times is to have a separate push tree + charry-picking the commit from current master. Then only add the new commit to the push tree (which already contains the pushed commit) and push to gerrit for review.Gerrit complained that you tried to push a patch that has been merged already to gerrit review. This happens because the Change-Id of the patch was the same as the merged one.

Patch Set 2:This bug is the case itself :)If you do a dry-run on 'nextmessage' frame going in prisoner -> master direction, you would notice that it would get stuck in the original if/else block because 'nextmessage' is a single-line message also. Hence, it is necessary for us to move this block above so that such 'nextmessage' frames are not skipped.I think it was always wrongly placed there, but we were never able to notice it because only few documents hit the 200000 limit (char buffer[200000] in SocketProcessor() function ).

Patch Set 2:(1 comment)> I think it was always wrongly placed there, but we were never able > to notice it because only few documents hit the 200000 limit (char > buffer[200000] in SocketProcessor() function ).The assumption was that the only multi-line message was nextmessage. That is, everything else evaluated to single-line, so the sequence was reasonable (that's my understanding).At any rate, I think we need to review these assumptions. For example the code now expects 3 cases: nextmessage, single-line, and a 3rd undocumented case.Please add the const (see note) and I'll submit this patch, then we need to review the protocol(.txt) and the code and make sure we have a solid situation. Thanks.

Patch Set 2:Another thing to take into consideration is that JUnit's assertEquals takes its arguments in the somewhat odd order "expected, actual" (which is important when JUnit reports a failure, and labels one value as "expected" and the other as "actual").  According to <https://docs.python.org/3/library/unittest.html>, the arguments to Python's unittest.testEqual are only named "first, second" (so not making it clear which should be the expected and which the actual value), but the examples on that page all use it so that the actual value comes first (which is probably also the more intuitive, albeit non-xUnit-style, way of ordering the arguments).

Patch Set 3:> Don't we have to quote double and single quotes when using single > quotes for DBGARGS, as printf already uses escaped double quotes in > the string to write?Beats me what you mean with that.The best way I'm aware of to pass an argument verbatim through GNU make into a sh printf invocation is with a recipe line of  printf '%s' '$(subst ','\'',$(value ARG))'(where the '%s' argument could of course also be given as "%s", but why use that form of quoting when it is not necessary to do so?).  I'm only aware that it fails if ARG contains a newline.

Patch Set 3:The changed line writes a double quoted string to the file, probably because the '--accept' parameter already uses single quotes. Therefore I thought you already need to escape the double quotes $DBGARGS, as it will end in the file, which uses then for the "-ex" string. I'm a bit lost in escaping and indirection here...printf " -ex __\"__set args --norestore --nologo '--accept=pipe,name=$(USER);urp;' %s __\"__" "$(DBGARGS)"So my idea was to just escape double quotes and you're as good as it can get.

Patch Set 3:> The changed line writes a double quoted string to the file,Ah, right, missed that part; it should arguably write single quotes instead.GDB documentation appears to be unhelpful in documenting the exact syntax of the "set args" command, but some experimentation makes it look like it supports sh-like quoting of that command's arguments.  So you would want to document in gbuild.help.txt that the value of DBGARGS provided by the user needs to be in such a form that it can validly be spliced verbatim into a "set args" command's argument text.

Patch Set 3:> GDB documentation appears to be unhelpful in documenting the exact > syntax of the "set args" command, but some experimentation makes it > look like it supports sh-like quoting of that command's arguments.ah, there is <https://sourceware.org/gdb/download/onlinedocs/gdb/Arguments.html#Arguments> "The arguments to your program can be specified by the arguments of the run command. They are passed to a shell, which expands wildcard characters and performs redirection of I/O, and thence to your program. Your SHELL environment variable (if it exists) specifies what shell gdb uses."

Patch Set 2:When cleaning up this, especially now with people from multiple companies working on LibreOfficeKit, it would be important to make the HAS macros actually work in the presence of all the UNSTABLE stuff.As discussed on IRC with vmiklos, currently it doesn't work as perhaps intended. In a LibreOffice instance, the UNSTABLE parts are compiled in, and thus the nSize member of the structs are initialised to include the size of the pointers to the unstable methods.So if we have a LibreOffice instance from before the addition of freeError (or other methods that will be added in the near future), and a client compiled against a bleeding-edge header (with the freeError present), the client will think that the freeError is present in the struct that the LibreOffice instance presents to it, even if it isn't, because the nSize is large enough to cover where freeError would be, even if what actually is in that location in the LibreOffice instance is some unstable function pointer.This will bite us hard at some point in the future unless we fix it soon. My initial suggestion, off-hand, is to move all the unstable function pointers into separate structs, and have a single pointer to such a struct as part of the *stable* API.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1This is wrong for several reasons.First, it sets hard alignment attributes depending on the number format type.Second, it ignores and overrides any alignment attribute the user may have set already.Third, it ignores RTL (Right-To-Left) context. In RTL languages you do not want text to be suddenly left aligned unless requested by the user.Instead of using and setting hard alignment attribution this should be evaluated in view context. See sc/source/ui/view/output2.cxx ScOutputData::LayoutStrings() where getAlignmentFromContext() is used.

In RTL languages you > do not want text to be suddenly left aligned unless requested by > the user. >  > Instead of using and setting hard alignment attribution this should > be evaluated in view context. Patch Set 3:LO uses 90px/in (=90px/72pt) in its own export to svg (at least on my PC, what do you get?). So where a conversion is needed on import, it should use the same setting.I have no strong opinion about how many px should be used for font-size="medium". This value alone says nothing about the rendered size. The unit px is equal to the 'user unit' at the place where px it currently used. Therefore the real size depends highly on viewBox and transformations.Other application have no unique value. Browser base the font-size="medium" to the user's default font size. Google Chrom and Seamonkey seem to use "medium"=16px as predefined value, Internet Explorer 18px, Batik seems to use 12px, and Corel Draw uses a value between 10px and 11px.For the table of scaling values for the other absolute-size keywords, I would stick to factor 1.2, as it is recommended in the first edition of CSS2, because factor 1.5 was noticed as bad. All the other things mentioned in the later specification of CSS2 (e.g. resolution of the device, quality and availability of fonts, no fixed ratio, avoiding <9px) are not necessary in a first implementation. I suggest, to improve the mapping in case of user complains.

Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1 Verified+1Code looks good, but there are some merge conflict with the current master.you need to do"git pull" on master, to have the newest, "git checkout -b test1""git fetch git://gerrit.libreoffice.org/core refs/changes/65/20765/4 && git cherry-pick FETCH_HEAD" to cherry pick you change set.then git will report the conflicts.
Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1 Verified+1I also verified with few samples generated with MSO2003. It looks fine.

Patch Set 2:> (1 comment) >  > Is there any corresponding issue in bugzilla? It will be easier to > understand the design if description of the problem and the > expectation were presented. With the test case you uploaded, > orientation doesn't seem to have any difference in MSO2010 and > LO5.0.3. It also confused why sectd mustn't reset landscape flag.I don't found any issue. It's not about the presentation but about the landscape flag because the presentation only depends on paperw and paperh.You are right, I should'nt reset landscape flag in \sect but in the RTF spec, landscape define a default value for the flag like paperw or paperh and I don't find a command to set portrait orientation in this default value.I found an interesting information in the RTF spec:\lndscpsxn: Page orientation is in landscape format. To mix portrait and landscape sections within a document, the \landscape control should not be used so that the default for a section is portrait, which may be overridden by the \lndscpsxn control.So, I think my files are incorrectly formatted:\sect \paperw16837 \paperh11905 \landscape \sectdThe file should use pgwsxn, pghsxn and lndscpsxn instead of paperw, paperh and landscape and sectd should be before paperw.----I will update my patch :- remove reset section in sectd- implement lndscpsxn to set the current value- let landscape to set the current and default value- edit commit messageAre you agree with that ?

Patch Set 2:It sounds good to implement lndscpsxn though I'm not sure what do you mean by "set current issue". My personal suggestion (although not a requirement ) is that you report an issue first on bugzilla so that others would know the context of the issue and the reason why you have to make the change. Upload some real samples that generated by other software, Word for example, and describe the expected and observed result. The original test case you uploaded seems very simple that I guess it is manually crafted. Without real world example, I felt that we were risking fixing the wrong thing if your interpretation of the problem is wrong.
Patch Set 2:Code looks good, but can you please solve the merge conflict and upload a new patch set.

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1Based on the discussion above I don't think the original patch is ready to get merged, even conflict been resolved.  I suggest don't merge before all question properly answered.

Patch Set 2:No, I don't find any bug on bugzilla.It's not a bug which imply a crash or a bad rendering, the orientation flag "IsLandscape" just doesn't contain the good value because : - \landscape is not used by Word (I tried with Word 2000, 2003, 2007, 2010 and 2013)RTF specification recommended to not use it because it defines a default value and it is not possible to invert it- \lndscpsxsn is currrently not implemented. And it permit to define the orientation flag for the current section (The next secd will reset it)I will edit my patch to implement lndscpsxsn

Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2Similar to 'tdf#47262 SVG: Parse gradient styles twice if the referred...' data referenced by other data is parsed preferred (pre-parsed). When there are more cases like these (as it seems) moving from parsing in one step to multiple or som priority-based parsing should be considered. This patch solves the imminent problem (so should be good for now), but shows a general problem in this importer and leads to the question: How many more bugs will there be due to single-parsing is the wrong approach? Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1> Hopefully benign, since a simple addition - would be good to have > in -5-0 though, otherwise bootstrapping via in-tree JARs suddenly > loses features ...What feature loss?The @since tags should really stay at "LibreOffice 5.1" (now that the corresponding master commit has been backported to -5-1); we don't add new features on micros (and there's no meaningful total order on major.minor.micro revs, only on major.minor ones).  Backporting this 5.1 feature to 5.0.5 would necessarily be "under the radar."

Patch Set 2:> The @since tags should really stay at "LibreOffice 5.1" (now that > the corresponding master commit has been backported to -5-1); we > don't add new features on micros (and there's no meaningful total > order on major.minor.micro revs, only on major.minor ones).  > Backporting this 5.1 feature to 5.0.5 would necessarily be "under > the radar."Good point, changed back to since 5.1 - would be cool to have thisin under the radar, as Bubli mentions, hard to get oldBootstrapConnector functionality replaced otherwise.

Patch Set 1:> > Hopefully benign, since a simple addition - would be good to have > > in -5-0 though, otherwise bootstrapping via in-tree JARs suddenly > > loses features ... >  > What feature loss?It's not feature loss in LO core, but in library using it (noa-libre). It used to have its own bootstrapping mechanism, which wasn't working with new LO anymore, so I killed it in favour of javaunohelper bootstrap. It however used to have the feature of passing custom options to bootstrapped soffice, which core LO didn't have until this commit.

Patch Set 1:My concern is:the point of TabsRelativeToIndent setting is to differentiate between two clearly distinct modes:1. When tabs are relative to this paragraph' start (e.g. 5 cm from paragraph left margin in LTR);2. When tabs are relative to page margin (e.g. 5 cm from page left)They are really different: in first, changing paragraph origin (e.g. moving table cell border, or wrapping from one column to another) moves the coresponding tab stops, while in second, the tab stop positions should stay positioned to absolute values on page, regardless the paragraph origin shift.But it's clearly not the case in current implementation, and was never so from the very beginning. Also, the bug existed from the start, too. So, I think I'd rather let the current way of operation and fix only the ruler bug, instead of forcing the (likely) intended logic with the risk of many existing documents' broken layout. Essentially, now this variable does not alter the tab placement logic, and affects only their saving to file/loading from file.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1I seem to be missing the point of removing the non-relative-to-indent tab stop handling within the ruler.Writer (unfortunately) was initially designed in a way that tab stops are calculated from the left paragraph indent.To be compatible to doc/docx a non-relative usage of tab stops has been added which is (again unfortunately) only used for doc/docx import. If you remove that code the ruler will show wrong tab stops in docx/doc import.

Patch Set 1:> I seem to be missing the point of removing the non-relative-to-indent > tab stop handling within the ruler.Please take a look at tdf#95846, which itself is based on tdf#76005 (linked there as See Also...). I noted the relevant OOo issue there, too. > Writer (unfortunately) was initially designed in a way that tab > stops are calculated from the left paragraph indent. > To be compatible to doc/docx a non-relative usage of tab stops has > been added which is (again unfortunately) only used for doc/docx > import.I see; that is what I explain in my first comment here... > If you remove that code the ruler will show wrong tab stops in > docx/doc import.The whole point is that _having_ this code in ruler _does_ make it show wrong tab stops in doc/docx import. You may notice in the tdf issue, that I discuss the bug manifestation vector to be exactly that: importing docx. Actually, you confirm that the flag is used on import only, and then the tabs are stored in memory in usual LO way (relative to left paragraph indent). From there, they are fed into the ruler code (being usual relative-to-indent), so why does it need to treat them differently in this case?

Patch Set 1:> The whole point is that _having_ this code in ruler _does_ make it > show wrong tab stops in doc/docx import. You may notice in the tdf > issue, that I discuss the bug manifestation vector to be exactly > that: importing docx. Actually, you confirm that the flag is used > on import only, and then the tabs are stored in memory in usual LO > way (relative to left paragraph indent). From there, they are fed > into the ruler code (being usual relative-to-indent), so why does > it need to treat them differently in this case?To me this looks like a related but different problem.Just open a docx with you patch active and apply some tab stops and then add a left paragraph indent. You will notice that in this situation the tabs in the ruler and the document don't match anymore.The problem of tdf#95846 might be that the column offset of the table calculated into the left indent.

Patch Set 1:> To me this looks like a related but different problem. > Just open a docx with you patch active and apply some tab stops and > then add a left paragraph indent. You will notice that in this > situation the tabs in the ruler and the document don't match > anymore. > The problem of tdf#95846 might be that the column offset of the > table calculated into the left indent.Will do that (after my Windows build finishes; that's a pain you know :) )However, I must notice that _now_ it doesn't match from the start; and that happens not only with tables, but with columns either (just checked without the patch on a file created with MSOffice).Will also check if modifying column offset calculations will fix this.Thank you very much for looking into all of this!

Patch Set 1:> I do not understand the term "CPU threads". A thread runs on a core, but multiple threads can run on the same core.I'm not sure why Michael used Threads rather than Cores.> review for master had the comment whether it should rather be "UI Render*er*" - so repeating it here..Saw the comment and think that with or without the *er* is fine.My patch is a first step to improving what was very unclear and we can always a follow up patch to fix whatever is agreed on, as it needs to be sent to master as well.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1> I'm not sure why Michael used Threads rather than Cores.Logically because thread is the correct term. I have right now a 4 core system with 119 threads (in total) running. In modern systems with libraries like lwp and (in systems like android) demand switching, there are no relationship between CPU/Core and threads. > My patch is a first step to improving what was very unclear and we > can always a follow up patch to fix whatever is agreed on, as it > needs to be sent to master as well.I would very much prefer we agree first, then send the patch. Your patch does not contain a lot more so no reason to merge this first.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1The naming is ~irrelevant to me; but it should be consistent between 5-1 to master and then locked down IMHO.JanI - we want to see how many threads there are that can run concurrently to start implementing code that best exploits the parallelism out there. The exact processor geometry etc. is too much potentially identifying information IMHO.As such the naming is pretty ~irrelevant IMHO; best not to quibble.

Patch Set 1: -Code-Review> As such the naming is pretty ~irrelevant IMHO; best not to quibble.Happen to disagree. "CPU threads" is for me very different from "threads", but of course might be because I am too deep into how the CPU works.Will not block this, but neither promote it.

Patch Set 1:This seems a ridiculous discussion to me ;-) doer decides is a vital meritocratic principle =) quibbling adds little value it seems to me.Beyond that - there is nothing simple about APU hardware; we have both GPU and CPU compute resources with things akin to threads in them. Cores is also an horribly misleading term in a SMT world. There are even pending law-suits around "what is a core" - how many resources can be shared etc. There is no "obvious" answer to this question.What we are returning is: the result of std::thread::hardware_concurrency() - we can provide a hyper-descriptive label for this: but then we'll be sending a truck-load of these across the net for years, and there is only so much space in Help->About =)What is in the patch has the merit of brevity; if someone wants to change it to CPU Threads Hardware Concurency - to follow STL or whatever, they are welcome to - preferably in a separate, follow-up patch - that also line-wraps this for Help->About.

When clicking a column or row header the dialog is not closed and stays there and can only be closed with Escape or Enter or selecting a different range. Additionally, when in that state clicking inside the edit field of the dialog, moving the mouse cursor acts as if the mouse button is still pressed, selecting/deselecting the reference text when moving left/right.It would also be nice if more than one column or row could be selected using the headers. Actually it works when using Shift+Click to extend the range, but not by just selecting the headers with the mouse.

We can also change the icon and tooltip dynamically, to make it clear what the button does in each state. > What would be useful is to have it as a split button and when > Save is not accessible, the main button is disabled, but the down > arrow is still accessible.This will make the dropdown non-discoverable, as the only difference between enabled and disabled dropdown button is its color ( black vs. grey).But I want to propose another solution: Currently the dropdown has 2 items: Save as - which already has its own button, and Save Remote File, which is actually a variation of Save As... - So why not leave alone the save button - and implement the dropdown only for Save As. Patch Set 3:Yes i think if the icon and tooltip changed, that would likely make it easier to identify, but i would assume the .uno:Save command (File > Save) should be rendered disabled when its in the Save As mode.About your other suggestion, Save Remote File is a save option more than an a Save As option, as the option to save a file to a remote location isnt available in the Save dialog. Patch Set 3:> Yes i think if the icon and tooltip changed, that would likely make > it easier to identify,Can you please suggest the icon/tooltip to use? > but i would assume the .uno:Save command > (File > Save) should be rendered disabled when its in the Save As > mode.Sure. It doesn't affect the menu in any way.BTW, I forgot to mention that the behavior of this button is now configurable through "expert config". Any user is free to revert it to the state before this patch, or even to drop the dropdown completely:Type "SaveToolbarController" in the search field and hit Enter.To revert to the previous state, change "Controller" to "com.sun.star.comp.framework.GenericPopupToolbarController", and "Value" to ".uno:SaveAsMenu". Leaving "Value" empty will bring back the old simple button.

Patch Set 3:So we just discussed this in the Design Call and came to the following conclusion:Instead of changing the mode of the button, we want to switch icons. So we'll have one icon for the save button indicating that the document is saved (the current one) and one that it has changed (the current one with a decorator, like a start or something).We'll also enable the save button always, no matter the state of the document, so that only the icon changes, but the button is always clickable.In the same run, we'll remove the configuration option for "enable save always" from the options dialogAt last, we'll hide save as from the toolbar.Maxim, Jay, hope you are fine with that?!Maxim, do you have time to work on this?

Andreas has agreed to create an icon. Until then you can use a placeholder icon.

Patch Set 2:> I have changed this to allow adjacent border deletions only. It no > more turns on the adjacent cell borders.The more I think about this automatic behavior the less I like it..silently modifying attributions of cells that are not selected IMHO isa no-no. There will always be situations where the user does not expectthe result, for example if a row of cells has a thick bottom border asfor header cells, and cells of the table below have thin borders.Removing the thin borders should not remove the adjacent thick border aswell.Though Excel has this behavior, because there adjacent cells share theborder and removing it from one cell removes it also from the adjacentcell.The best would be to offer a checkbox "Remove border from adjacent cellsas well" or some such, to be activated only if borders are to beremoved, and only if checked remove borders from envelope cells.Maybe a second correct attempt, if we don't want another checkbox, couldbe to remove an adjacent border only if it has the same attributes(color, width, style), but that would mean having to compare allenvelope cells with their selected neighbour instead of doing it in onego. > I tested in 5.0. If we turn on all four borders of a cell, then we > wont be able to delete one border at a time using sidebar or the > format cell dialog. For deletion of a particular border  ( say > right ) we have to set "no borders" first, then turn on all borders > except right.? Works for me in the Format Cells dialog. Note that there the bordersare tristate, "Border", "Don't care" (which kicks in if borders aredifferent among selected cells) and "Border". So you may have to clicktwice to remove an existent border.

Patch Set 4:Michael, many thanks for the review. I have fixed the name, also improved the patch to limit GetObject only at repeated image loading/overloading, and pushed to the master. (The  repeated image loading could be a result of the repaint triggered by the second call of GetObject - after the successful asynchronous loading of an image.)
Patch Set 5:(2 comments)Still confused here ?

Patch Set 6:> FnHashSet ? - what is the function ? surely a better, more descriptive type name is possibleI have renamed as AsyncLoads in the patch set 6.> Also - I suggested a much clearer name for this hash; but ... this is not it =)I had already changed the member variable name, but you checked an older patch set (patch set 3 instead of the last 5 at that time). > Why have this variable rather than using an empty-hash (and hence no lookup match) ?I have already removed that code in the patch set 6.> Why are we erasing here ? this seems inexplicable to me; I commented on it before; you seem to have responded to the comment - but this is not clear.> If the load of this filename is in-progress - then we prematurely remove it from being in-progress here, before it is loaded (right?) - why ?We want to skip only one LoadFile_Impl() call to avoid immediate paint and recursive image loadings. This skipped LoadFile_Impl() call is the last for the object, when the image loading is finished (see backtrace "Second LoadFile_Impl() call of an asynchronous image loading" in the Bug 95614).Or this call can be the first LoadFile_Impl() call of an other SvFileObject loading the same picture, so we won't start that image loading immediately.This stops freezing with linked images and recent scheduler.Many thanks for the review.

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1Seems reasonable enough I guess - I would name the member variable something sensible; m_aAsyncLoadsInProgress.I'm also really unclear why we erase the item from the hash if it is already there - when requesting the image [ that seems ... odd ] Surely we want to erase that when the async loading has completed (whether it succeeded or failed) - rather than when the 2nd image request is made (what about a 3rd request ?).Anyhow - conceptually loading the same graphic twice does indeed look bogus & good to stop; though whether this is truly the root cause of the freeze is unclear to me =)Thanks.

Patch Set 4:> what other part of the patch makes this become necessary now?Most of the issues I'm trying to fix (containment of macros, namespace conflicts, etc) I discovered while working on improving pch files (patch to follow shortly). I made sure this patch was purely defensive and doesn't include any breaking changes, so nothing in this patch requires this.However, changing the order of includes, or adding certain files in pch, breaks a lot of files (this patch and a handful others that I've submitted hardened our code and fix those issues). The breaking of files has a domino effect, so they are rather hard to find and fix (and consume an inordinate amount of time to track the source and figure out a workaround). My attempt was to make the minimum change to fix macro leaks and other conflicts across headers and files. This patch is for Windows related issues only.RGB happens to be defined by wingdi.h and leaks from multiple places. This was the easiest/simplest fix; to undef it where it conflicts. For other cases it was enough to undef them in postwin.h and make sure it's called after including windows headers.

Patch Set 4:> RGB happens to be defined by wingdi.h and leaks from multiple > places. This was the easiest/simplest fix; to undef it where it > conflicts. For other cases it was enough to undef them in postwin.h > and make sure it's called after including windows headers.But wouldn't it be better to handle undef'ing RGB in postwin.h, and make sure any include of wingdi.h is wrapped in prewin/postwin.h?  The current fix allows workdir/CustomTarget/officecfg/registry/officecfg/Office/Common.hxx to be included, but if a source file happens to first include that officecfg/Office/Common.hxx, then include wingdi.h, and later wants to acutally use the struct RGB from Common.hxx, it still runs into a problem.

Patch Set 4:> > RGB happens to be defined by wingdi.h and leaks from multiple > > places. This was the easiest/simplest fix; to undef it where it > > conflicts. For other cases it was enough to undef them in > postwin.h > > and make sure it's called after including windows headers. >  > But wouldn't it be better to handle undef'ing RGB in postwin.h, and > make sure any include of wingdi.h is wrapped in prewin/postwin.h? I tried that. And can give it another try. But it would require a much bigger change, obviously. The main problem is that wingdi.h is actually included from other windows headers too. So we can't fully control when it's included. But can give it another shot and narrow it down further. In fact, I spent hours trying to find what file includes the conflicting values to create this patch. > The current fix allows workdir/CustomTarget/officecfg/registry/officecfg/Office/Common.hxx > to be included, but if a source file happens to first include that > officecfg/Office/Common.hxx, then include wingdi.h, and later wants > to acutally use the struct RGB from Common.hxx, it still runs into > a problem.Well, that would be be a problem _only_ if wingdi.h was already included _before_ Office/Common.h, and in that case the build would fail because the macro would conflict with the declaration of RGB (my patch avoids this situation).However, if wingdi.h was _not_ included at the point of #undef RGB, then nothing bad would happen if it is included afterwards. Unless I missed something, I don't see how there would still be a problem, as wingdi.h will define RGB without issue.I should add that I hated this particular line of my patch. I share your view that it's best avoided altogether. But I couldn't find a better solution. Will try again though.

Patch Set 4:> > The current fix allows workdir/CustomTarget/officecfg/registry/officecfg/Office/Common.hxx > > to be included, but if a source file happens to first include that > > officecfg/Office/Common.hxx, then include wingdi.h, and later wants > > to acutally use the struct RGB from Common.hxx, it still runs into > > a problem. >  > Well, that would be be a problem _only_ if wingdi.h was already > included _before_ Office/Common.h, and in that case the build would > fail because the macro would conflict with the declaration of RGB > (my patch avoids this situation). >  > However, if wingdi.h was _not_ included at the point of #undef RGB, > then nothing bad would happen if it is included afterwards. Unless > I missed something, I don't see how there would still be a problem, > as wingdi.h will define RGB without issue.But assume wingdi.h does  #define RGB foo(or whatever exactly it defines RGB to), and the .cxx file including first officecfg/Office/Common.hxx and then wingdi.h then has code  officecfg::Office::Common::Image::Color::RGB::Red::get();that would be pre-processed to  officecfg::Office::Common::Image::Color::foo::Red::get();and fail to compile.

Patch Set 4:>  > But assume wingdi.h does >  > #define RGB foo >  > (or whatever exactly it defines RGB to), and the .cxx file > including first officecfg/Office/Common.hxx and then wingdi.h then > has code >  > officecfg::Office::Common::Image::Color::RGB::Red::get(); >  > that would be pre-processed to >  > officecfg::Office::Common::Image::Color::foo::Red::get(); >  > and fail to compile.Of course. But my change will neither help nor harm that case :)(I only fixed the reverse, which is that wingdi.h is included before Common.hxx.)And I believe that case doesn't exist now (if they existed, I fixed them).Containing windows headers in postwin.h will help (which I fully support). But even then, once a header that includes wingdi.h (directly or indirectly) is included in the pch, then we still face the same issue. So it's really tricky.Since I was working on pch files, it was this latter case that really made things complicated. The way to avoid that is to never include an uncontained header that leaks in the pch, which is what we do. So the only case that breaks the build is when RGB is defined before Office/Common.hxx, which I patched.Actually, I think what we should do is add #undef RGB to postwin.h (even when currently it's not needed). I think that's the right thing to do and guarantee that wingdi.h is as contained as possible at all times.

Patch Set 4:I wish we had aw080 already, all SdrObjects fully transformable, mirroring preserved...The current Rectangle unfortunately allows such bad/inconsistent states (left() > right()), thats why justify is needed (and why B2DRange is better, this can not happen). The Rectangle is *not* the place to keep such information. It's place is at the model (the SdrObject). See ::TRGetBaseGeometry implementations where the mirroring is coming from - e.g in SdrObjCustomShape it *is* a model member (X and Y).Currently - except for the SdrObjCustomShape and SdrGrafObj - the mirrored states are not preserved - the mirroring is geometrically *executed* on the existing geometry, that's it (aw080 changes this).You can see this sad truth e.g. at the graphic object - insert one in Draw/Impress and add text. Hor mirror does not change the text at all, vertical mirror uses a 180 deg rotation, *not* a true vert mirroring.This only does not come to more attention due to the fact that nearly all shapes are CustomShapes nowadays...Do not forget: mirror in X and Y equals a 180 deg rotation (can be seen/proved looking at the corrresponding homogen matrix)

Patch Set 4:(1 comment)You do what is possible with the current model - execute flips on the existing geometry. Just be aware that a call to TRGetBaseGeometry will not return these changes. Flip handling needs to be moved before shear.

Is that a +1? :) >  > Only issue i have is that when enabling/disabling it, it jumps to > the cursor position after it finishes rather than to keeping the > position of where i was when i changed the state.Tricky. When changing the state, the layout is invalidated and the the default logic of repaginating and page-layout does its thing on next idle timer event. So changing this behavior will affect others as well. While changing the position is not desirable, changing the cursor and losing selection is even more problematic--both of which I prevent in this patch. >  > On a separate issue, it might be better to have the entry labelled > 'Whitespace' and change the toggle behaviour, so when its > unchecked, it goes into hide whitespace mode.Interesting point. The 'Hide Whitespace' was chosen to be similar to MSO. Would 'Show Whitespace' be better or just 'Whitespace'? Should I change it (in separate patch) or you want to confirm (possibly by getting input from others) ?

Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2 Verified+1This is a starter so that at least a case-sensitive matching list is picked if one exists instead of a case-insensitive one that just happens to be encountered before.Further improvements in case handling can be made in follow-up changes.Also, currently there is no differentiation if lists differ by order of entries, e.g. with lists aaa,bbb,ccc and aaa,ccc,bbb and cells aaa,ccc selected, still aaa,bbb,ccc is picked.

Patch Set 2:Another idea:FillAnalyse calls ScUserList::GetData().  ScUserList is container of all ScUserListData.ScUserListData::GetSubIndex() is case insensitive.ScUserList::GetData() currently has a loop that calls GetSubIndex() on every ScUserListData object.If we change GetData() to have two loops, first does case-sensitive search on all ScUserListData objects, second loop does case-insensitive search,  and we add extra default sort lists for each case,  that might do it as well.I think this change wouldn't add much overhead because GetSubIndex does a case-sensitive search first and then a case-insensitive one.  By this change we'd just be changing the order of the searches.

Patch Set 2:> Another idea: > FillAnalyse calls ScUserList::GetData().  ScUserList is container > of all ScUserListData. >  > ScUserListData::GetSubIndex() is case insensitive. >  > ScUserList::GetData() currently has a loop that calls GetSubIndex() > on every ScUserListData object. >  > If we change GetData() to have two loops, first does case-sensitive > search on all ScUserListData objects, second loop does > case-insensitive search,  and we add extra default sort lists for > each case,  that might do it as well.I'd like to avoid cluttering up the default lists. > I think this change wouldn't add much overhead because GetSubIndex > does a case-sensitive search first and then a case-insensitive one. >  By this change we'd just be changing the order of the searches.See my previous comment, the algorithm lined out there takes less thantwo full loops in worst case (if nothing matches).

Patch Set 3:Jan: the summary line is precious...adding solved/fixed and other editorial words isnot very informative.. think of it in the context of someone scouring the log to find a patch related to some situation/bugs'solved' is really not adding any value to the message.2/ referenceing the source is very useful, so it is a good thing to bug the cid number here..but fro grepability is it conventional to use the <prefix>#<number>notation. it make it easier to greap for human and easier to have machine-automated linking to external reference while limiting the false positive.in doubt git log --grep can help to find how other have done it$ git log --grep "^coverity#" --format=oneline | wc -l    5185$ git log --grep "^cid#" --format=oneline | wc -l     271$ git log --grep "^CID#" --format=oneline | wc -l     260$ git log --grep "^CID " --format=oneline | wc -l       2

Patch Set 3:> Jan: the summary line is precious... >  > adding solved/fixed and other editorial words is > not very informative.. think of it in the context of someone > scouring the log to find a patch related to some situation/bugs > 'solved' is really not adding any value to the message. >  > 2/ referenceing the source is very useful, so it is a good thing to > bug the cid number here.. > but fro grepability is it conventional to use the <prefix>#<number> > notation. it make it easier to greap for human and easier to have > machine-automated linking to external reference while limiting the > false positive. >  > in doubt git log --grep can help to find how other have done it >  > $ git log --grep "^coverity#" --format=oneline | wc -l > 5185 > $ git log --grep "^cid#" --format=oneline | wc -l > 271 > $ git log --grep "^CID#" --format=oneline | wc -l > 260 > $ git log --grep "^CID " --format=oneline | wc -l > 2Thanks I will keep that in mind for my next patch set.

Patch Set 1:To elaborate on how to amend a patch: The trick here is preserving the same Change-Id of the commit message, so that Gerrit recognizes it should be on the same thread. Locally, you do a new commit, then you do `git rebase -i HEAD~2' to squash that with the previous commit. Then you push and Gerrit will detect your updated squashed commit as a new version (or 脭脟拢patch set脭脟脴) without creating a new thread. Hope this helps!

Patch Set 1:> To elaborate on how to amend a patch: The trick here is preserving > the same Change-Id of the commit message, so that Gerrit recognizes > it should be on the same thread. Locally, you do a new commit, then > you do `git rebase -i HEAD~2' to squash that with the previous > commit.Git commit --amend is a much easier way to do that.iow checkout your gerrit patchdo the modificationscommit them using --amendgit push origin HEAD:refs/for/master Then you push and Gerrit will detect your updated squashed > commit as a new version (or 脭脟拢patch set脭脟脴) without creating a new > thread. Hope this helps!

Patch Set 2:ordinary number string like 123:  Microsoft Word works the same way.  No U+ is required there.  I very intentionally wrote it to work the way it does.control codes:  It could be useful to be able to SEE what code exists, by toggling FROM the control code TO hex notation.   Of course, once you do that, you want to be able to get back to the original code again with another toggle just like you would do with every other character...  (Well, there is always undo instead I guess.)  MSWord doesn't work from 0-1f either I see.  I didn't see any harm in allowing it.  Inadvertent use of Alt-X will always result in unexpected results (as with any feature).

Patch Set 3:Thank you for your review.I think that DECODE_WITH_CHARSET is better than DECODE_TO_IURI.If the file name is "foo%2Fbar", the return value of getUnpackedValueOrDefault() will probably be "foo%252Fbar".Because the return value is url-encoded(percent-encoded).If we use DECODE_TO_IURI, decoded result will be "foo%252Fbar".If we use DECODE_WITH_CHARSET, decoded result will be "foo%2Fbar".

Patch Set 3:"If we use DECODE_TO_IURI, decoded result will be 'foo%252Fbar'."  No.Also, looking more closely at the code in MediaDescriptor::requestAndVerifyDocPassword, disregarding the unfortunate variable name "aDocumentName" and the equally unfortunate naming of corresponding css.task.Document[MS]PasswordRequest members as "Name" ("the name of the document," ts ts), what is apparently intended is to pass the document's URI (cf. PasswordDialog ctor in uui/source/passworddlg.cxx, where the corresponding value is more properly named "aDocURL").  So it is probably better to mark-up the URI in a more "user friendly" way directly in that PasswordDialog ctor instead.Also, given that tdf#89694's example involves a filename also containing a space, an even more "user friendly" way might be to use DECODE_UNAMBIGUOUS instead of DECODE_TO_IURI even (which would display the space as " " instead of as "%20").  Note that there is no single "right" answer whether to use NO_DECODE, DECODE_TO_IURI, or DECODE_UNAMBIGUOUS here.  Each produces a string that could unambiguously be converted back into a true URI, just with varying degrees of "user friendliness" of the produced string.  On the other hand, DECODE_WITH_CHARSET produces a string that in general cannot unambiguously be converted back into a true URI, so loses information and potentially presents a misleading result to the user.

Patch Set 3:(1 comment)Thank you for your advice.I also think that the variable name "aDocumentName" is very misleading.1. About the insert point to decode URL.As you wrote, I think that the best way to convert is in PasswordDialog ctor.However, to reduce the influence I now was according to the method for the other formats(odf,etc...).For the other formats, probably insert points to decode URL are just before calling the UNO API, Document(MS)PasswordRequest(2). (e.g.   http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/sfx2/source/appl/appopen.cxx#245  http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/sw/source/filter/ww8/ww8par.cxx#5468)Somehow, those APIs want "the name of the document"... Therefore, in the case of OOXML, I think that the insert point to decode URL is either within MediaDescriptor::requestAndVerifyDocPassword() in unotools or DocPasswordHelper::requestAndVerifyDocPassword() in comphelper.Because the latter point has a smaller effect, I will modify the patch.(I think in the comphelper, INetURLObject can not be used because of the module dependencies. So, I will call directly rtl::url::decode().)2. About decodeMechanism for converting URL.I tried the two ways of rtl_UriDecodeWithCharset and rtl_UriDecodeToIuriRI, I have attached screen shots to bug report tdf#89694.https://bug-attachments.documentfoundation.org/attachment.cgi?id=113966https://bug-attachments.documentfoundation.org/attachment.cgi?id=113967I used this patch.https://bug-attachments.documentfoundation.org/attachment.cgi?id=113965I think the case in rtl_UriDecodeWithCharset is more user-friendly.If I mistake,  please point out.

Patch Set 3:>Therefore, in the case of OOXML, I think that the insert point to decode URL is either within >MediaDescriptor::requestAndVerifyDocPassword() in unotools or >DocPasswordHelper::requestAndVerifyDocPassword() in comphelper. Because the latter point >has a smaller effect, I will modify the patch. (I think in the comphelper, INetURLObject can not >be used because of the module dependencies. So, I will call directly rtl::url::decode().)Sorry, this is a bad idea.If we modify DocPasswordHelper::requestAndVerifyDocPassword() in comphelper, that modification influences in the other formats(odf,etc...).

Patch Set 3:Re "1. About the insert point to decode URL.":  Those other places are misguided in passing a marked-up "document name" instead of a URI.  The only reasonable design is to centrally mark-up the URI in the PasswordDialog ctor in uui/source/passworddlg.cxx, where it is presented to the user.  The PasswordDialog ctor gets it right in calling it "aDocURL," all the other places unfortunately get it wrong in vaguely calling it a "document name."Re "2. About decodeMechanism for converting URL.":  See my earlier "Also, given that tdf#89694's example involves a filename also containing a space [...]" comment.

Patch Set 1:This bug could be exhibiting multiple problems at higher levels, so I'm considering this fix to be a band-aid.  These problems are way above my expertise to comment on or investigate (see the bug report for background information.)1.)  I'd guess that adding support for some InsertObjectXXX toolbar functions registers a binding for a new textsh, which becomes dirty for every key press.  That seems expensive and buggy.  It is these "outside events" that are affecting the selection.2.)  I can't even guess at the circumstance that requires the popping of a cursor to cancel a selection.  Why is that code even in wrtsh1?  It seems to have been there since day1 and I have no idea how to identify whether it would be safe to remove it now.3.)  I hope there aren't any 脭脟拢necessary consequences脭脟脴 of calling push/pop that I've lost in bypassing them.  I think my proposed change is the least intrusive method of resolving this MAB quickly.4.)  I'm dancing around with cursor脭氓脝HasMark(), shell脭氓脝HasSelection() somewhere, and shell脭氓脝IsSelection() with cursor presently in a selection.  Am I correct in equating HasSelection with HasMark?  Otherwise, the fix could be further limited to IsSelection.

Patch Set 2:I don't think that the document will be rendered differently once LibreOffice saves it. I agree that this fix is not ideal, but it would take a lot more effort to solve it correctly.All the labels are treated as strings, not as numbers.  So we could do that we apply the number format on import, and still keep the result (like "Oct-12") as string, which would make them displaying nicely. The drawback is the export / roundtrip, as then the string with the applied number format would get saved.  But I believe will make the situation for export (roundtrip) not much worse than currently, because we are exporting the labels as strings anyway, not as numbers, so now after roundtrip, the user sees 41183 instead of Oct-12 anyway.

Patch Set 2:How will this not result in different rendering once LibreOffice saves the document. All the code that is behind the *MSO* flags in the chart2/source/view/* code will only be hit for documents that have been saved by MSO.None of these code paths will be hit if the same document has been saved by LibreOffice.Additionally I consider the idea to put such code into the chart2/source/view/* the worst idea since the decision to use UNO inside chart2/*. The chart2/source/view code should never ever contain checks for the file format and even less for the producer of the file.At least I would never accept such code inside of chart2.

Patch Set 4:> I am not sure, but a compiler should use some optimizations for > loops here and it will not affect basic operations as much.What optimization do you have in mind? > Moreover (I am sure that you know about it :) ) sum, sum of square, > count and product for a single reference, a range of cells and a > list of values (I mean e.g. "=SUM(2;3;4)") are calculated by the > ScInterpreter::IterateParameters, not by ScMatrixImpl methods. The > second ones are called for values in brackets ("=SUM({5;3;1}"). I > probably missed something, cause I'm still finding new things in > the code, but I think a bit worse performance could be noticeable > only in some corner cases, e.g. when user will type by hand a few > thousand numbers between parenthesis ...but still.You're missing generated matrix operations in array context, for example {=SUM(some_condition_of(range))}(entered as array formula with Shift+Ctrl+Enter) for range A:A willproduce a one million rows matrix of 1 and 0 values whether thecondition is met for each cell in range and count the number of matches(sum of 1 elements). This is not a far fetched example, it is commonspreadsheet practice. Actually you could test/time performance beforeand after your change with a simple {=SUM(A:A=2)}after having filled column A with alternating values of 2 and 3. Usinga millisecond timer resolution probably already should show thedifference.Things may get worse if multiple conditions are evaluated using forexample multiplication, which acts like a logical AND in {=SUM(condition1(range1)*condition2(range2))} > Similarly for average, max and min values - most of the time they > are calculated by ScInterpreter, not ScMatrix methods. Could it be > changed to have one operation in one place?I dont know what you mean. > I made this change thinking, beside performance, also about further > code reductions. It will be nice to have one functor for all > operations resulting in a single value, but it seems that I didn't > take a few elements (e.g. some operations count elements, other do > not) into account and it's rather a premature optimization than a > real gain. In the end, for now, the solution with two templates > seems to be the best for me.Probably, yes.

I > > probably missed something, cause I'm still finding new things in > > the code, but I think a bit worse performance could be noticeable > > only in some corner cases, e.g. when user will type by hand a few > > thousand numbers between parenthesis ...but still. >  > You're missing generated matrix operations in array context, for > example >  > {=SUM(some_condition_of(range))} >  > (entered as array formula with Shift+Ctrl+Enter) for range A:A will > produce a one million rows matrix of 1 and 0 values whether the > condition is met for each cell in range and count the number of > matches > (sum of 1 elements). This is not a far fetched example, it is > common > spreadsheet practice. Actually you could test/time performance > before > and after your change with a simple >  > {=SUM(A:A=2)} >  > after having filled column A with alternating values of 2 and 3. > Using > a millisecond timer resolution probably already should show the > difference. >  > Things may get worse if multiple conditions are evaluated using for > example multiplication, which acts like a logical AND in >  > {=SUM(condition1(range1)*condition2(range2))}Thank you, I didn't know about this. You were so right... I've checked three versions and the previous one is about two times slower than the original (under callgrind), suprisingly for me. This version is about 1.2 times slower, but I do not know why at the moment. There is pass-by-value and assignment outside operator instead pass-by-ref, but I suppose it's not problem and there is something else. > > Similarly for average, max and min values - most of the time they > > are calculated by the ScInterpreter, not ScMatrix methods. Could it > be > > changed to have one operation in one place? >  > I dont know what you mean.I didn't notice one call to the ScMatrix, sorry. Never mind.

Patch Set 3:鈹济紆kasz, could you address my concerns and provide some means to not execute these loops or other conditional code for ops that consist of only one operation? Even if it would require to have two WalkElementBlocks templates. But maybe you have some better idea?

Patch Set 3:I am not sure, but a compiler should use some optimizations for loops here and it will not affect basic operations as much.Moreover (I am sure that you know about it :) ) sum, sum of square, count and product for a single reference, a range of cells and a list of values (I mean e.g. "=SUM(2;3;4)") are calculated by the ScInterpreter::IterateParameters, not by ScMatrixImpl methods. The second ones are called for values in brackets ("=SUM({5;3;1}"). I probably missed something, cause I'm still finding new things in the code, but I think a bit worse performance could be noticeable only in some corner cases, e.g. when user will type by hand a few thousand numbers between parenthesis ...but still.Similarly for average, max and min values - most of the time they are calculated by ScInterpreter, not ScMatrix methods. Could it be changed to have one operation in one place?I made this change thinking, beside performance, also about further code reductions. It will be nice to have one functor for all operations resulting in a single value, but it seems that I didn't take a few elements (e.g. some operations count elements, other do not) into account and it's rather a premature optimization than a real gain. In the end, for now, the solution with two templates seems to be the best for me.

Patch Set 3:Now I am confused, are these really equivalent?

Patch Set 3:Replying to myself: Yeah, they are.USING_X11 is TRUE when we are building for a platform that uses X11, and we haven't used the --without-x option. with_x is "no" when we have used the switch --without-x (which used to be called --enable-headless), and that de facto has been developed only for platforms where X11 *could* be used. So USING_X11!=TRUE turns out to be equivalent to with_x==no. Unless I miss something;)In theory one could also imagine building a LibreOffice for Windows or OS X that would not use any display-oriented APIs, but that would be fairly pointless, as that functionality is always present in the OS anyway. It isn't like Linux, where some people think it is useful to have installations without any X11 stuff.
Patch Set 3:If I get it right, we should always check for USING_X11 instead of with_x. USING_X11 always has the value of with_x, but additionally it has the OS defaults.
Patch Set 2:Using UNDO_START and UNDO_END allows the inside functions to define the comment - which they properly do.  Without providing a SwRewriter argument, the variables are left undefined.

If so, it may be better to use.    #if __clang_major__ == 3 && __clang_minor__ < 7 && __clang_patchlevel < xAs stated in the bug report I could be wrong here, but this is what I got to compile on my computer. Comments or constructive criticism are welcome!
Patch Set 1:I just did some digging around and it looks like the change to forallBases occurred in commit af49942c7. The commit is under the current stable, but is not under 3.7 as far as I can tell.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1(1 comment)> Do we know the exact patchlevel that the parameters for > CXXRecordDecl::forallBases were changed? If so, it may be better to > use. >  > #if __clang_major__ == 3 && __clang_minor__ < 7 && > __clang_patchlevel < x >  > As stated in the bug report I could be wrong here, but this is what > I got to compile on my computer. Comments or constructive criticism > are welcome!I routinely build the compilerplugins code against current builds of Clang trunk.  When there is breakage, I add #if blocks using the upcoming __clang_major/minor__ versions, but it may be the case that sometimes these breaking changes will not actually appear in that (then upcoming) version, but will only remain on trunk (towards the next version).  I have never yet seen it necessary to discriminate based on __clang_patchlevel.
Patch Set 2:(1 comment)>I have never yet seen it necessary to discriminate based on __clang_patchlevel.Good to know!Thanks for the comments.
