Patch Set 1: Verified-1Looks good. However, two things:- When selecting a whole cell, the conversion doesn't work- Can you please add some sensible text to the undo stack?

Patch Set 1:Undo:  I don't see any example code in calc that sets an undo message, and from what I DO see the text is a hard-coded response based on the type of 'edit'.  If I just type regular text, I also only get "input" (from InsertText() call) with no extra detail.  So what I have works identically to regular changes, and I don't see ANY ability to set an undo comment. cell editing:  This would need to be done in a totally different section.  In the editsh EXECUTE(), the Alt-X keystroke isn't even being captured when the cell is only selected.  So, effectively Calc is not in edit mode yet, and thus Alt-X doesn't apply.  If the "cursor" is either in the cell itself OR in the top editview, then the alt-x function works.  I would expect people to be editing the text when they use Alt-X, not finding an entire cell of data and trying to convert the whole thing.  So I don't think it is necessary to duplicate all of this code to handle that situation.

Patch Set 1:Possible usecase for cell-level Alt-X support: building a table demonstrating unicode characters.  Select a row of cells, Alt-X and convert all to unicode character (or vice versa).  I'll look into what that will take.  It would be a separate patch.

Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2 Verified+1Ah the irony =) they're only disabled temporarily. I wanted to look at those guys and see if we can't improve them. We previously had tests that passed reliably =) I had hoped that eg. taking the median mark/space ratio between a few dozen AutoTimer triggers and comparing that to what it is supposed to be would show us whether we were spinning the mainloop hard rather than doing nice periodic updates eg.But I didn't read the unit test code too carefully - thanks so much for re-basing the cleanups =) lets submit as/when CI builds it cleanly if it can.

Patch Set 4:> Ah the irony =) they're only disabled temporarily. I wanted to look > at those guys and see if we can't improve them. We previously had > tests that passed reliably =)My tests are far more stringent than previous tests, AFAIK. > I had hoped that eg. taking the > median mark/space ratio between a few dozen AutoTimer triggers and > comparing that to what it is supposed to be would show us whether > we were spinning the mainloop hard rather than doing nice periodic > updates eg.That would work. The tests I wrote were counting the number of times the timers trigger in a multi-timer scenario. What I had discovered is that there is a lack of consistency, which I have plans to fix/address.For example, when two timers have the same timeout and priority, one could get a very low trigger rate (or none at all). This is because the trigger logic always picks the one with highest priority that is next in line, and so can end up picking the same timer to trigger every time, starving the other(s).I have a patch to address this and also to fix make IdleTimer fire only when the process idles. >  > But I didn't read the unit test code too carefully - thanks so much > for re-basing the cleanups =) lets submit as/when CI builds it > cleanly if it can.The reason I had disabled the fail condition when the new tests were excluded is because the remaining code is useful in detecting timers that don't trigger during the watchdog timeout. That is, timers should eventually trigger, even if they don't trigger with any accuracy. So I was effectively disabling the accuracy test, but the timers should've triggered during the dozen seconds that the watchdog ways (which you've increased). The test not passing reliably was because of the strictness of the precision tests, not the fact that timers weren't triggering (which would be a real bug). The precision tests are only meaningful if they come with some delta, and I had used 10-20%, increasing it would mean more passing runs, but less useful precision tests. Let's keep them disabled for now.Thanks again for the reviews and helping with this. And please expect more patches on timers.

Patch Set 6:> Tried over buildID f15cbf2451d08ccddde9643c9f926a322f9f9917 > The Hide Withspaces checkbox works as expected. > I did a test with a very long document (https://bugs.documentfoundation.org/attachment.cgi?id=117873). > Not sure if there is not race condition with automatic spelling > verification and words count. At some moment I needed to off/on the > checkbox when scrolling through this large document. Unless that > the whitespace between pages was not hidden.Thanks! This is a rendering change. There should be no change/impact to other functionality. I'll take a look and try to reproduce your case. It might be unrelated issue that is triggered by this test doc.

Patch Set 6:> Tried it out as it wasnt what i was expecting, as it is not what > the bug report is asking for. Which part of the bug report were you > adopting?The implementation is to remove headers and footers and reduce margins to a minimum in this mode. I haven't implemented in-layout controls to enable/disable this mode, just the menu entry. I also haven't implemented any other requests in that bug report or others (please see my email title "Writer: draft layout and hide whitespace [long]" on the maillist for an overview of the current requests and what I'm suggesting we support).The original description of #39080 is fairly accurate as to what I've implemented, except it's not a new layout, just a menu option (no settings or other controls, yet, either).Of course we can add features and complexity once we agree on the approach and what we want to support.

Patch Set 6:> Also noticed that between-page gaps reduced and popped back to its > original size after enabling 'Hide Whitespace', though changing the > zoom level or reopening the document solves that issue.Thanks for the feedback. Do you mean it changed the gap while scrolling/refreshing? Or was it a rendering glitch that went away after zooming? Is it possible to have a screenshot? What OS were you running it under (I only tested under Windows)?

Patch Set 6:> What i saw wasnt similar to the original description, as it didnt > ask for left and right page margins to disappear. About the margins > at the top and bottom of each page, the top margin on the first > page and bottom margin on the last page shouldnt disappear. I'm not > sure whenever headers and footers should disappear either, but i'd > have to double check in MSO to know for certain. > I see what you mean now. As I said, I didn't try to replicate MSO exactly or the bug report, just a first hack at the request to reduce/hide whitespace. And, IMHO, I don't see why we should clone the feature as-is from MSO (or any other) instead of deciding what would be best in terms of usability for our users (myself being a heavy user of Writer).I don't have a preference except to make the feature as useful as possible. In that respect, left/right margins can be reduced in book- and multi-page views (and could be left as-is in the single-page view).I would really like to get UI designer and user feedback here, as this is a usability feature, not a technical one per-se.
Patch Set 6:> Screencast - https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B6qJrVIa0SAlRDF6RjhWWFo0dTA/view?usp=sharingThanks. This is perfect. Will investigate further.

Patch Set 6:I checked MSO and i was mistaken with my assumptions, all is fine except that the left and right margins should be left as is. The intent of the feature is to eliminate white space between (above and below) pages, so there is less scrolling up and down through the document, so there isnt a to need hide left and right margins, as that alters how the page would be displayed, as more content jumps to previous pages. It seems that removing the header and footer also causes content to jump to the previous page, as the page isnt being cropped but instead the content is allowed to flow within the full size of the page space.In case i didnt mention it before, i am part of the design and UX teams. :D

Patch Set 6:> so there isnt a to need hide left and right margins,Should we hide left/right margins in book-view and multipage-view ?Let me update the patch and let you play with left/right margins hidden only in book- and multipage-view, and see what you think. > It seems that removing the header and > footer also causes content to jump to the previous page, as the > page isnt being cropped but instead the content is allowed to flow > within the full size of the page space.Yes. I mentioned this somewhere as a limitation. The reason for this is that the page size is the same, but the margins are removed/reduced. So the text is allowed to fill in more surface area. This could be solved by changing the page dimensions in hide-whitespace mode. I didn't try to do that, again, to get initial feedback. > In case i didnt mention it before, i am part of the design and UX > teams. :DFantastic! Thanks again.

Patch Set 1:> by the way "include-what-you-use" should report these as well, > although not in windows-only code yet because we'd need to be able > to build with clang on windows first. >  > see also easy-hack  https://bugs.documentfoundation.org/show_bug.cgi?id=42949Thanks Michael. Good to know. The reason I wrote this script is because I have another patch that improves pch generation (a rewrite of update_pch in python that updates every single pch in the codebase in a few seconds). It was obvious to me that to improve the pch generation to make builds faster I had to deal with the problem of conflicting headers (that are excluded from pch) and required headers (that will break the build if left out). This script solves the latter problem, so now what is included in pch headers is purely to accelerate builds, not to prevent the build from breaking.Will submit the update_pch script and updated pch files sometime soon, as time permits.

Patch Set 4:Also I need to note, that the bugdoc itself is slightly ill-formed. The number of records in its header is reported 21, while it contains 22 records in total (including header and EOF). The [MS-EMF] specifies that ALL records must be counted there (the example EMF there confirms that), but the producer of the bugdoc clearly counts only records following header. LO does nothing special on EOF record (just makes hard reset of number of records left to zero), that's why it's safe reading such files.

Patch Set 3:I think the problem is that there is this case where an empty rectangle is passed as the control region, and the spinbutton area is passed down as a controlvalue. The empty control region gets mirrored for rtl from left(0), top(0), empty, empty to right(number), top(0), empty, empty and so the cairo_translate call is given a non-0 number and it all falls apart.Lets try not mirroring the empty rectangle arg, and take the first hunk of this patch which is clearly ok and then the second isn't needed.Hopefully this doesn't break any other native-rendering platforms, looks ok for gtk2 and gtk3 for me at least

Patch Set 5:(2 comments)> don't really know what this does :-), but it has a unit test and > the build passesI know this has already been merged but Laurent asked me to look at this (and only now I am getting a chance)As far as I understand it ('cause I am not so familiar with this stuff either and anything I did know I have mostly forgotten) this looks like in general the correct approach.There needs to be a version bump for the binary format, there is already a version bump prepared (that was missed) see http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/s?refs=B_EXT_IMG_VERSION&project=core  E.g. the binary format was supposed to be changed to B_EXT_IMG_VERSION but it never happened, probably it was around the time of openoffice->libreoffice or something I can't remember, I do remember we were waiting for a new release to bump the version. Patch Set 5:Hi Ashod - is it -really- the case that our periodic timers don't work  =) I'd be really worried if that was so - we need a unit test for it. Any chance you can create one ?Thanks !

Patch Set 5:> Hi Ashod - is it -really- the case that our periodic timers don't > work  =) I'd be really worried if that was so - we need a unit test > for it. Any chance you can create one ? > Thanks !Depends what you mean by "work." The timers of course _do_ work, but that is not the problem I'm fixing. I'm fixing the issue with high idle CPU utilization. Periodic timers should reset their start time so that they re-fire only after the duration has expired. The issue, I found, is that Timer thinks it's ready to fire again at the next tick. Ticks come in for the _soonest_ next timer delay (this is because we really have only one system timer callback, and we need it to fire for the next timer in the queue). In the worst case they come in immediately (after 1ms) and in those cases Timer thinks it's ready to fire again, which it does. This doesn't cause any obvious problems, other than CPU utilization where there shouldn't be any (because Timer handles background jobs, like spellchecking, which wastes some CPU and returns, but the waste is proportional to the document size and number of documents open).It is clear from the code that nowhere is the start-time reset. Of course I had the luxury of debugging and seeing what was happening, but the code and my comments make it almost trivial to trace the variable in question and see that without changing it, it will trick Timer into firing again. (See Timer::ReadyForSchedule where mnUpdateTime is used.)I can add unittest for this but, from experience, timers are not reliable enough to trap them within a reasonable time frame from make the test meaningful. On a non-realtime OS, they come with no guarantees. And they are less consistent across a number of OSes. We can have a crude "test fire once" and "test don't fire too soon" but it's harder to have "fired too late." Also, it's much harder to simulate the myriads of jobs we have and the arbitrary periods of each (and how they overlap).I'll give it a shot, but applying and running a large document with this 1 liner will show that the idle CPU utilization does go to 0.
Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2 Verified+1Going to go with the long plausible wall of text :-)

Patch Set 2:6343754e310a589cb49e2a1da0cd68472571179d "cppcheck:noExplicitConstructor" broke e.g.  m_xCachedProps.reset(      new CachableContentProperties( aResource ) );in Content::open (ucb/source/ucp/webdav/webdavcontent.cxx) by removing the possibility to implicitly convert from aResource of type DAVResource to ContentProperties (as expected as arg to CachableContentProperties ctor) via (non-explicit) ContentProperties ctor.However, this change here effectively elides the original converting ContentProperties ctor call, but that ctor e.g. has special-handling code for a "Title" property.  Are you sure this change is fine?

Patch Set 1:The point of the change is that without this, part switching in Calc does not work, as Calc does not invalidate everything after a part switch (unlike Impress), and we suppose the right fix for this is to let the clients throw away the tiles, rather than letting Calc send out invalidations, too.

Patch Set 2:Address reuse shouldn't be a problem any more than with plain Python objects - as long as the PyUNO object exists as a dict key or set entry, it hasn't been destroyed, so the intended use case is covered. The hash code isn't itself a unique identifier, it must be used together with an object equality check through __cmp__() (PyUNO_cmp)Neither is the hash supposed in this instance to be a guarantee of content equality. If what the UNO object points to changes somehow, in content or by a (more) remote bridge doing something odd, that's still irrelevant - this is exactly comparable to the hashing behaviour of ordinary user created Python objects: by default, __hash__ is id(object) (... which is really its memory address), and an object is equal exactly and only to itselfMore specifically, the requirements are:- The hash value must not change over the lifetime of the object (true, the address of the wrapped UNO object can't change, and the same wrapped object is reused even if pulled across the bridge several times)- Hashable objects which compare equal must have the same hash value (true, PyUNO objects only compare equal if they have the same wrapped object)

Patch Set 1:hmm... rtlRandomPool definitely needs to use some real entropy instead of the ridiculous __rtl_random_initPool()but i'm not sure if reading from /dev/urandom in __rtl_random_initPool is a good idea - how much do we read from there? where is this rtlRandomPool used? will that drain the kernel's entropy pool (so that other process reading /dev/random block)? would it be better to only initialize the pool from /dev/urandom and then use the old MD5 based generator from there?

Patch Set 1:/dev/urandom is non blocking and is already 'PRNG'There is 2 uses case:either we want just 'random-like enough' numbersand then we could just use c1++ mt19937, primed with /dev/urandomor we need crypto-level random data, and we need /dev/urandom | rand_s straight. trying to re-implement a second layer of CSPRNG would simply, at best do what urandom does, with the additional risk of fuck-upsince rtlRandomPool does not distinguish both case afaikit would be safer to take the second approachNote using /dev/urandom does not make /dev/random block more afaik

Patch Set 1:AFAIK on Linux /dev/urandom will deplete the entropy pool while entropy is available and fall back to PRNG if no entropy left, while /dev/random uses entropy pool only - so you can use urandom to DOS random.e.g. "man urandom" says      The kernel random-number generator  is  designed  to  produce  a  small       amount  of  high-quality  seed material to seed a cryptographic pseudo-       random number generator (CPRNG).  It  is  designed  for  security,  not       speed, and is poorly suited to generating large amounts of random data.       Users should be very economical in the amount  of  seed  material  that       they  read  from  /dev/urandom (and /dev/random); unnecessarily reading       large quantities of data from this device will have a  negative  impact       on other users of the device.*however* it may well be that the problem is not with the implementation of rtlRandomPool but with its *usage*.what you say about using it only for cryptographic purpose and using std::random for everything else makes a lot of sense and we shouldn't generate too much actually cryptographic data.problem is, during OOo times the rtlRandomPool was basically the only thing available that was better than rand() so it was used for a lot of things that have no need for CSPRNG but would be happy with Mersennetwister.but i guess we can merge this and see what happens.hmmm there is a file to get the available entropy:/proc/sys/kernel/random/entropy_availwonder what happens if you add this patch and do a "make check" :)

Patch Set 1:easy to simulate#!/bin/bashc=0cat /proc/sys/kernel/random/entropy_availwhile [ $c -lt 100 ] ; do      head -c 256000 /dev/urandom > /dev/null      cat /proc/sys/kernel/random/entropy_avail      c=$(($c + 1))doneoverall that is the equivalent use for 5 millions tempfile ina row.on my system entry drain quickly but then hover at or about 128 bytes....

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1the only MIME types that are valid without an "x-" prefix are the ones registered with IANA:http://www.iana.org/assignments/media-types/media-types.xhtmlneither "image/eps" nor "image/bmp" are on that list.it doesn't really matter much if some random website lists these, as whoever wrote that could be completely clueless, or worse, a PHP programmer.filter/source/config/fragments/types has some MediaType properties that arguably should be considered as some sort of precedent; in any case we should be consistent across the codebase.Regina is mostly right, except that we historically use "image/x-eps" for EPS; it's arguable whether EPS is the "same" format as PostScript, since it has an additional header and restrictions on the content (for an image, only one page is allowed, and it needs to have a bounding box).for WMF we currently use "image/x-wmf" - not sure which one is the "right" one, none of them is registered with IANA.

Patch Set 1:I know that previous argumentation was so weak for the questions, basing on not official websites.I agree some of them are not on the IANA list, but we must be consistent across the codebase. I've found the mime types used in the filter OOXML (oox/source/export/drawingml.cxx, function:  DrawingML::WriteImage, line 818). This function uses the same mime type than my proposal for ODF, except for ".eps".....        case GFX_LINK_TYPE_NATIVE_GIF:            sMediaType = "image/gif";            pExtension = ".gif";            break;        // #i15508# added BMP type for better exports        // export not yet active, so adding for reference (not checked)        case GFX_LINK_TYPE_NATIVE_BMP:            sMediaType = "image/bmp";            pExtension = ".bmp";            break;        case GFX_LINK_TYPE_NATIVE_JPG:            sMediaType = "image/jpeg";            pExtension = ".jpeg";            break;        case GFX_LINK_TYPE_NATIVE_PNG:            sMediaType = "image/png";            pExtension = ".png";            break;        case GFX_LINK_TYPE_NATIVE_TIF:            sMediaType = "image/tif";            pExtension = ".tif";            break;        case GFX_LINK_TYPE_NATIVE_WMF:            sMediaType = "image/x-wmf";            pExtension = ".wmf";            break;        case GFX_LINK_TYPE_NATIVE_MET:            sMediaType = "image/x-met";            pExtension = ".met";            break;        case GFX_LINK_TYPE_NATIVE_PCT:            sMediaType = "image/x-pict";            pExtension = ".pct";....

Patch Set 1:The first problem is that it returnsRectangle(aRect.x, aRect.y, aRect.width, aRect.height)when Rectangle takes right and botton not width and height for its two last args so this is the wrong Rectangle anyway except for the monitor 0 case where its close enough.The other problem is that these tooltips are positioned by ImplSetHelpWindowPos in vcl/source/app/help.cxx taking into account the Rectangle returned by GetDesktopRectPixel to ensure the tooltip is put inside the DesktopRectangle. That just calls this directly. In this GetDesktopRectPixel the help window hasn't been positioned yet, so it is still on monitor 0, so you always get monitor 0 dimensions not 1. One could query the parent window here, which would also make it work a lot of the time when the tooltip should be displayed on the monitor that most of the parent is on, but that'll fail in the case that you display a tooltip on a minority part of a window that's over two monitors.But anyway I guess the bottom line is that this method is apparently expected to return the usable rectangle of the overall desktop rather than of the individual monitor the window is on

Patch Set 1:I changed 2 bits:-don't give a suggestion when editing (inserting characters) and the character next to the caret is alphanumeric-don't give a suggestion when editing in conditions where a tip would be shown below (with argument tips)The agressiveness is gone.The only 'drawback' is when you start with=ABS(2)start edit, and remove B and then move caret to the right of S. In this situation, no tip is given.If, starting with =ABS(2), you start edit, remove B and S and type S, you do get the hint.I think this behaviour is fine, but of course I'm interested in your expert opinion.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1(1 comment)Apart from the ascii-alnum problem it would also be nice if inside of quoted literal strings no tooltip was displayed, e.g.  =LEN("bet  displays the tip for BETA.DIST, but you can do that as a follow-up commit if you want.Regarding the =ABS(2) behaviour, the old behaviour wasn't correct either because it displayed the below-tip with arguments (though without argument position indicator) while the cursor was on the function name, contrary to all other cases where the parameter-tip is displayed only when the cursor is actually within the function's parentheses.

Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1OK - false alarm.  Sorry - I'm making false connections in my mind about what the old code actually did, and all of the situations it messed up.  The old code DID only handle increasing sequential links - just sometimes it ran across the bigger one first, and then matched with the first higher/lower one that it came across.  It was MY example that actually was numbered in the reverse order and so wouldn't have worked on the old logic.  OK - shouldn't be a regression after-all.  And your test document loaded/looked fine.

Patch Set 6:OK - false alarm.  Sorry - I'm making false connections in my mind about what the old code actually did, and all of the situations it messed up.  The old code DID only handle increasing sequential links - just sometimes it ran across the bigger sequence first, and then reversed the logic to matched with the lower one.  It was MY example doc (albeit vml) that actually was numbered in the reverse order and so wouldn't have worked on the old logic. And your test document loaded/looked fine.  So in my mind I'm combining all that plus some things I saw (can't remember all where) about mso-layout-flow-alt indicating a reverse sequence - where the highest number starts the chain instead of ends the chain, but although this alt-flow is put in the grabbag, it is never used.  In the end the lack of reverse chaining is still a (potentially) missing feature, not a regression.

Patch Set 7:(1 comment)More thoughts:* Do not introduce a function returning std::vector into the stable URE API.  Things like libstdc++'s __cxx11 namespace show that std entities /do/ change in ways that would make it unnecessarily complicated for us to maintain backwards compatibility in the URE API.* That implies that getElementsAsVector should be #ifdef LIBO_INTERNAL_ONLY (and in a PRIVATE_* section in gcc3.map).* That, however, implies that external code needs to continue to call getElements, which now incurs a performance impact (as it always needs to call the equivalent of comphelper::containerToSequence).  Not sure the (assumed?) performance improvements of switching from Sequence to vector justify that (assumed) performance degradation.

Patch Set 3:Thank you for your advice.> Why did you introduce another variable? Is the member bIsPhantom not enough?I just hesitated to capture "this".I hope this revision follows what you expect.

Patch Set 3:> I'd say it is intentional. Child nodes should follow the setting of their parent node.OK.> I think you need to capture bIsPhantom, not this.Let me clarify your suggestion.Because specifying a member variable in lambda-capture is not allowed,I think possible working expressions are:bool b = bIsPhantom;ForEachNonNull(this, [&b](SmNode *pNode){pNode->SetPhantom(b);});or:ForEachNonNull(this, [this](SmNode *pNode){pNode->SetPhantom(bIsPhantom);});or:ForEachNonNull(this, [&](SmNode *pNode){pNode->SetPhantom(bIsPhantom);});or:ForEachNonNull(this, [=](SmNode *pNode){pNode->SetPhantom(bIsPhantom);});or else?But all the last 3 cases are caputuring "this" either by copy or by referencein this case, in my understanding of C++11.

Patch Set 3:> Because specifying a member variable in lambda-capture is not allowed, I think possible working expressions are:> bool b = bIsPhantom; ForEachNonNull(this, [&b](SmNode *pNode){pNode->SetPhantom(b);});All right, I missed that limitation. So I think we should use this variant to be on the safe side. Just a nitpick: it is pointless to capture a bool (or any other integral type) by a reference.

Patch Set 4:The limitation confused me too.I searched for avoiding capturing this to refer a member variable in lambda, but only found C++14 introduces more flexibility into lambda-capture.Thanks a lot for paying your attention to this topic.

Patch Set 2:thanks for working on this; it's looking fine;the only issue is that the commit does add 2 new en-US stringsthe feature as currently implemented should not be in the 4.4 release,inserting fields that cannot be stored is utterly pointless- but adding new strings is not allowed now, not surewhat to do?  can the new strings be avoided for 4.4?also when i try it i get this in the file:<loext:page-name><slide-name></loext:page-name>i think the field text should be the same as in the document display, i.e. the character content should be "Slide 1"

Patch Set 2:> thanks for working on this; it's looking fine; > the only issue is that the commit does add 2 new en-US strings It does, I'm well aware of that, also of the fact that the strings aren't going to be translated. However, they're only used as placeholders for export (and in master view, but come on, how many users will see them there?)   > the feature as currently implemented should not be in the 4.4 > release, > inserting fields that cannot be stored is utterly pointlessIt is. Some LibO hackers with commit rights sometimes go around and merge patches to the code they have almost no clue about. And then other LibO hackers advertise such half-baked features in release notes. > - but adding new strings is not allowed now, not sure > what to do?  can the new strings be avoided for 4.4? Either use English strings directly in C++ code (but that doesn't change the user experience, there will English strings either way), or see below: > also when i try it i get this in the file: >  > <loext:page-name><slide-name></loext:page-name> >  > i think the field text should be the same as in the document > display, i.e. the character content should be "Slide 1"<slide-name> is a placeholder and it'll be substituted by real slide name after import, during rendering. I've looked at what other fields do and some (e.g. page number SvxPageField) don't save the real content of the field either, but use a placeholder. So I did the same.For this particular 4.4 backport, we could maybe save the slide name as character content. That would nicely bypass the problem of new (and untranslated) English strings

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1Hmm, I think unfortunately this patch is not correct. The bug is about "if there is no \par at the end of the doc, then no newline should be inserted when the paste is finished". But that means if there *is* a \par at the end of the file, then we still need a newline. The bug claims that this is a regression, as it was OK in 3.3; and that's what 3.3 did.I'll check the writerfilter part, I can easily imagine that your changes are mostly OK, it's just that you mirrored the ODT import code, which always adds an empty paragraph at the end of the import result in case of pasting, and writerfilter has to do the same if we want the correct end result.
Patch Set 3:Right, hold on. :-) I have some writerfilter changes that will make the uiwriter hunk unnecessary, then the rest of the change looks OK.

Patch Set 3:> The bug is > about "if there is no \par at the end of the doc, then no newline > should be inserted when the paste is finished". But that means if > there *is* a \par at the end of the file, then we still need a > newline.No. You may just check that LO does add \par at the end of any text copied to clipboard (its RTF part). Then, if You paste it to, say,MSWord or Write for Windows, You don't have newline.The same is true for RTF files. You may create a file with the samecontents that You used in unit test, and see that LO/OOo/AOO, and Write/MSWord doesn't add newline in the end. But if You add another\par (with just one space or CRLF) before last one, You'll havethat newline.While RTF spec does say about \par as special character, it isdeclared "End of paragraph", not "newline", as described in "SpecialCharacters".RTF spec is not quite consistent about it: "Paragraph Test" saysthat "\par" is "New paragraph". But the <textpar> says that \par must be followed by <para>, that includes at least one character."Mathematics" says similar: "A math paragraph may be part of a text paragraph (text ending in a \par and either starting a document or following a \par)." > The bug claims that this is a regression, as it was OK in > 3.3; and that's what 3.3 did.No; it was marked as "Inherited from OOo" in Oct 2013 > I'll check the writerfilter part, I can easily imagine that your > changes are mostly OK, it's just that you mirrored the ODT import > code, which always adds an empty paragraph at the end of the import > result in case of pasting, and writerfilter has to do the same if > we want the correct end result.Well, however you may change the copying to buffer part, you should not treat ending single \par as newline to be consistent with reference implementations; so the old unit test is still incorrect.

Patch Set 3:Hi,If that's OK for you, I will tweak writerfilter to emit different doc model for documents having a final \par or not, then merge your patch to properly remove the second fake node.If you would like to have RTF copy&paste not create a newline when the paste is from LO, I would rather tweak the RTF export to do that: so that what we export is in what e.g. Wordpad does.I think tweaking our import to work around what can be improved on the export side is suboptimal. :-)And yes, sorry about the mess, bug 90260 and 70318 is really similar, but only one is marked as a regression, I looked into fixing the regression one, you did the other -- I wish these linked somehow together before we started fixing them. ;-)Thanks,Miklos

But anything else is highly questionable. Also note that to make this really useful for the majority of users, liblzma would have to be bundled. System liblzma is only useful for Linux distro packages.

Patch Set 4:@KoheiSounds good. But I am not sure how to convert the decompressed SvStream type back to io::XInputStream. I guess the sc code expects io::XInpuStream type when querying MediaDescriptor with MediaDescriptor::PROP_INPUTSTREAM(). Please advise.

Patch Set 4:That is interesting.  I would first look into SfxMedium::GetMedium_Impl() to see if we are indeed loading the input stream twice, or something else is going on...  That method is located in sfx2/source/doc/docfile.cxx at line 2228.

Patch Set 4:That's a surprise to me because I had assumed that SfxMedium would get instantiated from the MediaDescriptor object which contained the input stream, and it would re-use the already allocated input stream from the media descriptor.  Would you mind digging a bit into this to see what's going on there?Thanks for doing the investigation.  So far you've been doing great.

Patch Set 4:@Kohei : After textdetect filter call, in the call to SfxMedium::GetMedium_Impl()both pImp->xStream and pImp->xInputStream are populated. At line number 2340, in this method, pImp->m_pInstream is populated from pImp->xStream rather than pImp->xInputStream due to the order of if-else statements. I think that pImp->xStream is uncompressed as I did not set MediaDescriptor::PROP_STREAM property in media descriptor in the detect code.The csv import dialog uses the xInputStream directly where as the ScDocShell::ConvertFrom() uses SvStream from SfxMedium::GetInStream()I tried to reverse the order of if-else statement in SfxMedium::GetMedium_Impl() (starting at line number 2340). But soon realized that it is not correct as1) it breaks some unit tests (import of pdf files failed)2) Though the spreadsheet now shows uncompressed data, the csv import dialog shows empty data !. I thought it was due to file stream position set to the end, but seeking the pImp->xInputStream to the beginning did not solve that.So I reverted this change and instead tried assigning to both MediaDescriptor::PROP_STREAM and MediaDescriptor::PROP_INPUTSTREAM properties in the textdetect filter code as follows :uno::Reference<io::XStream> xStreamDecompressed(new utl::OStreamWrapper(*pDecompressedStream));                                                                                                    aMediaDesc[MediaDescriptor::PROP_STREAM()] <<= xStreamDecompressed;                                                                                                                                aMediaDesc[MediaDescriptor::PROP_INPUTSTREAM()] <<= xStreamDecompressed->getInputStream();This change seems to work, no unit test failed, and uncompressed data in both spreadsheet and csv import dialog. I will push this patch to gerrit shortly.

Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1The import part looks good, and functions very well.  Great job on doing your analysis and coming up with a very well thought-out solution.Now, the only remaining issue is the saving.  Right now, when you open a csv.gz file, edits it, and hits Ctrl-S, it saves it back to the file uncompressed, while the extension is intact.  This is not ideal.I can think of 2 ways to resolve this.  The first way is to support saving it back gz compressed, by somehow storing the information that this file has been uncompressed and using that information and trigger gz compression on saving.  In this scenario, you need to be careful not to compress on save when the user decides to save the file with a different name.  There would be other corner cases you'd have to handle when going this route. Personally I don't like this solution.The 2nd way is to load the file read only when the file is automatically uncompressed during file detection.  This way, when the user wants to edit it and re-save it, she won't be able to overwrite the original file.  I personally like this solution.Here is the gotcha, though.  Forcing a read-only load is as easy as setting the read only flag to true with the media descriptor, which will prompt you that the document has been opened read only, and to edit it, the user will need to click "Edit document" to create a new document instance.  When you do that, Calc will still load the compressed stream into the 2nd document instance, not the uncompressed version.  This needs to be addressed.I hope this will not be too much trouble to solve.  Good luck!

Patch Set 8:@Kohei :1) While pursuing your second method, I found that the impl_detectTypeAndFilter() [1] is not getting called while clicking "Edit Document" button on the read-only document, hence the automatic decompression is skipped and it fills the spreadsheet with compressed raw data.[1] http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/framework/source/loadenv/loadenv.cxx#365Should I try to make it call impl_detectTypeAndFilter() by setting some flag in mediadescriptor during the readonly load phase in textdetect filter detect code ?But I feel that it is very inefficient to retry all filter detect code again.Unfortunately I could not find the place where X[Input]*Stream objects are recreatedduring the reload.2) Another thing I tried is instead of setting READONLY flag in text filter detect function, I set PROP_ASTEMPLATE in media descriptor to true, and then it loads a new untitled document with the uncompressed content. The issue here is that the document title is "Untitled 1" though the sheet name is intact.3) I also tried this : Without setting READONLY flag, I modified the PROP_URL property of media descriptor in text filter detect function within gzip detection block as : OUString aURL = aMediaDesc.getUnpackedValueOrDefault(MediaDescriptor::PROP_URL(), OUString() );                                                                                                    sal_Int32 nIdx = aURL.lastIndexOf(".gz");                                                                                                                                                          if (nIdx != -1)                                                                                                                                                                                      aMediaDesc[MediaDescriptor::PROP_URL()] <<= aURL.replaceFirst(".gz", "", &nIdx);Now Calc loads up the uncompressed data and when I modify the document and hit save, it saves to *.csv file rather than to *.csv.gz

Patch Set 8:Great analysis!  I personally think that (assuming that it works) your approach 3) is the best approach under the circumstance.  Could you make the change for that and update your patch?  I'd like to give that a spin.One very minor thing I would change is to switch from replaceFirst() to copy() to get a substring of the original URL in order to remove the .gz extension.  Using replaceFirst is fine, but I personally find using the copy() method more "natural" for that sort of use given that you already have the position of the ".gz" string.  You can use nIdx as the "length" of the new substring when using copy().Thanks a lot!

Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1Thanks. It works quite well. Though I still think that loading it read-only and somehow getting the issue with clicking the 'Edit Document' resolved would be the best approach, getting that to work would probably involve re-using the already loaded input stream rather than loading the content from the file again, which may involve more work than we are willing to invest at the moment.I've found another minor issue though.  When the csv.gz file is set read only i.e. set chmod 0444 on the file, it still loads the compressed stream.  I wonder this is the issue similar to the earlier one we encountered?

Patch Set 10:Yup, it works well. Thanks a lot for your patience!One minor issue, which I think we can ignore for now, is that when opening an read-only csv.gz file, it opens as non-read-only document.  I think ideally we should be loading such file as read-only just to be consistent with how it works with all the other format types, but we can just declare that as a known issue and handle it in the future (if we decide to).I'll push this change shortly.

Better discuss this now, don't you agree?

Patch Set 2:Please note: First, bug 90447 has not been marked as "NEW" yet - only partially verified by a third party.Second, the ::End() function really should be fully re-written, but that is way beyond my current skills, and also would be a "design from scratch" effort.  The big problem is that it changes the current cursor position and so "flashes around a lot" especially when multiple tabs are involved.  Instead the function should quietly compute the cell.Third, I bundled two related items into one bug report (my bad).  This fixes the ::end function.  The ::find function does work quietly, but adds a ->Select() at the end of the function.  The select could (should?) easily be commented out, but I assume that will break some people's code or something else.  Is it worth breaking bad vb coding to make the program act more like Excel in this case?  I'd like whoever reviews this code to comment on that.

Patch Set 3:the A?=B syntax is a way in Makefileto doif A has no value then A=Belse keep A's valuethat way one can export A= before the invocation of makeand the user value is honored.seehttps://www.gnu.org/software/make/manual/html_node/Setting.html#index-_003f_003d-1The proper way is to run the pch script from Makefile, in which case A would be set naturally with the appropriate value.Note our makefile support the target 'cmd' for that very purpose:make cmd cmd="./bin/update_pch.sh [..]"which avoid the evil use of get_config_variables

Patch Set 2:Thanks Miklos. Done as suggested.Two notes: Although I don't think the parallelism of the build is really related to this, I agree that this approach is cleaner and is a good starting point. Later we can add command line argument to override the parallelism to override the build parallelism.Second, for me at least, the PARALLELISM entry in the config_host.mk looks weird. There is an extra question-mark after the name (a non-printable character?) and the next entry has an extra space. Not sure what's going on. In any event, I added a fallback to '0' so xargs would decide the number level of parallelism if we fail to get a sane result from config_host.mk.export PARALLELISM?=20 export GNUCOPY=C:/Bin/cygwin64/bin/cp

Patch Set 6: -Code-ReviewJust FYI, the newest code change *looks* fine to me, but I still would like to test the change run-time.  Also, I'd like to make sure the new xml name for this attribute is consistent with the rest of the terminology that we use in the ODF.  We do use specific names for various parts of pivot tables, so I'd like for the new name to adhere to that convention.Last thing, we do need a unit test case for this new behavior to ensure that we won't accidentally break this in our future changes to the pivot table code.

Patch Set 6:I checked the run-time behavior and it works very well.  And I checked the ODF attribute name, and I *think* that, although there are several other names we could re-use for this purpose, repeat-item-labels is probably reasonable.Now, 2 things remain.  One is that we need a new unit test to cover this new feature.  Hopefully you can pick one of the existing test cases in ucalc_pivottable.cxx as a model and add a new test case.  Another one is that, because we are adding a new attribute that's not yet in the ODF standard, we need to use a different namespace other than 'table:', to make sure that when we export the document it will be a valid ODF.  I *think* you can use either XML_NP_CALC_EXT or XML_NP_LO_EXT for this.  Eike, do you have any advice on which namespace to use?That's all I have to say on this.  Great work!

Patch Set 3:>Kohei, I will rebase. Should I take out the "Repeat all item labels" checkbox in pivot table creation dialog ?IMO Yes, at least for now.  Our pivot UI is pretty limited, and I don't think we can accommodate that option without some UI redesign.  Also, having a toggle-all option would also mean a bit more work to synchronize it with the individual field settings.But if you feel strongly about having that option there, then I won't be dead set against it.

Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1This patch still has issues.1) The new option shouldn't be added to the popup window since it's not an action but it's an attribute. The popup window is the wrong place to house this option.  It should go to the Field options dialog which can be reached from the layout dialog by double-clicking on the field name (which is kinda hidden, I know).  Once that dialog is open, you still need to click on the Options button to get to the actual dialog where you need to add this option.2) This should be a field (or dimension as it's called in the code) option. As such, it should be stored in ScDPSaveDimension as a new boolean member, not in ScDPSaveData, which should only store table-wide options.3) ODF export code should also reflect that, and store the new setting as a dimension attribute.  Right now you are saving it as a table attribute, which is wrong.  I didn't check your change in the import code, but I'd guess it has a similar issue.I did check Excel once again. Excel doesn't offer this as a table wide option. Only a field setting option.  What you saw is probably the print option where the user can choose to repeat field names when printing. But that's an entirely different setting.

Patch Set 1:This change has one side effect when searching in selections, I'm not yet sure whether that is a positive or negative change, but I lean towards negative ;-)The anchors ^ and $ now anchor at the selection boundary because the only text the regex matcher gets passed is the selected text. This in two paragraphs aaa bbb aaa bbb aaa bbb aaa bbbwhen the selection spans from the second aaa to the third bbb, for ^aaa finds the second aaa, where previously it found the third aaa at the real paragraph start.This may not be expected by the user, because the behavior of ^ is described as "Match at the beginning of a line" (or paragraph in our case), which the previous implementation did.On the other hand one may argue that the selection is the only text considered and thus logically starts a line.I'm undecided.

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1The patch looks completely reasonable from the POV of the current state of the code. However, code archaeology suggests that merge commit 67d2af6fac2d9bad52a6b1f6e0cbd1229eb88a42 erroneously removed the call to "ImplUpdate" in MoveItem, since that line is present in BOTH parents of that merge. The "if ( nNewPos < nPos )" seems to be done for the sake of the ImplUpdate, to set the argument it will be called with. It looks reasonable, since the call is made with the default value of bDirect==false, then ImplUpdate updates *all* columns after its first argument (its argument inclusive). So it is essentially called with ::std::min(nPos, nNewPos).So it seems to me that we should rather fix the error in bd24a310be1459510b760b812838cb87923853c5 of using "nPos" instead of "nNewPos" in the second call of ::std::advance (the one before insert), but leave the "if ( nNewPos < nPos )" and reinsert the "ImplUpdate(nPos, ...)".Kendy, I know it is far away, but would you agree with my analysis of your merge commit?Julien, could you try out my suggestion above and test its effects, if the behaviour is good, the bug is still fixed, no other obvious bug is introduced, etc? Thanks in advance.

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1The basic idea is a good one here. Clearly the ScHorizontalAttrIter is used in a ton of places across the code-base, particularly in filters, and making it ~instant for all the common big-data cases is very helpful.The basic approach looks good too - the nMinNextEnd looks sensible to detect large runs of identical formatting.What doesn't convince me that much is the initialization and management of the pPrevColEnd array. It looks like that is not initialized initially [sic] ;-) and then there is an assumption that:                if ( bRepeatedRow )                    nCol = pPrevColEnd[nCol];-but- (AFAICS) there is no guarentee that pPrevColEnd[nCol] is setup correctly - it rather depends on the value of nCol that was used last time - which (in turn) depends on the shape of the data.So - I would suggest adopting a different approach for generating and managing that - along with some nicer data structure for this case. IIWY I'd detect the case where there is a large run of identical styles - and in that case do more work to analyze them into a complete structure - that can be re-used for several subsequent rows; eg. if there are > 2x rows with the same thing - then allocate & fill that structure in (eg.).Is that do-able ? hopefully it'll make the code flow more pleasant too =)I'd also like to see a unit test created for the case that looks like it should fail in the above =) where we have constant patterns down a run - but a random layout of cell content.Thanks !

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-2The missing initial initialization was intended, but it seems, I made a mistake in the usage of the indices of pPrevColEnd. I will fix it, also add/extend the related unit test. Many thanks for the review!

Either way - if we could kill the cut/paste on master I'd be rather happy.

Patch Set 1:Caolan: thought you might be interested in this patch since it's vcl.I think it should be ok since http://www.cplusplus.com/reference/vector/vector/erase/ indicates that even in C++98 erase method of vector returns an iterator.However, I wonder if this patch might have wrong side effects since it concerns vcl and not relationships part only.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1Calling maItemList.erase(it) indeed invalidates it, we are not authorised to use it any more.However, assigning to it the return value of erase does not match my understanding of the code block that follows the for loop, that is issue a SAL_WARN if the button id to be deleted was not found. Now this SAL_WARN would incorrectly be triggered when the last button (the one that is last in maItemList) is successfully deleted.At first I thought about: * introducing a boolean flag "found" for this information,   which is a bit awkward, especially for an information that   is used only in debug mode:   bool found(false);   for(...)   {       if(...)       {           found=true;           ....       }   }   if(!found)       SAL_WARN(...) * taking more control of the looping than in a "usual" for loop pattern:   for (it = maItemList.begin(); ; ++it)   {       if (it == maItemList.end())       {           SAL_WARN( "vcl.window", "ButtonDialog::RemoveButton(): ButtonId invalid" );           break;       }       else if (it->mnId == nId)       {           ...       }   }but then I got the idea of just replacing the "break" by a "return" since this is the end of the function anyway.

Patch Set 1:Also, since you are touching this code anyway, you could (but that is optional / up to you) make the SAL_WARN message better. For example:  SAL_WARN( "vcl.window", "ButtonDialog::RemoveButton(): invalid ButtonId: " << nId);  or, if ButtonDialog had a "getId" or "getName" or some such  (which I haven't immediately found):  SAL_WARN( "vcl.window", "ButtonDialog::RemoveButton(): invalid ButtonId: " << nId << " in ButtonDialog '" << getName() << "'" );If you do it, do it in a separate commit.If you want to do that kind of "drive-by" improvements is up to you.
Patch Set 1:Also, the way to reference a TDF Bugzilla bug is "tdf#" not "tdo#".

Patch Set 1:> For the loop, if we avoid the break and use return,> the "if" can be removed and we keep the trace.Ah yes, then the only way to get to the end of the loopis to having walked through the whole maItemList withoutfinding a match, so (it == maItemList.end()) is alwaystrue.Good find.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2So - it seems to me that with all our (well Caolan's really ;-) hard work on coverity fixing, my hope is that this prop handler should be able to cope with arbitrary broken / truncated / partially written / fuzzed & mangled data streams. Certainly, far better than we did in the past; and where they fail that is a handler bug we can fix separately.So - I'm strongly in favour of a more friendly locking mode; the alternative: of read-only opened files, when someone else is just browsing that directory; or worse - of making everyone's directory browsing slow by needlessly locking things remotely while they browse is pretty horrible =)It seems to fix a key MIMO issue seen in the wild, and is plausible, so I'm in favour =)

Patch Set 1:That's interesting. I had the impression that LO doesn't read SmartArt, since if I remove the contents of drawing1.xml in the original document, I get a blank page, and if I understand it correctly drawing1.xml is used only for DrawingML. If LO can import SmartArt and produce an editable diagram, why doesn't it do that by default? Unfortunately I don't have a good test document yet. For the bug page, I hacked up a version of drawing1.xml but it contains no SmartArt data.

Patch Set 1:SmartArt has some declarative data and also some pre-rendered drawingML result (since MSO 2010). LO only uses the drawingML result. That's still editable (depending on the setting), but it doesn't mean that you'll get the same editing experience than in MSO, what understands the declarative data as well. E.g. in LO, if the SmartArt has 5 points in a circle, then you can move one of the points, but in MSO, you can add a 6th point to the circle and it'll re-distribute them equally on the circle. In LO, the default is lock-down, so that the user is not encouraged to edit the SmartArt. If it's modified, we can preserve the declarative metadata and write it back to the OOXML file on export.

Patch Set 4:the vector is guaranteed to be sorted only to clients of SwpHints; the SwpHints class itself is responsible for guaranteeing that, and inside a SwpHints method the vector may be temporarily not in the proper sort order.of course no STL algorithms that depend on the ordering must be run in such a situation; do you have a concrete example that triggers an assert?

Patch Set 4:> of course no STL algorithms that depend on the ordering must be run in such a situation; do you have a concrete example that triggers an assert?Yes. As I said, I have reproduced it. It's not theoretical. Unfortunately, the doc that triggers it is impossible to share (it's private).The assertion happens as a result of calling Delete (line 2853) after entering the loop under "// change all attributes with key i". That loop (line 2862-2871) modifies the items of the sorted_vector. If that large loop in that function has more entries to merge, it hits Delete on line 2853 a second time, which calls GetStartOf, which searches for the SwTxtAttr* via lower_bound in the sorted_vector (which might fail because the items are no longer sorted, but asserts in dbgutil builds).The only downside to my fix is the potential performance hit, but I don't see any obvious fixes that prevents the issue, so correctness first.

Patch Set 7:> 5. i'm actually wondering what the "check if deletion actually took place before destroying attribute" nonsense is: perhaps it was a work-around for this bug? clearly Delete() can't fail?My thoughts exactly. Delete() may fail due to unsorted vector, and freeing the item that is still accessible in the vector will certainly not be a good idea.I'd add a comment to this effect for posterity, but not enough confidence to remove the check. Alternatively, Delete could return a bool status to signal deletion and at least make the code cleaner.

Patch Set 6: Verified+1 Code-Review+2ok, findings:1. the .DOC files fail on a different assertion, in RstAttrs2. it is possible to trigger the assertion, although   apparently not with libstdc++ _GLIBCXX_DEBUG,   but MSVC asserts3. there is no other modification of text attributes that   impacts sort order after this so we don't need to do   another sort on function exit4. the function should get a MATCH state at most 2 times   while inserting a hint, once "before" and once "after"   inserted hint, so re-sorting twice shouldn't be too   expensive5. i'm actually wondering what the "check if deletion actually took place before destroying attribute" nonsense is: perhaps it was a work-around for this bug? clearly Delete() can't fail?steps to reproduce:1. insert paragraph with some text2. set char style "Strong Emphasis" on 2 disjoint ranges in the paragraph3. insert hyperlink, starting from start of first "Strong Emphasis" range and ending after end of first S.E. range and before the second one4. select from end of first S.E. range to start of second one, set "Strong Emphasis"

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1(3 comments)i'm a bit confused here....do we need to export only the top level element table:table in a different namespace?it looks like you want to export table-row / table-column / cell in different namespace too and forgot covered-cell.but why change the namespace of these 3-4 elements and not the paragraphs contained in the cells etc. etc.?changing the namespace of everything inside the table is going to be quite painful, isn't it enough to only change the top-level table element?

Patch Set 1:Hi,> do we need to export only the top level element table:table in a different namespace?Just table:table is not enough, as you see in the patch, all the table-related elements have to be in the extension namespace, odfvalidator says so at least.> it looks like you want to export table-row / table-column / cell in different namespace too and forgot covered-cell.Indeed, I'll fix covered-cell.> but why change the namespace of these 3-4 elements and not the paragraphs contained in the cells etc. etc.?The idea is that table-in-shape is a new feature, but text-in-shape is not, so if a reader is not capable of table-in-shape, it can still import the text of the table into the shape. (Slightly related example: old RTF import did the same for nested tables.)> changing the namespace of everything inside the table is going to be quite painful, isn't it enough to only change the top-level table element?I needed the minimal changes to make odfvalidator happy. That means changing the prefix of table:*, but not the content of the tables, which would be indeed painful.I'll fix the rest on master and upload a new revision.

Patch Set 1: Verified+1 Code-Review+2This is a notoriously fragile area, but I cannot think of a real scenario that could cause problems (the only one I can imagine is akin to a willful sabotage, so I hope we do not do it .-) But I will be watching for regressions in Draw/Impress...

Patch Set 2:Thanks for the review. I confess this was a bit of a "provocation" on my part. I considered "working around" the problem in the form wizard code, but then I decided that especially since the wizard uses only our public API (which any user can use in their scripts), what it does *should* work. If it doesn't, we present our users with a lousy API / experience.Specifically the sequence is something like:// SETUPXControlShape aDateShape = factory.createInstance("com.sun.star.drawing.ControlShape");XControlModel aDateControlModel = factory.createInstance("com.sun.star.form.component.DateField");aDateShape.setControl(aDateControlModel);XControlShape aTimeShape = factory.createInstance("com.sun.star.drawing.ControlShape");XControlModel aTimeControlModel = factory.createInstance("com.sun.star.form.component.TimeField");aTimeShape.setControl(aTimeControlModel);xShapes = factory.createInstance("com.sun.star.drawing.ShapeCollection");xShapes.add(aDateShape);xShapes.add(aTimeShape);someXShapeGrouper.group(xShapes);// NOW, WHAT I EXPECT TO WORKaDateShape.getControl(); // SHOULD NOT RETURN NULL! SHOULD RETURN aDateModel!aTimeShape.getControl(); // SHOULD NOT RETURN NULL! SHOULD RETURN aTimeModel!I guess what I'm trying to say, is that even if this "aggressive" patch creates regressions in Draw/Impress, we should find some way for the above scenario to work, for the sake of the saneness of our public API.

Patch Set 2:Regarding backports, you have to propose it, then it either gets rejected or merged during review. So no need to ask, just propose it. :-)

Patch Set 2:My preference is to have the testcase and the fix in a single commit (after all, you should commit when you're done with something, and you're done when you finished the fix and the testcase), but in this case they were separate commits, so no need to bother with backporting the testcase as well.Also, please avoid the cherry-pick button if possible, that would let you propose a change without actually testing it first. We assume that you only propose changes which you already tested locally. If we figure out that you don't do that, you gain bad reputation. :-)

Patch Set 1:Sorry this took so long.  (I had had a quick look at the patch, which looks more complicated on first sight than it actually is, due to the necessary changes to indentation, but then lost sight of it again.)getAllJREInfos (jvmfwk/plugins/sunmajor/pluginlib/util.cxx, called indirectly from jfw_findAndSelectJRE via jfw_plugin_getAllJavaInfos) already searches JAVA_HOME and PATH for JREs, they just don't get priority treatment in the current jfw_findAndSelectJRE.  It would probably be better to not have that search code also in jfw_findAndSelectJRE, but rather transport the information about how a JRE has been found from getAllJREInfos to jfw_findAndSelectJRE, so that the latter can pick the "best" based on that and not only on version numbers.(Also, the plugin architecture in jvmfwk is probably over-architectured, and I would like to get rid of it, not the least to drop all the #ifdef DISABLE_DYNLOADINGs, and to ease maintenance of that code.)

Patch Set 1:Thank you very much for your feedback and your hints!I have thought about how to best implement this and would appreciate your feedback on my ideas.The possibilities I am currently thinking about are as follows:1) Add two new functions (e.g. "jfw_plugin_getJavaInfoFromJavaHome", "jfw_plugin_getJavaInfosFromPath") to vendorplugin.hxx and sunjavaplugin.cxx to obtain information about Java installations referred to by JAVA_HOME and PATH environment variables (similar to jfw_plugin_getAllJavaInfos). The two functions use the functions in util.cxx to get the information.jfw_findAndSelectJRE uses the two new functions to check for such Java installations and uses them if there are any, otherwise uses the algorithm that is currently used.This would avoid duplicate code in jfw_findAndSelectJRE and getAllJREInfos.2) Add additional (out) parameters to getAllJREInfos and jfw_plugin_getAllJavaInfos that hold the JavaInfos that have been found using JAVA_HOME or PATH.possible new signature:javaPluginError jfw_plugin_getAllJavaInfos(    rtl_uString *sVendor,    rtl_uString *sMinVersion,    rtl_uString *sMaxVersion,    rtl_uString * * arExcludeList,    sal_Int32  nSizeExcludeList,    JavaInfo*** parJavaInfo,    sal_Int32 *nSizeJavaInfo,    JavaInfo** parJavaInfoFromJavaHome,    JavaInfo*** parJavaInfosFromPath,    sal_Int32 *nSizeJavaInfosFromPath);If JAVA_HOME points to a suitable Java installation, parJavaInfoFromJavaHome points to it.If suitable Java installations are on the PATH, parJavaInfosFromPath holds the respective JavaInfos and nSizeJavaInfosFromPath is the number of JavaInfos found on the PATH.The additional parameters would be unused for "normal" calls to the method and only be used in jfw_findAndSelectJRE (which is possibly no good design?).3) Add an additional field to the _JavaInfo struct that tells how the Java installation has been found. I currently don't have a reasonable idea how to actually implement that field - which should be able to tell e.g. that the Java installation is referred to by JAVA_HOME, and/or is the 1st Java on the PATH, the 2nd Java on the PATH,..., or has been found in a different way.As far as I understand, the struct is defined in include/jvmfwk/framework.h and the new field would thus also be visible from outside the "jvmfwk" module.I personally consider solution 1) to be the best of those three, but would appreciate your feedback. Of course, a totally different solution is welcome, too.

Patch Set 3:sorry forgot to answer your question...you can simply apply a character style like "emphpasis" to some text and then apply an automatic style by clicking e.g. on the "bold" icon, since "emphasis" sets italic you should then see bold+italic text.(it's evey possible to have multiple character styles on the same text if you ctrl+click (or was it shift+click? i forgot) a second style in the navigator)the new size pool-items you insert will always be set as an automatic style (AUTOFMT) overriding any size that is already set at the same postion; so if there are multiple hints the last one for which you increment and set a new size will override all previous ones.iirc it should work fine with char-fmt + auto-fmt because the auto-fmt should be sorted "later" so it will override; but for the hyperlinks there is no fixed ordering wrt the other ones so it's possible to set the increased font size of the hyperlink when it should be the size of the existing autofmt.

Patch Set 1: Verified+1 Code-Review+2(1 comment)this is much better.one subtle problem remains: if there is both an auto-format and char-format (or both an auto-format and hyperlink) on the same text range you will return several pams with items covering that range, and set multiple new font sizes - the last one will win.for auto-format and char-format the thints.cxx code guarantees that they don't overlap i.e. if they cover the same range they must have same start and end position; for hyperlinks there is no such guarantee, hyperlinks may overlap formatting hints.

I tried to pinpoint this in the model for RVNGInputStream, but either I am doing something wrong, or coverity is not smart enough to recognize it. Maybe I should just disable marking of the read data as tainted...

Patch Set 3:Hi Mikos, I don't understand how export tests were done. That's why I did it in a more conservative way, putting it in import tests.It is my concern that numbering types are not one to one mapping. A sequence like import, export, import lose information by nature. For example there are many cases fallback into NUMBER_LOWER_ZH. However it seems that the patchset for rtfexport can compile ( did it ever make check? ) , It contradict my guess.

Patch Set 3:When designing the framework, we had two basic ideas:- interesting document models are easier to be loaded from some format, than building them from code- checking an in-memory document model is reasonably easy (usually by using the UNO API), at least easier than asserting a written file (think of manually checking a binary .doc result)That's why for export tests, we do an import->export->import sequence. That ensures that the doc. models can be still stored in a file, allows asserting the result using the UNO API, and still export problems are detected. (I'm just re-stating what's in sw/qa/extras/README, just in case for some reason that file is not clear.) Hopefully this makes it clear how export tests are done. :-)Regarding loosing data during import/export: sure, sometimes that's necessary when e.g. our numbering types and MSO's numbering types do not match. In your case, the provided tests passed just fine when also the exporter got included in the chain, that's why I changed that. As long as it passes, it's safe to change, and it ensures that your export improvements won't break in the future silently. ;-)

Patch Set 1:Mikos Vajna,I can only save my inline comment as draft, hence I reply here directly:1. Regarding test cases: I have test files but I'm not able to write cpp unit test code. I don't know how to submit those test files.2. Regarding numeric tokens: Those numeric tokens exists before my patch ( ex, 5=ARABIC ). You found mixing of numeric tokens and NS_ooxml:LN_something because RTF import filter share dmapper with OOXML import filte and RTF import filter implementation didn't define constants or enumeration for it.

Patch Set 1:Hi,Once you're ready with your inline comments, you can just push the reply + send button (without filling the textarea), and then your comments will be published.About numeric tokens: would it be possible to adjust rtftok to emit the necessary NS_ooxml::LN_something tokens instead? The idea is that RTF is a no longer developed format, while OOXML still introduces new features, so RTF is a subset of OOXML. Based on that, dmapper should in general handle OOXML, and rtftok should just emit those ooxml tokens, not its own ones. So there should be as minimal RTF-specific code in dmapper as possible.About unit tests, see here for documentation: http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/sw/qa/extras/READMEOne RTF, one DOC and one DOCX export test would be the optimal.Thanks! :-)

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1> I noticed that the behavior seemed to be the same with translate and lookat in the AerialView. But I could be wrong.The two branch behaves differently. First branch (mbAerialView) moves the camera to the new position and change view to make the camera look at the center of the model (orbit mode invariant).Second branch only moves the camera to the new position, but does not change the direction of the camera view, which means camera will look at a new point (right behavior in walkthrough mode, but wrong in orbit mode).

Patch Set 2:So UPD has been computed as the somewhat silly  10^(floor(log_10(max(minor, 1)))+1)*major + 10*minorever since 74bd1f57b56918a3ef5f27aa2565397a4c6e85e1 (and before that had been manually tracked as something like RSCVERSION=350 in solenv/inc/minor.mk).  This clearly has drawbacks if ever minor > 9.So, instead of carefully mimicking that silly formula via application of OString::number and OString::toInt* to integer literals, I would suggest turning to a more sane formula instead, like  1000*major + 10*minor(Whether it is better or worse to include micro in that formula I don't know.)

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1On the question of whether it is sufficient to resolve the problem: please test it. Create a query (with an outer join) in design view, and then switch to SQL view. Is the "{ OJ" in lower case? If not, "git grep -w OJ -- connectivity/ dbaccess/" gives this interesting match:dbaccess/source/ui/querydesign/QueryDesignView.cxx:                                            aStr += "{ OJ ";This indiscriminately puts all tokens in lower case; however fdo#84073 is about the "{ }" escapes *only* (which are not in the SQL standard, they are an ODBC / JDBC escape/extension), not the whole SQL standard. I'd rather we changed only the ODBC/JDBC escapes: { oj ... } // outer join { ts .. } // timestamp { d .. } // date { t .. } // time(any other I'm forgetting?)The date/time ones seem to be in (if not in sqlflex.l)connectivity/source/commontools/DateConversion.cxx:                            aRet.appendAscii("{TS '");

Patch Set 1:@Robert Antoni Buj i Gelonch:This patch affects _C_ and not _C++_.For C we specifically only support C90 (and not C99 or later) as e.g. MSVC doesn't support newer than C90 (and gcc appears to default to that too), hence it's useful for devs with clang (which doesn't default to C90) to be able to catch potential build problems (i.e. non C90 compliant code) locally.(And incidentally LO is buildable with C++03, and can't use C++11 only features (for now), as we still need to support some older systems.)

Patch Set 2:I tested it in OS X Yosemite DP2 with -std=gnu11 and it worked well.gnu11 was detected by using the piece of code attached within a previous comment. I also think that it can be useful for other gcc compilers.$ clang --versionApple LLVM version 6.0 (clang-600.0.34.4) (based on LLVM 3.5svn)Target: x86_64-apple-darwin14.0.0Thread model: posix

Patch Set 2:"I tested it in OS X Yosemite DP2 with -std=gnu11 and it worked well."But what benefit would we have from compiling the (little) C code that we have with -std=gnu11?  AFAIK, we do not actively try to make use of any C99/C11 features where available in any of our C code, anyway.On the contrary, what this patch is about is restricting more capable compilers to the C89 subset (enforced upon us effectively by MSVC), so that developers across different platforms can more easily prevent adding new code violating C89 (which would otherwise break only on platforms they did not test their new code on).
Patch Set 2:If you think that the best option is to force the usage of C89 to everybody, the best is to add the AC_PROG_CC_C89 macro at the top.

Patch Set 3: Verified-1When I open a file in Impress 4.2 that has been saved with a password to modify, the document is opened read-only, without a notice about the password protection.Then you can toggle the edit mode and edit the document without entering a password. You can also save it.When you open it again, it still has the read-only state.Can we do something about this?

Patch Set 3:Yes -- backport the code, or at least its relevant part, to 4.2. To be able to read, prompt for and use modify password, Impress/Draw code must read the appropriate data from ODF container - ModifyPasswordInfo bits from settings.xml. And since 4.2 Impress/Draw doesn't have that functionality yet (this is only added with my change to UnoDocumentSettings.cxx), it simply ignores the existence of modify password and allows user to edit the document w/o entering one.Otherwise, password protection created in 4.4 and newer will be null and void when opening such document in 4.3 and older

Patch Set 3:I wouldn't add such message (warning users that the document they're about to save might not be opened with older versions of %PRODUCT) -- unless there's a couple of precedents of doing it already elsewhere in LibO. I don't know about any ... Such messages, imo, add little value and largely only annoy the users.What certainly should be done is documenting this limitation in release notes.

In any case, this proposal offers a great improvement.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1(7 comments)For each UNO exception type E we currently generate three ctors in Java:  public E() { super(); }  public E(String Message) { super(Message); }  public E(String Message, Object Context, T1 m1, ..., Tn mn) {    super(Message);    this.Context = Context;    this.m1 = m1;    ...    this.mn = mn;  }I would suggest to generate an additional three ctors that each take a first argument  Throwable causeand call the corresponding super ctor that passes the cause along.

Patch Set 1:"I would suggest to generate an additional three ctors that each take a first argument Throwable cause"That would cause a minor compile-time incompatibility, in that a call  E(null)would now be ambiguous, but arguably such a call had always bordered on beeing illegal (as it sets the UNO css.uno.Exception string Message member to null, and null is not among the java.lang.String values that are valid UNO string representations), is probably rare in practice, only causes a compile-time and not a run-time problem, and is trivially fixed in the source code.  (But technically, it would make the commit an [API CHANGE] again.)
Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1If you do so, you can accidentally call methods for type conversion, i.e. when the java constructors are not protected for using misplaced parameters.

Patch Set 1:Hi Maxim,1. Well the tooltip needs to be simple and descriptive and the standard single word tooltips like 'Undo' are soon to be replaced by long descriptive tooltips like 'Undo Last Action', so we would ideally want a useful tooltip that we wont have to go back to later on and change. So 'Zoom & Pan Tool' or 'Zoom and Pan Tool' are both good in my book.2. GIMP has the zoom tooltip as 'Zoom Tool: Adjust the zoom level'. The word tool simply identifies that its not a one click action button like 'Zoom In', which is why i believe the old behaviour was so not understood.3. Yes i think that button should be renamed, as i've never seen the word 'shift' used for pan in any app.

Patch Set 1:Actually this is incompatible with the pre 4.1 behavior (that's right - it's broken since 4.1, and no one ever complained until now). For example, for the edit verb a user could use in a macro both -1 (which is correct) and 65535. Of course we can emulate the old behavior by simply casting back SfxUInt16Item::GetValue() to signed, but I wonder whether it's a good idea to carry this ancient bug (as it seems there's no much user code that depends on it).

Patch Set 1:Thanks for the hint. Obviously I need to learn more about git and gerrit, I had a hard time finding out how to back-port a change at all. Do you want me to abandon this change and redo it with git cherry-pick -x? Or just modify the message?One more question, If I do "git cherry-pick -x", should the hash after be the Change-Id or the commit-id. Also I need to have the libreoffice4-3 branch checked-out before I do the git cherry-pick -x, right?Sorry if these are stupid questions, but I've had a hard time finding good info on how to do this.

Patch Set 1:No no, your questions are fully reasonable! You switch to the 4-3 branch and do git cherry-pick -x commit-id there. The commit-id of your commit in the master branch is unique inside the whole git tree. So this works this easy.You don't need to abandon this change. If your new patch has the same "Change-Id" as this one gerrit will notice it as second version of this patchset. So you do git cherry-pick -x and after that change the "Change-Id" to Ibd04cf5329b4d226aac102d214a45e45811982e7 . That should be enough :)

But even if the sidebar is hidden, you can show the formatting pane by selecting "More" from the styles drop-down.Maybe we can merge this even if it's not perfect yet and then discuss further improvements with UX-Advise. I'll continue to work on this.
