Patch Set 1:Ah, but indeed I build with --enable-debug, so not optimising. Presumably the (bogus) warnings are generated only when the compile is optimising? Perhaps even only when using LTO?Not sure if checking $(MSVC_USE_DEBUG_RUNTIME) is the right thing, isn't it so that we use the debug runtime when --enable-dbgutil was used, and that does not correspond 1:1 to not optimising.

Patch Set 1:Those warnings are from tb Win-x86_42, I think it's VS2012. But without --enable-debug. LTO is off for this machine.I think the underlying problem is the definition of SAL_WARN_IF athttp://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/include/sal/log.hxx#304For non-debug "SAL_DETAIL_ENABLE_LOG_WARN" is false then, and "condition" is never reached, so it's unused in this case, maybe that's what MSVC complains about.

Patch Set 1:Sure, sure, but the point is that it is (in my not so humble opinion) wrong if the compiler claims that variables are "unused" if they occur only in the right-hand-side of an && expression where the left-hand-side is a false constant. But yeah, we can't do anything about that, so probably we should apply this patch. Except that instead of MSVC_USE_DEBUG_RUNTIME we should check whether optimisation is used.

Patch Set 3:package com.mycompany.tests;import java.io.UnsupportedEncodingException;import java.nio.ByteBuffer;import java.util.ArrayList;import java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit;import java.util.logging.Level;import java.util.logging.Logger;import org.openjdk.jmh.annotations.Benchmark;import org.openjdk.jmh.annotations.BenchmarkMode;import org.openjdk.jmh.annotations.Mode;import org.openjdk.jmh.annotations.OutputTimeUnit;import org.openjdk.jmh.annotations.Scope;import org.openjdk.jmh.annotations.State;import org.openjdk.jmh.runner.Runner;import org.openjdk.jmh.runner.RunnerException;import org.openjdk.jmh.runner.options.Options;import org.openjdk.jmh.runner.options.OptionsBuilder;/** * * @author rbuj */@State(Scope.Thread)@BenchmarkMode(Mode.AverageTime)@OutputTimeUnit(TimeUnit.NANOSECONDS)public class DecodeUTF8 {    String query;    public DecodeUTF8() {        this.query = "";        for (int i = 0; i < 500; i++) {            this.query += "%5B";        }    }    @Benchmark    @BenchmarkMode(Mode.All)    @OutputTimeUnit(TimeUnit.MICROSECONDS)    public void v1_decodeUTF8_test() {        try {            String ans = v1_decodeUTF8_function(query);        } catch (Exception ex) {            Logger.getLogger(DecodeUTF8.class.getName()).log(Level.SEVERE, null, ex);        }    }    @Benchmark    @BenchmarkMode(Mode.All)    @OutputTimeUnit(TimeUnit.MICROSECONDS)    public void v2_decodeUTF8_test() {        try {            String ans = v2_decodeUTF8_function(query);        } catch (Exception ex) {            Logger.getLogger(DecodeUTF8.class.getName()).log(Level.SEVERE, null, ex);        }    }    @Benchmark    @BenchmarkMode(Mode.All)    @OutputTimeUnit(TimeUnit.MICROSECONDS)    public void v3_decodeUTF8_test() {        try {            String ans = v3_decodeUTF8_function(query);        } catch (Exception ex) {            Logger.getLogger(DecodeUTF8.class.getName()).log(Level.SEVERE, null, ex);        }    }    private static int hexToInt(int ch)            throws Exception {        int c = Character.toLowerCase((char) ch);        boolean isDigit = ('0' <= c && c <= '9');        boolean isValidChar = ('a' <= c && c <= 'f') || isDigit;        if (!isValidChar) {            throw new Exception(                    "Invalid UTF-8 hex byte '" + c + "'.");        }        return isDigit ? ch - '0' : 10 + ((char) c - 'a') & 0xF;    }    private static String v1_decodeUTF8_function(String s)            throws Exception {        ArrayList<Integer> v = new ArrayList<Integer>();        for (int i = 0; i < s.length(); i++) {            int ch = s.charAt(i);            if (ch == '%') {                int hb = hexToInt(s.charAt(++i));                int lb = hexToInt(s.charAt(++i));                ch = (hb << 4) | lb;            }            v.add(new Integer(ch));        }        int size = v.size();        byte[] bytes = new byte[size];        for (int i = 0; i < size; i++) {            Integer anInt = v.get(i);            bytes[i] = (byte) (anInt.intValue() & 0xFF);        }        try {            return new String(bytes, "UTF-8");        } catch (UnsupportedEncodingException e) {            throw new Exception(                    "Couldn't convert parameter string to UTF-8 string:" + e.getMessage());        }    }    private static String v2_decodeUTF8_function(String s)            throws Exception {        try {            if (s.contains("%")) {                ArrayList<Integer> v = new ArrayList<Integer>();                int length = s.length();                for (int i = 0; i < length; i++) {                    int ch = s.charAt(i);                    if (ch == '%') {                        if (i + 3 > length) {                            throw new Exception(                                    "Incomplete trailing escape (%) pattern");                        }                        try {                            ch = Integer.parseInt(s.substring(i + 1, i + 3), 16);                        } catch (NumberFormatException e) {                            throw new Exception(e.toString());                        }                        if (ch < 0) {                            throw new Exception(                                    "Illegal hex characters in escape (%) pattern - negative value");                        }                        i += 2;                    }                    v.add(new Integer(ch));                }                int size = v.size();                byte[] bytes = new byte[size];                for (int i = 0; i < size; i++) {                    Integer anInt = v.get(i);                    bytes[i] = (byte) (anInt.intValue() & 0xFF);                }                return new String(bytes, "UTF-8");            } else {                return new String(s.getBytes(), "UTF-8");            }        } catch (UnsupportedEncodingException e) {            throw new Exception(                    "Couldn't convert parameter string to UTF-8 string:" + e.getMessage());        }    }    private static String v3_decodeUTF8_function(String s)            throws Exception {        try {            if (s.contains("%")) {                int length = s.length();                ByteBuffer bb = ByteBuffer.allocate(length);                for (int i = 0; i < length; i++) {                    int ch = s.charAt(i);                    if (ch == '%') {                        if (i + 3 > length) {                            throw new Exception(                                    "Incomplete trailing escape (%) pattern");                        }                        try {                            ch = Integer.parseInt(s.substring(i + 1, i + 3), 16);                        } catch (NumberFormatException e) {                            throw new Exception(e.toString());                        }                        if (ch < 0) {                            throw new Exception(                                    "Illegal hex characters in escape (%) pattern - negative value");                        }                        i += 2;                    }                    bb.put((byte) (ch & 0xFF));                }                byte[] bytes = new byte[bb.position()];                System.arraycopy(bb.array(), 0, bytes, 0, bytes.length);                return new String(bytes, "UTF-8");            } else {                return new String(s.getBytes(), "UTF-8");            }        } catch (UnsupportedEncodingException e) {            throw new Exception(                    "Couldn't convert parameter string to UTF-8 string:" + e.getMessage());        }    }    public static void main(String[] args) throws RunnerException {        Options opt = new OptionsBuilder()                .include(".*" + DecodeUTF8.class.getSimpleName() + ".*")                .warmupIterations(5)                .measurementIterations(5)                .forks(1)                .build();        new Runner(opt).run();    }}

Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Verified+1Pushing with a remark: This resolves the crash but results in unexpected cell references in the formulas of column D. Though logical in itself (keeping the referenced cells that were sorted away) it breaks the logic of the column in that the cell of the previous row is referenced in each formula. Excel keeps that shared formula intact.

Patch Set 2:I disagree there completely.  Excel's behavior here is not the model to follow, which is actually very rare.  That behavior is highly illogical and I don't see why you would call that logical.

Patch Set 2:So you are proposing to intentionally forget to update references only in one specific use case?  I still disagree completely, to me that's just illogical secound-guessing only to satisfy a single use case at the expense of everything else.

Patch Set 1:> this is only used in practice to remove ".." components, right?Yes, this is only for to remove the inner ".." parts of the absolute paths. From the Linux and Windows tests, the external linguistic libraries get absolute paths for the installed extensions, too, eg. "/home/laci/m/libreoffice-4-2/instdir/program/../program/../user/uno_packages/cache/uno_packages/luqm9pc0.tmp_/dict-de.oxt/de_DE_frami.aff".

Patch Set 7:i wonder what is the goal here?it is utterly pointless to build the LO bundled python as "universal" in any way, since the rest of the LO code supports only a single architecture anyway, so there are only downsides, i.e. it is a waste of space.IIRC the only reason why the --enable-universalsdk parameter is used is that it is the _only_ way to get python to build against the SDK, and not random stuff in /usr/include etc; it is somehow tangled up with building universal binaries in python's build system but that is (imho) a deficiency of python's build system.did you see the silly changes to fix that up in external/python3/python-3.3.0-darwin.patch.1?

Patch Set 12:ok so 2 things.1/ this patch start to suffer from feature creep.you know have 3 independents changes crammed into it.Let's keep these independent things in independents patches.(the JDK thing is orthogonal to the Python thing, which is orthogonal to the SDK thing)2/ I'm a bit confused by the rapid fire upload of new version.The idea of gerrit is to upload a version when you think it is ready for review... but here you got 7 version in rapid sequence without any review interaction.. and same after version 7...  Is the patch ready for review ? or should I wait for another hour for version n+1 ?iow:In a single patch: do one thing. Upload to gerrit when you think it is ready for review, ie ready, you think, to be merged.Review takes time too.. and every time you upload a new version it essentially invalidate the review done on the previous versionI'm encouraged by your patch.. there are good stuff in there.I'm just trying to adjust the process to make processing these patches easier for all involved :-)

Patch Set 1:Miklos: In ww8atr.cxx i have made sure to get the value using GetAuthorField().I have a doubt for authfld.cxxI will undo my changes as you suggested but in SwAuthorityField::ConditionalExpand, GetAuthorField() is called for AUTH_FIELD_IDENTIFIER irrespective of what is passed as eField which i think should be changed.In DocxAttributeOutput::EndField_Impl, ExpandField is called with AUTH_FIELD_TITLE which then calls ConditionalExpand but ConditionalExpand returns OUString as per AUTH_FIELD_IDENTIFIER which is wrong and should be changed.I have the patch ready...Could you please confirm?

Patch Set 1:My concern is that tweaking the DOCX export is fine, but you should not change how a field is expanded as that would change the layout of existing documents, which is a no-go (it would also affect e.g. ODF documents).SwAuthorityField::Expand() uses ConditionalExpand(AUTH_FIELD_IDENTIFIER), so if you change anything in ConditionalExpand(), you have to be sure that existing documents are not changed. If possible, best to not touch it at all.

OUString SwAuthorityField::ConditionalExpand(ToxAuthorityField eField) constAs per changes:-sRet += pEntry->GetAuthorField(AUTH_FIELD_IDENTIFIER); will be changed to sRet += pEntry->GetAuthorField(eField);I have calculated the impact of SwAuthorityField::ConditionalExpand:-a)ConditionalExpand is called from OUString SwAuthorityField::Expand() const with argument as AUTH_FIELD_IDENTIFIER so my change in ConditionalExpand will not affect existing behaviour.http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/sw/source/core/fields/authfld.cxx#543b)ConditionalExpand is called from OUString SwField::ExpandField(bool const bCached, ToxAuthorityField eField) constwith the argemunt as eField.The eField argument in SwField::ExpandField is a default argument having value AUTH_FIELD_IDENTIFIER only so my change will not affect existing behaviour.http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/sw/source/core/fields/fldbas.cxx#397The only possibiliy that is left is what if SwField::ExpandField is called with both the arguments and the second argument is not AUTH_FIELD_IDENTIFIER??I have checked the callers of SwField::ExpandField and came to know that it is called with only one argument and hence second augumrnt will be taken as default so there will not be any issue.The only time SwField::ExpandField is called with two parameters is for Citation only.so i request you to please consider this.Apologies for making you read so much."

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1For include files in the stable URE interface (include/salhelper/*), this change breaks the ABI and is wrong.For other "widely seen" include files (i.e., include/*) it could be debatable whether to prefer stability or performance, but is probably OK to prefer performance, given our relatively short build times and high flux anyway.But applying the optimization to trivial assignment ops (e.g., include/vmaccess/virtualmachine.hxx) looks odd.  If done at all, those assignment ops should arguably be better left implicitly declared.  (The rationale for the non-inline definition of all those exception classes' special functions is to avoid proliferation of weak vtables.)  Maybe the best thing would be to fix inlinesimpleaccessmethods.cxx to not trigger on "return *this;".(And, as a nitpick, "methods" is not a term of C++; even if Clang internals happily use it, too.)

Currently your git name is "PriyankaGaikwad", while in gerrit your two names are properly two words, so they don't match. Thanks!

Patch Set 1:Parsing looks fine; the output side is not working at all, however.The issue is that Pagemaker and LibreOffice use two different forms for representing an ellipse. Pagemaker uses bounds, skew, and rotation; LibreOffice uses center, length of x axis, length of y axis, and rotation.Before we can write the code, we need to figure out how to translate from one form into the other. Once we figure out that formula, writing the code should be easy.I'm pretty sure the last time I thought about ellipses was in school a decade or so ago, so I'm not sure exactly how to do this. I can spend some time tomorrow thinking about it. I think it's probably very standard; I just need to find it documented in a geometry book somewhere or figure it out myself :)If you upload the parsing piece as a separate patch, we can merge it in now, since it appears to work.

Patch Set 2:The commit had to be reverted for now, because SAL_WARN_IF is not available in C code, only in C++.The best approach to revive the patch would probably be to in a first patch convert those files from C to C++ as a prerequisite (which most of the time means just renaming the files to .cxx extension and moving them from gb_Library_add_cobjects to gb_Library_add_exception_objects in sal/Library_sal.mk), and then redo the OSL_ASSERT -> SAL_WARN_IF changes.However, you should always make sure your changes build OK locally before you upload them.  These changes are to Windows-only code, so if you are not developing on Windows, it is probably best to look for another easy hack for now.

Patch Set 1:In theory, changing a parameter's type from "T" to "T const &" can silently break code (think "misbehaving" const/non-const overloads of T member functions; think "creative" ways to make multiple threads end up with individual copies they can modify without further synchronization).  And C++11 revives pass by value with the pass-by-value-then-move idiom.But in practice, the places spotted here look like they are rightly spotted and should pass by const ref.  (The "minimal" copy assignment operator declarations that pass by value, and are left undefined, would generally be better replaced by the boost::noncopyable idiom.)

Patch Set 2:First, thanks for working on this.I am sorry, I could not test the patch easily because I do not longer work on LO and do not have the build environment at hands. So, I just react to the comments.If this patch causes that Draw behaves different way when pasting from Writer and Draw then it is even less intuitive that the previous behavior and I suggest to revert it.IMHO, it should not matter where you paste from. Also all LO appications should handle the pasting the same way.When I think about it, the confusion might be in the definition of selected object. If you select part of text in Writer and paste something, the selected text is overwritten, so writer behaves the same way as Draw.The problem is that in Writer, if no test is selected, the cursor is somewhere between two characters and pasted text is added. No text is selected most of the time when you write a text. You need to do explict action (select the text) to overwrite it.In draw, the last added or edited object is always selected, so most of the time some object is selected. This causes that the last object is overwritten when pasting. You need to do explicit action (deselect the object) to avoid overwriting.To be honest I am not sure how to solve this.PS: I am sorry if I added the comment a wrong way. I am not familiar with the current Gerrint interface. I did not find any way how to replay any existing comment.

Anyway, losing that is probably not such a big deal (since it was gone already in the past several releases and nobody seems to have noticed).It's good to know the original intention though.

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1osl/diagnose.h is part of the stable URE interface and its contents must generally not be changed incompatibly. Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1The use of AC_CHECK_LIB(c, ...) to look for a function in the normal C library that the compiler uses is bogus. (For instance, nothing guarantees that the C library is called "c". ) There is AC_CHECK_FUNCS for that, and it automatically sets the corresponding HAVE_FOO variables, no need to do it explicitly. (The existing use of AC_CHECK_FUNCS in configure.ac is slightly weird in that sense.) Anyway, I don't see how you would make those HAVE_FOO things you add propagate to the compilations?Also, I don't think it can be strictly correct to assume that a non-standard function like me malign, if it happens to exist, would have the semantics the code expects. Better to let the code that explicitly uses it explicitly just for Android be as is, IMHO. (The strictly correct thing would be to actually run a test during the configury to find out what memalign, does, if it exists. But that would be quite overkill, LO is not supposed to be portable to all possible and impossible OSes anyway, and besides, for cross-compilations (like for Android), such tests couldn't be run at configure time anyway.

Patch Set 9:The 'idea' when talking about patch designed ot re-introduce backward compat to a deprecated platform is1/ do not break other platform code2/ do no shift the burden on maintenance back onto other platforms3/ keep it clear that whatever hack is needed is for that purpose, so that we can clean it up easily later.

Patch Set 9:``1/ do not break other platform code'' Agree with this, I don't like to break working code.``2/ do no shift the burden on maintenance back onto other platforms'' Disagree here, becasue it is related to SAL (software abstraction layer), which purpose is to provide independency from any particular platform.``3/ keep it clear that whatever hack is needed is for that purpose, so that we can clean it up easily later'' Thanks for telling fairly that my work can be easily removed.

Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1I still don't see how you expect HAVE_POSIX_MEMALIGN and HAVE_MEMALIGN to propagate to the compilations. (Of course, you don't notice if/that they don't in your compilations, as you care only for the cases where they are not defined.)The OOo/LO codebase is full of delusions of grandeur and misleading names for various bits and pieces. Don't take the "system abstraction layer" expansion of the "sal" acronym too literally.Of course want it to be easy to remove your code at some point. This codebase is 20 years old now, and I expect (fear?) that it will be around after 20 years still, too. Do even you expect PowerPC Macs and OS X 10.5 to be around any more at that point in time?

Patch Set 11:It is misleading to claim that the code would "blindly guess" the availability of posix_memalign() (and others). The LibreOffice code is *not* portable to arbitrary platforms. We *know* what it is portable to. We depend on totally machine- and OS-dependent assembler code, for chrissake. We enumerate the platforms it has been ported to in the configure file (and elsewhere). Thus I think it does not make things any worse to not suddenly start pretending we are oh so portable and must do all the autoconf way for this one thing.

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1I don't think this is good.  If we offer a general-purpose, low-level rtl_allocateAlignedMemory that promises to return aligned memory, it should not be able to silently return non-aligned memory.  (If you're confident that it is OK for your 10.5 port to silently return non-aligned memory, then please make this conditional exactly on that 10.5 port.)

Patch Set 3:"can you please suggest solution for Darwin/OSX where are no posix_memalign nor memalign?"  Recent OS X does have posix_memalign, so it apparently only is a problem for the 10.5 port.  As I wrote, "If you're confident that it is OK for your 10.5 port [...], then please make this conditional exactly on that 10.5 port," i.e., I'd suggest using the usual MAC_OS_X_VERSION_MAX_ALLOWED < 1060 instead of a newly introduced HAVE_POSIX_MEMALIGN."Also, don't forget that there're another platforms where posix_memalign is not available."  Which relevant ones are that?  And they potentially offer some similar functionality already that we could use, like in the Android case."When this memory.c has been introduced? Why? For what purpose?"  See git log.

Patch Set 3:doug: "Also, don't forget that there're another platforms where posix_memalign is not available."this is in unx/*Unixes that are not Posix are not really a concern these days.Windows, the usual offender in that field, _has_ a _aligned_mallocso, no none of the supported platform have issues with that..Furthermore, jsut because something is 16 bytes aligned, does not make it conformant to memalign... of course malloc return a value that is addressable so typically at least a multiple of sizeof(void*)but posix_memalign is meant to deal with : I need page-aligned memory and this sort of things.

Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1OS X 10.0 has been certified as "100% UNIX", do you remember? Not 10.6, but 10.0. And posix_memalign is just an extension, not requirement to be POSIX Unix system.Anyway, I'd like to write it very-very compatible way.

Patch Set 9:the build failure is not due to this patch, I'll reschedule when it becomes available again now that the build failure is fixed in master.Yes, the GetGraphics returns NULL when there is no available graphics available for use by the caller. e.g. because there is a limited number of them which can be in use at any given time and they are all already in use. Some implementations can hand out a new one always, which is the simple case, some can have only one "checked out" at a time, and most have a pool where there can have a limited bunch in place at any one time.

Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1This isn't going to fly I believe. e.g.pGraphics /*= oldgraphics*/pGraphics = GetGraphics() becomesif (AcquireGraphics())    pGraphics = GetGraphics()so if we couldn't acquire graphics we have pGraphics pointing to the oldone, not NULL, so the expectations of the code have changed and I'm unconvinced that every case is handled correctly. Far simpler and safer would be to just rename GetGraphics to AcquireGraphics, which solves the problem and is safer.Also, one commit for one problem, mixing indendation changes, sal_Bool to bool and extra problems in one patch is making it very hard to unpick what's going on in any given commit.Leave this patch with me a while and I'll turn it into a GetGraphics->AcquireGraphics change and split out some of the additional bits in separate commits.

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1Thank you for the patch!  I wonder - do we have to introduce a new flag?  Isn't it enough to re-use the GETFOCUS_TAB here too?Also about removing if(GETFOCUS_TAB & GetGetFocusFlags()) - what now happens when you click there; won't it lead to extra focusing and unfocusing?  Or is that unrelated?The rest is nitpicking :-) - if we really need GETFOCUS_F6, it should be 0x0800, not 0x1000.  PreNotify() should return true's, not 1's.Thanks so much - and sorry the review took so long; -1's for now, hope that's OK, please set back to 0 when you upload a new patch at some stage.

Patch Set 3:Hi Kendy,> I wonder - do we have to introduce a new flag?Of course. In some case it is useful to differentiate focusing caused by F6 or TAB. e.g. in BackingWindow::GetFocus(), GETFOCUS_F6 + !GETFOCUS_FORWARD -> grab focus to thumbnailview while GETFOCUS_TAB -> nothing> Also about removing if(GETFOCUS_TAB & GetGetFocusFlags()) - what now happens when you click there; won't it lead to extra focusing and unfocusing? Or is that unrelated?Yes, you are right. I will revert this change and will add a more explicit solution which will select item just when it is actually necessary. Unfortunately ImplGrabFocus() can't be used outside vcl, which would be a simple way (e.g. using ImplGrabFocus(GETFOCUS_F6) inside BackingWindow too).> The rest is nitpicking :-) - if we really need GETFOCUS_F6, it should be 0x0800, not 0x1000.Are you sure? I just look these GETFOCUS_ flags are defined in this way leaving out 0x0008, 0x0080 and I thought maybe somewhere these flags are used in a special way (e.g. some special bit operation) which makes it necessary.> PreNotify() should return true's, not 1's.Oh, yes. This is the result of new bool improvements. :)

Patch Set 3:> maybe somewhere these flags are used in a special way I don't think they are (and git grep does not suggest anything like that) - I believe it was more a kind of grouping things together (TAB/CURSOR/MNEMONIC - one group, FORWARD/BACKWARD/AROUND another, etc.)

Patch Set 3:>> Also about removing if(GETFOCUS_TAB & GetGetFocusFlags()) - what now happens when you click there; won't it lead to extra focusing and unfocusing? Or is that unrelated?> Yes, you are right. I will revert this change and will add a more explicit solution which will select item just when it is actually necessary. Unfortunately ImplGrabFocus() can't be used outside vcl, which would be a simple way (e.g. using ImplGrabFocus(GETFOCUS_F6) inside BackingWindow too).I was wrong. It seems mouse click doesn't lead to GetFocus() call (maybe that's why there is no a GETFOCUS_MOUSE flag?) so for simplicity I keep at the first version (select first item in all case when GetFocus is called).

Patch Set 2:I did three changes:(1) JobExecutor did not implement XComponent, so would not be notified pre-exit by a component context/service manager dispose, but would only release its resources during atexit, with all the dreaded consequences. Patch Set 1: Do not mergeI still don脭脟脰t see any sense in removing it. It solves a couple of issues: it checks adapter existence before enabling / disabling it instead of checking everywhere, it should help to acquire adapter the proper way on higher platforms [1] instead of duplicating code everywhere. Plus you instantiate property directly but I was trying to init them in constructors only to avoid mess. Null checks is just element of style so I can close my eyes on this part.Anyway my vote seems to be ignored at all. [1]:https://developer.android.com/reference/android/bluetooth/BluetoothAdapter.html

Patch Set 1:Hmm, I'm not entirely 100% sure about this, but:getDefaultAdapter still exists and should work according to the API (it's not marked as deprecated, the methods docs haven't changed), and hence should work for us for all supported Android versions. Moreover there are no reports of it breaking with 4.3 that I can find (I imagine there'd be quite some uproar if existing apps were suddenly broken by Android 4.3)...It seems the getSystemService way of getting the adapter was added for consistency (as that's how the Wifi adapter is usually retrieved) -- and it's use is obviously encouraged for new apps, but we specifically want to support 2.3+ for now, so still need to at least have getDefaultAdapter.So, unless there is specific evidence that getDefaultAdapter has been broken we only need to support getDefaultAdapter and can ignore the getSystemService way of doing things, in which case the wrapper is unnecessary. (And in future once we no longer need to support < 4.3 we can migrate to whatever the wonderful new consistent API is.)

Patch Set 1:> it checks adapter existence before enabling / disabling it > instead of checking everywhere,1st of all that's not true. You're just wrapping the check into a function call, so that decision is just hidden behind a function and still executed everytime, just hidden between two or three levels of indirection. This makes the code harder to understand, harder to get into for newcomers.Newcomers read Android's api to understand what's going on and are thrown off by wrappers that they have to track through different files.2nd enabling/disabling the adapter is only triggered/used once each. So this is far from "everywhere".3rd your (I assume it is yours, since you're defending it so much) code acquires the adapter way more often than the changed code, where once it is acquired, it is stored in the member variable(s). The old code always calls getDefaultAdapter(), take for example the getPairingDeviceName() function.1st time when calling isAvailable, that indirects to getAdapter that in turn calls getDefaultAdapter.2nd time in the check for a device name (uses getAdapter that indirects to getDefaultAdapter3rd time when returning the name.And this for each Bluetooth device that is found. > it should help to acquire adapter the proper way on  > higher platforms [1] instead of duplicating code everywhere.Again you're making it hard for me to take your argumentation seriously. This has been mentioned in the previous comments already. A) There's absolutely no reason to introduce runtime-version checks. This would not only complicate the code, but more importantly doing test on the various codepaths. I would personally object any change that introduces a runtime version check without actual need for it. If docs would say: function will be removed in next version of Android, that would be a different story. But for the foreseeable future, the functionality will remain the same, B) Even when you want to acquire the adapter depending on the version, then *one single public static method* is enough to do this, no need for a whole class that wraps's the BluetoothAdapter's API. Apart from acquiring the actual adapter, there are absolutely no changes in the API. > Plus you instantiate property directlynot sure what you mean with property, I guess calling the actual API on the adapter? Yes, indeed I do it directly, since I believe in KISS - and I cannot think of anything simpler than just calling the function that is properly documented in the API docs, that every Android developer having dealt with BT already knows... >  but I was trying to init them in constructors only to > avoid mess.I absolutely cannot follow where. The Operator-wrapper's constructor is empty. And for launching the activities, you use intents, not constructors. I cannot find any occurrence where you'd pass the adapter in a constructor. (and also don't see a benefit), as it's static and can just be obtained on a if-needed basis. > Null checks is just element of style so I can close my > eyes on this part.I absolutely don't understand this comment either. You have *plenty* of null checks in the operator and in other places of the code, and they are the most straightforward/only way to check whether something is null. It also makes it immediately clear to the person reading the code that whatever is bound to the check won't happen because that adapter is null.  > Anyway my vote seems to be ignored at all.It is not that it is ignored, just that I have a completely different view on this topic. I want the code to be straightforward, easy to understand by people not familiar with it (just like I was before writing this patch. I neither had a take at android development, let alone the remote). I find all those redirections highly irritating. KISS should be the prime goal here. I see no need to split a function that happily fits on my small screen (i.e. less than 30 lines) if the parts that it is split into are not reusable/not used anywhere else.I also see absolutely no point in creating a wrapper to one-line function calls.If the Operator-wrapper would do more stuff that things that can be put into a single 80-column-line, then I'd be happy to keep that functionality, but all it has is a) a "renamed" null-check. A function that just returns the value of a comparison != null.and on top of that it unnecessarily requires the adapter anew. (something that can probably be optimized out by the compiler/the runtime, but still something I consider unnecessary. b) a "enable" function, that just calls the API function of the same name(wrapped along with the useless isAvailable check that you very likely already had checked before even trying to enable the adapter) c) a "disable" function where the same remarks as for the enable function apply, d) the getAdapter wrapper, that does nothing but call the getDefaultAdapter() API function.I see that this is the most debatable, and the one that is the only one that has at least a minimalistic reason to exist.But as written earlier: I see absolutely no reason why want to have runtime version checks if the code happily runs on the newest devices unchanged. After all we even use compatibility/support libraries to support old versions, why would you jeopardize this by explicitly targeting newer versions with such a runtime check?After all all that changes is the way to get a BlueToothAdapter object, nothing else. If newer Android version had a different Bluetooth api, then this would be a completely different story (but then again probably handled by the support libraries, so nothing one would have to deal with manually).And after all: I wrote a patch that fixes stuff. So that's why I in this case value my own opinion higher than yours (cynicism, don't take too seriously). I'm aware that I'm stepping on your toes now, and I'm sorry for that. But I won't change my opinion on this because of that.* my changes fix a couple of bugs* no previous functionality is lost* the wrapper did only most trivial stuffIn my opinion it makes the code much easier to grasp without all that redirection. Quoting from the Zen of Python (that applies here as well): [脭脟陋] Explicit is better than implicit. Simple is better than complex. [脭脟陋] Flat is better than nested. [脭脟陋] Readability counts. [脭脟陋]I hope the long response shows that I'm not simply ignoring your opinion, just that I don't share it.I'd rather add other missing features (like locking screen orientation and adding the "laser-pointer" feature) than arguing about this.

Patch Set 1:My only comment is that the old code conveyed some additional degree of information in the method names e.g. rememberBluetoothState(), restoreBluetoothState(), etc, that is now lost, or at least no longer obvious.It might be useful to retain some of that information by adding comments to the now inlined code.

Patch Set 1:Thanks for the comment re the telling function names that are no longer preserved - this is true, however in later commits that handling gets revamped anyway, for example instead of all that was-bt-enabled stuff there is then only a member variable "disableBTOnQuit that keeps the state and has a telling name:private static final BluetoothAdapter btAdapter = BluetoothAdapter.getDefaultAdapter();private static boolean disableBTOnQuit = btAdapter != null && !btAdapter.isEnabled();all the other state-saving/retrieval is moot that way, and the disabling of BT reduces toif (isFinishing() && disableBTOnQuit) { btAdapter.disable();}Similar for the setup of the viewpager/the tabs.I only created the split commits because I was asked to provide atomic commits - but that also means I'm touching parts of the code multiple other times in the later patches.

Second, changing target SDK should be supported via build servers to not fail. Patch Set 1:> Please try to provide atomic changes instead of all-in-one commit.This is an atomic commit. Splitting that up would result in unbuildable project/mix of abs and android support lib. Not what you want.And did you even bother to look at the patch? All those changes are trivial, basically replacing "Sherlock" with "Compat" or similar> First, you are changing minimum SDK version we are not interested in 脭脟枚 there is a sweet ICS future, it is more wise to move forward instead of backward.Changing the minimum version doesn't impact use of new ICS features at all. ActionBarSherlock previously, and the default android support library in the proposal.You fail to mention what ICS features are lost by that, so please elaborate. Target SDK is the version that is definitely supported, i.e. in this case the version that runs on a device I personally own, did personally test with. But again, no biggie to leave that at present values.> Third, we are not interested at moment in switching from ABS to ABCWho is "we"?> because LO Android port uses ABS anyway and,How is the LO Android port related to the Impress Remote? The remote(s) have already been decoupled translation wise, release-schedule wise, so I fail to see how the remote is bound to the Android port.Again the changes are small, the android support libraries stack up easily to support newer features.You mentioned that newer versions have nice features and you'd rather drop support for older devices: using the android support libs makes that easy. In Fact the ABS one already used the v4 support library itself.> again, this should be supported via build servers.And again no idea what you mean by that. If you mean it should be buildable by ant/using the makefiles and not by using Eclipse, you should see that I also updated the makefile.I didn't bother to add a check whether the v7 support library has been installed on the machine, as it is not built as part of LO anyway, and the error message will be pretty obvious in that case....If you insist, I can also add configure checks. Or do the easy way as with the abs and check it into the repo.> Fourth, SettingsActivity after your change wouldn脭脟脰t have an action bar on pre-Honeycomb versions.It will.> I agree with you that ABS 脭氓脝 ABC migration makes sense but there is a *really low* percentage of users using Gingerbread.I didn't change it because I wanted to lower the minimumSDK, that was just the result of the lint check that this is the minimum that the code uses.> It makes a very little sense for me to swap dependencies for things that just work for platform version which *potentially* could be dropped.I don't care about the minimum SDK, so don't fixate on that.  I did swap dependencies for the contrary, to make it easier to extend later with new features. Even the author of the ABS wrote that ABS has done its job, that with the android support lib v7 there is no reason to use ABS anymore. That of course doesn't mean one should swap components, never change a running system yadda,yadda, but the remote is small, the change as a whole is small, so it is (IMHO) a sensible thing to do.You also state on the one-hand pre honeycomb (aka gingerbread) would look different, but on the other hand you're willing to just drop support for gingerbread completely. So I fail to see how this then is a concern regarding this patch.

Patch Set 1:In general looks good to me :)The only problems I can see are with the project.properties:1.Presumably we want to bump the target to 17 here?2.Using ${sdk.dir} doesn't work with eclipse -- *maybe* it's worth having a ../v7-appcompat instead, and adding the project to the git repo, but ultimately I suspect we want to migrate from having ant OR eclipse, to using gradle which apparently uses exactly the same build no matter whether you are in an ide or not (but I haven't looked into the details so can't confirm how this works).Sorry, I can't easily quote previous reviews for some reason, but here are my view on the other issues:* API versions:> but there is a *really low* percentage of users using Gingerbreadas discussed on IRC and possibly the ML a few times, we want to support the vast majority of Android devices, that means at least API 10, and nothing wrong with going lower if we don't lose features (see http://developer.android.com/about/dashboards/index.html to see that API 10 is still about 30% of the market)* ABS:Also been discussed on IRC, we specifically want to get rid of ABS, both for the remote and for the main android app in order to reduce complexity & maintenance -- having ABS in the way is somewhat of a blocker for splitting the Impress Remote repo out, or would alternatively result in duplication between repos...Yes, we need to update the build guide, but the new procedure is simply different and not more complicated.* Build servers:- That's up to the tb maintainers to upgrade (same as the previous comment on installing the correct lib), not really an issue -- there is going to be significant change anyway when the repo is split, so worst case the tbs might be disabled for a short time, but they aren't hugely important for the remote.

Patch Set 1:> The only problems I can see are with the project.properties: > 1.Presumably we want to bump the target to 17 here?Eclipse's target version is different from the target in the manifest. Manifest basically that newer versions should enable compatibility mode and not apply for example a new system-theme. While target in properties defines what SDK Eclipse will use / defines the maximum api you can use without getting errors - so if you'd want to add runtime checks for versions > 14, then you'd need to raise the limit. As it currently is, it could even be lowered to minSDK..  > 2.Using ${sdk.dir} doesn't work with eclipse --Yes, but there is no way to know the relative path to the SDK from the build-tree beforehand. Even when checked into the code, then in Ecplipse it will only work when you don't copy stuff to your workdir (as then relative paths are again different).As having a correct path is not enough in Ecplipse, but you have to add the library project as an additional project in Eclipse anyway, I don't consider this a problem. I have to adjust the library reference in the code that uses abs, and also with the one that uses the android support lib. > *maybe* it's worth having a ../v7-appcompat instead, and > adding the project to the git repo,This will make building with ant easier, as you then can skip the python statement to determine the relative path, but would not help /that/ much for Eclipse. You would still have to import both the v7-appcompat as well as the sdremote projects.(in any case: only halfway nice, as it "pollutes" the sourcetree, as opposed to other parts of the LO sourcecode that leave the sourcetree alone, but do all the work in workdir or previously solver)

Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, approved> [...] While target in properties defines what SDK Eclipse> will use / defines the maximum api you can use without> getting errorsAhh ok, seems I've misunderstood how they all interact.> [...] As having a correct path is not enough in Ecplipse,> but you have to add the library project as an additional> project in Eclipse anyway, I don't consider this a problem. [...]I agree -- setting up Eclipse requires following the user manual and isn't plug'n'play either way so makes sense to optimise the non-eclipse case etc.Looking into the (or a possible) future, I'm investigating upgrading to the Android Studio / gradle build system which will *massively* simplify things (add "compile "com.android.support:appcompat-v7:18.0.+"" to the dependencies and you are ready to go...), but that's completely separate to this change in any case... That could probably be done in parallel to the current build, but I'll probably send that to the ML once I know more...

Patch Set 1:The tablet-layout itself is OK with the 50:50 split, but I kind of disagree with making the font larger also for the small-screen layouts. There doesn't seem to be a reason for this, as you hold the device in your hand to make use of it as a remote, so it is close to your eyes.And the 12sp is actaully rendering the text smaller than default (at least in the preview in eclipse) - sure about that? I'd probably use 22sp for tablets - that would correspond to "large" font size according to http://stackoverflow.com/questions/11590538/dpi-value-of-default-large-medium-and-small-text-views-androidBut I'd leave the size for phones at it's current value (and rather tweak the horizontal padding/spacing to maximize the usable screen-estate)

Patch Set 2:please be serious.Nowhere does this state it is about dropping support for pre-honeycomb.I say it is OK that instead of "ALL CAPS" they get "All Caps" (or whatever casing the string is actually present in the xml/translations).So if you insist that all-caps for those entries is a must, just have translators provide them in ALL CAPS and you don't see any difference.I personally dislike all-caps, and wouldn't mind also removing that from the styledefinition for newer devices.

Patch Set 2:And I say it is not OK ;-) As well it is not OK to keep strings as uppercase text. You can dislike uppercase but is headers style defined in guidelines [1] (and the whole platform uses it). I see no reason to remove things defined by the platform but you personally dislike, plus this custom widget causes no overdraw or other performance drawbacks.[1]: http://developer.android.com/design/style/metrics-grids.html#examples

Patch Set 2:While I appreciate that you took your time to comment on my patches, I cannot take your comments seriously.In the other patch you say it's fine to completely ignore the interaction guidelines (not enable BT without user's consent), but here you insist that a design that was introduced on newer devices must be enforced on older devices (that you're happy to not even support at all).You also fail to explain why just keeping strings that are meant to always displayed upppercase in all-caps in the resources is no solution.

Patch Set 2:> In the other patch you say it's fine to completely ignore the interaction guidelines (not enable BT without user's consent), but here you insist that a design that was introduced on newer devices must be enforced on older devices (that you're happy to not even support at all).I see this as a visual design and UX. The visual design is defined. If Android has the Roboto font developers should consider using it instead of Comic Sans. If the whole platform uses uppercase headers developers should consider to implement it as well. On other hand the UX of Bluetooth interaction has a kind of broken state 脭脟枚鈹es, in perfect world users should enable it themselves, but why there are no dialog for disabling it themselves? Does it make sense to force user to use dialog every time one launches the app? Why user should even care about enabling or disabling Bluetooth at all? I脭脟脰m not trying to reject things I don脭脟脰t want to see or use 脭脟枚鈹 try to think about better implementations which cause pleasant experience and not emotions like 脭脟拢oh this dialog again脭脟脴, 脭脟拢again this app causes battery drain脭脟脴.> You also fail to explain why just keeping strings that are meant to always displayed upppercase in all-caps in the resources is no solution.1. It is easier to translate strings when you see simple words instead of WORDS. 2. If in the future the platform remove this headers style we can just tweak the style for the text and not the text for the style.
Patch Set 2:use plain TextView that (gets styled as all-caps anyway - no big deal if that style isn't supported on older versions of android)I'll get rid of that custom Text-widget in another commit

Patch Set 2:> It is a design decision based on idea that in landscape> we have a little vertical space so it makes sense to > show a slide more detailed.What do you mean with "more detailed". The aspect ratio in landscape means that you have lots of dead space left and right in the current/old design. And even has lots of padding around that gives it even less vertical space.Vertical space is limiting the size here, that's true. So if you cannot display a large slide anyway, why not use the empty/unused space in a useful way?Compare the old:http://frupic.frubar.net/shots/30949.jpgand new:http://frupic.frubar.net/shots/30950.jpgwhich one makes better use of the space to show a as-large-as-possible preview slide?And why would anyone even use landscape mode, when that does show less information than portrait?> On other hand there are tablets but tablets support> should be implemented in other scale than just > 脭脟拢use the same everywhere脭脟脴.Tablets are not really the target-devices for the remote. If you need to hold a big/heavy device, you can just step up to the desk... As the previews are low-quality anyway, larger screen will not bring much benefit.

Patch Set 2:I see. But imagine using not a HD display ;-) They are still much more popular these days [1]. I see that the text has a very little width at your layout as well and I脭脟脰m looking at the HD display not an average medium screen. I tend to disagree about tablets as well 脭脟枚鈹 cannot say numbers from the dashboard (probably) but there are *really* many tablet users.[1]: http://developer.android.com/about/dashboards/index.html#Screens

Patch Set 2: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedLooks good to me!Whilst phones are the primary audience, I still think having specific tablet support is useful, as a tablet is still a lot easier to place in a convenient location than a laptop (or even more so a desktop) is. I think that it might be worth adding a tablet specific landscape UI where the notes get more space (with a smaller preview -- due to the resolution a huge preview makes little sense there as mentioned), but that would be a completely separate topic to this patch in any case.

Patch Set 1:I don't think it's the localised or not version of MSVC that matters, but the system codepage. Apparently MSVC insists that C++ source code is a valid byte sequence in the system codepage, and this UTF-8 comment is not in yours. Or something like that... I guess you don't want to change your system codepage...?

Patch Set 3: AbandonedWe have to set the values to the _maximum_ SDK we want to use. Otherwise Windows features will be dropped and not be available to LibreOffice. If features are implemented eg. since Windows Vista we need to do runtime checks and define the corresponding structs, function and so on.But the minimum supported Windows version must be checked with _WIN32_WINNT set to the corresponding version. And get a regular build to detect such problems! If this is set to WinXP (0x0502) only parts of the SDK are enabled, which are within these conditionals (checked by _NTDDI_VERSION, _WIN32_WINNT and sometimes _WINVER). Defining _WIN32_WINNT defines both other macros to the same value. Only by setting _WIN32_WINNT we could detect incompatible features, which build fine on Windows 7 and don't work on Windows XP/Vista/whatever.Those WINVER conditionals are bogus, because they are highly dependant on the build machine! If the sources are build on Windows XP and delivered for all other versions of Windows only Windows XP features are included. If we build on Windows 7 and have runtime checks for special calls to windows functions, which are only >=Windows 7
Patch Set 3: RestoredWill submit a better patch which is a good compromise between being perfect and some required updates - as we require at least XP.
Patch Set 5: Verified; Looks good to me, approved

Patch Set 1:No, that wouldn't be right. The docu says "If you define NTDDI_VERSION, you must also define _WIN32_WINNT.". So we should use both. Somewhere I read that NTDDI_VERSION was the new approach to overcome all those different macros (esp. because of the former 98/NT difference). But rumor says, that it's not fully supported - as the documentation says, too.For simplicity I would only set _WIN32_WINNT and WINVER. And replace _WIN32_WINDOWS with _WIN32_WINNT .
Patch Set 1:I still don't understand why we need to define any of these in out sources? What breaks if we just leave out them?

Patch Set 1:And pointing to stuff in mingw-specific mailing lists is hardly that relevant as we don't build with mingw? (We used to be able to cross-compile most of the sources with mingw, but that hasn't been maintained and is presumably badly broken at the moment.)

Patch Set 1:I chose the mingw mailing list entry, because there's a nice compilation of old WINVER defines, which the Microsoft documentation doesn't offer :)And at the moment we need to set WINVER because it has everywhere different values. Or we have hacks like adefd564d07a6e70cc1d9fad8febe5b434511e83 or a9fd489834b63e423d4745f0d71cf15396e3e3eb. At least for fpicker it's relevant because with 0x0501 you wouldn't get the window previews in the taskbar with Vista/7. So we need 0x0600 there, but we can't set it global to the project if we still want to support Windows XP.But you're right, after that commit many of them could be simply dropped.

Patch Set 6:on closer examination it turns out the warnings (at least in sal) come from outdated precompiled headers - so clearly i was wrong and i take back the previous comment :)this needs a "make clean" apparently.

Patch Set 6:Sorry, I didn't mention it, but yes this does need a make clean. The patch was indeed finished.I didn't wonder about the WIN32_LEAN_AND_MEAN redefinition, because this is how it's done in some other makefiles. Thanks for fixing this.Nice that this finally got into core :)

Patch Set 2:Now the settings are applied globally.And I found out how to use the macros:_WIN32_WINNT sets NTDDI_VERSION and WINVER automatically to the same version.But setting NTDDI_VERSION or WINVER sets only the macro itself.If we want to target Windows XP we need to set _WIN32_WINNT, because otherwise other SDK stuff is still included under Windows 7. But this brings us some kind of dilemma: How do we add features which are added in Windows 7 (like 9a4a84df5406cdcde1f4d23a1cea2b109998f35b)? If we set WINVER globally those features are never activated.One solution could be to check:#ifdef NTDDI_WIN7Works fine, but checks only what is supported by the Windows API (what if Win8 SDK is installed on Win7?).Maybe we should move this to the mailing list.

Patch Set 1:Here is how I would do it:You want to make sure that a given XML element exists. You take the XPath of it, then:assertXPath(pXmlStyles, "blabla", 1);makes sure that there is exactly one node matching that XPath. If it was missing previously, that was 0.In the ooxmlexport suite, testStyleInheritance has plenty of such examples, also e.g. testBnc834035 shows how to assert an XPath in document.xml.Does that help? :-)Sorry for the nitpicking, but in the past I at least remember two cases already when we fixed hyperlink/redline/field end problems, so this is an area where we really want unit tests. Thanks!

Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approveSo - in general in-lining headers like this is fine - assuming that we are just moving these redundant extra headers into others that are included anyway.However - looking at the number counts we do more than this:0       65      slideshow/source/inc/animationfunction.hxx104     6       slideshow/source/inc/eventmultiplexer.hxx28      2       slideshow/source/inc/expressionnode.hxx176     2       slideshow/source/inc/listenercontainer.hxx30      1       slideshow/source/inc/shapeattributelayer.hxx0       61      slideshow/source/inc/shapecursoreventhandler.hxx0       67      slideshow/source/inc/state.hxx0       59      slideshow/source/inc/userpainteventhandler.hxx0       67      slideshow/source/inc/viewrepainthandler.hxxSo - a lot more code ends up in the new headers than is removed from the old ones: where does that come from ?I'm very scared by things like:+class MutexBase+{+public:+    struct Guard : public osl::MutexGuard+    {+        explicit Guard(MutexBase const& rBase) :+            osl::MutexGuard(rBase.maMutex)+        {}+    };+    struct ClearableGuard : public osl::ClearableMutexGuard+    {+        explicit ClearableGuard(MutexBase const& rBase) :+            osl::ClearableMutexGuard(rBase.maMutex)+        {}+    };++    mutable osl::Mutex maMutex;+};Then I noticed that you just forgot to git rm 'listenercontainerimpl.hxx' that has this stuff in it.Quite why we have this 'MutexBase' class I have no idea it looks odd to me - but that's a problem for another commit =)So - anyhow - this is good. There is really not a lot of value using a pimpl pattern for classes that are internal to slideshow anyway, so - this inlining seems rather helpful.Thanks ! will push in a sec.

Patch Set 2:Hmmm - the problem is, when loading such a document, the strings getmatched against existing table styles, and then the table design paneselects the right icon for the currently-selected table object.Now, if you change the name, when loading an old doc, Impress willon-demand create a new style (since the name 'turquise' is unknown),and assign a matching icon. So you'll end up with a bunch of dupeentries in that widget.I wonder if this rather cosmetic change is worth that user annoyance?Alternatively, one could of course map the names on import, doubtfulthough if that's worth the hassle ...

Patch Set 2: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedso it looks like we actually write the name of these table styles into the ODF file...... as table:template-name="turquise" on table:table element.this means that the values will be read from the ODF file anyway so it shouldn't matter what the styles are called internally (that will just affect new files).the only problem i can see is that if you load a document with the old spelling you can see an additional entry in "Table Design" but i think it's not really a problem.

Patch Set 1:The SCSTR_COLUMN and SCSTR_ROW strings already contain the "%1" placeholder, apparently that was added to actually allow translations to specify if the column/row should be prepended or appended. sc/source/ui/src/scstring.src has String SCSTR_COLUMN {     Text [ x-comment ] = "%1 is replaced to column letter, such as 'Column A'" ;     Text [ en-US ] = "Column %1" ; };All other places using these strings already correctly substitute the placeholder with the column/row number, this one was just missing. It doesn't break anything unless translations omitted the %1 placeholder, but then it broke in several other places as well.

Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, approved"All other places using these strings already correctly substitute the placeholder with the column/row number, this one was just missing."Ah, ok, then translations without the placeholder are broken already. Sorry, I didn't consider that. :)

Patch Set 1:Circa 2009 I asked OOo development to let sysadmins disable the new database button, through a configuration parameter (default was to let users create new databases). The main reason is that in many corporations, scattered databases in desktops (such as Access or Base) are conseidered a breach in data security, uncontrollable data leak and poor data management.I beg to let sysadmins to keep installation to prevent the creation of new databases, as its is today.The configuration that hides the New Database from the dialog is here (should be added in main.xcd)----------------%<----------------------- <?xml version="1.0"?><oor:data xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:oor="http://openoffice.org/2001/registry"> <dependency file="main"/> <oor:component-data xmlns:install="http://openoffice.org/2004/installation" oor:name="DataAccess" oor:package="org.openoffice.Office">  <node oor:name="Policies">   <node oor:name="Features">    <node oor:name="Base">     <prop oor:name="CreateLocalDatabase" oor:type="xs:boolean">      <value>false</value>     </prop>    </node>    <node oor:name="Writer">     <prop oor:name="DatabaseFields" oor:type="xs:boolean">      <value>true</value>     </prop>     </node>     <node oor:name="Common">      <prop oor:name="EditDatabaseFromDataSourceView" oor:type="xs:boolean">       <value>true</value>      </prop>    </node>   </node>  </node> </oor:component-data></oor:data>----------------%<-----------------------

Patch Set 1:Hi Olivier,I believe the "New Database" you are referring to is completely unrelated to the change above -- my change only affects the options when already creating a .odb file (via the "Connect to an Existing Database" option, and even then only when creating a new .odb that is intended to link to a firebird file database. It will in no way affect the first page of the Base Dialog which offers the "Create a New Database", "Open an existing database", "Connect to an existing database" options.In other words it will still be possible to block creation of new .odb files using the previous config options.

Patch Set 1:Lionel, Andrzej: I put you as reviewer because perhaps my patch is too naive.I mean it seems to work but perhaps I'm just hiding the problem.The problem is after:964             XRow xRow = UnoRuntime.queryInterface( XRow.class, _xResultSet );_xResultSet is null and I don't know why

Patch Set 2:I expect _xResultSet is null because it is passed as null as argument to that function; the root cause is higher in the call stack (that is in the function that calls StringsFromResultSet, or in the function that calls this one, or etc).I expect the root cause is "just" some unimplemented interface / part of the firebird driver.However, I find that independently of the above, your patch seems to increase the robustness of the StringsFromResultSet function, and that's a good thing. I'd just wish we identified the root cause.Does the table wizard actually fully work after applying your patch?

Patch Set 2:At least, I can go to the end of the table wizard with 1 or 2 columns and by default options. I haven't made lots of tests, just validated I could get throught the whole wizard with simple options.

Patch Set 2:> Just to put it clearly, _xResultSet wasn't null before the line: >XRow xRow = UnoRuntime.queryInterface( XRow.class, _xResultSet );Wow. That's weird / abnormal and will likely make other problems elsewhere. I'll try to track down the cause of that.

Patch Set 2:I've made the test again, I must have made a mistake because _xResultSet is null even before XRow xRow = UnoRuntime.queryInterface( XRow.class, _xResultSet );BTW, the value of "XRow.class" is:interface com.sun.star.sdbc.XRow

Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is mergedIs there something missing here, what value is LO_LDFLAGS supposed to get?

Patch Set 1:Roi replied in personal email:Nothing it should get no value in the configure stage you can't now the results of the build But a script from Xcode can populate it for the build so it automatically scan the libs and populate the value for the xcconfig
Patch Set 1:Ah but then it is pointless to have it in lo.xcconfig.in.

Patch Set 1:Well I needed an anchor to add the data and when adding new variables in to an xcconfig file dynamically you need to restart Xcode. another way is to resolve this using gbuild at the end of build somehow

Patch Set 1:Hmm, not sure I follow, but OK... Without the corresponding script, though, this now means others will not be able to build the MobileLibreOffice app, right?Also, I think the name LO_LDFLAGS is misleading, as it isn't consistent with the other LO_FOO settings in lo.xcconfig(.in), which originate from LO's configury. Some other name would be better, and please don't use "LDFLAGS" in the name as "LDFLAGS" traditionally is used for flags, not a list of libraries.Sorry if this seems like nitpicking, but experience has taught me that code needs to use existing conventions and terminology to be understandable later...

Patch Set 1:Well this is LDFLAGS not a list of libraries it adds -l and -L and any other flags needed to link against Libreoffice static lib repository and it is added to Xcode other link flags so LDFALGS is accurate for the LO part tell me what is the best prefix
Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, approved

Patch Set 6: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedIn case I insert a page at the end of a new doc (numbered "1", physically 3 out of 3), the toolbar says "Page 1 3/3". (No idea why not "Page 1 2/2".) In this zero case, it says "Page 0/4", which is a bit confusing.OTOH I guess it improves the current situation, so let's get it in.Oh, and one more thing: in SwLayHelper::CheckInsertPage(), it's not trivial why you check the page number of the *follow* style. It would be great to have a follow-up commit that adds a comment, explaining that.

Patch Set 3:> vmiklos: I have updated all the relevant places to now use 'optional'.Great, thanks!> In 'sw/source/ui/utlui/uitool.cxx' the 'SfxUInt16Item aPageNum' is set in the function 'SwToSfxPageDescAttr'. Question is - now that 'GetNumOffset' *could* return NULL - what should be done if it *is* null ? should we set '0' to the 'SfxUInt16Item' (like I've done) ?If we're speaking about SwToSfxPageDescAttr(), what about just not putting the SfxPoolItem to the item set? Of course, then the consumer of that item set (insert->manual break dialog?) should handle the lack of the pool item in the set, but I guess that's logical: item missing -> "change page number" checkbox is false, item there -> "change page number" checkbox is true and the value can be even 0, if you need it.> In 'sw/source/ui/table/tabledlg.cxx' the code *used* to set the 'NumericField' with the value from the 'GetNumOffset()' function, but now it returns an optional value. so if the value is NULL - should it *not* set the NumericValue or it *should* set it, but with 0 (like I've done) ?This is the UI I was mentioning above. :) I guess null should be "checkbox false, numeric field empty", while 0 should be "checbox true, numeric field 0". Hopefully that's intuitive enough.

Patch Set 5: This need some tweaks before it is mergedI do not see the problems raised on Sep 6 to be addressed yet. Create a new document, insert -> manual break, set style to default style, check 'change page number', then you can't set page number to 0, and if you enter "0" manually, it's interpreted as 1.In case UI is intentionally left out from this commit, please mention it in the commit message.Thanks.

Patch Set 1:Commit message states, that https://gerrit.libreoffice.org/#/c/1164  inadvertently introduced a regression. 2bd856e6 added extensive tests (250 LoC): https://gerrit.libreoffice.org/#/c/1164/17/connectivity/qa/connectivity/commontools/FValue_test.cxxThese tests must be extended to cover the bool->string conversion problem that is fixed in this change.
Patch Set 1:Yes, extending the unit tests would be good, but IMHO it does not make sense to block the bugfix in our stable branch waiting for the unittest.

Patch Set 1:We are always very good in finding justifications why we don't write/extend unit tests:* that module (Base in this case) doesn't have tests* that method is not get tested in existing unit test class* we are in hurry to hot fix our stable branch and don't going to spend time to writing/extending unit testsIMHO we should stop that praxis and start writing/extending unit tests.

Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approveSeems good to me, deadlock-wise; I'd avoid ever using the internal mutex there personally and stop pretending we're multi-threaded, and bin the 'external' lock, and hard-code the Solar mutex etc. ;)I'm curious as to how the         forgetExternalLock();            // this ensures that the lock, which may be already destroyed as part of the derivee,            // is not used anymore        ensureDisposed();works - that is assuming that 'disposing' may get emitted during ensureDisposed (but now without a lock held ?).Then again, my impression with locking issues it that: we can't really make it much worse so ... ;-)

Patch Set 1:had the idea of hard-coding SolarMutex too - problem is this code is in comphelper so below "tools" which is the lowest module knowing about SolarMutexbut at least i changed it in commit da21e9de6a71dcd1926f5bf167049bce0590515e to remove the ctors that were used to initialize the class _without_ providing SolarMutex

Patch Set 1:ensureDisposed() called from dtor shouldn't need a lock -the lock guards m_pImpl, and when we're in dtor alreadythere shouldn't be a way for another thread to access the object.although it looks like revokeClientNotifyDisposing receives a "this" pointer, and if it sends that as Reference to event listeners when called from dtor then that's perhaps a different disaster waiting to happen...

Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedIf you're happy with it - etc. ;-) as I say - the threading is so mind mashed, that IMHO all we can hope to do is to restore ~the whole app to use only the Solar Mutex and then think again :-)

Patch Set 2:Can you please be more verbose in the commit message?  What problem exactly is that change supposed to fix?  (Bugs around SolarMutex are notoriously delicate, so the more information the better.)  Also, fdo#61950 "Change Presentation Minimizer from bundled extensions to plain code" doesn't look really relevant for this commit?

Unfortunately i don't have a link to pastebin.com with the back trace any more. I posted it yesterday on the IRC and Michael suggested to make that change in this file. This solved that problem. In any event i don't know what the original problem with solar mutex is/was and why this line solved it.@Michael can you upload a new version of this change with updated commit message, please?Concerning de-externalization of the presentation minimizer in fdo#61950 it is only related, because it would be a valid test case after migration: it should work again. But currently it doesn't work as extension either ;-)Bur formally you are right, we could remove the mention of this bug from the commit message, create a new bug and link to it, or just let it as is ;-)

Patch Set 1:Sorry, that the patch is big. Important bits are Gallery.mk and CppunitTest.mk, where 'xcsxcu' in CONFIGURATION_LAYERS is changed and 'module' is no more used.I hope something like this is possible.. patches to remove $(OUTDIR)/xml are almost done ;-)btw: 'xcsxcu' and 'res' in CONFIGURATION_LAYERS in instsetoo_native/CustomTarget_setup.mk have the same value, is it right ?Otherwise only 'xcsxcu' is now used AFAICS, so possibly also configmgr can be simplified ?

Patch Set 1:"Sorry, that the patch is big. Important bits are Gallery.mk and CppunitTest.mk, where 'xcsxcu' in CONFIGURATION_LAYERS is changed and 'module' is no more used. I hope something like this is possible.. patches to remove $(OUTDIR)/xml are almost done ;-)"That would mean that the affected modules would now (circularly, at the module level) depend on postprocess, right?  (Not that is necessarily a bad thing to introduce such "false" module-level circular dependencies.)"btw: 'xcsxcu' and 'res' in CONFIGURATION_LAYERS in instsetoo_native/CustomTarget_setup.mk have the same value, is it right ? Otherwise only 'xcsxcu' is now used AFAICS, so possibly also configmgr can be simplified ?"Each of "xcsxcu", "res", and "module" parse slightly different sets of files, cf. configmgr/source/components.cxx.  What you loose with the changes to CppunitTest.mk is to read the localized instdir/*/share/registry/res/*.xcd files, which also include the fallback *-en_US.xcd ones, which might or might not be a problem for (some of) the tests.  But if it turns out to be a problem, we could easily add that afterwards.

Patch Set 5: This need some tweaks before it is mergedAlso here some more explanation would be great, as this is not iOS-only code, but cross-platform.So the commit comment is a bit misleading, too.

Patch Set 5:The vigra::copyImage is not handling copy areas in the same image so the code is checking whether the src and dst are same buffer and directing it to scaleImage which is very slow.The whole concept of pixel accessors is a huge overhead in the case of direct pixel copy (vigra::copyImage is also using pixel accessors).The idea here was to identify when direct memory copy is applicable (when src.size==dst.size && src.format==dst.format) and use direct memory block copy and not pixel wise copy.The result is 100x faster than vigra implementation.This direct copy is also handling the case when the src and dst are same buffer by copy it from bottom to top when needed and using memmove instead of memcpyabout using long or int for iterating i'm not keen on the cross platform details please advice how to do it properly.

Patch Set 5:Yep, no beef with the function per se - my verbose comment was more a documentation of why this is a good idea. ;)For the variables - please double-check this, but from the math, sal_Int32 should be sufficient. This is on all of our platforms interchangeable with int, so why not use that.If the original intend of long was 'something bigger than int', then you should use sal_Int64 (I doubt it is needed though).

Patch Set 7: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedFound the problem, it wasn't a fencepost error after all, but the problem was with 1- and 4-bit-per-pixel formats, where obviously it doesn't make sense to copy pixels with memmove() (unless one adds complexity by first copying an integral number of bytes and then any remaining bits). I am not sure that is worth it, for now I just added a condition to call the new implDrawBitmapDirect()  only for formats that use an integral number of bytes per pixel.

Patch Set 6:Spurred on by Tsahi's talk here at the conference, I took a look at this again, and added Tsahi's comment from above to the commit comment. However, I now notice that the patch causes a unit test failure in CppunitTest_basebmp_cpputest. I will try to see if I can figure out what is going on.

Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is mergedNearly there - great work finding the place! :-)  Unfortunately it does not work perfectly yet; it does the right thing when you are decreasing the size of sidebar (going with the mouse pointer to the right), but not when you are increasing it (going to the left).  Can you please have a look?Instead of computing the delta, and trying to apply it the right way, can we change it to act with absolute values there?  That way might be easier than trying to find out the constraints for the delt, couldn't it?

Patch Set 6:Great work - thank you for that! :-)Before pushing, I did a small modification; instead of if() for checking the max size, I changed that to a min() function which will ensure that we set the maximal size in case the mouse pointer was moved very far away.
Patch Set 6:Okay, thank you! :-)

Patch Set 3:Hi Kendy,We have 2 cases here, when the sidebar is attached towards the  lhs/rhs of screen. Under each case, we need to track whether the mouse is been dragged towards left or right, because of which the track of 'nDelta' is important.Moreover, I think the absolute values would not work perfectly for each desktop because mnMaxSize stores the container width of the current working desktop. For me, this value is 1366 which may differ for desktop to desktop, that is why I preferred using this value instead of working directly with absolute values.

Patch Set 3:I probably wasn't clear - as you can see, the delta is being used as a value to increase or decrease nNewSize.  Instead, I think we should compute nNewSize directly based on the mouse pointer position - this is what I meant by 'absolute'; ie. 'absolute' in the term that you will do nNewSize = function_of(mouse_pointer_position); not nNewSize = previous_size + nDelta;  Does this make sense, or is there anything else that prevents this?
Patch Set 4:This perfectly makes sense and I can't foresee any problems  with this better implementation idea :-)I've tried to implement this thought process in my patch set 4 pushed above!

Patch Set 2:This part is meant for LibreOffice 4.1, too. The reason is to cover the following regression:Until 4.0, one could do: Dim d as Date ' set d in some way aDateControl.DateMax = CDateToIso(d) d = CDateFromIso(aDateControl.Date)That's relatively easy. This patch intends to make possible on 4.1: Dim d as Date ' set d in some way aDateControl.DateMax = CDateToUnoDate(d) d = CDateFromUnoDate(aDateControl.Date)instead of the current more verbose / harder to come up with: Dim d as Date ' set d in some way Dim ud as new "com.sun.star.util.Date" ud.Year = Year(d) ud.Month = Month(d) ud.Day = Day(d) aDateControl.DateMax = ud ud = aDateControl.Date d = DateSerial(ud.Year, ud.Month, ud.Day)

(I have no idea really)).Apart from that, sprinkled a few comments across the patch, many of them minor nits anyway.

Patch Set 1:To be honest, I don't understand how these removals differ from <https://gerrit.libreoffice.org/#/c/274/>. I mean by removing commented code I might also introduce merge conflicts, or not?Or is your comment only because I added braces in some parts to make the code more readable? If so, would it help to provide a second version (at the moment I am not sure how) with only removed code but nothing added?

Patch Set 1:removing commented sections is usually rather safe -- cherry-picking is somewhat robust against that. For blank lines, there is no convention on how many we should have were, so this might easily lead to a fight over that (and we shouldnt bother with that then). And brace-only changes are even more tricky: The might successfully merge -- but still be wrong.So as long as there are still germanisms in the codebase it would be awesome, if you stick to those! ;)
