Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is merged(19 inline comments)This is a lot of nice work. Unfortunately, it needs some improvements, see the inline comments. We need the clean up but we need to keep the readability. And do not break the code ;-)Also we should not change the style too often. Even the comments might create conflicts when merging fixes between branches.I wonder if you do the patch using a script or manually. I think that it is best to do this using some scripts (bash,sed, perl).In each case, I strongly suggest to split such changes into more commits next time. The big patch was wery hard to review (hard to keep concentration, my right hand was aching after going through all the pages). So, you could get faster feedback with a smaller patch. Also, you will be able to do the other parts better after the feedback. Finally, it will help you to keep concentration as well. Note that you even removed two pieces of code by mistake.

Patch Set 5: This need some tweaks before it is merged1) Is the helpcontent2 hunk of the patch intentional?2) It seems the patch mixes two ways: on one hand, it adds a support for restart being 0 (and using -1 for "not set"), but it also adds a boolean flag to "avoid" changing unsigned membes to signed ones. I think adding a new boolean member is fine, but then please check for that boolean everywhere, and don't do the 0 -> 1 change.3) Seems most of the heavy-lifting in core is about allowing a restart with value == 0, but the testcase doesn't check this, only a normal restart.I would suggest either adding a section with such a "zero restart" as well, of just do the fixes in two separate commits: one commit adding just the restart support, and an other fixing the zero restart corner case.

Patch Set 5:I mean, my understanding is:Previously, the page number offset was a single unsigned integer, where 0 meant "no restart", other values meant a restart with a positive value. This is obviously a problem if you want to have a restart with a zero value.The patch introduces bNumOffsetIsSet to signal if the page number offset is valid, this is a good move. However at other places it also starts to use -1 to signal that the page number offset is valid or not, so now we have two places storing the same info (bNumOffsetIsSet == true or page number offset == -1), which looks redundant.

Patch Set 5:I think I will simply remove the boolean flag, change it from 'unsigned int' to 'signed int' and analyze all the places that use the function to get the value, to make sure I don't corrupt any existing logic.That way - in the entire codebase - '0 or more' will mean a specific page start value, and 'negative value' means no page start value.

Patch Set 3:Hmm, when building with Clang after the patch, I get:TestCase.cpp:91:25: error: C++98 requires an accessible copy constructor for class 'CppUnit::TestCaseMethodFunctor' when      binding a reference to a temporary; was private [-Werror,-Wbind-to-temporary-copy]So maybe the compiler should be allowed to generate a default copy constructor for it after all?Also:../../include/cppunit/TextTestResult.h:26:16: error: 'CppUnit::TextTestResult::addFailure' hides overloaded virtual function      [-Werror,-Woverloaded-virtual]  virtual void addFailure( const TestFailure &failure );               ^../../include/cppunit/TestResult.h:85:16: note: hidden overloaded virtual function 'CppUnit::TestResult::addFailure' declared      here  virtual void addFailure( Test *test, Exception *e );               ^

Patch Set 3:Well, I cannot argue with the compiler. If it says that it wants a copy constructor, I will have to give it one. :-)I was not aware of that detail of the 98 C++ standard, and it is a bit unintuitive. Why should a copy constructor be called when constructing a temporary object?Anyway, I will check how to tell GCC to be strict about the 98 C++ standard, recompile and resubmit the patch.Is there anything I have to do apart from that, e.g., somehow reverting the commit?

Patch Set 3:The former warning goes away (of course) if I remove the private constructors for that class that your patch added, but the latter one is more complicated. The multitude of virtual and non-virtual addFailuer() methods in the multiple-inherited base classes of TextTestResult is quite confusing to me, and apparently also to the Clang version I use on Linux (clang version 3.2 (branches/release_32 170558)). But oh well.
Patch Set 3:No need to revert this change, I tried compiling cppunit with Clang just for completeness. (And the addFailure() problem was there even without this change.)

Patch Set 2: This need some tweaks before it is merged* The declaration in uno.h is not necessary; the definition in uno.hxx is enough.* The definition must be in namespace com::sun::star::uno.* For maximum generality, use std::basic_ostream<charT, traits> instead of std::ostream, as in e.g. include/rtl/ustring.hxx.* There is no need for a HANDLE_UNSUPPORTED_TYPE macro.  The type is readily available as a string via Any::getValueTypeName (and it would arguably be a good idea to always include it in the output, like "Any of type T with value V", or for cases where we have no code to print the value just "Any of type T," or something less verbose but containing the same amount of information).* The TypeClass values UNION and ARRAY are unused historic mistakes; and typelib_TypeClass_MAKE_FIXED_SIZE is an artefact of the UNO C++ language binding, not a legal value of UNO enum TypeClass.* Likewise, the TypeClass values TYPEDEF, SERVICE, MODULE, INTERFACE_METHOD, INTERFACE_ATTRIBUTE, UNKNOWN, PROPERTY, CONSTANT, CONSTANTS, and SINGLETON are only used to represent UNOIDL entities unrelated to the UNO type system.  They are never used for values of type Any.* Likewise, a UNO ANY cannot contain a nested ANY (cf. <http://www.openoffice.org/udk/common/man/typesystem.html>).  That is, all cases other than VOID, BOOLEAN, BYTE, SHORT, UNSIGNED_SHORT, LONG, UNSIGNED_LONG, HYPER, UNSIGNED_HYPER, FLOAT, DOUBLE, CHAR, STRING, TYPE, SEQUENCE, ENUM, STRUCT, EXCEPTION, and INTERFACE should be subsumed under  default:    assert(false); // this cannot happen    break;(And whenever I write code that lists all those UNO type system tags, I stick with the above order as given at <http://www.openoffice.org/udk/common/man/typesystem.html>, not the completely stupid and arbitrary one from the TypeClass enum.)* Add @since LibreOffice 4.2.

Patch Set 2:Also, code like  sal_Int64 i;  any >>= i;  o << i;has the problem that, in general, >>= can return false and not write a value into i, so "o << i" could read an uninitialized i.  Some compilers warn about that.  We do know that >>= will not fail in this case, so the best is probably  sal_Int64 i = sal_Int64(); // avoid uninitialized warnings

Patch Set 1:note to self: possibly this could be replaced by sax::Converterhttp://www.w3.org/TR/NOTE-datetime appears to be very similar to xmlschema2; only difference is that http://www.w3.org/TR/NOTE-datetime allows to omit elements so has the 3 additional forms YYYY     YYYY-MM   YYYY-MM-DDThh:mmTZD   that would be invalid xmlschema-2

Patch Set 1:actually i had a look at "ECMA-376 Part 1 3rd edition"(is this the relevant reference?) and it has:<quote>17.18.9ST_DateTime (Standard Date and Time Storage Format)This simple type's contents are a restriction of the W3C XML Schema dateTime datatype.</quote>which is apparently for the word processing part;then there is this about spreadsheets:<quote>18.17.4Dates and TimesEach unique instant in SpreadsheetML time is stored as an ISO 8601-formatted string, which is made up of adate component, a time component, and a timezone component.L.2.16.9.1Date Conversion for Serial ValuesAll date values stored in cells within a SpreadsheetML file are stored in the ISO 8601 format.</quote>yay - a standard with 2 different normative references for date formats!however can't find any reference to http://www.w3.org/TR/NOTE-datetime  in there - where did the idea come from that that was relevant?

Patch Set 3:> Lionel, any response to Michael's review?So, in general terms, the situation is that I stumbledupon broken code while doing something else and Ifixed it. Details:>> possibly this could be replaced by sax::ConverterYes, that seems desirable in the middle-to-long term.However, the name of the function referred to anotherstandard than what sax::Converter aims at, so I consideredit more prudent to fix the code "locally", referring to thestandard it purposes to implement, rather than replaceby a call to sax::Converter::parseISO8601 (or some such).Especially since I meant for this to go into our release branch(es).If someone wants to invest the time to merge this withsax::Converter, I agree it would enhance the code qualityof LibreOffice: one (hopefully not buggy) implementationof parsing date/time (that is well-tested because used much,tested by unittests, etc) instead of multiple implementationswith different bugs that possibly show up only in corner cases(and thus linger for a long time before being found).However, that someone is not me, at least not in the shortterm. > I had a look at "ECMA-376 Part 1 3rd edition" > (is this the relevant reference?)Dunno. Not my area of expertise. Looks plausible to me. > ST_DateTime (...) W3C XML Schema dateTime datatype > Dates and Time (...) SpreadsheetML (...) ISO 8601-formatted > string > Date (...) SpreadsheetML (...) stored in the ISO 8601 format > however can't find any reference to > http://www.w3.org/TR/NOTE-datetime in there > where did the idea come from that that was relevant?The function is called GetDateTimeFromW3CDTF. Duckduckgoing(or Googling) for W3CDTF makes it clear that "W3CDTF" usuallymeans http://www.w3.org/TR/NOTE-datetime, so I assumed thatthis was the format the function was supposed to parse. 1) Was the W3CDTF in the function name meant as a reference     to that note? Dunno, ask its author. 2) In that case, was the reference itself an error? Michael's     research seems to indicate this would be the case.IRC (or mailing list?) discussion also basically said that as faras we know, the timezone component of this fix may not mattermuch since Microsoft Office always writes UTC (Zulu) time,so the bug would never get triggered. I think that it is stillpreferable to fix the bug to avoid that other code calls thisfunction in situations where the bug happens.So, my opinion would be:1) As proactive safety, apply this patch to master & 4-1.    (possibly an adapted part of it to 4-0; adapted because    sub-second stuff is different in 4-0: centiseconds instead    of nanoseconds) 2) In master, provided we have a volunteer to unravel that     quagmire (that knows about OOXML or willing to find out     about it), merge with sax::Converter date/time-parsing     if appropriate... If not appropriate, maybe migrate this     function to sax::Converter (along with documentation-by-     comment explaining why we need different parsers for     different formats and the difference between them), so     that our date/time-parsing code is all in one place.Since nobody clearly vetoed this patch, I'm going to push "1)" to master soon, unless someone vetoes.

Patch Set 1:Kohei, since the origin of the "problem" is commit ac7acb0ab1329913b0cec79790adcde0263960be Author: Kohei Yoshida <kohei.yoshida@gmail.com> Date:   Thu Oct 11 16:13:12 2012 -0400    Merged SvTreeListBox and SvLBox.I'd appreciate if you took a look at this:Is there any nasty side-effect that I didn't think of in making Select() virtual?In other words: the virtual -> non-virtual change was not on purpose, right?Other classes that have an override (and thus impacted by this):SfxOrganizeListBox_Impl (sfx2/inc/docvor.hxx now renamed to include/sfx2/docvor.hxx)FmFilterNavigator (svx/source/inc/filtnav.hxx)NavigatorTree (svx/source/inc/fmexpl.hxx)

Patch Set 1:Side effect?  I'm not sure. The reason why I tried to reduce the amount of virtual methods on this class is to limit the amount of surprises and makes it easier to track who's using what method.  Turning this to a virtual would add that down-side again... Once a method becomes virtual, it also becomes harder to track how it's used, and making it more difficult to debug for all users of this class.The only way to be sure there is no side effect is to test all places where this class is used.... It's hard for me to say just by looking at the code change...

Patch Set 1:Well, since we clearly have four classes that try to override this particular method, to me it looks like the safest (for our release branches) to make it virtual so that the four derived classes "work as they did before".If we want to make Select() non-virtual, we can do that later in master, changing the four derived classes to achieve the same effect than they intend by overriding Select() in some other way.Does that sound reasonable? In other words, do you agree to this change for 4-0 and 4-1?
Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedSure, that's reasonable.
Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedSure, makes perfect sense, thanks!

Patch Set 1: Verified; This need some tweaks before it is mergedThis adds a new delete pPropertyBrowser;which is in total contradiction with the removed and still remaining comments: // Removes the property browser from the layout. (...) It'll destroy itself.and in baside3.hxx    // property browser (created by this, deleted by toolkit)    PropBrw* pPropertyBrowser;OTOH, I don't immediately see who/what ("toolkit") deletes pPropertyBrowser.So either: - these comments were wrong (and we had a leak before) - this patchset removes the "delete by toolkit" in a way that is not obvious to me - this patchset introduces a double deleteSo essentially, I'd like to clarify this before commit to 4-1.

Patch Set 1:This is indeed completely non-obvious.  It is the odd entanglement between Window and VCLXWindow life-cycles that makes this work; if PropBrw has already been destroyed by the time that DialogWindowLayout's ~Window calls UnoWrapper::WindowDestroyed, it has apparently already been removed from the datastructures that are walked there to destroy "children created with ::com::sun::star::loader::Java that would otherwise not be destroyed until the garbage collector cleans up."However, if you remove "delete pPropertyBrowser" from ~DialogWindowLayout, things will continue to work, too (~PropBrw will now be called again from UnoWrapper::WindowDestroyed as in the commit msg's backtrace, though of course it will no longer call back into DialogWindowLayout, what was causing the original problem).  So it might even be better to leave the explicit "delete pProperyBrowser" out and rely on this scheme of UnoWrapper::WindowDestroyed cleaning it up---I honestly don't know.

Patch Set 1:In theory yes, but somehow not calling Clear() didn't affect the formats of imported edit texts. I'd tested a variety of combinations.  And Clear() is expensive, so I left it out.Having said that, I'm not against putting Clear() back in, just to be safe.  We could put that right before we call SetText(), to ensure that we don't call Clear() for cells that don't use edit engine.

Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is mergedWork in progress. This is a quite complex dialog, full of corner conditions1) Widget sizes should be adjusted at will2) The Line preview (CTL_PREVIEW) need to be fixed for correct display3) To test the dialog: Create a spreadsheet with one graphic object and one line chart. 4) Inside the chart, select the data series line object and click "format selection". The icon sub-dialog now appears. In the icon sub-dialog, the menu button allows many choices. The #define scalars for the menu choices had to be adjusted. I have no idea on the scalar  values definition except by looking at the packing of the menuitem (order in packing).The Gallery option shows a long list of graphics objects, not all work, specially png's and svg's. This is a bug, and I wil file it when the patch is committed.5) Selecting the graphic object outside the chart will show arrow styles and corner & caps sub-menus. Adjust listbox sizes at will.6) The previous non-widget dialog had glitches in the enable/disable condition for the arrow styles starts/ends.7) A whishlist: Some GtK widgets (mostly listboxes and spinboxes) should have a label associated, so that Enable/Disable and Show/Hidecan be simplified (like checkboxes and radiobuttons).

Patch Set 1:My undersdtanding is that it reverts the code back to the state in 2001, see http://cgit.freedesktop.org/libreoffice/core/commit/?id=1903d481790c799a110cda43a436e472ab554aadThere was:--- cut ---- for( sal_Int32 nIdx = 0; nIdx < nCount; nIdx++ )- pState[nIdx] = getPropertyState( pNames[nIdx] );+ if( mpImpl->mpMaster )+ {+ for( sal_Int32 nIdx = 0; nIdx < nCount; nIdx++ )+ pState[nIdx] = getPropertyState( pNames[nIdx] );++ }+ else+ {+ for( sal_Int32 nIdx = 0; nIdx < nCount; nIdx++ )+ pState[nIdx] = getPropertyState( pNames[nIdx] );+ }--- cut ---This change added the if condition but still the same for-cycle was called in both ways.If I am not blind, David did a long cycle back to the pre-2001 code.

Patch Set 1:I still don't get it.. merging the logic from SvxShape::getPropertyState() and that now changed loop it results in    for( sal_Int32 nIdx = 0; nIdx < nCount; nIdx++ )    {        if( mpImpl->mpMaster )        {            pState[nIdx] = mpImpl->mpMaster->getPropertyState( pNames[nIdx] );        }        else        {            pState[nIdx] = _getPropertyState( pNames[nIdx] );        }    }which to me is not different from the current code except that it determines the condition inside the loop instead of outside. Note the leading underscore for the !mpImpl->mpMaster case in both versions, it is not the same method called.

Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)Two comments in addition to Eike's comment:* It would be good to give the rationale for this change in the commit message (presumably, to get it in line with the changed UNOIDL struct).* osl_getDateTimeFromTimeValue and osl_getTimeValueFromDateTime in sal/osl/w32/time.c needed no conversion precautions in the past, given that Windows SYSTEMTIME's wYear is a WORD (i.e., same underlying value range as sal_uInt16).  Now, strictly speaking, one would need to check that pDateTime->Year >= 0 before assining it to aSystemTime.wYear in osl_getTimeValueFromDateTime.  However, wYear is documented as "The valid values for this member are 1601 through 30827," so negative pDateTime->Year values would in practice wrap around to wYear >= 32768 > 30827 and SystemTimeToFileTime should return false, so everything should happen to work out fine.

Patch Set 3: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedLooks good, but the contents of the listboxes got lost. The "stringlists" of old ListBoxes in .src files can be described in .ui as GtkComboBoxText and fill the list into the "items" of that. (There is another more complicated way to do it with GtkComboBox by adding a ComboBox Model to them, but we only need to do that if we need to, e.g. associated data with an entry)

Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedOK, this looks great. Lot of work required for that seemingly small tabpage. Just two small things.a) Keep the %VARIABLE stuff in the new .ui stuff. There was a bug in the %PRODUCTNAME replacement for items in lists which I fixed now, so that probably was the problem there. So I'll push a follow up patch to restore those variables again.b) Use "bold" not "semibold" for the frame titles, cause that's what we used for all the other ones.c) The hungarian (light version) variable naming scheme in LibreOffice is aFoo for an object and pFoo for a pointer.

Patch Set 2:> Heh, I wonder if such table names are supported also by the other functionality, e.g. queries, views. Anyway, this fix allows users to rename them at least ;-)That's up to the database engine. Essentially, you have to understand that "Query" is an SQL command that is stored by LibreOffice in the .odb file. So the "name" of that query is something that is up to LibreOffice, the database engine never sees it. That's why "SELECT * from qryName" will not work, because this will send qryName to the database engine, and it does not know it.As far as queries are concerned, code archeology shows that this special treatment of '/' in query names dates back from a "new feature: hierarchical queries". I have no clue what this feature is :)However, views are a database engine feature. They are an SQL command that is stored by the database engine in the database. Their name is up to the database engine. As such, they are just like tables to LibreOffice: LibreOffice selects, updates, deletes, etc from them directly (as far as supported by the database engine).

Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedIt makes the table visible and the change looks sane => it is great step forward => pushing.Heh, I wonder if such table names are supported also by the other functionality, e.g. queries, views. Anyway, this fix allows users to rename them at least ;-)

Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is mergedAndras is right: the 64bit dlls are copied to solver/bin so that the installer finds them since they are packaged as files, while the 32bit ones are in some mystery MSM thingy and (apparently) don't need to be in solver.confusingly the same find_msvc_x64_dlls function also finds debug dlls (for the build CPU architecture, not necessarily 64bit), which should not be in the installation set; i'm not sure if it's actually necessary to copy these to solver/bin nowadays (AFAIR it was needed for MSVC 2008 but they should actually be installed on the system by MSVC).so clearly there's some need for cleanup here.

Patch Set 2:So this script would replace occurrences of e.g.  #include "sal/config.h"with  #include <sal/config.h>The latter is wrong, or at least less portable than the former (and thus the script should never be used to modify the code base).  The <...> form is for standard headers (provided through the compiler), while the "..." form is for arbitrary source files (provided by the compiler's client).  (The use of "header" in the Standard does not necessarily reflect colloquial usage of that term.  The exact mechanisms are implementation-defined in any case, but the <compiler/platform> vs. "client" is the general idea.  And I know that lots of places in the code erroneously use the <sal/config.h> form, but that doesn't mean that it is good; it just never bothered anybody enough in practice to fix it.)

Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, but someone else must approveMikl鈹溾攤s, thanks for your review. The simplicity of the patch is conscious. Using the character sequence "\t" is an artificial problem in footnote numbering, but you can specify it using standard Unicode methods, adding a zero width non joiner between "\" and "t" (U+200C).This patch fixes a real problem (*bug of the user interface* distorts the document, prohibits the stable work of a fine workaround for a long-term problem). It is not the *ideal* solution, but there were more than 10 years to fix the original problem, the missing right aligned footnote numbering, without any known result (only my Graphite solution with Linux Libertine G and Biolinum G a few years ago). I was very glad to find a general workaround not depending my particular font enhancements a few days ago, fixing it with this patch, but if you will be able to fix the original problem in a more proper way (eg. adding a check box for right alignment) for LibreOffice 4.1, I won't want to force this patch. This is only a temporary UI fix to keep stable document format. More about this problem (in Hungarian): http://libreoffice.hu/2013/06/13/jobbra-zart-labjegyzetszamozas/Thanks again. Laci

Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedThe root of the problem, that vcl's Edit control does not handle TAB character for some reason. Maybe it makes sense, maybe not. This patch can be accepted as a temporary solution to the specific problem. Of course "temporary" may mean yet another 10 years. :) I'll extend the help to document this great improvement.

Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is mergedIf you want to turn Automatic and AutoSize into one string, I would rather go for AutoSize instead. Patch Set 1:I prefer to review this patch because:1) it doesn't solve the problem (blank page), just fixes the crash2) is it the good way to fix this?a) If yes, does it mean we should propagate this into the whole file? (at least)b) If no, how to deal with this in a clean/efficient way?

Patch Set 1:The root cause is that this is not a normal docx file, it's under the http://schemas.openxmlformats.org/wordprocessingml/2006/2/main namespace, which was used by some beta version of Word. I think for now all we want to do is just not crashing on this input. Even if later support for this old namespace is added, it's always a good idea not to crash on unexpected namespaces.

Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is merged(1 inline comment)This looks like it changes the operation from thread-safe to thread-unsafe. For a well-known example of this issue, see e.g. the difference between strtok and strtok_r in libc. Unless access to the ShapeList is always mutex'ed (wich I don't see as being the case), this is unsafe.There are several alternatives how to proceed to make traversing the list linear:1) Just use getList() and iterate over that2) implement the C++/STL iterator concept for ShapeList and use that in calling code instead of getNextShape

Patch Set 1: Do not mergeunfortunately there's a substantial problem here - Fedora ships jpeg 6 and the maintainer has publicly stated that packaging jpeg 8 will not happen:http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.linux.redhat.fedora.devel/173253http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.linux.redhat.fedora.devel/173299so we should not have a hard dependency on any features that are not in jpeg 6.
Patch Set 2:So now we are checking for JERR_BAD_CROP_SPEC, does it work fine on Fedora?

Patch Set 2:Michael, if you download the vanilla libjpeg fom here http://www.ijg.org/files/ you don't have JERR_BAD_CROP_SPEC in jpeg6b but you have it in jpeg7. Then from a user point of view JERR_BAD_CROP_SPEC means nothing and i'd prefer suggest a version that to force one download and grep source code. I think fedora (and other distros i suppose) have patched versions?

Patch Set 4:I am not really happy about the commit message. Reading it, it is hard to understand what effect the patch actually has. Please don't use passive voice. Write simple, imperative statements describing what effect the patch has.If you need to refer to the behaviour of code before the patch, be explicit, as in "Foo previously did bar", not "The way it works now". (Saying how something works "now" is ambiguous, does it mean "now, after this patch" or "now, before this patch".)Instead of "saving to docx is fixed", say "fix saving to docx". (But does the patch really fix saving to docx in general, was that broken? Or do you mean compared to a previous version of the patch? In that case, no need to mention it, once this goes into git, any iterations ("patch sets") it had in gerrit is irrelevant.
Patch Set 4:Sure. And sorry for nitpicking about the commit message...

Patch Set 2: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedI think the bounds are indeed safe, but this method is such a train wreck it doesn't hurt to be safe, so I added a bounds check and tweaked the commit message to include the easy hack id

Patch Set 1:Is this a fix for some easy hack? If so, please include "fdo#NNN" in the first line of the commit message, where NNN is the bug number.If not, please be more verbose on what problem your commit fixes/improves.

Patch Set 1:The commit message should be one line of plain, readable English. Not a bunch-of-words-with-hyphens. And it would be very nice to have more than one line of commit message: An explanation of the rationale for the code change. Sure, this can seem silly for a two-line change, but still.

Patch Set 4:It does find the ICU, but there is then a call of pkg-config again to get CXXFLAGS. I am not sure whether they are really useful. Now in libcdr, we check whether the pkgconfig flags are set from outside and if they are, we simply don't call the pkg-config at all in that case. In this case a patching out of that call in configure itself could work
Patch Set 3:I have added a harfbuzz package, but I have trouble in making it use internal icu and freetype, and making the includes available to vcl.RepositoryExternal.mk changes made as well.

Patch Set 2:Hi Eike, I was unable to reply on the thread of the inline comments so I preferred to write those things here:If I don't make the changes in sc/source/filter/xml/XMLConverter.cxx, then on doing 'make' I get an error :/home/elixir/libo/sc/source/filter/xml/XMLConverter.cxx: In static member function 脭脟每static void ScXMLConverter::GetStringFromFunction(rtl::OUString&, ScSubTotalFunc, bool)脭脟脰:/home/elixir/libo/sc/source/filter/xml/XMLConverter.cxx:145:11: error: enumeration value 脭脟每SUBTOTAL_FUNC_SELECTION_COUNT脭脟脰 not handled in switch [-Werror=switch]cc1plus: all warnings being treated as errors .with --enable-werror [ I enabled this, since warnings are no good and mac crashes with warnings is what I've learnt through irc conversations ].So handling 脭脟每SUBTOTAL_FUNC_SELECTION_COUNT脭脟脰 in switch became necessary.The rest of xml file changes follow this change.And definitely I shall take care of indentation. :)I small doubt: Should the hidden rows be counted in 'Selection count', i.e. if the row was hidden, its value should be added or not?ThanksPrashant

Patch Set 2:> If I don't make the changes in sc/source/filter/xml/XMLConverter.cxx, then on doing 'make' I get an error :As discussed on IRC, handle that with an empty case statement.> And definitely I shall take care of indentation. :)Good :-)> I small doubt: Should the hidden rows be counted in 'Selection count', i.e. if the row was hidden, its value should be added or not?Good question.. I think they should be treated the same as for the otherfunction cases so that Count2 and SelectionCount deliver the same resultif all selected cells are filled with data.

Patch Set 7:Hi Erack,Thanks for the review and suggestions! I'll definitely abide by them.I got my mistake for that small annoyance and has corrected it in my new patch. I've uploaded the patch against the latest master.May be this one should go finally :)Thanks,Prashant

Please avoid lines longer than 120 characters if possible.Please update your patch with this one.Other than that it looks good so far, there's just one little annoyance:If from a selection one cell is removed with Ctrl+LeftClick the count is not updated, it looks as if the current cell cursor position is always counted, even if a selection not including that position exists. This is not the case with for example the CountA function for which the count is correctly decremented by one.Could you please look into that?

Patch Set 1:Eike, I put your name there as reviewer as I am very much interested in your opinion regarding my toDO-comment.When nDaysinYear should be a double, the number can represent th enumber of days in a year in proportion to the number of days in the leap year and the number of days in the non-leap year.That seems to me the most 'exact' YEARFRAC-result that is possible.

Patch Set 1:This is already a step into the right direction. However, when already at it to really solve the YEARFRAC calculation the algorithms lined out in ODFF could be implemented, see http://docs.oasis-open.org/office/v1.2/cs01/OpenDocument-v1.2-cs01-part2.html#YEARFRAC and http://docs.oasis-open.org/office/v1.2/cs01/OpenDocument-v1.2-cs01-part2.html#Basis that for each mode gives the procedure to obtain day count and year count.Are you willing to do so? :-)

Patch Set 1:This patch fixed the conditional style handling of tables if importing docx files. As described in: http://social.msdn.microsoft.com/Forums/en-US/os_openXML-ecma/thread/1febafab-67d7-4a26-ac51-fec69a39c2fe/The cnfStyle doesn't have a function and should not be used to determine the table style, instead the tblLook property has to be used.I fixed this, I added a bugdoc that contains a table without cnfStyle Properties, this file looks bad in LO, but good in Word.As a side effect, now also the table corner styles are imported properly.Best regards,Sven

Patch Set 2: Verified; Looks good to me, approveduploaded a new patch set just to rebase on dtardon's makefile renaming, nothing changed here.a) For aligning things the trick is to have *another* size group with the labels in it, that way they all request the same size and it works out as expected.Well, it should, it appears I have a small bug in how that works. It seems that margins should be part of the request, but I'm adding those on after the request, not as part of the request. But we can workaround that by putting a one element box around the elements with margins and put those boxes into the size group instead. That way it works now, and will continue to work after I change the request+margin logic.b) The tristates are a pain, I thought they would be very rare elements. Catch is that they are always set to "state unknown" on .ui load, while in .src load they default to "state nocheck". So, yeah, to be super sure that the logic is unchanged its best to set them explicitly in .cxx to "state nocheck". I'll do that in a follow up patch.c) As an aside, the accessibility relation between the checkbox and the numeric field can be retained in the .ui with label-for/label-by under the a11y tab of glade (wheelchair icon). If it was a label and a numeric field then the mnemonic_widget relationship would add a default accessibility label-for/label-by relationship which is why the other "Start at" element doesn't need or have that.

Patch Set 4:This code looks like it concerns the query design UI.If that function is called each time the user changes something in there, then the field name/formula (aField string in the code) can definitely be empty, since the user can type anything. Whether that is a valid choice, and whether we catch that "user error" earlier is another question. In other words: it may or may not be that in the case of an empty aField, that codepath is not taken at all. Given the situation, I'd rather not rely on aField's non-emptyness (too much).But from a semantic point of view, the issue is moot anyway, since that test should be aField == "*"and not aField.beginsWith("*")I'm changing that in master.

Patch Set 2:"Maybe there should be a check for length before accessing the element at operator[] as the comment describes @param"I'm not sure patch set 2 is actually an improvement.  Adding a check for a condition without knowing whether the condition can actually ever not hold is a slippery slope down "defensive programming" that leads to unmaintainable code.  ("What /are/ the invariants of that code?" people will start to ask, seeing a mixture of redundant and non-redundant checks.)Given that the original code did not check for validity of accessing index 0, that could either mean that it was sloppy and "cleverly" relied on the fact that both String and OUString are null-terminated, so accessing index 0 is always valid technically (and the check for '*' guaranteed to fail for the empty string), or that there's an invariant enforcing aField to be non-empty anyway.Only in the first case would patch set 2 be an improvement.  In the latter case, the correct fix would rather be an assert(!aField.isEmpty()).Maybe Lionel can shed some light on this?

Patch Set 2:Ricardo: Ah it was not meant that Patchset1 is not good. Only some loud thinking about GetChar()/operator[] and what happens if that accesses an index greater the string len.Stephan: I set you as reviewer to get an opinion, if it's a possible problem if operator[] accesses an index out of range. If yes, then maybe a check for that should be in the operator[] method. Or am I wrong?

Patch Set 2:"I set you as reviewer to get an opinion, if it's a possible problem if operator[] accesses an index out of range. If yes, then maybe a check for that should be in the operator[] method. Or am I wrong?"Yes, rtl::O[U]String::operator[] -- with documented prerequisite "index must be non-negative and less than length" -- should contain an assert(index >= 0 && index < getLength());  I'll take care of that.However, esp. in code that got converted from tools' String to OUString (where String::CharAt remains silent about its prerequisites), there may be "clever" code that relies on s[s.getLength()] returning null.  That code would now be caught (in --enable-debug builds) at runtime due to the assert, and can be fixed to be less clever and more explicit.(Though that does not necessarily pertain to the code in SelectionBrowseBox.cxx, where it is still unclear whether aField can legitimately be empty.)

Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedI think that it is an optimization. It goes though many objects in the "while(aIterator.IsMore())" cycle and makes notes which type of fill is used. The b*FillUsed variables are set to true if the given fill type is used and it never goes to false => it does not make sense to check the variables once they all are set to true, such check could not change anything.I think that we could actually end the cycle once both bLineUsed and bAllFillUsed are true. The variables can't change with more iterations :-)anyway, it is great change and I push it

Tried "File/Save As" as "HTML Document"    Result: Same as above.Did I anything wrong or the patch is incomplete, please?Is there any related bug number where I could find more details or a test document?Otherwise, I would be really happy to integrate it because it sounds very promissing.

Patch Set 1:This change is related to columns in text sections, not columns for pages. I guess page columns are not exported to HTML because there is really no generally applicable way of doing that; HTML pages do not have fixed height like pages in Writer do.To test this you need to- Open a new empty Writer document- Choose Insert -> Section- Go to Columns tab and type in a number, 3 for example, click Insert.- now you can see the little grey section markers, paste some long text inside those.- save as HTML, you should end up with a HTML document that has a MULTICOL element that contains the column count both in the old non-standard COLS-attribute and in the new css column-count attribute.PS. I hope this is the right way to respond to the review comment. I'm just trying to learn how to use this Gerrit tool.

Patch Set 1:Thanks for your patch.  Yup, I believe this patch does the right thing.  I only have two minor nitpicks that are both about aesthetics.  First one is that, we do use the 'b' prefix for boolean variables, so your aProceedHyperlink should actually be bProceedHyperlink.  The second one is that, it's probably better to return the function when bProceedHyperlink is false, which would make the code a bit easier to follow.  Anyway, since this is your first patch submission, I'll make these changes for you. :-)

Patch Set 2:I think the two load options should be set to not expand vertically, looks a bit silly.The warning could go under the dropdown that it applies to now that nothing has to be manually moved in the code.odfwarning never seems to appear but maybe that's a wider/theme bug

Patch Set 2:> I think the two load options should be set to not expand vertically, looks a bit silly.The reason I did it this way was because otherwise the width of the combo box would change dynamically depending on the current selection, and I wanted to avoid that. I guess I could have set the width to a fixed value, but I wanted the GUI toolkit to do the sizing, feels more flexible.> The warning could go under the dropdown that it applies to now that nothing has to be manually moved in the code.I put it in the end because it was there in the original code, and because otherwise I would have to leave an empty row there, or have everything under it move down when it appears. I thought I should try to keep all the GUI elements static, and not jump around when a user changes something, to avoid confusion.> odfwarning never seems to appear but maybe that's a wider/theme bugIt did appear for me under Linux Mint 14 MATE, what OS are you on?

Patch Set 2:> The reason I did it this way was because otherwise the width of the combo box would change dynamically depending on the current selection, and I wanted to avoid that.You could set Vertical Alignment to 'start' on the grid but that seems to break the text wrap...> or have everything under it move down when it appears.I think that's quite a good property for a warning but I'm not a UX guy so whatev :D

Patch Set 3: (2 inline comments)this looks plausible; apart from the ugly 0/1 as bools another point:how about checking if one of the comments is in footnote and the other in the footer?hmm... if the comments in ndarr.hxx are correct, footnotes are in GetEndOfInserts() which precedes GetEndOfAutotext() which contains the Headers/Footers, so this should actually work already (please add a comment that says so).

Patch Set 4:Thanks for your review.As far I tested, there is no need to distinguish the Footnotes from the Footers. This because the Footnotes are stored before the Footers, so the anchors are determined correctly. The only thing I improved in this patch is to check the anchor is placed in Footer or Footnote (by FindFootnoteStartNode() and FindFooterStartNode(). If this isn't the right way, please feel free to say so, but it works (please also see my test document in the commit comment and bug report).Kind regards,Joren

Patch Set 6:"Input: export PYTHON_LIBS="-lpython2.7" export PYTHON_CFLAGS="-I/usr/include/python2.7" ./autogen.sh"This is not enough, it did not work before either!You need to use also --enable-python=system :-)Really we don't want people to build with python 2 ;-)

Patch Set 6:>This is not enough, it did not work before either! You need to use also --enable-python=system :-)>Really we don't want people to build with python 2 ;-)Or that's really messy ;-) and definitely doesn't comply with the rule of least surprise:i have:  --with-system-libsi have python 2.7 up and running on the system i do not have python 3.3 (only 3.2)i do pass PYTHON_FLAGS aboveand it still pick up the wrong python.i would suggest to support python 2.7 as the first class citizen without all that noise above (i. e. without CFLAG & LIBS):if --with-system-libs passed and no other python options provided then try to pick up the best system python or fail:try system-python 3.3try system-python 2.7FAIL unless internal python option override the global --with-system-libs provided.How that sounds?

Patch Set 4:Too late now, but I must say that from the point of view of somebody who has to debug code, anonymous namespaces are a bit (but just a little bit) more painful than plain old "static" functions. Much more and harder to type in gdb something like "b '(anonymous namespace)::foobar'" than "b foobar". IMHO there is nothing wrong with static methods...

Patch Set 4:See http://www.informit.com/guides/content.aspx?g=cplusplus&seqNum=463 , http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4726570/deprecation-of-the-static-keyword-no-more etc. It seems this is just a matter of taste. There is no technical reason why anonymous namespaces would be "better" than static, and the "deprecation" of static was commonly seen as meaningless (because no way were they going to actually remove that feature from the language and break tons of existing, perfectly fine, code), and was later withdrawn.

Patch Set 3: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedGenerally I'm not a big fan of turning a nice, localised readable token like 'static' on a method into something that requires hunting about the code to see what namespace we're inside ;-)On the other hand - since there are some nice inline fixes (from the C++ migration), and dunging out that sunpro mess - lets put this in :-)I'd not want to see the code de-staticised-generally though without a wider consensus.Thanks !

Patch Set 2:Normally with this patch, all method marked static are now in an anonymous namespace (static method is deprecated in c++98 if I remember well), so visibility doesn't change, except if I did a mistake.

Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedSetAccessibleRelationMemberOf: I think the old use of "SetAccessibleRelationMemberOf" is a kind of workaround to show that those widgets are logically all children of a pseudo-frame in the a11y view. Now that they are truly children of a real frame I think we don't need them anymore.If it turns out that being implicit children of a frame isn't sufficient for a11y, then hopefully we don't need to manually insert them everywhere but instead make one centralized change down in vcl to automatically present children of frame as "AccessibleRelationMemberOf"s.RID_SVXQBX_DELETE_HEADFOOT: This one is still in use, so I added it back

Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, approveda) Don't use seperaters between the buttonbox and main area. I know the original has them, but we're not putting them explicitly into conversions. If there is a big demand for them then we can build it into the builder to do it in one place (but I'd prefer not to )b) Bold headings for frame labelsc) Watch out for title vs name for the toplevel dialog

Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this(2 inline comments)As I see these comments dont point to real problems, but I have noticed two other one. 1. In SQL view, users can use 0*[0-9]* numbers and with changing view these numbers will be 'transported' to the LimitBox, which cant contain such numbers.2. During initialization the default 'All' value is not sent to OQueryController. So when the content of LimitBox is not changed, the SQL statement will contain a 'LIMIT' keyword without value which cause syntax error (m_sLimit is empty by default).So need some improvement.

Patch Set 1: Verified* Build 4ca857384 on WINDOWS https://ci.libreoffice.org/job/buildbot/62 : SUCCESS* Build 4ca857384 on LINUX https://ci.libreoffice.org/job/buildbot/60 : SUCCESS* Build 4ca857384 on MAC https://ci.libreoffice.org/job/buildbot/61 : SUCCESS

2. Don't have to deal with overflow\underflow. The LimitBox(ComboBox) and the SQLParser also use OUString so I suppose they pay attention for such problems.2. Hindi numbersYes, It will be good to get some advice to solve this checking generally.3. grabFocusFromLimitBoxLimitBox sends data to OQueryController just when it loose its focus. So to have recent data for SQL run for example, we have to grab focus from LimitBox.In what situations appears it? For example when a new LibreOffice user try out this feature. He\She is adding new limit values and running to see the result. In this casethere is no effect of adding limit, because with clicking on the run toolbar item the focus is stayed on the LimitBox, so its data is not sent to the right place and not used in the running SQL statment."

Could you please change the patch to disable OLE objects only inside tables? you can check for m_pCurrentBuffer, if it's not null, we are inside a table (or similar complex container).Also, a testcase is missing, see here:http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/sw/qa/extras/Or if that sounds too complicated, I can create the testcase for you after the patch itself is correct.Thanks,Miklos

Patch Set 2:> I don't get why m_pBroadcaster is a pointer with NULL checks when there seems to be no way it cannot be non-NULL. Presumably a reference would be sufficient there.Right, reference would be just fine. It is just that at one point I thought it would be necessary to handle SFX_DYING hint, in which case the pointer would be cleared, avoiding use of a dead object in destructor. It turned out this is not really needed, but I forgot (or was too lazy; your pick :-) to change the pointer into a reference.

Patch Set 1:Note that in order to approve this patch, I think the following steps are necessary:1) Somebody needs to have an Apple code-signing certificate in their keychain. Or maybe a certificate issued by some other entity would also work, or a self-signed one, I don't know. (I only have experience of handling Apple-provided ones in Xcode.)2) And then do a full "normal" (Intel) release build of the 4-0 branch3) And then somebody (else) needs to try the produced dmg on machines running 10.4, 10.5 and 10.6 and check that the app runs fine, that the signed binary doesn't cause problems in an older dynamic linker which doesn't know what the signature stuff inserted into the binary means.Alternatively, if somebody can find a definitive reference that promises signed binaries will work also on 10.[456], I guess we should trust that...(For 10.7 and 10.7 I think it is safe to assume the signing won't cause trouble, and for 10.8 where Gatekeeper is checking for signatures, I have already verified that signing indeed helps to get rid of the scary warning about "unidentified developer".)

Patch Set 1:Thank you for your suggestions, I will change the code (and test it) and submit as patch set 2.All these handy functions as ScRange::Intersects and ScDocument/ScTab::FindAreaPos are hard to find if you don't know where to look for them. And just browsing through the code is nigh impossible ... But I try to learn :)

Patch Set 1:yes finding those methods is hard, really sometimes given the size of the code its a case of a) someone tells you or b) you come across it while looking at the issue you are trying to fix or c) you came across the code previously ( and managed to remember it )you are doing a great job in anycase, don't dispair, calc is tough nut to crack and you seem to be managing fine. Anyway think we are there with this patch and we should be able to push your next update

Patch Set 1:Thanks for your supportive message.I try to concentrate on calc and so be able to use what I found out earlier (if indeed I could only remember it).The intersect-check has been changed and works fine, the FindAreaPos is a dead-end (if that's proper English). It stops at hidden columns/rows and continues until it finds a non-empty cell. Imagine a sheet with some data in row 1 and some in row 2 and you wanting to cut row 2 and paste+shift down above row 1. FindAreaPos will check (MAXROW-2)*MAXCOL cells, where only MAXCOL cells need to be checked. But I started looking around in the code and found ScDocument::IsEmptyBlock() and that looks promising. Still building though (slow machine at my work) and I want to test it before submitting the new patch set.
Patch Set 2:looks really good, thanks for your patience and perseverance. I will test ( and push ) it later on

Patch Set 1:I did it on first assignmentvoluntarily.'size' can be modified by the call to 'RegQueryValueEx'. It is reseted to sizeof(value) before each of these calls within the function.I wanted to be consistent with this behavior. So IMO it is better to remove first assignment.

Patch Set 1:That is not what I was meaning.RegQueryValueEx can change the value in 'size', so it makes sense to me to explicitly assign it before each call. There is no reason to have the first one different from the others.See comments below.static void add_NS_keys( HKEY hKey, PluginLocationMap & rPlugins ){    TCHAR value[MAX_PATH];    DWORD dwType, size;    // 4.7    size = sizeof(value);                                          <---- size is reseted before calling RegQueryValueEx    if (::RegQueryValueEx(        hKey, _T("Plugins Directory"), NULL, &dwType,        (LPBYTE)value, &size ) == ERROR_SUCCESS &&                 <---- size can be changed        (dwType == REG_SZ || dwType == REG_EXPAND_SZ))    {        addPluginsFromPath( value, rPlugins );    }    // 6    size = sizeof(value);                                          <---- size is reseted before calling RegQueryValueEx    if (::RegQueryValueEx(        hKey, _T("Install Directory"), NULL, &dwType,        (LPBYTE)value, &size ) == ERROR_SUCCESS &&                 <---- size can be changed        (dwType == REG_SZ || dwType == REG_EXPAND_SZ))    {        int n = size / sizeof (TCHAR);        if ('\\' != value[ n -2 ])        {            value[ n -1 ] = '\\';            value[ n ] = 0;        }        addPluginsFromPath( ::lstrcat( value, _T("Plugins") ), rPlugins );    }    size = sizeof(value);                                          <---- size is reseted before calling RegQueryValueEx    if (::RegQueryValueEx(        hKey, _T("Plugins"), NULL, &dwType,        (LPBYTE)value, &size ) == ERROR_SUCCESS &&                 <---- size can be changed        (dwType == REG_SZ || dwType == REG_EXPAND_SZ))    {        addPluginsFromPath( value, rPlugins );    }}

Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedGreat, code converted correctly. Some small nits...ObjectNameDialog:  - Lets make dialogs resizeable unless there's a reason not to. The old ones weren't resizeable because of the lack-of-layout defect.   - some pixel size-requests on edit-boxes, maybe worried about its default size? So I set a "width in chars" on the edit box to make it wide enough, that way we don't have to worry about measuring things in pixelsObjectTitleNameDialog   - Lets make it resizeable, as above.  - The original had a scrollbar, so added a scrolledwindow to it with always vertically scroll  - For the textview to give it a default height, rather than using pixels I let it take its width by expand to the above edit widget width  - For its height, added a non-translated text buffer with 5 blank lines and tweaked the ctor to set that as its permanent height request  - GtkTextView maps to class VclMultiLineEdit instead of MultiLineEdit. This is a sort of bizarre impossible to know about corner case. But they should be equivalent, so I just changed MultiLineEdit to VclMultiLineEditNameDialog:  - width requests as above  - set name_entry as the mnemonic widget of name_entryMessBox:  - I set the label to be vertically centered for the resizeable caseI've been keeping things as one dialog per .ui file, which as a side effect allows no name collisions between various "ok" buttons being called "ok", etc, so I split them up like that.

Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit thisHmm, I am not sure that I like this change. It does not create the formatting entry without any explanation. You were able to edit the unused formatting and add the range later in the past.For example, imagine that you define some formatting, forget to define the range, and press the "Add" button. You will not know why the entry was not created. You will need to select everything again and again until you find why it does not work :-)IMHO, the best solution would be to preffil the range with the current selected cell(s). For example, the DataPilot or Chart is created from the current selection by default as well.Hmm, the prefil would be annoying if you lose some older formatting  in the selected cells. In this case, I would prefer to leave the behavior as is and fix it with the error dialog for 4.1. IMHO, the behavior is more annoying with the patch than without it.BTW: I really like the conditional formatting. It is very cool and useful feature. Thanks a lot for the hard work in this area.

Patch Set 1:The reason why this change is a good thing is that being able to define conditional formats without ranges and later storing them in ScConditionalFormatList may result in crashes.Calc core always assumes non-empty conditional format ranges because they have to be kept in sync with the cell attribute storage. Inside ScConditionalFormatList::UpdateReference we will additionally delete ScConditionalFormat instances with an empty range. I also added a check to xmlcondformat.cxx that removes all conditional formats that are imported without a range to prevent a crash.The idea is to add for 4.1 an error dialog that makes clear that you either have to define a range or use Cancel. This is however not possible in 4-0 because of the string-freeze.
Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedOK, I am fine with the change then. We do not want crashes :-)

Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit thisThanks for your patch submission.The intent of this change is good, but the code needs a bit more polishing in minor details.1) We use BSD bracing style which isif (foo){    ...}else{    ...}rather than if (foo) {    ...} else {    ...}Inconsistency in bracing style affects readability. Let's make it consistent.2) Normally, when branching with an if statement on a boolean conditional, it's best to set the code block for the true condition first, followed by the one for the false condition in the 'else' block.  So in this case it's best to doif (Application::GetSettings().GetLayoutRTL()){    <code for RTL>}else{    <code for non-RTL>}This will make following the logic of the code a teeny bit easier for human brain.3) Last point is that, the only differences between the RTL and non-RTL case is the value of nXOffset (the first line in each block) and the rendering::TextDirection enum value (the last line in each block). Let's just make these values conditional while keeping the rest of the code outside the if statement block. Code duplication done this way is not a very good style. Let's fix that...

Patch Set 1: No scoreBtw, Regarding my earlier comment, 3) is the most important point, while 1) and 2) are just minor nitpicking.  So, once 3) is fixed then the patch is in good shape to be committed I would say.

Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit thisRemoving functions from sal.map strictly speaking requires bumping SONAME, and that is too disruptive a change for merely getting rid of those deprecated functions.Like what has been done for osl/semaphor.h, please:* do remove rtl/memory.h and rtl/source/memory.cxx,* but keep sal.map intact and add aborting stubs for the removed functions to sal/osl/all/compat.cxx* add a section to <http://wiki.documentfoundation.org/Development/LibreOffice4> for incompatible changes in LO 4.1, and add the removal of rtl/memory.h there* Prefix the commit message with "API CHANGE:"

Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this* "if S1 exits before dialog establishment":  Are you concerned about S1 exiting cleanly while the connection protocol is running?  In that case, the logic to not allow S1 to terminate while the protocol is running should be fixed (in case it is broken).  If you are rather concerned about S1 crashing midway through the connection protocol, then (a) the comment "the other instance may have already terminated" is misleading (should talk about "crash" rather than "termination"), and (b) it is unclear to me whether one wants to really (re-)do all the actions specified on the command line -- e.g., the command line might contain a print request, and from the crash of S1 S2 cannot tell whether or not that had already succeeded or not.* addArgument returning false is a permanent error, it does not make sense to retry establishing a connection in that case.

Patch Set 2:Yes, I intend to do it (btw, it seems another place in Windows startup code implements this protocol, but I believe it's unused: see desktop/win32/source/officeloader/officeloader.cxx).But I'm also fixing a related Windows only issue #33484.I hope to get both patches ready soon (what's the deadline for 4.0 ?)

Patch Set 1:Wouldn't it be better to keep throwing a PropertyVetoException from setSize, but let setHeight/Width translate that into a WrappedTargetRuntimeException?  That way, other clients of setSize would not be affected.Also, constructing an instance of Reference<XInterface> from *this confuses me -- not sure why it works here and if all compilers will accept it.  The standard idiom there is static_cast<cppu::OWeakObject*>(this).

Patch Set 2:> Wouldn't it be better to keep throwing a PropertyVetoException from setSizeYes, fair point. Corrected that.> but let setHeight/Width translate that into a WrappedTargetRuntimeException?No, throwing a WrappedTargetRuntimeException still leads to a crash.> Also, constructing an instance of Reference<XInterface> from *this confuses me -- not sure why it works here and if all compilers will accept it. The standard idiom there is static_cast<cppu::OWeakObject*>(this).Other places in the code definitely do it from *this, but indeed far fewer than with the static_cast<cppu::OWeakObject*>. I must have seen only the "bad" examples before...

Patch Set 6:So is the lesson learned here that it's pointless to write long (negative) reviews in gerrit?

Patch Set 6:No. For a better visibility the discussion was moved to dev ML and the minimal consensus there was to preserve the old option name. All other negative comments were fixed. So the lesson learned is that even something controversal like that get done after some discussion.

Patch Set 6:I read all the comments and the patch before merging it - is something broken ? having just got yet-another build-from-clean without the symbols I was expecting [ true I moved machines and had and older autogen.lastrun ], and in view of the attractive ascii-art in the commit message - I was seduced by this patch :-)Is there anything actually wrong with the version that got committed that can't be fixed ? :-)
Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit thiswell, not all archs use -Os afair, and even then e.g. Debian policy says -O2. *If* you submitted this please leave optimization alone :)

Patch Set 2: Do not submit(2 inline comments)With this patch there would be two independent ways to control whether -g is used, the other being ENABLE_DEBUGINFO_FOR, and moreover this breaks the other way, i.e. the selective debuginfo feature.It also might be a good idea to reconsider the "symbols" name, unless you want to repeatedly explain it to people who for some reason keep getting confused by all this stuff over and over again (it's a lot of fun I can assure you, and "debug" vs "debug symbols" is just asking for it).It possibly might make sense to fold --enable-symbols and --enable-selective-debuginfo in one option and functionality.Finally, I suggest the commit message just says that the option is back in order to avoid having to specify -g or similar manually, instead of the long list of claims you copied from the ML, as a number of those claims are questionable or just plain incorrect.

Patch Set 2:I was not questioning symmetrical, balanced and clearly visible braces, I was talking about the braces around single commands that only add visual clutter. And that is why it is a matter of taste. As this is not "your" code (it is not, is it, you wouldn't be asking for review otherwise, or would you?), with this approach the next person to do a random modification to this code could very well revert all those back, and so forth. And that's why people shouldn't do "cleanups" to their taste of code they otherwise do not work on.As for the changed sal::static_int_cast, either put that back to make it visible the conversion is taking place, or you can remove the C-style cast altogether, as the C-style cast serves no purpose there at all.

Patch Set 1: (4 inline comments)When I sift through 1000s of line of code, with sometimesindividual function of 500+ lines, symmetrical, balanced and clearly visible braces are not a matter of taste anymore, and it sure serve the purpose of allowing me to read and re-readthe code.But It is true that for reviewing purpose they get in the way. I have tried to keep most of these in a separate commits so far, but here I have left too many behind, sorry

Patch Set 1:The whole check appears to be rather pointless. Do we actually use the result anywhere?
Patch Set 1:Not sure if it is actually used anywhere. I just wanted to get rid of the warning in my tinderbox.Also we force the 0x into the cxxflags bit later down in the configure.

Patch Set 1:Also system boost supports it, there is no reason why it should not do so.You only have to use the header with the standard enabled in cxxflags, and if you don't it warns on you like this:                 from /usr/include/boost/unordered_map.hpp:16,                 from conftest.cpp:69:/usr/lib/gcc/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu/4.6.3/include/g++-v4/bits/c++0x_warning.h:32:2: error: #error This file requires compiler and library support for the upcoming ISO C++ standard, C++0x. This support is currently experimental, and must be enabled with the -std=c++0x or -std=gnu++0x compiler options.

Patch Set 1:So why not drop the check (and all mention of HAVE_BOOST_UNORDERD_MAP in configure.ac) completely?  A system boost will hopefully have an unordered_map.hpp that works just fine with the compiler switches that will be used during the build -- and otherwise, we'll get a compile-time error at least anyway.

Patch Set 1:Stephan's idea sounds good to me. In general, I think we occasionally try too hard to figure out at configure time if compilation will fail later. Sure, it can save some hour(s) of waiting before the compilation then fails, but it adds a lot of complexity to the configure.ac, with corresponding possibilities that the check is wrong anyway, either gives a false positive or false negative.
Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, approvedIf you know of places where this could make the code simpler, sure, why not.

Patch Set 1:Is it necessary to introduce the AsciiL variants as new API? They are meant to complement the obsolete RTL_CONSTASCII_USTRINGPARAM macro, so they preferably should not be introduced as new code.

Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this* Setting MALLOC_PERTURB_ to zero reportedly (<http://udrepper.livejournal.com/11429.html>) disables it, so we should make sure $rndbyte is never zero.* Trying   dd if=/dev/urandom bs=1 count=1 2>/dev/null | od -tu1 | cut -s -d " " -f2does not always produce a number for me, as od outputs the 1-to-3-digit number right aligned, so cut -f2 sometimes hits "nothing" in between leading spaces.* I personally never --enable-linkoo, so it would be cool if we could put this somewhere where everybody can benefit (though I have no good idea where that would be; maybe its time to split program/ooenv in two, things that are useful for all developer runs, like MALLOC_CHECK_=2, and things specific to linkoo, like fiddling with LD_LIBRARY_PATH).

Patch Set 1:I agree with michael stahl that a fixed bogus value would be 'better'... ideally something 'displayable' and very unlikely to be the repeased trailing end (that is not 0x20 :-) ) '#' for instance.

Patch Set 1:maybe I am doing something wrong but doesn't seem to work as expected. When I select Grids(lines & characters) initially max base text size is 20, characters per line is 24. If I change max base text to 10 then I see no changes in characters per line ( previously after apply and reopen I would have seen 48 for chars per line ) however if I now enter 5 for max base text I get 48 ( and after apply and reopen I get 96 ) it's like the change is based on the previous value.

Patch Set 1:Hi Noel,Thank you for your review.I agree your observation, anyway the point is when the entered value reflects on new Characters per line's range.It is not just after entering "10" or "5" for max base text size, but further after the focus leaved (e.g. typing tab key) to indicate end of editing.That timing is same as the existing synchronization of Lines per page's range following max base text size.Note also that the reflection occurs immediately after spinning the value by clicking up or down arrow.

Patch Set 1:discussing this with sberg, I agree that this change _should_ do no difference as otherwise the ::boost::unordered_map<>::erase(iterator, iterator) interface is useless.But it does: without this change and only with a std::list->std::deque replacement in vcl to evade possible C++11-ABI poisoning, LibreOffice crashes after some ~10 iterations of xmluno_api -- with the patch it:- ran 140 iterations once and then crashed on a different stacktrace- ran 250 iterations without any issueReverting the patch, I get:- the fdo#51324 stacktrace after 7 iterations- the fdo#51324 stacktrace after 1 iteration- the fdo#51324 stacktrace after 1 iteration- the fdo#51324 stacktrace after 6 iterationAs the change should not hurt a nonbroken boost::unordered_map implementation, might heal (or evade) a broken boost::unordered_map implementation and is more readable, I suggest to cherry-pick this to libreoffice-3-6

Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit thisIndeed, good catch, and the patch seems to be correct.But instead of all the indexOfAsciiL() with ugly and error prone hard coded length argument we now can benefit from the new internal::ConstCharArrayDetector indexOf() template, see sal/inc/rtl/ustring.hxx just before the indexOfAsciiL() declaration.So, instead ofaFilterName.indexOfAsciiL("impress8", 8)we can simply writeaFilterName.indexOf("impress8")It would be great if you could submit a new patch using that easier to read and maintain method.And yes, using >=0 is perfectly valid and fine.

We either need an empty static string (which I personally don't like) or check all callers and think about just returning by value and hope that it will optimized.

Patch Set 1:I will try to fix the memory leaks and upload a new patch. I agree that an empty static string wouldn't be elegant (although thats basically how it worked before with tools/string), so I will try to change the call sites, which should be possible as most other getString methods (including one in the same object, with other parameters) return by value.

Patch Set 1: Do not submitRegarding memory leaks when replacing EMPTY_STRING and ScGlobal::GetEmptyString() with new'ed instances of OUString:The empty String used so far is a refcounted instance to avoid creation of additional instances for every empty string. We should have a similar mechanism for OUString, e.g EMPTY_OUSTRING and ScGlobal::GetEmptyOUString(). So if you could just add such mechanism it would be fine.

Patch Set 2:I followed Eike's suggestion and added EMPTY_OUSTRING and ScGlobal::GetEmptyOUString() and changed the returns of empty strings to use these. That should remove the memleak. Thanks for the reviews

Patch Set 1:I think the problem is that your build for some reason decides to compile pyuno against the system python, which is very old (2.7) and should as fare as I know not be used. Would be interesting to understand why that happens. We should use the internal python on macOS as far as I know.

Patch Set 1:We are discussing this in IRC, commenting here just for completeness. It seems that the problem is caused by janIV having a separately installed newish Python in PATH, which fools the configure script into thinking that the "system" Python is good enough, and thus it sets the PYTHION_CFLAGS to point to the Python 2.7 headers in the SDK.

Patch Set 1:> If we now *know* that we will never want to use the Python 2.7 that > macOS presumably is stuck with as system Python, why does the > configure.ac even have code like: >  > PYTHON_CFLAGS="-I$FRAMEWORKSHOME/Python.framework/Versions/${python_version}/include/python${python_version}"we have hoped that one day Apple will upgrade its 5 year old system python to something current.  it looks like we may have to hope a little longer. > instead, if it notices that it thinks it should use a system Python > on macOS, it should AC_MSG_ERROR.that's a good idea, the python 2.7 support is really only supposed to be used in old enterprise distros that don't have python 3 and don't allow us to bundle python 3.

Patch Set 1:Called functions: probably setFloat / setDouble / setInt / setLong / ... or updateFloat / updateDouble / updateInt / updateLong / ...From the point of view of the driver, it should provide all of those, and the calling code chooses which one to call. Calling code can not only be LibreOffice C++ code, but also user macros, so it cannot be predicted what choice is made.When you create a table and select a DECIMAL or NUMERIC field type, don't you have the following field properties, including "Decimal places"?Entry requires: Length: Decimal places:Default value:Format example:The rounding may be because the driver tells the rest of LibreOffice that 0 decimal places are allowed. Or it may be in the configuration of the UI element. Create a form, and edit the properties of the form control: do you use a formatted field or a numeric field? In a numeric field you can set the decimal accuracy. Check what is put there.When all else fails, I single-step in a debugger from the control's "write to the database calls" into the different layers. But that is a bit heavy-weight :)

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1(1 comment)The idea to merge the two threads (callback handler and tile rendering) is reasonable, but we should discuss the approach.The starvation you noticed happens because you are using the tile-queue, which is designed for... well, yes, tiles! :)It reorders the messages such that it renders tiles in large blocks first. So with heavy typing the callback messages always end up getting overtaken by tiles, which the queue explicitly favors, thereby starving callback events.So this is one problem with the current implementation. I think the tiles should have its own queue, and callbacks a separate one. The thread that pumps them would process one callback, then one tile-rendering.Another issue with combining these threads is that there will be reduction in performance. This is because before and after rendering a tile there is significant work being done that does *not* execute with the Solar lock. This code (mostly encoding to PNG) is CPU intensive and can run in parallel to other code (even to other rendering calls).Finally, I have submitted my patch (342125b8ea) to fix the missing tiles issue. Should be easier to read than describe it here (it's only +27, -6). It comes with detailed commit log too. So this approach is mostly an optimization to reduce the thread-count, but, as mentioned, we need multiple threads because we have opportunity to parallelize, and merging them will reduce performance (unless benchmark proves otherwise, of course).

Patch Set 1:Wrt. the starvation - actually that was due to the logging; we have so much debugging stuff that it was blocking considerably when writing to the console, making the queue grow.  Without that, all works fine even with the unmodified TileQueue :-)But I worked on the TileQueue too - it seems unnecessary to do all the priority shuffling when inserting, when the prioritization changes with every view switch, and instead do it only when the tile is requested - which seems to work nicely.Wrt. an own queue for tiles - that is exactly the thing that makes the synchronzation hard, as then it is necessary to synchronize between those 2 queues; which in turn kills all the advantage of 2 queues :-)Wrt. PNG compression; if we want to thread it, then let's thread just the compression - that'll make it local, more maintainable, and we can go with as many threads there as we wish (for just the PNG compression piece of code).Wrt. the 342125b8ea - thanks for that!  Unfortunately that again just adds code :-(Either way, please check https://cgit.freedesktop.org/libreoffice/online/log/?h=private/kendy/tilesandcallbacks , I'd really like to get that in...  I've tested it with several people in a session, and it performed pretty well thanks to all your work I was able to build on.

Patch Set 4: Code-Review-2Hmm, I wonder if this can ever work, so marking this -2 for now -- not because the code provided so far is bad per se.Here are a few things noticed:- The original image is set when inserting the image, so when inserting an image, saving and reloading, it one cant "reset"- this doesnt do undo and might well confuse/crash the undo stack (e.g. when doing multiple actions, and then undoing them on a different state)- storing the image on the writer shell doesnt work with multiple images: e.g. insert two images, modify the first, reset the first => first image then duplicates the secondBut before taking this further I think we need to take a step back and clarify what is actually needed/wanted here and if we can provide it: I dont think we want to inflate files by storing both the original and the modified images (people might also find it surprising that their original image contents are "leaked"). Also I think most file formats currently dont support this. Finally, for big documents with lots of big images, this would possibly duplicate memory usage.So for now, I would suggest to discuss what is actually wanted and if it realistically can be provided without confusing users too much.

Patch Set 1:> -1 for 2x: include + forward declares in AccessibleControlShape.hxxOops, those forward declares shouldn't be there. Thanks for catching that :) > for discussion: > stuff from hpp files is api which hardly changes. > to reduce bloat, includes and forward declarations in hpp files > should not appear in regular hxx headers againI prefer not doing this since I think that headers should directly include everything they need, except private headers and some other cases. It's easier to do that instead of keeping track of the includes and forward declarations that each .hpp file has already, especially since there's so many of them, and I don't think that files should rely on that, regardless of how often the API changes. Leaving those includes and forward declarations in also allows someone reading that file later to know everything that it depends on more easily. If a file relies on an include or forward declaration that isn't already in that file, iwyu considers that as an error and will suggest to place it back in. That would make reading its output harder if I decided to rely on any includes present in .hpp files.Also, GCC and Clang can perform what is called the 'multiple-include optimization' as described here: https://gcc.gnu.org/onlinedocs/cppinternals/Guard-Macros.html and http://clang.llvm.org/docs/InternalsManual.html#the-multipleincludeopt-class...and thus, at least for those compilers, removing an include because it's already in an included .hpp file may have no measurable effect on build time.
