Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1I have to *strongly* disagree. LibreOffice is unique in its definition of "offset" - anyone coming from Microsoft Word or another program is going to expect the behavior I outlined. The old behavior lends no benefit to the user whatsoever, whereas the new behavior does.Also, the "current" way of "starting on a custom page" is extremely difficult for many users to understand and implement, and is somewhat unreliable in its nature. The main problem is that you wind up with a new empty page at the start of your document.It's a basic principle of software design: if many users are confused, that doesn't mean the documentation needs to be updated, it means the design needs to be updated.Thus, I vote that since the old behavior adds no value to LibreOffice, this patch be reconsidered. Otherwise, a very clear user-oriented case for the old behavior should be made.

Patch Set 6:I would be all right with dropping this feature, in favor of implementing a considerably easier-to-use "start page on" feature.However, we have to face the fact that a huge number of users rely on offset for exactly what this feature allowed, and we have even documented the workaround to achieve the exact same end as what I've described. Thus, before I could abandon this, we would need to:- Change or remove the UI for setting the "offset". It appears to be used exclusively for what is was not designed for, and not for whatever theoretical use it was designed for. Removing the UI for offset doesn't eliminate the feature, but it prevents its rampant (apparent) misuse.- Remove the "workaround" documented to force offset page numbers to overrun the end of the document. Since this is contrary to intended use, we shouldn't be telling users to use offset this way.- Make the means of "starting on" a page number VERY VERY clear.All that said, I don't believe it is wise to abandon this revision until all of those changes are made. This problem has been heavily reported and wholly unaddressed for nearly a decade. This fix isn't ideal, but it is considerably closer to expected behavior than the current behavior. Thus, we need to either provide the expected behavior, or adapt this to match how everyone uses it.

Patch Set 6:Oliver, I forgot to mention that, while this fix makes "Further comments on page <pagefield + n>." *possible*, it would require the user to go into that particular page number field and set the offset. That matches Microsoft Word's offset behavior. Offset is never globally applied across fields. It is applied manually to individual fields. A footer is just the most common instance (at which point, the one instance of the page number is offset on all footers because of the footer's functionality, not the page number's functionality).Whether we eventually abandon this or not (see immediately prior comment), I'll address your inline comment. Good catch!

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1(4 comments)This is a horrible implementation. This now checks every single selected cell if it is a text cell. I think that Eike proposed something different in the bug report.Selecting a huge text range will be horrible performance wise.

Patch Set 1:>This is a horrible implementationPersonally i don't see any need in checking first cell, I think it should be always false. As another approach we may check 2 rows.Currently complexity is O(n^2) which is bad, agree. What's your suggestion?

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1(2 comments)Checking each cell of the entire selection is clearly unnecessary and a huge performance bottleneck.If two or three rows of a column selection are of string type then maybe the first row is not a column header. Similar for a row selection.Things are different if more than one column or row is selected and a cell type of the alleged header row/column is not of string type, then likely it's not a header row/column. Maybe a check of the second row/column would be appropriate if the first row/column was detected to contain only string cells, if also the second row/column contains only string cells then it is uncertain. If it contains at least one non-string cell then likely the first row/column contains headers.Please also see again my comments at https://bugs.documentfoundation.org/show_bug.cgi?id=91305#c13 and https://bugs.documentfoundation.org/show_bug.cgi?id=91305#c15

Patch Set 4:This will commit every transaction the user started manually as soon as a statement is executed successfully. Not a good idea, since then the user cannot rollback the transaction should he choose to.Taking a look at Connection.cxx, I see that there is already the whole infrastructure to enable autocommit. So I suggest that the code (probably in dbaccess/) that creates a Firebird connection to an embedded database enable autocommit (by calling setAutoCommit(sal_True) on the connection) and that's it.

Patch Set 3:(1 comment)Good that you look for both .fbk and .fdb and that you give .fbk priority.Will this silently "upgrade" an .odb that has an .fdb to one that has a .fbk on the next save? Not that I necessarily oppose it, just to be clear.

Patch Set 7:> Saving an opened file:> When the user saves the file, there is a .fbk file> stored in the odb. The driver checks for the fbk> first, and then (if not found) it looks for an fdb.> Should the old .fbk file be removed in the second case?> I think if we want to remove the old file,> there should be an extra check to be sure the> .fbk file works successfully.You mean "the old *fdb*" I suppose. On the one hand,letting old cruft lie around is not good, and lettingthe old fdb in place will also lead to an .odb thatopens a different database (with different data) dependingon which version of LibreOffice opens the file...On the other hand, you are right, risk of data loss if we screw up and the fbk is not functional.On the balance of it, I'd say "people should make backups, remove the old fdb". Ideally, we would make a popup that warns people about this "silent upgrade", too.> Anyway I don't think it will be a common happening,> because it works only with fb 3.0 fdb files,> and the update comes in the same time.This part of the code will indeed be useless as longas we bundle Firebird 3.0 because it cannot openFirebird 2.5 .fdb files. However, since the FB devs planthat a future 3.x release will be able to open Firebird 2.5.fdb files, my plan was to already have the right logic (code)in place in LibreOffice so that (hopefully soon), when weupgrade our bundled Firebird, it will just fall in place :)

Patch Set 37: Code-Review-1> These *.d files are dependencies normally generated with the -MMD > option of gcc. On Windows, because of the lack of gcc, I copy these > files from external (modified a bit with sed).You are asking the wrong question and giving a wrong answer. Given your patch set 36 where you've added generated header dependency files to GIT, I'm even don't know where to start with the explanation why it's wrong thing to do.What the problem are you trying to solve in the last sane patch set 35 of this change?sed failure, trying to substitute stuff in generated .d files, that should be generated by gcc with -MMD option. Check this Paul's explanation on auto-dependency generation in GNU make + gcc combination: [1]. One important thing to understand though, in LO build tool chain, we are abusing the gcc with gcc-wrapper machinery on Windows, to not mess around with all those MSVC project files and having only one integration tool chain for external libraries. That why, as you noticed -MMD cannot be understood by the cl.exe that get invoked by gcc-wrapper in the end.So the correct question to ask on patch set 35 is *not* where and how to get those .d files, but of course why they are needed in the first place and how to disable all this header tracking feature altogether on windows platform.After you are asking the right question, you should already have the 99% of the answer to this question: Before this change, compilation worked on windows platform for FB 2.5 with the same approach. What was changed? Firebord upgrade? Fine. But why it's related?When you invoke the make with -d option, to see what is actually going on, it's telling you that "sed ... wildcard ..." is get invoked. Why and from where?grepping on "wilcard" line in FB 3 source code, reveals the lines in question in make.rules. Comparing this file with FB 2.5, reveals that there weren't any sed invokation there.So the missing 3 lines in patch 35 to solve sed missing *.d failures in FB 3 are these deleted 3 lines in make.rules (at least on windows platform): [2].* [1] http://make.mad-scientist.net/papers/advanced-auto-dependency-generation* [2] http://paste.openstack.org/show/534815

Patch Set 3:Caolan, honestly, I do not think this is the right way to go...I do not think that it is good to 'hack' the animatedBitmapExPreparator - which is a by purpose isolated piece of tooling - into parts. It's purpose is to provide all frames of a GIF in one run.The GIF itself is shown and/or played or not. If just shown, the 1st frame will be needed, if played the whole stack will be needed to do so (all extra actions to create on-demand here will just let it stuck in the 1st loop). If not shown, all the stack can be flushed.There may be the case that only the start frame is needed (screenshot/preview), than this should be optimized. The 1st frame of the GIF is available using simple steps, maybe added to the tooling.So I see no value in on-demand creating *single frames* of the stack, besides that I do not see code to flush it if not used. It will just use the same amount of mem when the GIF is shown and played once.My approch would be to create (a) the 1st frame on-demand, (b) the whole stack on-demand if played (not at load time), and (c) find a way to flush the whole stack if not used (timer/usage based, or the owner getting invisible, there are possibilities). The step (a) would already solve the too-much-mem-after-load problem, the others would make it smart.

Patch Set 3:> Caolan, honestly, I do not think this is the right way to go...This is essentially the same thing as the earlier prototype which seemed acceptable. The frames are still created on demand. Its just that in practice I see that on playback sometimes frames are skipped due to timing issues, in which case we need to occasionally "catch up" the missing ones. i.e. play 0, 1, 3, 4 skipping 2. so frame 3 renders 2 into the virtualdevice as well as 3 to get the right final bitmap. > If just shown, the > 1st frame will be needed, if played the whole stack will be needed > to do so (all extra actions to create on-demand here will just let > it stuck in the 1st loop). If not shown, all the stack can be > flushed.I think we're getting hung up on the first frame, the first frame gets requested occasionally during the playback of the animated gif (by the preview I think) so it seemed natural to treat that one separately by caching it so as not not affect the shared virtual devices in use by playback of the active sequence. > So I see no value in on-demand creating *single frames* of the > stack, besides that I do not see code to flush it if not used. It > will just use the same amount of mem when the GIF is shown and > played once.As the animation is played each frame is requested in sequence and each frame bitmap is generated and returned, rendered, and forgotten about, so (ignoring the first frame cache) there is only one bitmap in memory at a time. > My approch would be to create (b) the whole stack on-demand if played (not at load time)What I want to avoid though is 382 simultaneous 1920 x 1080 bitmaps. Its not so much an issue of lingering bitmaps, but the pile of them getting created together and the attempt here creates, uses and destroys them in sequence during the animation.
Abandoned

The animated one is the specialization from my POV, so that one should be created for gif/animated, be derived from BitmapPirimitive2D and do special needed things for animated stuff.Just my 2ct...

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2Why do you think this is necessary?  css::uno::DisposedException is derived from css::uno::RuntimeException (which can be thrown from every UNO interface method).  (Also, the definition of getPreferredVisualRepresentation in offapi/com/sun/star/embed/XVisualObject.idl does not redundantly mention DisposedException, either; that would be a mild argument in favour of redundantly adding it here, too.)

Patch Set 1:> Why do you think this is necessary?  css::uno::DisposedException is > derived from css::uno::RuntimeException (which can be thrown from > every UNO interface method).  (Also, the definition of > getPreferredVisualRepresentation in offapi/com/sun/star/embed/XVisualObject.idl > does not redundantly mention DisposedException, either; that would > be a mild argument in favour of redundantly adding it here, too.)Hi, Stephan!Actually, I was not sure it was the right thing to do, because of the inheritance from css::uno::RuntimeException.But then I checked out css::lang::IllegalArgumentException and it turned out it derives also from css::uno::RuntimeException.You can verify it here: workdir/UnoApiHeadersTarget/udkapi/normal/com/sun/star/lang/IllegalArgumentException.hdlSo I thought that we should list all exceptions

Patch Set 1:IllegalArgumentException is a special case - when most of the IDL files were written it derived from Exception, not RuntimeException; it was changed to derive from RuntimeException in 2012.

Patch Set 1:> IllegalArgumentException is a special case - when most of the IDL > files were written it derived from Exception, not RuntimeException; > it was changed to derive from RuntimeException in 2012.Indeed, that's another reason why IllegalArgumentException tends to redundantly show up in UNOIDL raises/C++ throw clauses.However, there are also other examples of redundantly specified runtime exceptions, e.g., css.resource.XResourceBundleLoader.loadBundle explicitly raising css.resource.MissingResourceException.  Lets just be forgiving and close our eyes when a C++ function redundantly mentions a RuntimeException-derived exception in its throws clause because the corresponding UNOIDL method specified it, too.  But don't needlessly add further redundant exceptions to such C++ functions.
Abandoned

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2IMHO in this case the whole class SwVectorModifyBase doesnt make sense at all and should be killed. It is only used five times:- as a base for SwGrfFormatColls and as a base for SwTextFormatColls with DestructorPolicy KeepElements- as a base for SwFrameFormats, SwCharFormats and SwSectionFormats with DestructorPolicy FreeElementsWith DestructorPolicy KeepElements there is no magic in this class AFAICS -- so SwGrfFormatColls and SwTextFormatColls only use the wrapper functions from SwVectorModifyBase.With DestructorPolicy FreeElements, there is magic happening on destruction, but I dont think that the inheriting wrapper is a good choice to implement this. E.g. a unique_ptr with a custom deleter is likely a better choice.So IMHO the way forward would be to:1/ Make SwGrfFormatColls, SwTextFormatColls directly use a plain std::vector instead of the SwVectorModifyBase -- that should be simple enough2/ In a follow up patch do the same for the other clients using a unique_ptr with a custom deleterPatches should be minimal and small, so start with just one class per patch (e.g. SwGrfFormatColls).

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1I don't think this is a good idea for the following reasons:The basic number formatter codes follow the ones Excel uses. The new 'MIMI' upon Excel export would have to be mapped to 'mm', re-reading such file the information would be lost.If there are ambiguous corner cases, those would have to be handled anyway as importing an Excel file could expose them as well, for example the code mentioned in the bug "yymmdd-ssmm" can be assigned in Excel.Adding "minutes-unambiguous" to ODF from a standard's view is suboptimal, from an ODF view the <number:minutes> element is not ambiguous. Likely a <number:minutes-unambiguous> element will not make it into the standard.

Patch Set 2:Hi,> this would need to return a http://api.libreoffice.org/docs/idl/ref/interfacecom_1_1sun_1_1star_1_1style_1_1XStyle.htmlAgreed.> there isnt anything like a XTableStyle interface in UNO so farRight. If the same UNO API is implemented, then most of the table style import/export code can be shared between Writer and Impress in xmloff.> there is no separation between a table and its style in writer core so farThe "style" is the autoformat, SwTable::maTableStyleName stores the autoformat of the table, if it has any.> what should this actually return? Even the members in the existing basic XStyle interface like "isInUse()" cant be doneI guess it's fairly straightforward to implement it: need to iterate over SwTables, and see if any of them has the autoformat set to the given autoformat.So yes, I agree that table style is different to paragraph/character styles, but given that we have autoformats, it's reasonable to build on top of that, and I think it's fairly possible to provide UNO API, filters, UI building on top of this. Patch Set 1:The first line of the commit message should say what the commit does. It is not strictly necessary or useful to tell what parts of the code a commit touches in the commit message, because one can trivially see that in the 'git log' output anyway (by using the --stat option). Sure, I know that many of my esteemed colleagues feel the need to mention it anyway. But in this case, listing several directories on the first line of the message is not helpful. You can here just use the bug title, "Remove conditionals depending on OSL_DEBUG_LEVEL > 1", it works fine (in this case; that is not always the case).

Patch Set 1:In general, I am personally not that convinced that adding such #ifdef DEBUG_FOO_BAR is that useful. There is a large risk that the code inside those will bit-rot anyway sooner or later. And if this code at some stage needs debugging, it is questionable whether the specific optional debug code that was perhaps useful some time ago will still be useful, or whether one will need to write more complicated or complete debugging code anyway. I would just remove it. But I am not insisting.

Patch Set 1:Hi Kendy,Please look into this and tell me if it is the right way to proceed.This throws the Unknown Property Exception as indicated below.I think we may need to call this setPropertyValue() <http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/editeng/source/uno/unofield.cxx#675> instead of the one currently being called <http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/sw/source/core/unocore/unofield.cxx#2152> which is throwing up an Unknown Property Exception at <http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/sw/source/core/unocore/unofield.cxx#2165> One is sw's implementation while the other is editeng's implementation. Moggi was of the opinion that the setPropertyValue() from editeng couldn't be called here. But the current one is unable to support that property (UNO_TC_PROP_TEXTFIELD_TYPE). How would it be possible to proceed?I'm influenced by this comment <http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/offapi/com/sun/star/text/textfield/Type.idl#19> when I say the above.Also, I did a '#define UNO_NAME_TEXT_FIELD_TYPE "TextFieldType"' in <opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/sw/inc/unoprnms.hxx> taking other properties from here <http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/include/editeng/unonames.hxx> as an example. Patch Set 1:Maybe describe what you want to do (not how you want to do) in the commit message. :-)EXTENDED_TIME is a Writer field type, Writer field types are exposed as different service names in the UNO API. What is the intention of using setPropertyValue() to set the field type, when you already specified the field type when you created the instance by specifying its service name? If the name set by setPropertyValue() is the same as the one you used at construction time, then it's redundant. If it's something else -- then just create a new field instance, don't try to change an existing one.

Patch Set 1: -Code-Review> EXTENDED_TIME is a Writer field type, Writer field types are > exposed as different service names in the UNO API. If the name set by > setPropertyValue() is the same as the one you used at construction > time, then it's redundant. If it's something else -- then just > create a new field instance, don't try to change an existing one.But then UnknownPropertyException and IllegalArgumentException are thrown when we do a getPropertyValue() and this certainly indicates we aren't setting the properties correctly.Isn't this case similar with : From UserDataType <http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/offapi/com/sun/star/text/textfield/ExtendedUser.idl#48> and UserDataPart<http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/offapi/com/sun/star/text/UserDataPart.idl>, I could notice similarities with the present case. Except that the fields are related to corresponding XML fields and are set here <http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/xmloff/source/text/txtfldi.cxx#630>

Patch Set 1:OK, so what is your goal? I see the following possibilities:1) You want to extend LO's document model, field implementation etc to handle the extra field markup produced by KWord or2) You just want to make sure that the document can be imported without editeng's UNO code throwing, i.e. minimize data-loss.Do I see correctly that you currently go after 2)?

Patch Set 1:> OK, so what is your goal? I see the following possibilities: >  > 1) You want to extend LO's document model, field implementation etc > to handle the extra field markup produced by KWordI would like to go after the first one since someone might file a bug report for that in the future and since its an enhancement request in Apache's OO, we might as well have it here.But again, I guess this is Kendy's decision.
Patch Set 1:If you want me to do 2) first and then 1), that is fine too. In the long run I would be looking at accomplishing 1) though.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-136270776a68c0cd0f472ebd7124c93d7936caf04 is an example on how to add a new property to a Writer field. In case the field is in shape text, then you want to do something like that in editeng, since editeng providers the shape text. The idea is that there is a C++ class that internally stores the new member, and then there is an UNO API wrapper class that exposes that in the API.I.e. no change to xmloff yet, and no change to offapi/type_reference. If you need to change the later to not break the build, that means you tried to change the API in an incompatible way, that's a no-go.
Abandoned

Patch Set 2:Agreed - so I imagine that the idea is that the intermediate created VclPtr<> is converted to a reference_type * by an operator - and then the VclPtr<> is then unreffed - before the reset() completes. I hope that's unlikely - surely the intermediate VclPtr should stick around not just for the scope of operator, but the nested parent function call too ?

Patch Set 2:> Agreed - so I imagine that the idea is that the intermediate > created VclPtr<> is converted to a reference_type * by an operator > - and then the VclPtr<> is then unreffed - before the reset() > completes. I hope that's unlikely - surely the intermediate VclPtr > should stick around not just for the scope of operator, but the > nested parent function call too ?Given that its an inline method, possibly the compiler is hoisting the deref above the call? Would have to disassemble to know for sure.We could fix this in a generic fashion by adding a   void reset(VclPtr<T>)overload to VclPtr

Patch Set 1:Could you please elaborate what the "too many OpenOffice Calc spreadsheets with DDE inside which become unusable after migrating to LibreOffice" problem is?

Patch Set 1:The users might get confused because they have to make a decision and many of them will not know what DDE links are. But what about the old Calc documents with existing DDE links? When the user wants to add more links he will get a mixture of DDE and File links in the end?

Patch Set 2:To summarize what has been discussed on IRC today:I'm not a big fan of encouraging users to use deprecated and insecure protocols (let's be honest, DDE *is* deprecated and insecure). If this is mainly about inserting links with relative paths, maybe your goals could be achieved by using relative references, i.e. =DDE("soffice"; "some/relative/path"; "SheetX.CellY")would become ='some/relative/path'#SheetXCellY'and the development effort could be targeted at implementing some UI and clipboard support for relative references and fixing outstanding relative reference issues (sometimes target doc doesn't update if source doc changes, ~/ path doesn't expand correctly etc.)

Patch Set 2:> Migrating existing DDE to File links is not an option for us, > because we need the support of relative paths like > 脭脟拢~/example/src.ods脭脟脴: >  > =DDE("soffice";"~/example/src.ods";"Sheet1.B6") >  > We have a lot of calc sheets which are exchanged and edited by > several co-workers and therefore DDE is essential.I don't see the argument. What exactly is the problem with using external references instead of DDE links for new links to be created?

Patch Set 2:> > Migrating existing DDE to File links is not an option for us, > > because we need the support of relative paths like > > 脭脟拢~/example/src.ods脭脟脴: > > > > =DDE("soffice";"~/example/src.ods";"Sheet1.B6") > > > > We have a lot of calc sheets which are exchanged and edited by > > several co-workers and therefore DDE is essential. >  > I don't see the argument. What exactly is the problem with using > external references instead of DDE links for new links to be > created?Or is this actually about the ~ tilde character not being evaluated as $HOME?

Patch Set 2:The main argument for us is that our OO Calc users want the DDE links back because LO Calc File links do not work for them: In order to share calc spreadsheets between different users relative paths with 脭脟拢~脭脟脴 are used which is not working with LO Calc File links (yet).

Patch Set 2:> The main argument for us is that our OO Calc users want the DDE > links back because LO Calc File links do not work for them: In > order to share calc spreadsheets between different users relative > paths with 脭脟拢~脭脟脴 are used which is not working with LO Calc File > links (yet).So actually implementing the '~' evaluation and what's necessary around it would be the appropriate fix instead.

Patch Set 2:DDE is a deprecated, insecure technology that is going to be removed at some point. I don't think that we should accept this patch into LibreOffice.Eike already outlined the correct way to handle the problem. This involves implementing the missing features in the cross-platform solution.

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-2@Noel: Urgh, indeed.FWIW, the whole mpAntiImpl think is a mess. SvtFileView_Impl creates mpAntiImpl (a VclPtr) from the naked this ptr of SvtFileView, which I assume is ref-counted and hold by whatever created it.So the SvtFileView is owned by the VclPtr in SvtFileView_Impl _and_ by the VclPtr of whatever created the SvtFileView. This cant end well.Sooo -- mpAntiImpl should probably be a plain reference as:- the wrapper should always live longer than the impl anyway- the impl doesnt have any business at all in messing with ownership of its wrapper.

Patch Set 2:I wanted to use orange because it was previously used, and also because we're working with Impress (and not the whole Libre Office suite), so I think we should still use orange. However, if we think of it as an "extension of the whole suite", and not take into account that it works with Impress only, it should then be green. HOWEVER, if we plan to materialize the Viewer/Editor app, it would also have green color, and maybe we should distinct the two. Also, if we switch it to green, we'd need a new icon (I'm working on it, as soon as I get CorelDraw working on Linux). Also, consider that this (blue) accent doesn't have much contrast between green and it.P.S. should I abandon this change now? I will abandon it, and you "resurrect it" (lol) if you think that we need it, but I guess we basically moved all the useful changes to your commit.

Patch Set 1:Checked deeper. There is only a single call to BlendBitmap with that many parameters in DrawDeviceAlphaBitmapSlowPath. It uses a helper class called TradScaleContext to create the mappings. That class already tries to use mirroring:        const bool bHMirr = aOutSize.Width() < 0;        const bool bVMirr = aOutSize.Height() < 0;Sidenote: Metric values like Width/Height can be negaitve, currently allowed by the definition of Rectangle. this is by itself not good - better use B2IRange and transformations.Thus, this already applies mirroring to the array (as suggested in last coment). Since bHMirr, bVMirr are calculated the same way this should happen.Thus mirroring gets already applied in the index arrays (as suggested in the last comment). So this patch is more about the 'alignment' of the to-be-blended part relative to the target bitmap. In that case all may be as intended.Still not sure about the indices and if nMapY, nMapX are safe in the call to pA->GetPixelIndex to be in bounds. If not, LO will crash

Patch Set 1:Hi Pasqual, thanks for having a look.The BitmapRead/WriteAccess methods do assert in debug, but nonetheless then execute with out-of-bound values, esp. in product version this is often the cause of immediate crashes. I have seen/fixed quite some in that area. 'Reasonably sure' is not adequate for BitmapWriteAccess from my experience. If you are just reasonably sure, I would suggest to encapsulate with if(...) statements which guarantee the in-bound access.

Patch Set 1:Is this necessary after 2428e1164b5f38da9fc2f24c5bb478e548f54a6f?Christian, sorry about the brief commit message. I was a bit upset that the headless patch was merged even though the ESC asked the author not to merge it in its current form. The opengl situation on our Android port is a bit unclear. On one hand, we disable opengl in configure, OTOH it seems we build most of the opengl code in vcl. My commit just restored that status quo, fixing the build. I also verified that the build result actually works. :-)Given that at the end Android uses cairo to render the tiles, the opengl code is not useful on Android. However, probably it's a good idea to not work on removing it from the Android binary till it's not clear if those opengl #ifdefs will go away or not in the long run. (Currently we have those ifdefs, but it's possible they will be reverted, it's not clear yet.)

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1I don't think that creating new instances of CommandInfoProvider each time is the right approach. If anything - there should be no CommandInfoProvider instances at all, just plain static functions. And the singleton-related SetFrame/FrameListener logic should be killed as well.

Patch Set 1:It seems to me that this patch is trying to do something else than what is meant in tdf#45789.Your code does something when saving the report definition. At the time of saving the report definition, it is not possible to know what data will go in there (only at report *execution* time), so I don't see how your code can do the right thing for tdf#45789, whose purpose is to set the row height to what is needed FOR THE DATA FILLED IN.Conceptually, the work is "simpler" as far as the report execution engine is concerned; it just needs to set the "this row needs to have automatic height" bit on the table row(s) in the odt output and *writer* will compute the correct row height. No need of computation of row heights in report builder.On the other hand, it requires some work in the Report Builder UI to add a user-settable property there in order to allow the user to choose whether the row should, or should not, have automatic height.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1It isn't completely clear to me why (cf. <https://groups.google.com/a/isocpp.org/forum/#!topic/std-discussion/oyLCkCUKpfU> "Linkage of: namespace { extern "C" { void f() {} } }"), but compilers do require the "static" on functions in extern "C" { ... } blocks, even within unnamed namespaces.You can use compat::isInExternCContext (compilerplugins/clang/compat.hxx) to filter them out in your plugin.A naive grep showed that your various "tdf#97966 Drop 'static' keywords" changes drop it from such extern "C" functions at least in  cppu/source/uno/lbenv.cxx  pyuno/source/module/pyuno_module.cxx  sax/source/expatwrap/sax_expat.cxx  stoc/source/javavm/javavm.cxx  stoc/source/proxy_factory/proxyfac.cxx  toolkit/source/awt/vclxtoolkit.cxx(And you deliberately left in some such "static" that the current plugin would warn about in module sax, as dropping "static" there would lead to linker errors?)  But there may be more cases that my naive grep missed, so to be safe please redo all the changes with the updated plugin.

Patch Set 1:Just a small nit-pick, but it is good to get this right from the beginning: Commit messages should be in present tense, and as close to normal prose as possible. I.e. here, a much better commit message would be:tdf#97966: Remove 'static' keywordsNo need to put a number in the message even if you have several that do similar things; nothing says they will be accepted in the same order anyway, and even if several commits have the same  message, git log --stat will tell those curious what parts of the source code were affected.

Patch Set 1:Code looks good.  However, pushing it now would break builds that have the Clang plugins enabled.  So please use the plugin to find and fix all places it warns about.  If it is just a handful, you can do one patch including all fixes.  If it is significantly many (which I assume), better split it into manageable chunks, like one patch per module (plus accompanying include files under top-level include/ dir, if any)."stinnspace" is a somewhat incomprehensible tag.  Maybe renaming (all of tag, class, filename) to something like "staticanonymous" would be better.  (Technically, it's called an unnamed namespace, not an anonymous one, but it's probably OK to be imprecise as "staticunnamed" sounds less clear.)Some of the first plugins that got written (and which you apparently took as blueprint) use a somewhat odd coding style.  It's OK to leave things as they are, but you can also change it if you feel more comfortable with any of the alternatives:* The standard license header from TEMPLATE.SOURCECODE.HEADER.* Putting everything into a single .cxx file (and into an unnamed namespace).* Not indenting a block's enclosing curly braces the same as the enclosed content.

Patch Set 2:Apologies for my late response on this issue. The following is my rationale for reverting strdup back into PL_strdup:--https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Projects/NSPR/About_NSPR"Memory managementNSPR provides API to perform the basic malloc, calloc, realloc and free functions. Depending on the platform, the functions may be implemented almost entirely in the NSPR runtime or simply shims that call immediately into the host operating system's offerings."-> thus replacing PL_strdup with strdup may cause different results on different platforms--https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Projects/NSPR/Reference/PL_strdup"Returns a pointer to a new memory node in the NSPR heap containing a copy of a specified string.Syntax#include <plstr.h>char *PL_strdup(const char *s);NotesThe memory allocated by PL_strdup should be freed with PL_strfree."--http://linux.die.net/man/3/strdup"DescriptionThe strdup() function returns a pointer to a new string which is a duplicate of the string s. Memory for the new string is obtained with malloc(3), and can be freed with free(3)."-> there is no guarantee that memory on the heap used by strdup (i.e. the heap used by malloc) can be freed using PL_strfree.--Due to these concerns, I would like to request for this change be reopened and re-evaluated. Thank you for your patience on this issue.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1(14 comments)First, thanks for the overall performance improvement, the numbers you gave in your mail were quite promising.For my nitpicks see the inline comments ;-)I have one concern though, that we somewhere might miss to set the mbMayHaveFormula flag if there is a formula cell added to the column, which at the end would lead to wrong calculations. Can we somehow make sure that it *always* gets set if a formula cell is present?

Patch Set 5:I'm not sure how you get your numbers. Maybe you are not using a release build.In a release build using the 200 row test case the ScColumn::StartListeners method is responsible for about 7% of the whole calculation time. Nearly none of that is related to std::for_each and nearly everything is related to the expensive calls in that method.

Patch Set 5:Hi KoheiYou were right my builds were not clean and i had some debug code. Sorry for that. I did a full rebuild of the libreoffice project with ./autogen.sh --without-java --without-help --without-myspell-dicts no more --enable-dbgutil  and i hope it is sufficient for enabling optimizations. I made more tests, and the code is still slightly faster (1 to 2%), but i think it is in the error tolerance, and anyways things are really more important than percent... i was talking about saving three seconds over a ten minutes computation. Not really worth it ;)So i will revert to the original code and the functor.Now my question is, do you you have a prefered way to send information between ScColumn::StartListeners and class StartListenersHandler ?My first idea is to add an extra parameters to the constructor, a reference to the column, so it could set the FomulaFlag? How about this ?

Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1@William:Reading now that the initial performance improvement numbers you gave (in your mail back then) were obtained with a dbgutil build, they were certainly misleading. I tend to believe that the actual improvement in a standard/release build would be much less and would not justify this change, and introducing a still possible risk that presence of a formula cell would go undetected and lead to wrong calculations is a no-go for me.

Patch Set 5:@EikeI fully understand that if the gain is not sufficient, stability prevails. Honestly i am no longer sure if my builds were debug or not... The information i posted were misleading because i switched to debug when i created the performance unit test. I do not remember my september builds.I am currently running a performance test with today's version and release build (./autogen.sh --without-java --without-help --without-myspell-dicts) using the different test case i used, and my original test file. So far the execution ratio is about 1.43 with the 2,000 lines file and about 1,35 with the 5,000 lines file.The performance test with the original file will take hours... so i propose to wait until tomorrow, then i will post more results and tests case you need. So far i have processed about 17% and the current line ratio is about x2. It is a current value, not an average. Average on the first 17% is close to 1.45 but should raise.

Patch Set 5:Hey William,so what I propose is that we take the performance tests that have been pushed already to master and start from a purely algorithmic perspective.I had a short discussion with Eike and Kohei and reading the patch and looking at the results of the performance test I feel that we can easily win much more by doing some algorithm improvements to the subtotal code.If you look at the current callgrind output we are basically inserting n rows and execute the same operations in the code for each inserted row. Most of these operations however are not necessary for n-1 iterations as the only valid update happens in the last iteration. Examples for that are starting and stopping listeners, updating references.Not all of these places are easy to refactor but I think all in all we can find an incremental approach moving to this goal. If you are interested in that let us move the discussion to the mailing list.The huge advantage of that approach is that the code will be simpler and more robust (the boolean flag is easy to forget in the future in some new code path) and will give the same speed up for columns with formula cells as well.

Patch Set 5:HiSince yesterdays afternoon i have processed my original test files (about 100,000 lines) on a box faster than the one i used this summer with two different builds. Release builds. The first one was build from yesterdays master branch, the other with this patch set.The processing time was 5.80 hours with the current version of LO, and 3.29 hours with the patched version. That is close to a 1.75 ratio, and it saved two hours and a half of processing time. Most of the time was spent into the pDocument->InsertRow calls (from table3.cxx ScTable::DoSubTotals). During this night runs, the time spent in this method was ranging from 85.177 to 1089.3 ms with the current code, and from 81.755 to 394.771 ms with the patched code. The second most time consuming method is the call to SetString, with execution time varying from 0.01 to 147ms.

Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1> > Why would you want to link all these libraries into libmerged? > The hope is to start faster. e.g. if it runs as conversion server.And does it help?The point of libmerged was to merge libraries which are always loaded on start.You can get them with something like similar script:for app in 'writer' 'calc' 'draw' 'impress' 'base'do    LD_DEBUG=files OOO_EXIT_POST_STARTUP=1 ./instdir/program/soffice "--${app}" 2> temp_${app}.txt    cat temp_${app}.txt  | grep "calling init"  | cut -f 2 | cut -d " " -f 3 | sort  | uniq > libs_${app}.txtdonecat libs_* | sort | grep home | uniq -c | sort -r > libraries.txtFrom these, only acc should be merged.If it really will be useful for some scenario,maybe try resurrecting --enable-mergelibs=allor somehow enable to define specific set of libs on configure or...(See also fa8aaaadc38372185d6d29d8d91391907e95b689)

Patch Set 4:Some functions seems in need to handle both. I guess we can't change the VBA interface ;-)Now there is INetURLObject(OUString const & rFSysPath, FSysStyle eStyle), so probably we can get rid of osl::FileBase::getFileURLFromSystemPath, if we set eStyle according to the system settings?I also missed the smart parsing functionality. I had a look now, but didn't find code which would just accept system specific local paths, as there seems to be no system setting for FSYS_*, as FSYS_DETECT will - as far as my fast gimplse at the code told me - happily accept file URLs in any system notation, if you pass FSYS_DETECT.And there are a lot more users of osl::FileBase::getFileURLFromSystemPath, which expect a local path right from the start. Some expect to use the input path, if it's correct, while others want the GetMainURL(). But I just found one with a different decoding then NO_DECODE.I can convert everything to smart URL and run make check, but I can't verify all places. We just need to define a FSYS_SYSTEM value somewhere, so we won't accept other system file encodings.

Patch Set 4:So looking at 1d1fd4d2b6ee1db407a8f16dee84900b4f0ff5b2's use of TryUrlFromSystemPathAsString in the SwMailMergeDlg InsertPathHdl (sw/source/ui/envelp/mailmrge.cxx).  The original content of m_pPathED/sPath is either known to be a URL (pModOpt->GetMailingPath(), aPathOpt.GetWorkPath(), xFP->getDirectory()), in which case it is unfortunate that that information was thrown away in the first place.  Or it is some text the user created in m_pPathED.  There is already code in SwMailMergeDlg::ExecQryShell to interpret m_pPathED as a URL, using URIHelper::SmartRel2Abs (so also handling relative paths).  I would stick to that code here, too.It is very rare for the smart-parsing INetURLObject ctor to create an instance with INetProtocol::NotValid, so the  if (INetProtocol::NotValid == aProtocol)in TryUrlFromSystemPathAsString will rarely hit, so when called with bFromURL=false, it will typically return an empty string.  I have no idea what 1d1fd4d2b6ee1db407a8f16dee84900b4f0ff5b2's use of TryUrlFromSystemPathAsString (with bFromURL=false) in SwDBManager::ExecuteFormLetter (sw/source/uibase/dbui/dbmgr.cxx) is supposed to do.Generally, regarding smart parsing, I would not worry too much about FSYS_DETECT being too liberal in accepting foreign filesystem notations---the input it would thus accept would hardly be anything a user could reasonably intend to be something meaningful that should be interpreted differently.  And if there should be any real problems there (but I'm not aware of any), we could probably replace that FSYS_* enumeration with code that just smart-parses the syntax of the given platform.  (A more useful addition to INetURLObject's smart-parsing functionality would likely be a static factory function that, unlike the smart-parsing INetURLObject ctor, does not require the caller to specify a "smart scheme."  That would also address the need of adding an INetProtocol::DEFAULT value.)
Patch Set 3:I didn't really find a good name for these function. Any suggestions for a better name welcome.

Patch Set 3:Is this producing better results than using the existing INetURLObject "smart parsing" functionality?  (I suspect that many, if not all, of the places you identified are using their cumbersome ways out of ignorance of the existing functionality.)

Patch Set 6:Thanks for looking at the code and your patience :-)I actually changed the MM dialog to always return a valid URL, so all the hacks in dbmgr.cxx are gone, and a single line of INetURLObject::TryUrlFromSystemPathAsString sw/source/ui/envelp/mailmrge.cxx in 8c511dc1bc285c312c6d98c876a103915853ffc9 remains.My alternative solution is 58fb4ec04eee05de26f1ca3b580ec0d5e6fec1a2, which uses URIHelper::SmartRel2Abs, as you suggested, and gets rid of my use of  INetURLObject::TryUrlFromSystemPathAsString.And I've simplified the embarrassingly wrong code in INetURLObject::TryUrlFromSystemPathAsString - sig :-( > Generally, regarding smart parsing, I would not worry too much about FSYS_DETECT being too liberal in accepting foreign filesystem notations---the input it would thus accept would hardly be anything a user could reasonably intend to be something meaningful that should be interpreted differently.  And if there should be any real problems there (but I'm not aware of any), we could probably replace that FSYS_* enumeration with code that just smart-parses the syntax of the given platform.  (A more useful addition to INetURLObject's smart-parsing functionality would likely be a static factory function that, unlike the smart-parsing INetURLObject ctor, does not require the caller to specify a "smart scheme."  That would also address the need of adding an INetProtocol::DEFAULT value.)I just added the DEFAULT for convenience, as a some functions defaulted to Http.So what about all the duplicated code? Should this become an easy hack to inspect all the code pointers and convert it to more appropriate code, whatever that is?

Patch Set 6:> So what about all the duplicated code? Should this become an easy > hack to inspect all the code pointers and convert it to more > appropriate code, whatever that is?Yes, I think it's better to use the existing smart-parsing functionality of INetURLObject (or adapt it slightly if necessary), than to add yet another function to it.  INetURLObject is a mess with a long history, and it already has too much functionality to make it easy to pick the right function to call.  Let's not add to that. ;)
AbandonedRewriting the code pointer with smart parsing code can be an easy hack.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1(1 comment)1) This doesn't compile!2) Your code does something when saving the report definition. At the time of saving the report definition, it is not possible to know what data will go in there (only at report *execution* time), so I don't see how your code can do the right thing for tdf#45789, whose purpose is to set the row height to what is needed FOR THE DATA FILLED IN.Conceptually, the work is "simpler" as far as the report execution engine is concerned; it just needs to set the "this row needs to have automatic height" bit and *writer* will compute the correct row height. No need of computation of row heights in report builder.But it does need some work in the Report Builder UI to allow the user to choose whether the row should, or should not, be allowed to adjust automatic height.

Patch Set 1:Hi Katarina,i have made a other fix for that problem, can you look to https://gerrit.libreoffice.org/#/c/20971/I has set the patch to abandon, while i found the reason patch, but when this patch not right, then my other fix (20971) resolved the CRASH.

Patch Set 1:> I has set the patch to abandon, while i found the reason patch, but > when this patch not right, then my other fix (20971) resolved the > CRASH.The other patch is a better approach, but you need to somehow untangle those messy parent-child window relationships further.As you can see in Window::ImplInit, mpBorderWindow is a parent of this window. Moreover, mpClientWindow member variable of mpBorderWindow points to this window too. So by doing mpBorderWindow.disposeAndClear(), we're effectively ending up calling dispose() on this window recursively. Or so it seems.Unfortunately, I've no immediate remedy or creative idea how to fix the issue once and for all, without causing regressions. Maybe have a look at Window::SetBorderStyle, that makes some attempt to break the window relationship in a way.

I have not found where the mistake is happen, when the Floating change to Floating-Dialog in FloatingWindow::ImplEndPopupMode, but maybe is in this method the problem?I have no more ideas we could be solved the crash, but of my opinion we must solve the crash, crashes are very ugly.

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-2(2 comments)The bug is the result of the functionality added incommit 138d29aa09417eba4d15ade4c9f4dab2620b6326"support fast MM printing in non-single-file mode only for CUPS"The point of this commit was to skip the expensive concat'ing of the ODT document and let the CUPS backend concat the multiple jobs from MM printing into a single job of multiple PS files.This has actually a lot of inherited problems, as all printing options, which effect multiple pages (reverse, n-up, empty pages) won't be applied to the overall document, but just the single jobs.This patch actually works, because it uses a merged document again, instead of a concat'ed print job of multiple documents, so it simply reverts to the functionality before the patch and is the same as commenting the line:// bCheckSingleFile_ = !psp::PrinterInfoManager::get().supportsBatchPrint();Actually it's even worse, because it manually splits the merged document into single page jobs again, which will be concated by the CUPS backend again.

Patch Set 1:> The reason it was done that way (by me) is that the toolbar button > is a split button (i.e. it can be clicked on the button *or* on the > dropdown part), so it's possible to apply the last used color > easily. So the toolbar button shouldn't update with the current > color, but instead show the last used one.Uhm, I get the split button part (and I kept it in place), but I'm slightly challenged with what's the desirable behaviour supposed to be otherwise1. Sidebar and toolbar colour buttons don't update each other and at any time, they can contain totally disjunct sets of colours (status quo, almost)2. Sidebar and toolbar colour buttons are in sync, any time colour in sidebar changes, corresponding toolbar button is updated and vice versa3. Sidebar updates toolbar but not the other way round4. Toolbar updates sidebar but not the other way roundI don't want to step over conscious better design decisions, so the new text background colour button needs to follow the same path, whichever of the above it is

Patch Set 1:Well, for me this is the desired result:1. A simple button (i.e. with ToolBoxItemBits::DROPDOWNONLY bits) should show the current color of the selected text/object.2. A split button (i.e. with ToolBoxItemBits::DROPDOWN bits) should initially show some common color, and later the last used one, for easy re-applying it on another text/object.3. All buttons of the same kind (simple vs split), and that are representing the same text attribute, should be synced, and show the same color, regardless whether they are on the toolbar or on the sidebar.This means that if we have .uno:Color on both the toolbar and the sidebar, and *both* are split buttons, they need to be synced - but with the last used color, not with the current one (i.e. if you move the cursor to a text with a different color, it shouldn't affect the button). That's why SvxColorToolBoxControl::StateChanged has the check for bSidebarType, so split buttons won't be updated with the current color, but keep the last used one. This bSidebarType is simply used for distinguish between simple and split buttons, allowing them to share the same code, it's just poorly named (because most of the buttons in the sidebar are simple buttons - except the ones from the text panel, and all the toolbar buttons are split ones).Now, this scenario of syncing split buttons is not yet implemented (and already reported in tdf#82438). The problem is that the last used color is stored inside PaletteManager, and we have separate instance of it for each visible button. This causes also that the last used color resets after closing and re-opening the toolbar (because SvxColorToolboxControl instances are destroyed together with the toolbar) - see tdf#61868, tdf#71413, tdf#72991, tdf#83789.One possible solution is to turn PaletteManager into a singleton, so we'll have only one instance, and could manage all visible buttons from there. That way we could also sync the "recent colors" palette between all visible pickers, and maybe also the currently chosen main palette. Right now each visible button has its own instance of all these settings. Even worse - right now each instance has its own list of all palettes and their colors, thus wasting resources. Such kind of things surely should be managed in a centralized way.

Patch Set 1:> Regarding the removal from the toolbars, it shouldnt be done as 'Save As' isnt accessible in the Save drop down when no modifications are done to a documentThen maybe we should always enable the save button, even if no modifications are done.There are other indicators whether a document is saved or not (Statusbar and Title)

Patch Set 1:> Then maybe we should always enable the save button, even if no > modifications are done.In this case we should change the bits of this button dynamically to DROPDOWNONLY when the main command is disabled, otherwise the setting "Allow to save document..." from Tools->Options...->LibreOffice->General would have no visible effect.A note about implementation:Recently I unified several menu-based buttons to use the same class in framework/source/uielement/popuptoolbarcontroller.cxx, which can be controlled by a values from Controller.xcu. We can add additional value there to indicate buttons that should not be disabled. It can be separated by a semicolon, the same way I did in framework/source/uielement/subtoolbarcontroller.cxx.On the other hand, I'm not sure that such scheme is useful in other cases, so it might be better to simply derive from PopupMenuToolbarController a dedicated class for the save button.

Patch Set 1:> In this case we should change the bits of this button dynamically to DROPDOWNONLY when the main command is disabled, otherwise the setting "Allow to save document..." from Tools->Options...->LibreOffice->General would have no visible effect.Like the idea. Do you have time to prepare a patch? Would be good to have this before the freeze tonight.Note that we already have a toolbar controller for the save button (framework/source/uielementsaveasmenucontroller). It's just wrongly named.I would add the functionality there.

Patch Set 1:> Like the idea. Do you have time to prepare a patch? Would be good > to have this before the freeze tonight.I will try. Unfortunately my free time today is highly limited... > Note that we already have a toolbar controller for the save button > (framework/source/uielementsaveasmenucontroller).It's a *menu* controller, you can't use it on toolbar as-is. So what we're doing right now is to wrap it in a generic toolbar controller in popuptoolbarcontroller.cxx. This way it's possible to create toolbar buttons from *any* menu controller - so menus can be shared between menubar/toolbar.

Patch Set 3:Using a test file with unescaped path:http://192.168.1.80:8080/alfresco/webdav/Sites/davtest/documentLibrary/Lorem_ipsum un'altra copia.odtOpen it navigating the webdav server folders and opening it, the escaped path received by ucp.webdav content is:http://192.168.1.80:8080/alfresco/webdav/Sites/davtest/documentLibrary/Lorem_ipsum%20un%27altra%20copia.odtand this is the path used for the lock and to store it locally.When I try to save it, a PUT operation has instead a path ofhttp://192.168.1.80:8080/alfresco/webdav/Sites/davtest/documentLibrary/Lorem_ipsum%20un'altra%20copia.odtFormed internally where the last fragment is formed with NeonUri::unescape(rURL),during the ucp.webdav internal procedure that lead to PUT.This leads to a collision with the former lock acquired withhttp://192.168.1.80:8080/alfresco/webdav/Sites/davtest/documentLibrary/Lorem_ipsum%20un%27altra%20copia.odtAt the server they are the same, but the for the lock store they are not (NeonLockStore::findByUri usesneon functions to check that).Apparently if I open the file directly, without navigating the webdav folder structure the escaped path received by ucp.webdav content is instead:http://192.168.1.80:8080/alfresco/webdav/Sites/davtest/documentLibrary/Lorem_ipsum%20un'altra%20copia.odtthat doesn't cause problems.I needed a unique escape path representation at the DAVResourceAccess level.Probably the NeonUri::unescape(rURL) can be substitued by some other more correct unescape method.What's your suggestion?Adding method to NeonUri ? Or is there some helper function in LO that does a clean job?

Patch Set 5:(1 comment)"What's your suggestion? Adding method to NeonUri ? Or is there some helper function in LO that does a clean job?"The best solution is probably to use INetURLObject's inherent normalization here to get rid of variation in "harmless" escapes in URLs passed to the UCP; something like:  INetURLObject obj(aURL);  if (obj.HasError()) {    SAL_WARN("ucb.ucp.webdav", "bad URL <" << aURL << ">");    return aURL;  }  return obj.GetMainURL(INetURLObject::NO_DECODE);

Patch Set 5:>  > INetURLObject obj(aURL); > if (obj.HasError()) { >     SAL_WARN("ucb.ucp.webdav", "bad URL <" << aURL << ">"); >     return aURL; > } > return obj.GetMainURL(INetURLObject::NO_DECODE);used something similar to normalize URL:    INetURLObject aInURLObj( aURL );    if ( aInURLObj.HasError() ) {        SAL_WARN( "ucb.ucp.webdav", "The URL <" << aURL << "> has errors!" );         return aURL;     }    OUString aDecodedURL( aInURLObj.GetMainURL( INetURLObject::DECODE_WITH_CHARSET ) );    INetURLObject aNormalizedURLObj( aDecodedURL );     return aNormalizedURLObj.GetMainURL( INetURLObject::NO_DECODE );but then I ran into another problem: regression to a old OOo issue: ooo#81690, solved here:http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/ucb/source/ucp/inc/urihelper.hxx#70I decided to solve the problem another way: normalize the URL used internally in LO to store and check the lock held, with a chunk of code similar to the above.Testing it now, looks promising.I'll let you know..

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1Basically not a bad approach, but it should be done more modular, e.g. create a primitive class hich has gradient stops and decomposes to the already existing FillGradientPrimitive2D, so nothing has to change there (safe) and the new classes will extend the functionality in the sende of primitives (as intended). This would also avoid the from my POV unacceptable double definition of StartColor/EndColor.In general it can be done to extend all 'classic' gradients to gradient stops (modular), but is questionable - evtl. implementing the SVG gradient definitions and using these if needed would be superiour. This can also be done using primitives and a decomposition, so all renderers would be capable of crunching these.

Patch Set 6:Comment regarding GradientStop.RelativePosition: As it is relative, data type "long" makes no sense to me. Common values for a relative value are from the range 0 to 1 or in percentage syntax from 0% to 100%. ODF1.2 allows the element <svg:linearGradient> which has a child element <svg:stop>. This has the corresponding attribute svg:offset. It has data type double.Comment regarding color: ODF1.2 allowes <svg:linearGradien>. This has in its <svg:stop> child element the attribute svg:stop-opacity. com::sun::star::util::Color (in GradientStop.idl) can carry this information because it has an alpha channel. But basegfx::BColor is a B3DTuple and has only rgb. Opacity might not be necessary for OOXML but I think, that the design should be made in view of ODF1.2 too and therefore consider opacity in the internal maGradientStops vector.

Patch Set 1:(1 comment)"otherwise assertion failure occurs on data write":  You mean the  assert(pBuf && "Possibly Reallocate failed");in SvMemoryStream::PutData (tools/source/stream/stream.cxx) (which was changed form a DBG_ASSERT to an assert in 5ace3f3b4f2f916d8b2acab1b5cc0fe2a5a19dee)?Do you know a scenario where a TempFile::GetStream creates such an SvMemoryStream with eMode containing WRITE bit? Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1It is still confusing, what the purpose of this changes is. In the current linear gradient implementation a gradient exists independent of a shape. Therefore "diagonal" makes no sense. To get the same behavior as the gradient in MS, where a "45鈹枒" linear gradient is indeed diagonal for every rectangle, a new kind of gradient is needed. This can be the svg:linearGradient as used in ODF1.2. That would not need any private attribute.If this is only about a restriction in the UI, I think it should be discussed with the design-group. If the UI gives similar buttons as MS, this will arouse expectations, which currently cannot be hold.

Patch Set 3:> It is still confusing, what the purpose of this changes is. In the > current linear gradient implementation a gradient exists > independent of a shape. Therefore "diagonal" makes no sense.To get > the same behavior as the gradient in MS, where a "45鈹枒" linear > gradient is indeed diagonal for every rectangle, a new kind of > gradient is needed. This can be the svg:linearGradient as used inNo! 45 degrees is only for square - for rectangles the angle changes with reference to length and width of the object. So, "diagonal" is more like a floating angle with the condition that the fill needs to happen from one corner to another.Hope that helps, please?Thanks!Muthu Subramanian > ODF1.2. Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1OK - I've read the patch more carefully now...The comment "/// XStatusListener" is totally misleading.  Normally it means that the method implements XStatusListener UNO service, which scared me a lot, one has to be very careful introducing this :-) Having read it more carefully, it is not the case here luckily.Generally, please do not mix style changes with functional changes in the patches like this, then it looks like a much more complex change than it really is :-)  Of course it is OK to change the style of the actual lines you are touching, but when you do that for lines around too, it just makes the patch less readable.Also it is good to add comments to the places you are fixing / implementing - at least one line summary of purpose of a class is much appreciated.So I'd suggest the following: Split to more patches, where1) 1st patch turns ButtonStatusListener into VclStatusListener template liketemplate <class T> VclStatusListenerthat gets the widget as the template parameter, and calls its statusChanged() method.  In the toolbar code, the instantiation would look like mpStatusListener  = new WindowStatusListener<ToolBox>(this, ".uno:ImageOrientation");2) 2nd that actually implements the functionality for the toolbar.3) [optionally] some style clenaup arnoud, but better to avoid doing much of that.Also - is this all that was necessary to be done to fix the problem in the sidebar, or is an additional patch anticipated?Thank you for your work on this! :-) - and sorry about my initial reaction, the stylistic changes + the wrong comment triggered a warning light in my mind ;-)

Patch Set 8:Giuseppe: The problem with patching neon is that then it is impossible for the package maintainers to use the version provided by system on the Linux distros.Can you please try if it is possible to normalize the url's before calling the neon API instead?Thank you!

Patch Set 8:> Can you please try if it is possible to normalize the url's before > calling the neon API instead?I already tried in this proposed change:https://gerrit.libreoffice.org/#/c/18147/But I did poorly, as Stephan pointed out there.This is a description of the original cause, mainly from c/18147/Using a test file having an unescaped path of:<http://192.168.1.80:8080/alfresco/webdav/Sites/davtest/documentLibrary/Lorem_ipsum un'altra copia.odt>Navigating the webdav server folders using the LO native filepicker and opening the file, the already escaped path received by ucb.ucp.webdav.content is:<http://192.168.1.80:8080/alfresco/webdav/Sites/davtest/documentLibrary/Lorem_ipsum%20un%27altra%20copia.odt>and this is the path used for the lock method and to store it locally (in neon managed lockstore).When I try to save it, a PUT operation has instead a path of<http://192.168.1.80:8080/alfresco/webdav/Sites/davtest/documentLibrary/Lorem_ipsum%20un'altra%20copia.odt>Formed internally where the last segment (the file name) is formed with NeonUri::unescape(rURL),during the ucp.webdav internal procedure that lead to PUT.This leads to a collision with the former lock acquired with<http://192.168.1.80:8080/alfresco/webdav/Sites/davtest/documentLibrary/Lorem_ipsum%20un%27altra%20copia.odt>At the server end they are the same, but the for the lock store they are not (NeonLockStore::findByUri usesneon functions to check that).Apparently if I open the file directly, without navigating the webdav folder structure the escaped path received by ucb.ucp.webdav.content is instead:<http://192.168.1.80:8080/alfresco/webdav/Sites/davtest/documentLibrary/Lorem_ipsum%20un'altra%20copia.odt>that doesn't cause problems.IMHO a unique way of escaping the path should be provided by the clients of ucb.ucp.webdav.I discovedered thet at the ucb.ucp.webdav level is a bad idea to unescape a path and then escape it again, simply because the client application (e.g. framework) should have escaped it according to some rule ucb doesn't know anythinf about.I'll investigate the problem further, though.Starting from LO native file picker, I wonder why the path is not encoded in a unique way.

AbandonedAfter some check of the native file picker operation, I discovered the reason for the behaviour I observed depends from the WebDAV server in use.It seems that some among them don't implement correctly the escaping of the collection property, e.g. the file name.For the time being I'll abandon this change.A simple work-around can be used to open the file: use the full unescaped file path directly with the full path in the native filepicker dialog box.

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1You will need to re-write a bit of history in order to remove your dependency on your previous commit. The following should work.    git rebase -i HEAD~2You will see something like the following in your favorite text editor    pick 13fdbbf tdf#93240: replace boost::ptr_container with std::unique_ptr    pick 89645c3 tdf#93240: replace boost::ptr_container with std::unique_ptrchange the above to the following (the key part being "squash")    pick 13fdbbf tdf#93240: replace boost::ptr_container with std::unique_ptr    squash 89645c3 tdf#93240: replace boost::ptr_container with std::unique_ptrSave and close, and then you will see something like the following in your favorite text editor.    # This is a combination of 2 commits.    # The first commit's message is:        tdf#93240: replace boost::ptr_container with std::unique_ptr        Change-Id: I7141eea0fe7f72408da0d2a5ebe4a5e2893b6b7d        # This is the 2nd commit message:        tdf#93240: replace boost::ptr_container with std::unique_ptr        Change-Id: Iff01d31792a13a14ea720c477417297af0c01642In your case you need to keep the 2nd commit, so convert the above to something like the following    tdf#93240: replace boost::ptr_container with std::unique_ptr        Change-Id: Iff01d31792a13a14ea720c477417297af0c01642Then resubmit to gerrit to remove your dependency on your previous commit.

Patch Set 1:Do you have any source that says this is a good thing to do? Static local variables add extra code, as the initialization must happen exactly once, when the definition is encountered for the first time. And the variables must be deinitialized in reverse order.

Patch Set 1:TThank you for your points.My intention was as follows: a static local constant is constructed only once, and only when the execution enters its scope; so it may be possible to reduce the overhead if either its function is not called at all or is called many times.But I finally understand our compilers are smart enough not to allocate any storage of integer/float constants (with e.g. g++'s -O1 or bigger). So let's abandon this patch.

Patch Set 1:Hmm, is this only a nice-to-have patch or it makes life really hard on the g-d side if this is not accepted?I'm asking as up to today, we could freely add as many new signals as we wanted to the widget without breaking ABI. However, with your patch, the list of signals become part of the ABI and we limit the number of new signals ever to be added.In other words it's a large cost to support these function pointers -- if possible, it would be really nice to avoid this. The larger the interface we promise to be stable, the harder to make future changes.
Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1Let's -1 it before we have the answer, based on the comment :-) - hope that's fine.

Patch Set 1:> Hmm, is this only a nice-to-have patch or it makes life really hard > on the g-d side if this is not accepted?This is only a nice-to-have patch. It doesn't make life hard on the g-d side. >  > I'm asking as up to today, we could freely add as many new signals > as we wanted to the widget without breaking ABI. However, with your > patch, the list of signals become part of the ABI and we limit the > number of new signals ever to be added. >  > In other words it's a large cost to support these function pointers > -- if possible, it would be really nice to avoid this. The larger > the interface we promise to be stable, the harder to make future > changes.As there are two ways to connect to signals -- First is to connect via g_signal_connect, and the other one would be via these function pointers. We can always use the former, but I think later approach is better and cleaner way of doing things. We can sort-of know the order when the handlers would be called. With function pointers, we can precisely control the point at which the default handlers will be emitted; we can chain up to the parent in our default handler. This is similar to as we have done in lok_doc_view_class_init function for the widget class overriding their key_press_event, key_release_event etc.See: https://developer.gnome.org/gobject/unstable/gobject-Signals.htmlWith g_signal_connect-ed handlers, we would be having no idea which one would be called first.Currently this is not a huge problem; I can always make it work with g_signal_connect in g-d, but it would be cleaner otherwise, and in the long run.Regarding the ABI, yes we can add up as many new signals as up to today, but that leaves us with only one option of connecting to signals i.e g_signal_connect. The `gpointer padding[8]` should be enough and help us to preclude the ABI change.

Patch Set 1:The reason why 8 doesn't seem to be enough is that just in Writer internally (see the RES_MSG enum in sw/inc/hintids.hxx) we have 39 signals, and that does not include shared code, Calc and Draw/Impress. So I would like to keep the possibility to add from these to the widget as/when necessary, without breaking ABI.If we limit the number of new possibilities to 8, the last signal will be a "something happened" one, and we'll stuff everything else into that -- sounds like a bad outcome.Maybe let's wait with this till there is a user for which not having the function pointers is really a hard problem.
AbandonedBased on the Miklos comments, let's abandon this patch I guess; really sorry about that Pranav :-(
Patch Set 1:No worries. We can hold this on unless this widget gets a client that really needs this. :)

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1This patch obviously does not what is mentioned in the commit message.The second question is what is the use-case of adding the line to a test declaration. I understand the advantage of having a line in an assert macro as there might be several in one test case but for the the CPPUNIT_TEST_FAIL this would mean that you just get a pointer to the declaration. You get the sme with a quick git grep or even opening the source file and looking at the declaration of the tests.It would be the same as printing the source line of the test declaration in a CPPUNIT_TEST macro instead of the source line of the assert that failed.

Patch Set 1:> This patch obviously does not what is mentioned in the commit message.Well it adds the source position of the test declaration.I don't understand why you think the commit message is wrong?> The second question is what is the use-case of adding the line to a> test declaration. I understand the advantage of having a line in an> assert macro as there might be several in one test case but for> the CPPUNIT_TEST_FAIL this would mean that you just get a pointer to> the declaration. Patch Set 1:The msbuild tasks are already running in parallel with other stuff (at least in ideal case). So this could actually degrade performance, as in the worst case, msbuild would spawn N processes alongside N-1 processes already run by make. And it would be even worse if more of the msbuild tasks were running in parallel...

Patch Set 1:> The msbuild tasks are already running in parallel with other stuff > (at least in ideal case). So this could actually degrade > performance, as in the worst case, msbuild would spawn N processes > alongside N-1 processes already run by make. And it would be even > worse if more of the msbuild tasks were running in parallel...Yes, that's a possible worst-case scenario. But from observation, I noticed that cpu utilization is low during external project builds and peaks during the LO code build.Is it possible to get more accurate numbers from the build machines with this enabled (and compare to when it wasn't) ?

Patch Set 1:IMHO a much better way to improve CPU utilization, without overcommitting, would be to relax the dependencies on external projects a bit. A dependency of a library on external project is typically added by calling gb_LinkTarget_use_external_project; the current impl. delays building of any source file of the library until the external project is done, which is not necessary unless the external project generates a (public) header during build. This could be changed to depend only on the unpacked tarball and only the link target itself on the external project, possibly with a second argument forcing all to depend on the full external project (I do not know if this would be actually needed. A test build would show.)

Patch Set 1:> relax the dependencies on external projects a bit.Sounds like a good idea. I can't commit to it though, but can run tests with and without my patch and come back with numbers. If we can reduce build time with such a trivial patch, I think it's a good first step. Otherwise, we abandon this and aim for your suggestion.

Because I use the value, this allows someone to quickly generate a table of numbers using a formula, and then simply convert that table into the Unicode equivalent characters. Patch Set 2:> Wherever the code stored an iterator in an object field, I did not convert it> from list to vector.> And wherever it stored the end() iterator in a local variable, I made it> compare against .end() directly.> I think that covers the differences in semantics.I don't think so. The iterator validity difference between list andvector is, that deleting a list element only invalidates iteratorspointing to that element and no other iterators, whereas in a vector alliterators are invalidated whenever memory is (automatically or perreserve()) reallocated, or during insertion and deletion all iteratorspointing behind the insertion or deletion point.So actually you have to check also if iterators are remembered, forexample during a loop, and inspect deletion and insertion operationswhile these are held, or calls to reserve().

Patch Set 1:> are you sure that none of those uses of std::list rely on e.g. the semantics regarding iterator invalidation, which are different from those of std::vector?Wherever the code stored an iterator in an object field, I did not convert it from list to vector.And wherever it stored the end() iterator in a local variable, I made it compare against .end() directly.I think that covers the differences in semantics.

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-2OK, I think I found the actual issue here. Our OpenSymbol font has the wrong (swapped) glyphs for U+03C6 and U+03D5. This change was introduced in https://bz.apache.org/ooo/show_bug.cgi?id=105084 (see the attached document there). Given this is a relatively recent change (relative to the age of star office), I think the proper fix here is to swap the glyphs again  (and for the epsilon and varepsilon as well, because the change is wrong for the same reason) and keep using symbol names that are compatible with the rest of the math world.

Patch Set 2:OK, here is what I found:Loading .pro.user files doesn't work even in earlier versions. To make Qt Creator load the .pro.user file, you must go to ~/.config/QtProject/qtcreator/profiles.xml and copy the profile ID from there to the "ProjectExplorer.ProjectConfiguration.Id" key in the .pro.user file. This situation is unfortunate, but that's what we have right now.(Note that Qt creator will still create the .pro.user.3.2-pre1 file, but it's just a backup of the old file, and is not actually used, so it can be removed safely.)
