Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1Having dug deeper into this I think the change is wrong. The block of SetEditEngine() starting at line 1012 with if(bGrowCentered){} else if(bGrowToLeft){} else{} does not correspond to the block of EditGrowX() starting at line 1172 with if(bGrowCentered){} else if(bGrowBackwards){} else{}, but instead to the block starting at line 1260, which also is if(bGrowCentered){} else if(bGrowToLeft){} else{}. These blocks calculate the visual area, independent of the logical direction.

Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1--GetMark()->nContent might mean the same as GetMark()->nContent-- (I am not even sure, and I have 35 years of experience with C), but it makes the code much harder to understand. We don't want to do this kind of automatic blunt replacement.

Patch Set 4:*I uploaded the 4th patch because when you give me -1 on patch 3 there are an error in my code I checked it and fixed it.*This bug is a simple hack which I found it in the simple hacks list " https://wiki.documentfoundation.org/Development/Easy_Hacks/lists/by_Difficulty#Easy_Hacks_for_Beginners " Bug 89756*Here is someone also solved the same bug but she didn't fix all files which are mentioned in the Bug, so I fixed the rest " https://gerrit.libreoffice.org/#/c/14903/ "*Generally prefix bit better than postfix beacuse the compiler, upon seeing i++, creates a temporary object to hold the original value of i so that after the increment completes the original value of i can be returned.  A temporary is not required when compiling ++i since the value returned by the increment operation is the value i has after the increment has completed.  This means that i++ requires more memory and runs more slowly than ++i

Patch Set 4:We certainly don't want to sacrifice readability for imagined speed benefits not proved by profiling. Premature optimisation is evil. Patch Set 4:Thank you Markus, Caol鈹溍璶!Actually, this patch turned out to be not enough. It does fix the specific bug, but currently, there are too many problems with ScPostIt/SdrCaptionObj lifetime management that need to be addressed in a consistent fasion, so currently I'm preparing a draft specification for discussion of what changes are planned and why they are needed. That spec does describe why currently deletion of the object in real document (when, e.g. the ScPostIt was deleted by user) crashes the Undo/Redo operation (where only pointers to now-deleted object are stored). Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2AddGraphicObjectReference() is used for adding references of an existing graphic object. When there is no graphic object in the cache with the corresponding graphic ID, then no reason to add a reference (create a new cache entry instead).Next to that, AddGraphicObjectReference() fills its second parameter (rSubstitute) with the existing graphic object attributes, but if there is no such object this not make sense.Summary the code seems good to me as it was. No reason to use AddGraphicObjectReference() method here.

Patch Set 1:Sorry for this certainly naive question but about pId, what about creating a new pID with boost::scoped_ptr< GraphicID > apID; and apID.reset( new GraphicID( rObj ) ); in these cases?About the fact the cause of this bug is not in this part of code,  would it mean the patch makes the image stay just because of a side effect?

Patch Set 1:AddGraphicObject() has two kind of usages, which is not a good solution, but anyway..:So first usage when adding a full graphic object (with data), loaded from a file for example. In this case the code generates the graphic ID based on this object (apID). Checks the cache and create a new cache object or add a reference to an existing one. So it means actually adding an object to the cache.Second usage when "adding" an empty graphic object using an own ID (pID, this is used by save). This actually means getting the graphic object from the cache by ID. In this case the method fill the empty graphic object with the data what is found in the cache (if found).Yeap, it must be some side effect if this patch improve the situation.It can break things very badly, for me svtools_graphic test is crashes with this patch.

Patch Set 1:This patch does not repair the add-in function, but removes the add-in function from the UI and redirects old uses (saved in ods documents) to Calc's own GCD() function, which is fully ODFF1.2 compliant.The add-in GCD() function is only called when opening xls files, AFAICS.

Patch Set 2:@tml:Yes, The GCD() function is Calc matches the Excel function, with two notes:-Excel has limits for the size of the arguments (must be less than 2E53), Calc doesn't and never had that limit (neither Calc's own, nor add-in function);-Excel GCD accepts only integer arguments in Excel versions prior to 2007 and accepts floating point arguments since Excel 2007, Calc accepts all numeric arguments (both Calc's own as add-in function).It is quite common for Calc functions to be more tolerant with respect to type and/or numeric value limits than their Excel counterparts.

Patch Set 2:The analysis add-in LCM function uses the GCD function to create it's result.  If GCD_ADD must go then LCM_ADD should as well: it has at least as many error issues as GCD.  All of these (Gcd, Lcm, Mod, &?; built-in or add-in) use doubles for input and output values.  The IEEE double has a precision limit of some 50+ bits which is the mantissa width and hence it is the MS limit and an absolute 'natural' limit of precision in LO as well.

Patch Set 2:LeMoyne Castle, your suggestion to do the same for LCM_ADD could be a good one; I can't any bug reports on LCM_ADD though and I want this one (GCD_ADD) pushed first before submitting similar patches.The precision limit is not changed with my patch. My comment only intended to note the difference between many Excel functions and their Calc equivalent.

Patch Set 6:Hi Markus Mohrhard,As per OOXML specs, TickLabelSkip values from axis properties can not be zero. Thats why I made this change. I think its not correct that we set some wrong value  initially and later change it some other value at some other code. If this value is not available in XML then it should not be '0'. Before submitting this patch I verified UT's and tested many chart files manually too from all formats.Regards.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1So, as-is this compiles ... and crashes/asserts for now -- at least with a debug build.There have been some attempts to use unique_ptrs or scoped_ptrs on SwUnoCrsr -- however, as these are kept as naked pointer in SwUnoCrsrTbl too, which mindlessly deletes everything it still finds around on ~SwDoc, the ownership of these is a terrible mess.I'd suggest to use the blunt device of a shared_ptr as a starting point (and a weak_ptr in SwUnoCrsrTbl) to get somewhat sensible ownership of these in the mid-term.In the long run, the users of the SwUnoCrsrTbl should likely be listeners to all the SwUnoCrsrs (registered right in CreateUnoCrsr) and thus removing the need for having a SwUnoCrsrTbl in the first place. But that is still way off.So, as an intermediate step: using shared_ptrs.@mst, caolan: opinions? is this worth finalizing this?

Patch Set 1:> do we really need this? i.e. are there any unique_ptr<SwUnoCrsr> or > scoped_ptr<SwUnoCrsr> that are not on the stack but on the heap?various other UNO wrappers objects have them as members, quite a few as plain naked pointers. > do you clear the dead weak_ptr from the SwUnoCrsrTbl at some point? > any UNO call will create at least 3 new instances, so we should > release the memory at some point.Sure. For a start we should do that from ~SwUnoCrsr as it was done before -- that hardly will make it worse.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1See my general comments at <https://bugs.freedesktop.org/show_bug.cgi?id=86784#c2>.That said, if choosing this approach, please do not introduce an old-style properties-only UNO service here.  Keep it simple, add a bootstrap() overload that takes a String[] argument, say, allowing precise control over what arguments are passed (in addition to the --accept argument, and probably also in addition to the --nologo, --nodefault, --nolockcheck arguments, as discussed).

Patch Set 1:answered in fdo#86784.regarding your suggestion to have not .idl file --> no objections.regarding your suggestion to accept String[] instead of PropertyValue[]: In general I want to use the defaults from the simplified bootstrapping, but just be able to switch off (or override) particular options. If the defaults in simplified bootstrapping in future will be changed for an option that is not explicitely overridden, I want to benifit from these changes, so that I don't need to adjust my client code. I want to keep the client code as stupid as possible regarding how to start soffice. Any suggestion how this can be achieved with a String[] approach?

Patch Set 1:I hoped you were not right :-) But yes, if there are conflicting settings for different use cases, it could be the case that the client code needs to be adjusted - even with my approach. The chance for this is 2/6 (if I look at the current situation). But despite this matter of different views, for me there's another more interesting question:Did I understand right, that you suggested to also let the caller controll the "--accept=pipe,name=<sPipeName>;urp;" switch? Currently the pipe name is calculated within the bootstrap code and I really think that this is a detail should not be relevant for the caller. It's moving responsibility to a place where it should not be.

Patch Set 6:My main concern was that if hidden data was removed so far, then the default should be still removing, and only after using the option should it be possible that such previously removed hidden data is still mailed out.I'm not sure how the changed .xcu is supposed to work; probably then the config setting is "nil" by default, and you just don't handle the situation when extracting a bool from the setting fails.All in all, please do what Tor suggested to using the new configmgr API to read the setting, and also I think<prop oor:name="..." oor:type="xs:boolean" oor:nillable="false">would be better in the .xcs file, then you would have to provide an explicit default in the .xcu file:<prop oor:name="..." oor:type="xs:boolean">  <value>true</value></prop>That would ensure that no hidden content gets mailed out after an innocent upgrade.

Patch Set 6:* when making the prop non-nillable, the default needs to go directly into the xcs, not the xcu* one benefit of making props non-nillable is that the "new-style" code to access them becomes simpler, as a nillable prop is modelled by a boost::optional, and esp. for bool props C++ bool vs. boost::optional<bool> is error-prone* I don't think the ExternalMailer group is a good place for this prop; the prop is about how to dress up a document for sending, not about how to send a mail

Patch Set 2:"I can't understand under Windows: i must set the PATH to URE?"Yes, while the sofficeapp lib finds all its dependencies via its RPATH on Linux, it needs PATH set for that on Windows.It needs to find dependent libraries next to itself (e.g., the sfxlo lib) and in the URE lib dir (e.g., the sal lib).It is an error in the LOK code to hardcode the path to the URE lib dir, it should use the unoinfo executable (which is part of a stable interface) for that, as is done in odk/source/unoapploader/{unx,win}/unoapploader.c.On master towards LO 4.5, the contents of the URE lib dir will probably be folded into LO's program dir (and unoinfo adapted accordingly).  That means that for a LO >= 4.5, the LOK code will then only need to make sure that the sofficeapp lib finds dependencies next to itself.

Patch Set 2:The changes here are not really related to making LibreOfficeKit work on Windows, and just matters of taste, like the renaming of some functions, or allowing a relative path to an LibreOffice installation. But I'll look through closely and pick useful bits and commit (with credit to J鈹溾暆rgen).

Patch Set 6:My bad, sorry about that (I read the bugzilla comments without actually trying and poking at the code) ...But actually, the fix for this will be even more straightforward. The position of last selected slide is already saved into ODF, it is "SelectedPage" property, you can find it in settings.xml. Looks e.g. like this: <config:config-item config:name="SelectedPage" config:type="short">2</config:config-item>So, there is no need for you to create an extra setting in UnoDocumentSettings for that, you now only have to figure out why is this setting not used then the document is being loaded (hint: frmview.cxx, look for "sUNO_View_SelectedPage")

Patch Set 6:I still don't like introducing a new document-wide UNO setting when we already have a setting in ODF format doing exactly the same ...Anyway, I did some git archaeology and found out that this "Impress always opens on 1st slide" is an artificial restriction imposed by a design document + OOo feature request from 2005 (https://bz.apache.org/ooo/show_bug.cgi?id=50902)Moreover, keyboard accelerator listed therein (Shift-F5) that was supposed to be used to jump to the last edited slide (the one saved as SelectedPage) no longer works, since it is used for different purpose now (start a slideshow from current slide)So I think this restriction (always open on 1st slide, unless the presentation is an embedded OLE object) can nowadays be removed and that should be the way to fix this issue. I.e. removing this 'if ...( SFX_CREATE_MODE_EMBEDDED == pDoc->GetDocSh()->GetCreateMode()' condition when reading SelectedPage setting ... unless it crashes Impress or cause other nasties ...Anyway, I'm adding Thorsten to Cc: to get a second opinion on that ...
Patch Set 6:Katarina Behrens,Thanks for suggestions and the research.Yes it would be great if we could use the SelectedPage variable instead of adding another.Would wait for the reply from Thorsten.

This way the changes will not get saved to .odp file (not to mention other formats, such as .pptx, but that's prolly beyond the scope of easy hack)Or is this still work in progress?

Patch Set 5:The changes are being saved to the odp file when the file is saved because AFAIK,  UNO document settings are written again when we save the document.In settings.xml of the odp file:You can find<config:config-item config:name="CurrentPage" config:type="short">2</config:config-item>And if you modify document again and save at some other slide then, it would be modified:<config:config-item config:name="CurrentPage" config:type="short">4</config:config-item>Also the code in frmview.cxx  loads the current page while loading the document. (pDrawDoc->GetCurrentPage() )Can you please cherry-pick and try. I don't think we need that import and export code as mentioned in comment 3 on the bug page.Thanks for the letting me know about the variable naming, will fix that.

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-2To answer your question about how many icons are missing in Galaxy:Since the beginning of LibreOffice, contributors have been adding unfitting icons to Galaxy so that their features work in that theme as well as in Tango. Yes, a hideous approach. We are able to stop doing that now that we脭脟脰ve modified LibreOffice to stop considering Galaxy as the 脭脟拢parent脭脟脴 theme from which the rest is derived from.The default usage of Tango was also, back in 2010, a highlighted feature which helped to distinguish the newly released fork from OOo. The decision was made, among other reasons perhaps, on the basis that it was a more malleable icon theme (with sources available and compatible with our license) which we could modify to suit our needs. This is still a big advantage that would be lost if we switched to Galaxy in the platform with the most of our user base. Another big disadvantage is that it would make obsolete most, if not all, volunteer-writen guides.

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-2(3 comments)I just had a quick look at this mailmerge.py ... not pretty.BTW: you can drop the resolves from the commit message - just start with tdf#63388.Now for your patch.Normally one should try (in this order of preference): 1. StartTLS: SMTP + EHLO, check for STARTTLS and establish TLS (normally on port 25 or 587) 2. SSL/TLS: SMTP_S_ without STARTTLS (normally on port 465). This should directly start encrypted (SMTP_SSL)! 3. Insecure: SMTP (as 1.)The ports are just the well known ports, but servers can run on any.In the case of the SSL setting from LO, I would just probe 1 and 2 and skip 3. But feel free to update the GUI and add StartTLS.To be technically clear without probing one would need all three options: Insecure, Ssl and StartTLS.And note there is also the POP3 and IMAP code in this file, which should be unified in handling the connection setup. I'm not sure this is actually used. At the end all protocols offer the same three options.Anyway - you don't need to fix these too ;-)OTOH I'm unable to really test this. I'm just familiar with the LO C++ MM code, not the Python email handling backend.Currently a good read: https://www.fastmail.com/help/technical/ssltlsstarttls.htmlHope this comment doesn't shock you too much ;-)

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-2Yes, what Michael said is true. SdrPage's shapes are always sorted internally by z-order, which is always a consecutive sequence from 0 to N-1. But: 1/ This is an impl. detail of SdrPage. 2/ Even if it were not, it does not follow that any impl. of css::draw::XShapes must do that too, so relying on it in the export code is wrong.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1Looks lovely to me - but - I'm a tad concerned; in terms of making this a pure re-factor I think we need to ensure that widgets are destroyed at the same time as they were ...void IIIMPStatusWindow::dispose()+{+    m_aStatusBtn.clear();So - all of these type of dispose impls should be:if (m_aStatus.get()) m_aStatus.dispose(); m_aStatusBtn.clear();-except- that we really ought to have a helper method here to avoid recursion so:void doDispose(Reference<Foo> &rRef){     Reference<Foo> aTmp(rRef);     rRef.clear(); // we should use some 'swap' method ideally ;-)     rRef.dispose();    // unref as goes out of scope}And of course - we really need to move the body of ~Window into Window::dispose - (like almost all of it - and guard it against double disposes too ;)With those two in place this starts to look really sexy.Many thanks !

Patch Set 5:Hi Miklos,- I have been looking into the issue for visual disparity.- In order to understand the root cause of the visual disparity, studied what is missing/added to the XML which is leading to the visual disparity.- Compared the round trip file on master with the original file.- It is observed that the round trip file on master and the original file is not the same. The order of exporting the text and the table is different even on master.- Next, compared the round trip file  on my fix and the round trip file on master.- The sequence of writing the text and the table is same in these round trip files[master RT and fix RT].- Thus there is no regression added due to this fix.- Next, studied the styles.xml [master round trip vs fix round trip], it is observed that there is absolutely no difference.- Request you to have look on the screen shot --- http://wikisend.com/download/730630/OriginalMasterFix.png- I discussed with the DEV team here, as per our understanding, we can go ahead to with this patch as there is no technical difference between master and the Fix RT.- There is no critical issue like data loss and the main issue is with the corruption which has been resolved.- Let me know If I can re-base the patch with latest master and we can go ahead to merge this issue to master. Thanks :)

Patch Set 5:> Thus there is no regression added due to this fix.Sorry, this is not what I see. http://people.freedesktop.org/~vmiklos/2014/gerrit9914/2014-08-01/ clearly shows the regression this patch would introduce. Patch Set 2:Thanks for your review, David.First of all, i was wrong in the commit message. I should have written 'GetDenominator()==0'About if it is necessary or not.. i think that it is not immediately necessary.I identify three usages of invalid fractions:a) the fraction is created with Fraction(long nNum, long nDen). This allow create a fraction with zero denominator.b) the fraction is created with Fraction(double dVal). This allow the creation of invalid fraction if dVal is out of a long range, in which case the numerator is set to zero and the denominator is set to -1.c) if at least one of the operands in an operation is invalid, or if the result of an operation with valid operands is out of a long range, the result is an invalid fraction with numerator set to zero and denominator set to -1.In some pieces of the code i see conditions using GetDenominator()==0, which are false if we check against invalid fraction due "overflow" (cases b) and c)), but true against GetDenominator()==1.In my previous commit, 2ce0aededea43231d91a0955fc0676120dcc4f13, i missed the case 'divide by zero' or 'zero denominator'. In that commit we catch a division by zero when initialize a Fraction as an invalid value due "overflow".I think that we can do the following:a) revert the commit 2ce0aededea43231d91a0955fc0676120dcc4f13 and try a best effort in rewrite the Fraction classb) add two invalid cases in the Fraction implementation rewrite: "overflow" and "divide by zero", then we can rewrite the conditions such "GetDenominator()==0" as "IsDivideByZero()" (this patch)c) rewrite the conditions such "GetDenominator()==0" as "!IsValid()", but that can modify the usage of Fraction values, due that in some cases, in the if block of GetDenominator()==0 i'm see usages of GetNumerator(). An example is include/svx/svdtrans.hxx in ResizePoint: if (xFact.GetDenominator()==0) xFact=Fraction(xFact.GetNumerator(),1); // DivZero abfangenI'm waiting for your commentsGreetings

Patch Set 2:The include/svx/svdtrans.hxx example is not very convincing to me. IMHO the a/0 -> a/1 change just replaces one meaningless value by another meaningless value. It would be equally good (or bad) to use 1/1... Also, this code does not handle the overflow case .

Patch Set 2:Is good for you abandon this patch and rewrite all conditions 'GetDenominator()==0' as '!IsValid()'?I use the reverted commit http://cgit.freedesktop.org/libreoffice/core/commit/?id=47a2d7642d249d70b5da0c330a73f3a0032e4bba for search the 'GetDenominator()==0' cases.
AbandonedRewrite 'Fraction::GetDenominator()==0' conditions as '!Fraction::IsValid()' and use a value of Fraction(1,1) if the invalid fraction value is used inside a block

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1So, Markus and I had the same discussion years ago.  The reason why we still keep auto_ptr there was 2 things: 1) make the code exception safe, and 2) ptr_set requires auto_ptr to be passed to be truly exception safe.  2) is a loose requirement and you can also pass a raw pointer to ptr_set (as you noticed).  But your current change is a step backward in terms of 1).The best strategy for this use case is to use o3tl::heap_ptr to replace auto_ptr, and call heap_ptr's release() when passing it to ptr_set.  Then the code remains exception safe and we can get rid of auto_ptr.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2I don't really like that solution, as it would codify in the stable URE interface that on non-Windows wchar_t is 32-bit and represents UTF-32 code units, which need not hold in general.  (Also, include files that are part of the stable URE interface must not depend on Boost, but that would be a minor issue to fix.)  I would rather prefer to find a different fix for the underlying problem, and continue discussion by mail.

Patch Set 1:> codify in UR that on non-Windows wchar_t is 32-bit and represents UTF-32 code unitsWell, that's an implementation "bug". When LibreOffice is ported to a platform where it is not the case, the implementation can be updated for this platform. Or we could implement this function in a more portable way, for example using iconv (but polishing the code to fix the memory leak and all that):static iconv_t cnv = iconv_open("UTF-16", "WCHAR_T");sal_Unicode *buf=calloc(len, 2*sizeof(sal_Unicode))size_t cnvlen =  sizeof(2*sal_Unicode*len)const size_t cps = iconv(cnv, &str, &len, &buf, &cnvlen)rtl_uStringbuffer_insert( &pData, &nCapacity, getLength(), buf, cps );I actually think implementing this feature in a robust way it would be a service to C++ extensions (even if it does not get used much within LibreOffice).As far as the needs of connectivity/odbc are concerned, I'm happy with the solution suggested by email.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1(1 comment)Hi Yogesh, thanks for looking into this.I was worried about the change to wrtw8sty.cxx so I had a bit of a look at the bug myself to understand it better.  I found two different issues which contribute:- the import from docx appears to have a bug which is at play here: when I open the docx in LibreOffice I see that the first page footer has wrong spacing. This affects the export code which tries to join chained page styles into a single word section if they match.  The import bug means that they do not match, so it will try to export this as two different word sections.- however some code recently added to ww8/ww8atr.cxx in a31fbb53dba7 prevents the output of a new section at the page break in this case, as the paragraph on the first page is empty             if( isTextNodeEmpty )                bNewPageDesc = false;So I think these are the two issues that need to be addressed, rather than the change proposed in this item.  Fixing either one of them will solve the reported issue for this document, but it would be great to fix both.

Patch Set 1:Markus,I have not looked at xls, nor at specific binary filter routines, but at the code in general.I have two reasons:1. the pre-patched code consists of a mix of sal_uInt8 and sal_uInt16;2. from previous bug fixes I remember the advise to use size_t for size() types.If it is important to ascertain that the size does not exceed the xls limit, either all types should be sal_uInt8 or a specific check should be added. I would prefer the last option and not 'count' on overflow errors.Finally, as I don't want to mix this change with the fdo40835 patch, I submitted this as a separate patch.

Patch Set 1:The advise to use size_t is correct for common code but there are a few differences when dealing with binary formats.It is much more important to pay attention to the size of the types and we had in the past problems with refactorings silently introducing bugs when they changed the type.I think it makes more sense to keep the sal_uInt8 and if really necessary (I'm not sure that more than potentially an assert is neccessary right now) add a check in one central place.The two places that use sal_uInt16 look fine to me as they are like that to make the casting explicit.So all in all I don't see a reason why we would need to change anything in that piece of code right now.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1I see.The root problem on the LO side is that INetURLObject eagerly normalizes URLs, so something passed in as <file:///c;/...> gets passed out again as <file:///c%3B/...>.  Fixing this is quite a task, but eventually should be addressed.The problem with the proposed patch is that while it fixes this single problem, it may break others.  That aMustEncodeMap is used centrally in INetURLObject for all the different URI schemas, and ";" does have syntactical significance within path segments in general (e.g., in ftp URLs).  Also, would the odd behavior of MS Office 2010 be restricted to ";" vs. "%3B", or are there further characters that would need "fixing?"Also, how severe is this problem in practice?  What is the user's intent in making the URL dysfunctional by replacing ":" with ";"---is it about the user inadvertently introducing a typo?In short, I see no better fix than eventually tackling the root problem as described above.

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1Not ready yet, but now you should see something. The problem is that adding non-layout widgets as children to a dialog makes it snap into non-layout mode (for backwards compatibility) and so it breaks. If you --enable-dbgutil then you get the warning messages about this.So I mapped GtkSpinner to Throbber and converted that over for you and added a custom widget for the other case. (You can extends its "Init" to get the extra stuff it needs in there that used to go in via the ctor)

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1I don't think we need a special release_assert in addition to normal assert.  All it takes is to not define NDEBUG for release builds.  Any existing assert calls that are inappropriately resource-intensive for release builds can be wrapped in OSL_DEBUG_LEVEL etc. (I assume there to be very little if any of those).(I also see no need for what is effectively a redefinition of a typical C runtime's assert macro definition; all C runtimes that are relevant for us should already offer at least the same quality with the stock assert macro.)(Also, introducing macros with short, easily clashing names into a base include file would not be good.)

Patch Set 5:Hi Miklos,SDR object`s SetName() and GetName() functions are used for storing the shape's <id> value.In the case of a watermark object, this value is something like "PowerPlusWaterMarkObject93701316".Word uses the shape's ID to determine if this is a watemark object (it looks for the pattern "PowerPlusWaterMark" in the shape's ID).So, specifically with watermark objects - the shape's ID needs to be preserved.Thus the use of 'GetName' and 'SetName'.In addition, the 'o:spid' needs to be preserved, thus the addition of the new variable - 'msShapeOriginalId'.Hope this clarifies it.

Patch Set 5: This need some tweaks before it is merged> In addition, the 'o:spid' needs to be preservedThis is the part I don't get. Do you want to preserve it as part of preserving all the attributes, or you know the meaning of this attribute? The VML spec (鈹?19.1.2.19) says that this is an additional optional identifier, i.e. it doesn't say anything what's the purpose of this attribute.Based on that, handling this via InteropGrabBag sounds like a better option to me: but even if we do it as a normal property, then I think you misunderstood the meaning of "o" in "o:spid" -- "o" refers to "office" there, not "original".(And needless to say, either please also update the ODF filters if not going witth InteropGrabBag or at least state in the commit message that you plan to update them in the next commit.)

AbandonedI'm going to pull this... I've misunderstood how the SalGraphics interface is working. GetGraphics returns a NULL if the graphics instance is being used, it pulls back the graphics instance if it released and blocks it from reuse, otherwise if there is NO graphics device at all (either released or blocked) then it creates the graphics device and then returns the newly created graphics.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1I am afraid this is not exactly what we should be doing here.  The DataChanged() is a kind of fallback in case we were subclassing Application; so that the subclass can implement its own DataChanged() and react accordingly.  [In general, please be careful when changing signature of a virtual function, as when it changes in a superclass, but not in the subclasses, it usually leads to situations that the code in subclasses is not called any more.]The VCLEVENT_APPLICATION_DATACHANGED broadcast is kind of unrelated here, it is broadcasting to the others, does not affect the application itself.I am tempted to abandon your change, sorry for that :-( - unless you think nobody is actually using or going to use the Application's DataChanged(), and in that case we should just remove it from Application for good?
AbandonedThat's a fair call :-) My understanding was limited.

AbandonedI am sorry, but prefer not to do this :-)  The caller of PostUserEvent is notified when the call hasn't succeeed, because in that case the PostUserEvent returns 0, so it is responsibility of the caller to judge if it was an error situation, or not - too much SAL_WARN's in not-so-much-error cases can lead to programmers actually ignoring what it is trying to tell them :-)

Patch Set 1:Looking good - to readd it to this change, you need to run:git rebase -iThis will take you into your favourite text editor. Take the latter change (the last line) and where it says "pick" change this to "s". This "squashes" the commit into the previous commit. Save and exit the editor. At this point, you might be taken into another editor session, remove all the comments (and Gerrit changeset ID) from the commit you just squashed. Then save and exit again. It should rebase the changes into the first commit with the first commit message. Then push the change to gerrit again as you did last time.

Patch Set 1: Do not mergePlease try to provide atomic changes instead of all-in-one commit.We decided to interact with Bluetooth without user脭脟脰s interaction at all. Yes, Android脭脟脰s guide insists on showing a dialog but in such case this dialog should be shown on *every* launch which is *extremely* annoying. The concept of 脭脟拢work and auto-do things without touching any buttons or dialogs脭脟脴 is a lot better for everyone.BluetoothOperator is a layer of abstraction. For example, on Jelly Bean the BluetoothAdapter instance should be acquired the other way if you read the comment. Using your solution means replace simple call *everywhere* with something like 脭脟拢if (Build.VERSION >= JELLY_BEAN) then ... else ...脭脟脴. Makes a little sense for me. Another layer of abstraction actually helps readability this way.I cannot review other things because the commit is really huge. Can you consider opening an issue on Bugzilla first we discuss your problems with Bluetooth first and then fixing them instead of 脭脟拢recode everything脭脟脴?

Patch Set 1:> Please try to provide atomic changes instead of all-in-one commit.I can try to split it up, but of course only if there is a chance to get the changes in (honestly: without major changes in the way BT is handled, I'd not recommend the remote to anyone)> in such case this dialog should be shown on *every* launch No, only when BT wasn't enabled already. And how often do you launch the Remote, how often do you give a talk? Once a day? Once a Week? Once a Month or even just one year at a conference?> which is *extremely* annoying.I started and used the remote for testing quite a bit, and I think hitting OK is neither extremely annoying, nor very timeconsuming.> The concept of 脭脟拢work and auto-do things without touching any buttons or dialogs脭脟脴 is a lot better for everyone./That/ was a good one. The current remote* doesn't list bonded devices, I have to set the computer to be visible just to use the remote.脭氓脝 this involves more steps and clicks than just hitting "OK" directly after launching the remote (only if BT wasn't already enabled.* frequently enough kills my BT, so I have to reboot the phone to be able to turn on bluetooth again. Now /that/ is annoying.> BluetoothOperator is a layer of abstraction. For example, on Jelly Bean the BluetoothAdapter instance should be acquired the other way if you read the comment.That is only a concern once the API is completely removed and a check is needed. Until then, no problem to get rid offunciton do_stuff { return do_this(); }function do_this { reutrn call_something_else(); }function call_something_else { return A != B }> Another layer of abstraction actually helps readability this way.Having to traverse multiple files and even then multiple one-line-functions to track back a simple boolean comparison doesn't help readability at all. I find it highly annoying and irritating, like artificially obscuring what the code does by hiding it under a long chain of function calls.functions that are only called by one single other method, with no chances of being reused.You mention that aquiring the bt adapter might require version checks, but honestly: Before you use different api by checking the runtime version, you rather keep using the deprecated version that works flawlessly. > I cannot review other things because the commit is really huge.It just looks large, the changes themselves are small.> Can you consider opening an issue on Bugzilla first we discuss your problems with Bluetooth first and then fixing them instead of 脭脟拢recode everything脭脟脴?The problems are:* not showing known (bonded) devices, forcing the user to make the computer visible* forcing a discovery on every start, on every use, that is useless for most users, as they usually use the same devices. So they are known, and after initial pairing set to   hidden, so even the search would not show result.* even doing the recovery in an endless loop* killing the BT connection when rotating the screenProbably the last one in combination with the automatically started discovery is what puts my BT adapter in a non-working state where I cannot enable it anymore and have to reboot the device.

With the outer border now applied to the adjacent cells, applying another border to such adjacent cell effectively overwrites the outer border of the previous border. Patch Set 2:Patch set 2 is 'work in progress', well not so much progress at the moment ;)Notes:1. _ODF functions are saved as _ODF. FormulaCompiler::CreateStringFromToken() is not only called when saving to file, so using that function to rename _ODF functions, will rename them in the UI as well (and behave like non-_ODF function).2. when reading file, FormulaCompiler::Factor() also renames functions in qa and unit tests, giving unwanted and unjust exceptions.3. I changed behaviour of CEILING and FLOOR as I found out that CEILING(1.3;;) was accepted by MustHaveParamCount( nParamCount, 2, 3 ) in ScCeiling() resp. ScFloor(). Now empty is not translated to 0 (when this setting is enabled), but I think this should be done as preparation for the ODF1.2 compliant CEILING/FLOOR functions.

Patch Set 2: This need some tweaks before it is mergedAs mentioned on the mailing list, introducing *_ODF functions in the file formats is not the way to go.Btw, you can submit draft code for gerrit review by pushing it to refs/drafts/master instead of refs/publish/master, so git push logerrit HEAD:refs/drafts/masteror if you're using the logerrit script ./logerrit submit-draftThe difference of draft is, that only the reviewer(s) you add will see the change, others don't. May be better than just having WIP in the summary and no one accidentally reviews and pushes it, though the chance with these changes here would be rare ;-)

Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is mergedWhile the code looks ok from a first glance (I didn't verify yet) it will not solve the problem. The IANA language tag registry does not define default scripts for languages, it only defines suppress-script for a few. For all other languages you'd still not get the script. See instdir/share/liblangtag/language-subtag-registry.xmlFurthermore, we avoid at all costs to pull in liblangtag if not necessary (hence all the internal handling of known tags in canonicalize()) because (despite that the rsc resource compiler can't use liblangtag) it needs a significant amount of time to initialize its data, which at startup would add ~10% of startup time. If VCL needed liblangtag already just to display some glyphs that would be a heavy drawback.My suggestion to solve this would be to add an extra default script field in i18nlangtag/source/isolang/isolang.cxx to aImplIsoLangEntries and aImplBcp47CountryEntries and change the lang::Locale returns of MsLangId::Conversion::*() methods to a struct of Locale and additionally a Script field. They are used only internally by LanguageTag and not part of a public API so that would be no problem. Of course doing so would need quite some changes and finding all default scripts for all known locales would be a lot of investigation work.

Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is mergedThe invariant here (ImplEdgePointFilter::Input, ImplEdgePointFilter::LastPoint; tools/source/generic/poly.cxx) apparently is that mnLastOutside is only read if mbFirst is false.  And as mbFirst is initialized to true, and mnLastOutside written when mbFirst switches to false, all is fine as it is.If you really feel the need to initialize mnLastOutside in the ctor (to silence false warnings from static analyzers, say), a better way than to arbitrarily pick 0 for initialization is to go with value-initialization and probably a comment, see <http://lists.freedesktop.org/archives/libreoffice/2013-October/056756.html> "[Libreoffice-commits] bogus WaE: 'bValue' may be used uninitialized in this function."

Patch Set 1:"BUT, as it appears in include/sal/config.h it is also part of the SDK and extensions use it, so I guess we can't completely eliminate it and at least {osl,sal,rtl} need to live on with it. Or?"I would not mind changing include/sal/config.h to use _WIN32 and odk/settings/settings.mk to no longer set -DWIN32 in an incompatible [API CHANGE] commit.  There are no occurrences of WIN32 across odk/examples/ at least, so hopefully it is not used too widely in third party code either.  There might be third party build systems that do not use the SDK and currently do -DWIN32 "manually," but even if they are not adapted that's harmless as _WIN32 is implicitly defined by the compiler.However, there is a number of -DWIN32 in other parts of our code base (RepositoryExternal.mk, external/, redland/, soltools/) that should be audited, too.

Patch Set 1:This patch contains a possible way to load English or local add-in function names, depending on the global setting 'use English function names'. I wonder if this is the right way to do that. Currently, changing the global settings only is effected after a restart of LibreOffice; I haven't found a neat way yet to do this inmediately.The class ScUnoAddInFuncData has members aUpperName and aUpperLocal. It would seem to be logical to use these members, making a switch between local and English function names easy and efficient, but the 'normal' function list isn't used this way either. Why is this, or am I wrong?Some other lines in the code may possibly be removed, I would like some expert's opinion on this (see comments in the code).Any hints/suggestions on this subject is welcome :)(I will probably not be able to respond till 16 September or so, please don't be offended if I don't respond sooner.)

Patch Set 1:Uhm, so yes, seeing the patch and reading the bug, I indeed didn't realize that the intent is the opposite. However, are we sure this would be a worthy effort?My understanding is that typically a random source file in $srcdir/$module/source/sub/foo.cxx has -I for:- $srcdir/include- $module/inc- (sometimes) $module/source/sub/incIf getting rid of the second is the target, and the benefit is one less compile switch at a cost of modifying tons of source files -- is that really good?

Patch Set 1:This needs to be tested with buildbot.I made this patch with this bash script:#!/bin/bashfor k in `find $1/source -type f \( -name "*.cxx" -o -name "*.h" \) -print`do        echo 'File ' $k        for i in `grep "#include" $k`        do                  > ret                 if [ "$i" == "#include" ]; then                        continue                fi                  echo "Testing $i"                make $1.clean 1>/dev/null                sed "s|#include $i|\/\/test#include $i|g" "$k" > "$k".alter                rm $k                mv $k.alter $k                make $1 2> ret 1>/dev/null                if cat ret | grep -w 'error' 2>/dev/null 1>/dev/null                then                        sed "s|\/\/test#include $i|#include $i|g" "$k" > "$k".alter                        rm $k                        mv $k.alter $k                fi          donedoneSo, this script do a "make clean", comments a include, do a make, and if this throws an error, this script uncomment that include.So, this script helps us to find useless includes.Maybe the buildbot could find some mistakes, but this build nicely in Linux.

Patch Set 1: Do not mergeAgree strongly with thorsten. We should not rely on a nested inclusion of one system or own header by including another. On the contrary, we should always explicitly include all headers that declare API used in a particular source file. OK, so maybe not completely so; it's OK to include headers *whose purpose* is to include other headers.

Patch Set 8:how do one end up with CR in autogen.input ?that seems to indicate very bad editor setting, andyou should fail on autogen.input rather than risk polluting the rest of the code no?

Patch Set 8:> how do one end up with CR in autogen.input ? that seems to indicate very bad editor setting,Text editors on Windows use CRLF for line endings as default settings when they create new file. I think it isn't bad editor setting. I encountered fdo#66885 when I create new autogen.input file.Of cause when we open existing file, almost editors including I used adapts the existing file's line endings so it hardly occurs that writing CR on text file with LF.> ... and you should fail on autogen.input rather than risk polluting the rest of the code no?I think no. Because detecting polluted text files is the job of git's hook script or code review. It's not the job of autogen.input. Plus, git's hook script and code reviewing can't check autogen.input's line endings effectively. Therefore permitting CRLF for autogen.input is the best solution for fdo#66885.

Patch Set 8: Do not mergeI agree with Norbert. We want an editor that is used to create new files with unix file-endings, in the worse case, run dos2unix on your autogen.input file. As much as I liked the patch with the ignoring of empty lines, I don't line the CRLF one.

Patch Set 2: This need some tweaks before it is mergedsorry for taking so long to look at this, had something urgent to do last week and then forgot about it :(trying to fix a redlining bug... that's very ambitious :)from just trying it out it doesn't appear to work fully yet; with the steps from the bug description it appears to be even worse than before: the second paragraph gets reformatted to the style of the first (fully deleted) one when creating the redline, which did not happen before.this is also not reverted when Undo is applied...on Redo i get an assert from ~SwIndexReg but that is totally not your fault, happens without your bug too (note to self: investigate that).some obvious problems with the approach:- AppendRedline() is not really prepared to do changes that would require Undo- AppendRedline() may call itself recursively in case there are already existing redlines at that position; probably we would only want to modify styles for an actual newly inserted redline, not for something that has been inserted previously (since in that case the adjustment has already been done?)- the newly inserted redline can be split up too, do we want this to be done twice then?perhaps it would be better to do this in the caller of AppendRedline, when a new DELETE redline is created?hmm... the various RecurseThroughLinkedRedline calls don't appear to do anything with Undo either...of course this being redlining there are many non-obvious problems that i haven't thought of yet :)anyway this needs to be fully revert-able on Undo before it goes in.

Patch Set 2:>This need some tweaks before it is mergedOK> sorry for taking so long to look at this, had something urgent to do last week and then forgot about it :(Don't worry> trying to fix a redlining bug... that's very ambitious :)Indeed脭脟陋 it takes me some time to figure out what was going wrong and how to solve it.> from just trying it out it doesn't appear to work fully yet; with the steps from the bug description it appears to be even worse than before: the second paragraph gets reformatted to the style of the first (fully deleted) one when creating the redline, which did not happen before.It was done one purpose, it's the behaviour I want.When you activate the redlining (Edit 脭氓脝 Changes 脭氓脝 Record) without showing the changes ("Edit 脭氓脝 Changes 脭氓脝 Show" disabled) and you delete a paragraph the next one gets reformatted. Why should it be different when the changes are shown.When the modification showing is disabled the paragraphs linked by "deletion redline" became one and so are formatted with the same attributes. It should be the same when the modification showing is enable (else it became confusing for the user) so the patch makes sure all the formats (direct and named) applied to one paragraph are applied to the paragraphs linked with it by deletion redlines.> this is also not reverted when Undo is applied...I know, I put a TODO line in SwDoc::AppendRedline.I will try to handle Undo脭脟陋> AppendRedline() may call itself recursively in case there are already existing redlines at that position; probably we would only want to modify styles for an actual newly inserted redline, not for something that has been inserted previously (since in that case the adjustment has already been done?)What makes you believe AppendRedline can be called recursively?> the newly inserted redline can be split up too, do we want this to be done twice then?I don't get it脭脟陋> hmm... the various RecurseThroughLinkedRedline calls don't appear to do anything with Undo either...Indeed, I didn't bother about Undo when I was writing the patch (redlining was difficult enough). I will try to adapt it.> anyway this needs to be fully revert-able on Undo before it goes in.Understood

Patch Set 2:> It was done one purpose, it's the behaviour I want. When you activate the redlining (Edit 脭氓脝 Changes 脭氓脝 Record) without showing the changes ("Edit 脭氓脝 Changes 脭氓脝 Show" disabled) and you delete a paragraph the next one gets reformatted. Why should it be different when the changes are shown.indeed it shouldn't be different - but what should happen is that when Changes->Show is off, the next paragraph shouln't be reformatted.  the deletion with change tracking should have the _same_ result as deletion without change-tracking, and if you delete a paragraph _completely_ nothing of it should be "merged" into a neighboring paragraph.> When the modification showing is disabled the paragraphs linked by "deletion redline" became one and so are formatted with the same attributes.ah yes one fundamental problem with Writer redlining is that the Changes->Show, which is a View option, actually moves the deletion redlines around in the _Model_, which is totally insane.i've wanted to fix this for years but haven't had the time, this will probably take months to fix... perhaps after GSoC :)the redlines are also moved around on document load/store.well ideally the moving-around should not affect the part of the text that isn't inside a deletion redline but evidently that isn't the case currently.>> AppendRedline() may call itself recursively in case there are already existing redlines at that position; probably we would only want to modify styles for an actual newly inserted redline, not for something that has been inserted previously (since in that case the adjustment has already been done?)>What makes you believe AppendRedline can be called recursively?see e.g. docredln.cxx lines 612 644 1038 1085...>> the newly inserted redline can be split up too, do we want this to be done twice then?> I don't get it脭脟陋see docredln.cxx line 644 1085[...](btw i've fixed that ~SwIndexReg assertion now which actually happened on copying the deleted text to the clipboard, thanks to "clipit" tool i have running...)

Patch Set 2:>> It was done one purpose, it's the behaviour I want. When you activate the redlining (Edit 脭氓脝 Changes 脭氓脝 Record) without showing the changes ("Edit 脭氓脝 Changes 脭氓脝 Show" disabled) and you delete a paragraph the next one gets reformatted. Why should it be different when the changes are shown.> indeed it shouldn't be different - but what should happen is that when Changes->Show is off, the next paragraph shouldn't be reformatted. the deletion with change tracking should have the _same_ result as deletion without change-tracking, and if you delete a paragraph _completely_ nothing of it should be "merged" into a neighboring paragraph.I think it is not possible, it is not allowed by the 5.5.4 section of the OpenDocument v1.2 standard.For example :  first paragraph formated in format1  second paragraph formated in format2Imagine we delete the first paragraph and the beginning of the second.Three possibility the for the <text:deletion> :* inside a paragraph (<text:p>)* inside a header (<text:h>)* outsideFor this example "inside a header" isn't relevant.If the <text:deletion> isn't put inside a paragraph and we enable the redline showing then the second paragraph will be cut in paragraph. So the third case is not possible in this example.So the <text:deletion> has to be inside a paragraph.When the <text:deletion> is placed inside a paragraph "to reconstruct the original text [脭脟陋] insert the content that was deleted, but remove all leading start tags up to and including the first <text:p> element 脭脟陋".So if you want that the remaining part of the second paragraph to have the same format when redline showing is enabled or disabled, the first and the second paragraph have to have the same format.If not :* When the redline showing is disabled : <format1><skipped redline>second part of the second paragraph* When the redline showing is enabled : <format1><redline beginning mark>first paragraph\n<format2>second paragraph beginning<redline end mark>second paragraph end.

Patch Set 2:section 5.5.4 of the ODF spec is not all that well written and should be more explicit about what may or should happen with the attributes of the first/last paragraph... see also:https://tools.oasis-open.org/issues/browse/OFFICE-2796if you try a deletion that does not delete a whole paragraph at the start, then we can actually do something sensible, the ODF looks like this:     <text:deletion>      <text:h text:style-name="Heading_20_1" text:outline-level="1">cate</text:h>      <text:p text:style-name="Standard">adfkad</text:p>     </text:deletion>   ...   <text:h text:style-name="Heading_20_1" text:outline-level="1">Frobni<text:change text:change-id="ct140010071431448"/>fasdf</text:h>so the attributes of the first and last paragraphs are stored inside the <text:deletion> and are restored when the change is rejected.if the first paragraph is deleted completely it should work the same way but the code that moves the redlines around on file-save messes things up.so i wondered what other ODF supporting word processors do:MSO notoriously does not support ODF change tracking at all.Calligra Words apparenly does not support change tracking.AbiWord appears to do change tracking but does not store it in ODF format (it does store in its "native" .abw format).for the "delete whole paragraph" case AbiWord does it right: the following paragraph keeps the formatting it had before.

Patch Set 1: Do not mergeAgree with Petr here 脭脟么 way back when I was still a user of AutoPlay presentations, I used them because they seemed more like standalone applications to me.I see these major uses of AutoPlay presentations:* wanting to avoid having to go through the entire presentation software in front of your audience* wanting to make things easier (e.g. think, a secretary preparing a presentation for a rather tech-illiterate boss, "just double-click this icon and it starts")* sending colleagues "funny"/"cute" slideshowsNone of these applications is really helped by leaving the application open at the end.What may be a better idea would be to add an item "Edit Presentation" to the in-presentation context menu.

Patch Set 1: (4 inline comments)1) IMHO the negative year fix should go in independently of the time zone issue.3) Why should DateTimeRange contain only one time zone, as opposed to one for   the start value and one for the end value?3) You add time zone information to dates. I don't know the meaning of that.   What would it mean, how would it behave, what would it be used for?   For example, naively, one would think that combining a date with a time,   one would get a datetime. How does one get a datetime by combining   2003-05-17+05 with 23:00-06?   FWIW, SQL does not define a DATE WITH TIME ZONE type.4) I have my doubts about time-zoned time without a date.   How do you convert 20:00+00 to time zone +10?   Just "wrap around" modulo 24, i.e. make it 06:00+10?   If you answer yes to that question (that is, always compute modulo 24),   then what is the difference between 06:00+11 and 06:00-13?   The difference only makes sense if one speaks of dates...   Which says that timezones don't make sense unless we know at what date   to apply them.   FWIW, SQL defines a TIME WITH TIME ZONE TYPE, *but* here's what   the PostgreSQL documentation has to say about it:   The type time with time zone is defined by the SQL standard, but the definition exhibits properties which lead to questionable usefulness. In most cases, a combination of date, time, timestamp without time zone, and timestamp with time zone should provide a complete range of date/time functionality required by any application.   (...) we recommend using date/time types that contain both date and time when using time zones. We do not recommend using the type time with time zone (though it is supported by PostgreSQL for legacy applications and for compliance with the SQL standard).I have half a mind to add timezone *only* to DateTime and DateTimeRange,not to Date and not to Time. Note that this would more-or-less eliminateall conversion problems, and "unlock" the scenario "don't add timezoneto structs, but convert everything to UTC", since conversion of datetimevalues across timezones is AFAIK well-defined. "Convert everything to UTC"is SQL's behaviour; in SQL all non-timezoned values are assumed to be atlocal time and a date is converted to the timestamp "same date at time 00:00".Alternative approach to your "isTimezoned": have a separate struct "DateTimeTZ"?Your "isTimezoned" flag should IMHO be called "isUTC".Do we actually *need* *any* "unknown timezone / local timezone" value in memory?We could just make some assumption (UTC or local TZ) on import/parse/readand store only UTC in memory. Oh, but it would be convenient for our APIs to havethe capacity to take implicitly-localTZ values, yes.If we go the "assume that values without explicit time zone are in local time" route,then that flag should be called "isUTC".So, I've spoken of what SQL does as a reference;https://wiki.documentfoundation.org/Development/LibreOffice4#Changes_deferred_until_4.1mentions XMLSchema-2. Let's see what it does for another reference: - It (optionally) timezones everything: date, time and datetime. - I don't see a datetimerange in it. - It understands a date as a 24-hour interval   (a DateTimeRange, from date 00:00:00.00000000 to 23:59:59.999999999 for most days,    that is except for leap seconds),    while SQL seems to consider it more like an instant, time 00:00 at that day. - A value without timezone is "unknown timezone" and not comparable   to a value with timezone, but on the other hand, section 3.2.7 also calls   untimezoned values "local values", which supports the idea that they are   "local time". But "local time" is unspecified in an interchange file format,   because the file may move from one timezone to the other.   In SQL, everything is convertible/comparable because each session has an   active "local timezone" which is used for all untimezoned values.Pragmatically, how close to XMLSchema-2 do we need to be?1) Is there any part of ODF/OOXML/any other format where we need to import   or export a date with timezone?2) Is there any part of ODF/OOXML/any other format where we need to import   or export a time (*not* datetime) with timezone?3) Is there any part of ODF/OOXML/any other format where there can be a   datetime with timezone OR a datetime without timezone and the difference   has some semantic significance (other than "interpret value without   timezone in this timezone").4) Is there any part of ODF/OOXML/any other format where we need to import   or export a datetime value without timezone and preserve unmodified as   without timezone?   The kind of scenario I'm thinking of is:   We read a datetime value without timezone from some file, and the file   does not give a context that tells us what time zone to interpret that in,   the user changes stuff, but not the part with that datetime value,   *and* when saving the file again, we need to write back the same value,   as opposed to say the UTC value of that datetime-in-local-timezone   or the same datetime value with local-timezone affixed.5) Is there any part of ODF/OOXML/any other format where we need to import   or export a datetime value without timezone, do changes on it and preserve   it as without timezone?   The kind of scenario I'm thinking of is:   We read a datetime value without timezone from some file, and the file   does not give a context that tells us what time zone to interpret that in,   the user e.g. tells us "add one hour to that datetime value",   *and* when saving the file again, we need to write back the new value   as untimezoned, as opposed to say the UTC value of that   datetime-in-local-timezone or the same datetime value with local-timezone   affixed.

Patch Set 2:> 1) IMHO the negative year fix should go in independently of the time zone issue.negative year fix pushed to master> 2) Why should DateTimeRange contain only one time zone, as opposed to one for> the start value and one for the end value?it appears to me to unnecessarily complicate things with 2 timezones inDateTimeRange; also it makes it possible to have Start timezoned and Endnon-timezoned which is rather meaningless; having just 1 timezone putsthe obligation on whoever constructs the thing to make it consistent> 3) You add time zone information to dates. I don't know the meaning of that.> What would it mean, how would it behave, what would it be used for? in XMLSchema-2 a Date is really a 24-hour interval... so the timezonewould shift the interval on the "universal" UTC time-line.http://www.w3.org/TR/xmlschema-2/#date> For example, naively, one would think that combining a date with a time,> one would get a datetime. How does one get a datetime by combining> 2003-05-17+05 with 23:00-06?that's a very good question.  apparently Time is a set of infinitely manypoints on the "universal" UTC time-line, with 24 hour distance between them.a Time with timezone is simply offset that much (modulo 24:00).so i think the DateTime you get by combining these is uniquely determined byintersecting the Date 24-hour interval with the Time set of points. > FWIW, SQL does not define a DATE WITH TIME ZONE type.> > 4) I have my doubts about time-zoned time without a date.> How do you convert 20:00+00 to time zone +10?> Just "wrap around" modulo 24, i.e. make it 06:00+10?yes> If you answer yes to that question (that is, always compute modulo 24),> then what is the difference between 06:00+11 and 06:00-13?> The difference only makes sense if one speaks of dates...> Which says that timezones don't make sense unless we know at what date> to apply them.there is no difference: both denote the same set of inifinitely many instants.> Alternative approach to your "isTimezoned": have a separate struct "DateTimeTZ"?yes... but that has the disadvantage that everything that currently handlesDateTime would need to be adapted to handle DateTimeTZ too.probably there are a lot of places that pass a DateTime from A to B withouteven looking at it (... and we _could_ have just added DateTime2 etc. structsinstead of changing them, but it was too much work).> Your "isTimezoned" flag should IMHO be called "isUTC".possibly, if times all were converted to UTC; but not if all times wereconverted to local time.> Do we actually *need* *any* "unknown timezone / local timezone" value> in memory? We could just make some assumption (UTC or local TZ) on> import/parse/read and store only UTC in memory.we could (as i already outlined in the other mail).  but clearly there arefile formats where time zones are not specified or optional, so it's impossibleto tell where these are exactly on the UTC timeline (see"3.2.7.4 Order relation on dateTime") _unless_ one makes some assumptionthat is not guaranteed by the standard such as all un-timezoned valuesbeing local time.> 1) Is there any part of ODF/OOXML/any other format where we need to import  or export a date with timezone?dunno about OOXML, but ODF at least has numerous attributes of typedate.  it says nothing about time zones so by referencing the XMLSchema-2types they are allowed _everywhere_ a non-time-zoned date is allowed.examples are user-defined Document Properties and field created from them,variables, (non-text) table cells, database columns (presumably default value?).> 2) Is there any part of ODF/OOXML/any other format where we need to import  or export a time (*not* datetime) with timezone?most of the same as "date" apparently.> 4) Is there any part of ODF/OOXML/any other format where we need to import>    or export a datetime value without timezone and preserve unmodified as>    without timezone?good question... it is quite likely that there are many implementationsout there that do not support time zones at all, such as older LO versions,and for interop with these it would make some sense to preserve at least theun-timezoned values as-is (by writing the same string value that was read).for timezoned values this is probably less important since such consumerswon't handle it correctly in any case.> 5) Is there any part of ODF/OOXML/any other format where we need to import> or export a datetime value without timezone, do changes on it and preserve> it as without timezone?basically the same reasoning as 4) i.e. interop with non-zone-aware consumers.

I don't know the meaning of that.> > What would it mean, how would it behave, what would it be used for?>  > in XMLSchema-2 a Date is really a 24-hour interval... so the timezone> would shift the interval on the "universal" UTC time-line.> > http://www.w3.org/TR/xmlschema-2/#dateOh My Goodness..> > For example, naively, one would think that combining a date with a time,> > one would get a datetime. How does one get a datetime by combining> > 2003-05-17+05 with 23:00-06?> > that's a very good question.  apparently Time is a set of infinitely many> points on the "universal" UTC time-line, with 24 hour distance between them.> > a Time with timezone is simply offset that much (modulo 24:00).> > so i think the DateTime you get by combining these is uniquely determined by> intersecting the Date 24-hour interval with the Time set of points.I'd think one converts 2003-05-17+05 to UTC and 23:00-06 to UTC andcombines them, then throws a dice whether to convert the result toUTC+05 or UTC-06 ...> > Your "isTimezoned" flag should IMHO be called "isUTC".> > possibly, if times all were converted to UTC; but not if all times were> converted to local time.Indeed, times without any timezone information are not even UTC, butexpected to be the same local time wherever viewed.> > Do we actually *need* *any* "unknown timezone / local timezone" value> > in memory? Patch Set 2:>> 4) I have my doubts about time-zoned time without a date.>>     How do you convert 20:00+00 to time zone +10?>>     Just "wrap around" modulo 24, i.e. make it 06:00+10?> yes>> If you answer yes to that question (that is, always compute modulo 24),>> then what is the difference between 06:00+11 and 06:00-13?>> The difference only makes sense if one speaks of dates...>> Which says that timezones don't make sense unless we know at what date>> to apply them.> there is no difference: both denote the same set of inifinitely many instants.For the sake of the following paragraphs, I'm going to assume we want to keepthe timezone in the struct (as opposed to converting timezoned values to UTC).As far as reasonably possible, data structures should have a canonical format:Don't artificially introduce different values that denote the same. If we reallyare to consider that a time is a value in timeline quotiented by 24h interval(that is a representative of the equivalence class "all moments in the timelineseparated by 24h intervals), then we have no reason to allow (for the timezonevalue) anything overlapping. Your code currently says everything has to bebetween -840 and +840 inclusive. With this interpretation, we should makeone of the following choices: - timezone between -719 and +720 - timezone between -720 and +719 - timezone between 0 and 1439That's the logical conclusion of the interpretation you propose.What I had in mind was another interpretation (which I thinkis consistent with the SQL standard's behaviour): - a timezone region is a part of the earth surface, politically   defined, that has the same time (offset to UTC); that is   calendars and clocks agree all across this zone).   (Many specific points on the surface of the globe hop from    one timezone to another twice a year.) - a datetime is a moment in time in some timezone region. - a datetime is made of two parts, namely a date and a time. - the timezone is attached to the time part of datetime.In this interpretation, the timezone value between -840 and +840refers to a region of earth. Given two timezone regions, whetherclocks agree between these two timezones is a valid question,but not the only one and besides the point for data encoding;they are different timezone regions. E.g. timezone region +660(+11 hours) and timezone region -780 (-13 hours). Clocks agreeacross these two timezones, but calendars don't, so they aredifferent timezone regions where clocks just happen to agree.We could make the following valid choice / observation:XMLSchema-2 has fucked up semantics on time / date / ...,but for adherence to standards and interoperability, we"need" to adhere to it rather than doing something morecorrect.>> Is there any part of ODF/OOXML/any other format where we>> need to import or export a date with timezone?>> dunno about OOXMLThen bring (one of) our resident expert(s) in this discussion.> (...) ODF at least has numerous attributes of type date.> it says nothing about time zones so by referencing the XMLSchema-2> types they are allowed _everywhere_ a non-time-zoned date is allowed.So basically you are saying our hands are tied, we need to cover everythingXMLSchema-2 allows. Taking your word on that, further discussion on thefollowing points is pointless, we need - timezoned date in the range -840 to +840 - timezoned time in the range -840 to +840 - timezoned datetime in the range -840 to +840 - untimezoned date, time and datetime. - Base will have to map these concepts to the   SQL world to the best of possibilities. E.g., ignore   (drop) the timezone on timezoned dates, or   throw an exception when given a timezoned date   (require only untimezoned date).The remaining decision to be made is whether the UNO structsshould encode the timezone explicitly or be "all timezoned valuesare in UTC time". The issue is muddled a bit because the UNOstructs are both our internal working structures and our "external"(scripting) API date types. I'll discuss the two uses separately.I'm really torn on this issue. Seeing LibreOffice as a programmingplatform, the UNO structs are the data types of our "standardlibrary". By putting explicit timezone in the structs, we makethe programmer's life easier because (s)he does not have todeal with converting to UTC before making an API call. We alsomake hir life more difficult because (s)he has to deal with non-UTCtime for each *result* of an API call.Here's what I would consider optimal: - All our (date)time API calls take and return UTC (date)time or   untimezoned (date)time. That is, our (date)time structure   does not have a timezone in it. It is UTC or untimezoned. - We provide a UNO service that provides utility functions that   1) convert between timezoned (date)time on the one hand       and untimezoned time in a caller-provided timezone on       the other hand (*two* incoming arguments: a (date)time       *and* an offset to UTC).   2) convert between timezoned (date)time on the one hand       and untimezoned time in local timezone on the other hand       (*one* incoming argument: a (date)time). - Hmm... As an alternative / complement to the above service,   the (date)time struct constructors takes an optional argument   that says "the values I'm giving are UTC / localtime / untimezoned"   (we add a new enum with these three values), and the constructor   makes the appropriate localtime->UTC conversion.   Can we do that in UNO? I'm unsure. Actually, I don't expect so.The spanner in the works, and the reason I'm torn, is timezoned dates.They don't fit the above schema. I hate them. For timezoned dates,we *have* to include an explicit timezone in the struct, or expect thatcode will store timezoned dates as a pair of values (a date and anoffset) - bleh. This gives us an inconsistent interface between dateon one hand and (date)time on the other hand.So, the choice boils down to: - inconsistent, but best for (date)time: use UTC for timezoned data.   explicit timezone for timezoned date. - consistent, but unnecessarily annoying for (date)time: add explicit   timezone everywhere. Provide a UNO service that answers the   question "is this the same point in time"? (that is, semantic equality)Do we *really* *really* need timezoned dates, or are they a bugin the ODF specification?Now, I turn to our internal use. IMHO, untimezoned values should justbe incomparable to timezoned values. Throw an error if it comes up.The user of the values should "know" / decide what to do: - strip / discard timezone - convert to/from localtime - convert to/from UTC time - throw an error - ...In particular, different file formats may have different requirements.Different parts of code may have different requirements. Don't forceanything on them. Provide utility functions to do the conversion andthat's it.Having *two* sets of structs (one for timezoned and one for untimezoned)has the advantage that nobody will "naively" try to compare them...IMHO it fits this model better. No need to introduce an exception for"incomparable date/time/datetime value" and no need to handlethat exception everywhere.
