Patch Set 2:>> Don't artificially introduce different values that denote the same. If we really>> are to consider that a time is a value in timeline quotiented by 24h interval>> (that is a representative of the equivalence class "all moments in the timeline>> separated by 24h intervals), then we have no reason to allow (for the timezone>> value) anything overlapping. Your code currently says everything has to be>> between -840 and +840 inclusive. With this interpretation, we should make>> one of the following choices:>>  - timezone between -719 and +720>>  - timezone between -720 and +719>>  - timezone between 0 and 1439> That simply doesn't match reality. Currently we have values from UTC-11> (SST Samoa Standard Time) to UTC+14 (LINT Line Islands Time)> So at least (!) values between -720 and +840 need to be supported,> rather -840 to +840.You removed crucial context, namely, that the discussion was *time* values(and not date or datetime), *and* that the semantics of time had been definedas:>>>> Time is a set of infinitely many points on the "universal" UTC time-line, with 24 hour distance between them.>>>> a Time with timezone is simply offset that much (modulo 24:00).You see? An offset modulo 24:00, i.e. an offset modulo 1440 minutes. By this definition, it makes no sense to store offset values in a range bigger than 1440. I repeat: *by* *this* *definition*.Because the value 04:12:20+13 and the value 04:12:20-11 denote (again: *by* *this* *definition*) the same infinitely many points on the same time-line, it is bad data structure design to code them differently. Obviously, when parsing string, we can be *much* more liberal, and even accept e.g. "04:12:20+253". But when parsing "04:12:20+253" (253 = 10*24 + 13) , we wouldn't put "15180" (253 * 60) in the offset, right? So why allow 780?For DateTime, *obviously* '2009-05-04 04:12:20+13' and '2009-05-04 04:12:20-13' are not the same.If we take a *different* definition, for example one of: - a time with timezone is the time-part of a datetime with timezone - a time with timezone is a time in an unknown date;   the date can be "filled in" by providing a date without timezone or   date with the *same* timezonethen *yes*, going from UTC-14 to UTC+14 for times makes sense. But *not* with the definition that was in context.

Patch Set 2:> Obviously, when parsing string, we can be *much* more liberal, and even accept e.g. "04:12:20+253"Sorry, bad example due to the "2 digits only" syntax. Read above comment as: and even accept e.g. "04:12:20+85"and adapt the example accordingly (5100 instead of 15180, etc).

Patch Set 2: This need some tweaks before it is mergedSo, unless one of you has something else to say, I think the discussion has outrun its course.I vote -1, but I can be overruled.I remain convinced that we are designing a flawin our API / cross-platform programming platformby catering only to these two use cases: - combination of timepoint and geographical location (timezone) - date and/or time in a undefined/unknown/... timezoneand not catering to the COMMON use case: - timepoint (purely and alone)In some way, even if the internal LibreOffice code only has usefor the two first usecases, our programming API should offera full and maximally convenient interface to our users(programmers using our scripting API).

Patch Set 2:I don't think it makes sense for the DateTimeWithTimezone struct's DateTimeInTZ member to have the possibility of having different IsTimeZoned values.What about:1) DateTimeBase (or RawDateTime?) -> a copy of the current DateTime: NanoSeconds, Seconds, Minutes, Hours, Day, Month, Year2) DateTime: derives from DateTimeBase, adds IsTimeZoned bool member.3) DateTimeWithTimezone has a "DateTimeBase DateTimeInTZ;" member and a "short TimeZone;" member.I've thought long and hard about the "store in UTC" vs "store in localtime" issue.IMO, "store in UTC" is preferable:1) It aligns our API with what (AFAIK) most APIs do.2) Since our "store in localtime" is really "store in what was the local timezone at the moment that LibreOffice started", and not "store in what the OS tells you is the local timezone right now", we need to tell our users (programmers/scripters using our API) to use _LibreOffice's_ notion of localtime (that is, offset to UTC that defines localtime), rather than the system one's (and provide a UNO service that provides the offset). I'm rather worried about creeping bugs in the whole LibreOffice/extension ecosystem where scripts / extensions will blindly copy a UNO DateTime into a system structure (such as e.g. in Python a time.struct_time) and pass it to a library expecting local time (such as Python's time.mktime), and get (sometimes) wrong results.This is a concern "only" in long-running processes (or more precisely, processes that keep running across a DST change, the computer travelling, etc), but IMO there are several legitimate scenarios where this happens: - People that (like me) leave their computer on in the night with stuff left for the next day still open - LibreOffice quickstarter on Windows, probably? - A LibreOffice process running on a server (with --headless), and other programs / scripts connect to it through URP - laptops & pocket computers (e.g. smartphones, tablets, ...) put to hibernation before travel by plane and woken thereafter3) More generally, "store in startup locatime" forces our users to deal with a *third* timezone; they already have to deal with UTC and with localtime-as-understood-by-system, now we introduce them a different timezone that is nearly, but not quite the same as the latter, namely localtime-as-understood-by-UNO.4) "store in startup localtime" makes (serialisation of) our UNO DateTime struct NOT SUITABLE for interchange, EVEN ON THE SAME MACHINE.What problem were you trying to solve by advocating "store in localtime"? From your email:1) (...) VCL does not have a DateTime widget, but a DateField and a TimeField (...) cannot transparently convert from UTC to local timezone, because they would need both date+time to do that.Well, yes. As I understand things, these widgets only deal (and until they are changed, *can* *only* deal) with Time values with IsTimeZoned==false. If some other code reads their Value property, it is then that code's responsibility to interpret that as in a specific timezone.One could argue that since legacy code will generally blissfully ignore the IsTimeZoned member, it gives better backwards compatibility. This assumes that older OO.org/LibreOffice usually served local time in css.util.(Date)Time, which is not obvious to me. It seems to be the case in *some* places, but not in others, so we need a general cleanup anyway. OOXMLDocPropHandler::GetDateTimeFromW3CDTF is an example of a codepath that puts UTC in a UNO DateTime.Any other reason for "store in startup-time localtime"?

Patch Set 1:You are very brave for stepping into this can of worms :-)In lcl_ConvertTimeZone() in sax/source/tools/converter.cxx, you are attempting to convert times between timezones.I don't think this can be done safely without access to a DST (Daylight Savings Time) database.You need to know what DST offset was in operation at that specific source date, in order to be able to convert it to a UTC time, and then you need to know the DST offset for the destination date in order to correctly switch to it.See here for a good discussion:http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2532729/daylight-saving-time-and-timezone-best-practicesThe specific recommendation from that stackoverflow article that we should probably follow is that,if we are going to store a TZ offset with our Date/Time objects, we should also be storing a DST offset.Also, if we're going to create new commonly used types/structs, perhaps we can use shorter names, like DateTimeTZ?

Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)> In lcl_ConvertTimeZone() in sax/source/tools/converter.cxx, > you are attempting to convert times between timezones. > I don't think this can be done safely without access to a > DST (Daylight Savings Time) database. It depends what you call "timezone". If it is something like "Europe/Amsterdam", that is "the time in Amsterdam", then yes, DST matters. But here, the notion of timezone is just an offset from UTC. That is, we consider that Amsterdam *changes* timezone twice per year. In this case, sure, we can freely / safely convert, we just have to subtract the offset.

Patch Set 3:> One could argue that since legacy code will generally blissfully > ignore the IsTimeZoned member, it gives better backwards > compatibility. This assumes that older OO.org/LibreOffice usually > served local time in css.util.(Date)Time, which is not obvious to me. > It seems to be the case in *some* places, but not in others, so we > need a general cleanup anyway. > OOXMLDocPropHandler::GetDateTimeFromW3CDTF is an example of a codepath > that puts UTC in a UNO DateTime.I'd regard that as an exception to the general handling, it is not only*some* places but *most* places that assume local time. > Any other reason for "store in startup-time localtime"?Document persistence and API compatibility. But, I'd not even call that"startup-time localtime" because calculations of offsets may always beinfluenced by the *current* local timezone and DST. I'd rather call it"wallclock time" because Time/DateTime fields and cell values so farcontain a time not bound to any region. Setting/getting those via UNOAPI always assumed that. Reading/writing ODF assumes it. Passing an UTCtime with IsTimeZoned=true will make existing unchanged code assume theUTC time to be wallclock time instead.To me the IsTimeZoned member doesn't make much sense other than if it isset to false. The application does not know the actual offset, no matterif we define a) true==local_time_with_timezone or b)true==UTC_with_timezone, it will always use the current offsetusing/displaying different values in different timezones for b) orcalculating different UTC for a). For only this reason b) would bebetter because the actual used value would be UTC converted to currentlocal time. But then, if that is wanted, why not useDateTimeWithTimeZone and TimeZone=0 ?Btw, I'm tempted to rename the structs and members and .idl to not useTimeZone but Timezone instead. I find it a tad confusing visually to seeDateTimeWithTimeZone (a date and time with time and zone ...) and wouldprefer DateTimeWithTimezone, but maybe that's just me.. DateTimeWithTZwould also do ;)

Patch Set 3:>> Any other reason for "store in startup-time localtime"? > Document persistence and API compatibility I'm not sure I understand what you mean by "document persistence". As soon as the document is saved to file, it survives the LibreOffice process that created it, which is how I understand "persistence" in a computer science context. If the file format asks for a local time to be saved, the file format filter can do the conversion from UTC or from "startup-time localtime"; I have more faith in conversion from UTC, because if some code fails to do it, the bug will be obvious / immediate (to the vast majority of the world). By contrast, if some code fails to convert from "startup-time localtime", the actual occurrence of the bug will be quite rare and, and the bug can survive for a loooong time in our codebase (or in the code of a user of our API). As to API compatibility, well we are, by design, doing an incompatible API change here. Yes, for our internal code, we will need to convert / adapt code that *gets* a value before code that *gives* a value starts serving values with isTimeZoned==true. > To me the IsTimeZoned member doesn't make much sense other > than if it is set to false. To me, IsTimeZoned==true and IsTimeZoned==false are, in the abstract, two different data types. We stick them in the same UNO struct because it gives a smoother conversion / upgrade path, where we don't have to change the UNO struct/type in various places as we clean up the codebase. IsTimeZoned==true refers to a moment in the "global timeline" of Newtonian physics. We could encode it as Gregorian calendar / hour/minute/second UTC, we could encode it as martian days or as Neptune years, we could encode it in the Islamic calendar, in the Solar Hijri (Iran & Afghanistan), it the calendar of the Mayas; in the abstract it does not matter as long as each unique moment in time (up to a certain resolution) has its unique representation and vice-versa. IsTimeZoned==false refers to a Gregorian calendar / hours / minutes / seconds without pinning it on the global timeline; it is the datatype of the Gregorian calendar. (which by pure chance can also be "recycled" to be used for the Julian, Islamic and Solar Hijri calendars, but not e.g. for the Jewish or Maya calendar). > The application does not know the actual offset, no matter if we define > a) true==local_time_with_timezone or > b) true==UTC_with_timezone, > it will always use the current offset using/displaying different values in different > timezones for b) or calculating different UTC for a). Well, to be coherent, in the "a)" case, the application has to use the g_nTimeZoneOffset introduced in sax/source/tools/converter.cxx, and not whatever the current system offset is. If it wants to display a time in the current local/system timezone to the user, it will have to apply g_nTimeZoneOffset and *then* apply the current system offset. For our users (programmers using our API), we have to expose it in UNO. My worry, which seems to match yours, is that people (programmers) will, by and large, fail to do this properly and just use the current system offset instead of g_nTimeZoneOffset. Which makes "b" preferable, and my understanding is you agree: > For only this reason b) would be better because the actual used value would be > UTC converted to current local time. But then, if that is wanted, why not use > DateTimeWithTimeZone and TimeZone=0 ? Because DateTimeWithTimeZone is not a canonical (standard / normal) datatype for "a moment in the global timeline": It has several representations for the same moment in time, through the use of different TimeZone values. It is like storing the year as two integers instead of one integer: struct nonCanonDateTime{    int Year; // year    int Epoch; // Gregorian year chosen as year 0; Year+Epoch == Gregorian Year    unsigned int Month;    unsigned int Day;    unsigned int Hour;    unsigned int Minute; } Where the 14:55 on 5 October 1994 can be represented as: - Minute=55, Hour=14, Day=5, Month=11, Epoch=1238; Year=756; - Minute=55, Hour=14, Day=5, Month=11, Epoch=-722; Year=2716; - Minute=55, Hour=14, Day=5, Month=11, Epoch=0; Year=1994;   (Jesus Christ-based calendar) - Minute=55, Hour=14, Day=5, Month=11, Epoch=622; Year=1372;   (Muhammad Hijra-based calendar) - Minute=55, Hour=14, Day=5, Month=11, Epoch=-3761; Year=5755;   (Jewish "Annu Mundi"-based calendar) It would be just as "possible" to use this representation, storing a year and an offset to "standard year". But it would be a bad choice, because it encodes a denormalised form of "moment in time". Using DateTimeWithTimeZone for "moment in time" has exactly the same flaw: denormalised form. For the same reasons that we normalise "009" and "09" and "9" to the same normal (canonical / standard) bitpattern 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 0001 0001 or (depending on platform) 0001 0001 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 when reading it from file, we should normalise "moment in time" to a normal/canonical value.

Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is mergedAs already discussed elsewhere, I still think this is not needed and it is ultimately the use cases requiring a static empty string that should to be cleaned up rather.But if this were to be included, it needs fixing:* The sal library must only export C functions, not C++ ones.* All entities exported by the sal library must be listed in sal.map.* @since tags are missing.* A C++ function should be placed in a namespace, not use an "rtl_..." name.* Using "(void)" as parameter list of a C++ function is frowned upon.

Patch Set 1:1946794a is a mechanical removal of rtl:: prefixes, so it can't introduce new code. Ironically, since this function gets inlined, replacing that static OUString with plain "" actually reduces the size of the .o by about 3%.Without a proof otherwise I consider the empty string pattern to be just an ugly hack for whatever historical reason, similar to RTL_CONSTASCII_USTRINGPARAM, and I don't consider it worth it.

Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is merged"if you look at rtl_uString_new() (sal/rtl/strtmp.cxx around 1130), then there already is a global empty string."This looks to me like it is a global empty rtl_uString, not a global empty OUString. The patterns you suggest look like they create a fresh OUString each time, with always the same pData member.How much is saved by having a global OUString is unclear to me.I'm worried that the new function returns a non-const reference. Unless I'm mistaken, this means that a caller can modify this OUString and then all other callers will get a non-empty string! It should return a const reference.While you are at it, make the static variable a const, also.

Patch Set 1:For the record (in responce to Lionel)the point was _not_ performace but String() migration.String() has such 'global empty string reference' thingthat is used in many places...OUString conversion so far has lead to a proliferation ofstatic OUString my_own_local_empty_string()every time that pattern was 'converted from String()due to the lack of equivalent support in OUString()I head the 'that is a bad pattern to start with'.That maybe true, but it is nevertheless commonly used, and preventing OUString from providing used pattern is just going to make thing even more ugly

Patch Set 1:"then this really is simple"repeating it does not make it so...returning a const OUString& does mean that the guy the receive it cannot modify it... it does not mean that the owner of the reference cannot... and there is code that return a const String& of some internal variable, or a ref to the global empty string.it is not always that obvious that one can safely replace that ref by a value...beside if that was that obvious why did it get used to start with ?Anyway.. I've been pissing in the wind too long on that topic.. I'll do like everybody has done... create static OUString() as needed... oh well

Patch Set 1: Do not mergeWith the caveat that I presume the intent is not code 'cleaning', but doxygenification...two things:1/ random changing of // into //< or /// is not helping if that does not fit with how doxygen actually work... for instance, inside the implementation of a function I wonder what is intended2/ if you are going to tackle the very valuable goal of improving the doxygen documentation of a module, then stick to one and do it starting from the logical top (making sure the file/classes are documented)then work your way through the public header section, and eventually the private header section...Do not just randomly change a line or two here and there.. especially across completely unrelated source file.Note that this is much more work than it seems, since useful documentation require that you actually read and understand the class you are documenting... if it was as simple of a mechanical s@//@//<@ then we would have written a script to do so already.

Patch Set 1:Not sure if I like this as it perpetuates the misconception that Calc, Writer, Impress etc would be separate "applications". Sure, anybody who works on the code a bit more, or is capable of checking what processes are running in what situations, will notice that this isn't the case, but still.On the other hand, I do like it *if* this is supposed to turn into something that can be used through --disable-base to also bypass *build* of for instance all database-related functionality in *all* aspects of LO, i.e. what the currently stalled --disable-database-connectivity hack was supposed to to.

Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is mergedI agree with Tor's concerns - the idea that you can disable eg. charting, or calc - and still be able to load documents is -seriously- poisonous: it essentially cannot be done reliably -nor- are we interested in fixing the bugs.Last time I discussed this with you; I believe I mentioned that (from my perspective) this would only be acceptable in master with some serious warnings. As soon as a single one of these disable options is used we need to:* remove any versioning information from Help->About - and replace it with some scary string: "un-supportable version configured - this product is missing key functionality and will not work"  [ might do it ].* display a huge warning at the end of configure:  "You disabled some pieces of LibreOffice - you are now running an un-supported configuration against which we are not interested in receiving bug reports, you are on your own. Please, under no circumstances package or distribute  this sort of build, it will lead only to you getting a very hard stare."* Preferably add some form of interactive confirmation of this during the build to make it even harder for packagers to do this: a simple "hit enter to continue" followed by a 'read' statement might do it at the end of configure ;-)Anyhow - at least with that - if someone has shipped that - we can detect and ignore them more easily, and (I hope) packagers will not be so foolish as to do this.How does that sound ? :-)

Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approveAs already expressed elsewhere:http://nabble.documentfoundation.org/Master-branch-now-requires-liborcus-0-5-0-or-higher-tp4049684p4051339.htmlI am wary of spreading the tree of build scenarios even further. Its not as if we dont have enough work with the existing ones. However, with big-fat-red-warnings suggested by Michael, I think this is acceptable. After all Lionels point stands: Distros are doing it, so it is done already -- and _if_ its done, the right place is upstream, not some packaging hack.Oh, one more thing: This should not only get a warning in the binary, but also big one at the end of ./configure, saying that it is an "experimental and unsupported build, use at own risk ...".E.g. subsequentchecks will obviously fail with partial builds, and it not the job of those maintaining those tests to fix that up, but must be part of the work on this feature (as is helping out unsuspecting newcomers accidentally enabling this and asking for help on the list or IRC) before it can move anywhere from "experimental and unsupported".

Patch Set 1:Haven't really looked at anything here in depth, but one thing to note is that on Mac OS X native UNO components in extensions expect to find the URE libraries via @executable_path/urelibs/ paths.  (Where the relevant executables include, but are not necessarily limited to, "uno" from URE and "soffice".)  No longer providing those paths would thus be an incompatible change that can break existing extensions.

Patch Set 1:Hi Tor,The remove-and-rebuild test is indeed the criteria that I'm using. There's too many files to check by hand so a automated or at least semi-automated approach is necessary.Anyway, thanks for the comments! I hadn't thought about indirect inclusion. How about this refined approach:For each .cxx file,1) Use the brute-force approach to find candidate headers for removal, and use "g++ -H" to dump out a full list of all included headers 2) If a candidate header shows up *once* in the list from g++ -H, it's definitely unnecessary and we remove it. If it shows up more than once (via indirect inclusion), then we leave it alone for now.This should give a smaller list of includes to remove, or in the case of no indirect inclusions, the same list.Are there any other pitfalls that are worth looking out for? Cheers,Michael

Patch Set 1: Do not mergeSorry, no. The assert is there for a reason. It is *good* to use lots of assertions in the code. We certainly don't want to remove them. In a non-debug build that assert() expands to nothing, and thus to the compiler it seems that s is unused.So the correct fix is to either make the compiler ignore the unusedness of s by adding a   (void) s;   statement, or replace s with the expression that is assigned to it inside the assert().

Patch Set 2:Isn't this a bit like deciding the right language for implementing UNO services in core?There (as far as I understand) the opinion is that new code should use C++, but Java -> Python conversion is considered useful (think of converting wizards). Patch Set 1:Stephan, LO targeting a version > 1.5 does not need to change jvmfwk because newer java versions can ALWAYS consume older class files, so regardless of the version we are targeting, jvmfwk can continue to produce class files tagged with the 1.5 version.

Patch Set 1: No scoreStephan, then I say we should just remove that configure mechanism. If we say we support 1.5+, then we should just unconditionally generate 1.5-compatible class files.People keep getting confused anyhow, thinking that they have to set the configure flag to match their currently installed version of java.

Patch Set 1:"make classfile.cxx use the "_java_target_ver" variable to determine what class-file version number it should spit out":  But why change classfile.cxx at all?  Generating 1.5 .class files there in all cases works just fine, at least as long as we have no need to make use of more recent features in the generated .class files anyway.  (Originally, the generated .class files were even designed to work with then-relevant 1.4 while also making use of 1.5 features where available, though that needed to be changed later with <http://cgit.freedesktop.org/libreoffice/core/commit/?id=26643fb59e0005f0bc83708b785d20d62d8e7411> "codemaker: write version 49 (1.5) class files.")
Patch Set 1: AbandonedThis patch seems to be lingering in gerrit without action. The review was negative. Abandoning it! One can always resubmit if needed.

Patch Set 1:"... Originally, the generated .class files were even designed to work with then-relevant 1.4 while ..."@Stephan: How is this something we set at the upstream project level? IMHO the choice of building compatible against a specific Java-version is the responsibility of the guy releasing the binary (Linux packagers, TDF release builders). Ultimately, trying to enforce this in the source tree is futile anyway -- a release engineer might happily patch you over (and will, if there are good reasons for it).

Patch Set 1:There seems to be some misunderstanding how Java versions work, and how Java is used in LO.IMNSO, this whole "configure the JVM version" thing has no purpose at all.LO, to the best of my knowledge, requires a minimum version of Java, but other than that has no Java-version-specific code at all.And Java is fully backwards-compatible. A newer VM can __always__ run .class files from an older VM.So allowing the user to change the version of .class files we produce has no benefit, and only adds unnecessary complexity.The only thing we should be doing at autogen time is confirming that the version of Java available to autogen meets our minimum version requirements.

Patch Set 1:@Noel: Well, in theory targeting a newer VM might give you optimizations and faster execution, shouldnt it? In practice, there likely is no relevant improvement in JVMs on that since 1.5.So in practice, having yet-another-configure-switch for this minor benefit is not entirely justified. At least not without some serious profiling.IMHO _that_ is the rationale to decide this on (and indeed -- as of now to respectfully reject it), as for the rest the decision will be on the packager anyway and is mostly none of the projects business (which should care about the source and not about the binaries).

Patch Set 1:that option is used for both source and target java version, making it possible to use newest java features (since 1.5):http://cgit.freedesktop.org/libreoffice/core/tree/solenv/gbuild/JavaClassSet.mk#n29 gb_JavaClassSet_JAVACCOMMAND := $(ICECREAM_RUN) $(JAVACOMPILER)   $(JAVAFLAGS) \    -source $(JAVA_SOURCE_VER) -target $(JAVA_TARGET_VER)

Patch Set 1:@David, that flag does NOT impact end-users.It perfectly possible to compile our LO code with "-source 1.5 -target 1.5", and for the customer to use Java version 1.6 or 1.7 or 1.8 language features to write their own extension or plugin code, just as long as they also install a newer JRE.So changing this flag has no useful purpose.

Patch Set 1:"'... Originally, the generated .class files were even designed to work with then-relevant 1.4 while ...'"@Stephan: How is this something we set at the upstream project level? IMHO the choice of building compatible against a specific Java-version is the responsibility of the guy releasing the binary (Linux packagers, TDF release builders). Ultimately, trying to enforce this in the source tree is futile anyway -- a release engineer might happily patch you over (and will, if there are good reasons for it)."Bj鈹溍俽n, I'm sorry, but I completely fail to understand how your question and comments relate to the sentence of mine that you quote.

Patch Set 1:@David, ah, thanks, I see what you want.But I still don't see what's keeping you from unconditionally setting "-source 1.6 -target 1.6" in your private tree until such time as your work is ready to make it's way upstream, at which point this patch might make sense.But even when your work is ready, I'd argue for a more specific autogen flag, something like:   --enable-java-invokedynamicwhich is less likely to cause confusion, and more likely to be used correctly.While you are working on your feature, you can always hide it behind a #define of your own making.My private non-binding opinion as a johnny-come-lately LO developer is still that this feature currently has a negative cost-benefit ratio, because it's benefit is limited to one already-skilled developer, and it is known to cause confusion amongst the wider LO developer community.

Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)Lionel:Sorry, I made a mistake with gerrit patch."thought you might be interested in this one. What Noel proposed could be very useful indeed but could there be cases where we do want specific treatment if first parameter NULL? (and so the NULL argument should be dealt before calling macros SQL_IS_RULE and others)"

Patch Set 1:In this specific case and with the current SQL grammar, pParamRef cannot be NULL: a general_set_fct has at least four children (and in particular strictly more than two), so pParamRef has been initialised with: pParamRef = pColumnRef->getChild(nColumnRefPos);That's too subtle for coverity (and possibly warrants at least a comment).I'm not opposed to adding a specific NULLness check, which would future-proof the code a bit against changes in the grammar.Adding the NULLness check to the macro looks good to me from a safety POV; it could make the code in general a bit slower, but I don't think the impact would be significant enough that anybody would care.

Patch Set 1: AbandonedThank you Lionel for your feedback.I'm really hesitating about all this, the more I think about this the more I consider the check in SQL_IS_RULE like equivalent to hide the problem. I suppose I must be wrong but I prefer to abandon this patch.

Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)Hmmm, if we are already customizing the categories, I wonder if we should rename it from 'verified' to 'tinderbox', as the 'default workflow' proposed by the gerrit authors uses 'verified' very different -- for manual testing of a fix: http://source.android.com/source/life-of-a-patch.htmlJust some random rambling as I dont know how much additional work that is, but it might spare newcomer to LibreOffice some confusion (esp. if they are used other customs from other projects).

Patch Set 2:'VRIF' is generic category, i. e. you can verify by a tinderbox, or you can verify manually.If you introduce new category: TNDB for Tinderbox, then both have to be positive: VRIF & TNDB.What Norbert come up with is to have the follow values for VRIF -2,-1,0,+1,+2And let gerrit buildbot verification only vote -1,+1,+2, so that the developer still can overwrite the failure (-1) with his +2, in case he thinks it was false negative.

Patch Set 2:My proposal was rather to have no 'verified' field as other gerrit installations use 'verified' in the sense it is used on e.g. bugzilla: 'I have run the application and can confirm the bug is gone with this.' -- which is not what our tinderboxes do (or can do).So using a field titled 'tinderbox' would be a bit more honest: a +1/+2 just means that, and a developers manually giving a +2 there is meaning just that: 'I tested the build or am reasonably confident that it doesnt break the build (but I have not tested the fix to remove the bug its claiming to fix)'.No blocking whatsoever from my side, just some thoughts.

Patch Set 1:m_xRootFolder = m_pRootFolder = new ZipPackageFolder( m_nFormat, m_bAllowRemoveOnInsert );where m_xRootFolder is ::com::sun::star::uno::Reference < com::sun::star::container::XNameContainer > m_xRootFolderlooks to me that we're not supposed to call delete directly on that m_pRootFolder.CID 704153 (#1 of 1): Resource leak in object (CTOR_DTOR_LEAK) [select issue]    1. alloc_new: Allocating memory by calling "new ZipPackageFolder(this->m_nFormat, this->m_bAllowRemoveOnInsert)".    2. var_assign: Assigning: "this->m_pRootFolder" = "new ZipPackageFolder(this->m_nFormat, this->m_bAllowRemoveOnInsert)".    3. ctor_dtor_leak: The constructor allocates field "m_pRootFolder" of "ZipPackage" but the destructor and whatever functions it calls do not free it. 160    m_xRootFolder = m_pRootFolder = new ZipPackageFolder( m_nFormat, m_bAllowRemoveOnInsert ); 161} 162    Yeah, I think its a false positive in coverity which doesn't take the m_xRootFolder into account. Its odd code, but I don't think there's a leak.

Patch Set 3: Fails; I would prefer that you didn't submit thisThe hardest part of this was finding out that X11SalGraphics::GetGlyphBoundRect was involved, so kudos to discovering that.The workaround to search the lower levels if a glyph isn't found however is a bit of a bodge, because I don't think we shuold be asking for the wrong glyphs there in the first place. I think http://cgit.freedesktop.org/libreoffice/core/commit/?id=98f56121858b4bea54d056a073005a10648785c6 should work instead.In MultiSalLayout::GetBoundRect we loop through each fallback font and union each level's GetBoundRect to get the result, which seems reasonable, except that for each level that's means a call to SalLayout::GetBoundRect which calls X11SalGraphics::GetGlyphBoundRect.Those sublevels SalLayouts don't know that they are sublevels so they never set the level bits on their glyphs. Which results in X11SalGraphics::GetGlyphBoundRect always searching for that glyph in the level 0 font, so there's a mismatch between the font the SalLayout's are created to use and the font that gets used.Now, SalLayout::GetBoundRect is a fairly simple thing, it just calls GetNextGlyphs 1 by 1 and X11SalGraphics::GetGlyphBoundRect on the result of that.  So I *think* that if we remove the specialized MultiSalLayout::GetBoundRect in favour of the default implementation, then because MultiSalLayout::GetNextGlyphs is specialized to do-the-right-thing and set up the glyph ids correctly, then we bubble the ids down to X11SalGraphics::GetGlyphBoundRect correctly to get it to use the right font and we get the correct bounding size.

Patch Set 3: AbandonedI agree using MultiSalLayout::GetNextGlyphs is right way to fix this bug . I didn't remove MultiSalLayout::GetBoundRect  because i thought removing it might break something else.Thanks for reviewing patch

I would prefer to remove this for three reasons:- our ./configure is already way too complex- this is not really a build configuration thing (but some DSCM topic) and doesnt even belong in ./configure- having this in ./configure suggests it to be a 'supported scenario'. Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit thisThis change improves situation somewhat in the case that the search term is present only in cell A1 in the sense that "Search key not found" doesn't pop up anymore, but if the search key occurs elsewhere in the sheet the search still finds that other occurrence instead. Actually the change only suppresses the dialog but does not change the behavior.Note also the scenario described in https://bugs.freedesktop.org/show_bug.cgi?id=36800#c9"Before I press replace, I want to confirm that the correct reference will be replaced (A2 also contains "quick", which I don't want replaced).  If I press "find", it will go to Cell A2.  But if, instead of "find", I pressed "replace", it would replace the "quick" in Cell A1, not Cell A2."Additionally, with this change you now don't get the "LibreOffice Calc has searched to the end of the sheet. Do you want to continue at the beginning?" dialog anymore if the occurrence is only in cell A1 and A1 is also the current cell. This is inconsistent, the dialog is presented if the search key occurs in any other cell only.What we actually needed would be that the search would find the current cell first (as does replace), and not touch the logic when dialogues are presented.

Patch Set 1: Fails; Do not submitNice idea :-)  But.. it doesn't work as intended.First, the function should not calculate both paths (which is automatically done to pass results of expressions as arguments), it should work more like the IF() function, where a conditional path is only calculated for the corresponding condition.Second, this implementation works only for some cases. =IFERROR(1/0,2)works and result is 2, but already =IFERROR(1/0,2+3)propagates the #DIV/0! error instead of returning 5. Also =IFERROR(1+1,1/0)propagates the #DIV/0! error instead of returning 2.I suggest you take a look at the implementation of ocIf and use a similar approach with only one conditional path instead of two, for which the condition is calculated from the expression's result whether it is an error or not and then a jump is executed or not. There is some special code in the compiler to calculate jump paths (lookout for ocIf), and handling is different from normal functions in the interpreter. Feel free to ask for details and pointers on the mailing list.

Patch Set 2: Do not submitThanks for tackling this issue ! I have a few comments however:It seems to me that using isalpha / isprint on string characters like this is a particularly horrible way to achieve this :-)To copy/paste a similar chunk of text twice like that is rather poor style - in programming for maintainability the aim is always to minimise the number of new lines we add: to maximise the sharing of lines of code etc.As such - I'd really strongly prefer as much of the if (rtl) { } cases to be shared with the non-rtl cases - can we not setup variables that alter the order of iteration / layout placement / rendering in advance and then use them in a shared block later ?When we do:+            // this code are for reverse the number of sildes in TitleThe title we have there seems to come from:void PresenterPaneBase::PaintBorder (const awt::Rectangle& rUpdateBox)...            mxBorderPainter->paintBorder(                mxPaneId->getResourceURL(),                mxBorderCanvas,                aLocalBorderBox,                rUpdateBox,                msTitle);msTitle - can we not translate translate and/or generate that msTitle (SetTitle?) in the first instance ?Is that created from a template in:void PresenterController::UpdatePaneTitles (void)if so - we should fix it there in just one place :-)That template prolly comes from the (localised?) configuration and just needs changing there ?Anyhow - thanks again for looking at this - with a few tweaks (as above) I think we can make it a lot sweeter.Thanks !

Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit thisIn general, such ifdeffed-out code should not be removed just blindly, but one should check for how long it has been ifdeffed out, and whether there is any comment indicating it is soemthing a still active developer intends to get back to, etc.In this case, I think this code might well be useful, if only we had somebody who was working on this part of the code and was interested in this self-check functionality.(Personally I have no idea what a "job" or "job URL" is.)There is a comment in joburl.cxx that says: "It's used for internal purposes only and never a part of a legal product. Use it for testing and debug only!" so I think it's clear that the intent is that you #define ENABLE_COMPONENT_SELF_CHECK only in your own work copy while working on this code, and that such a #define never gets into version control.Now, another question is then whether we have anybody who knows what this code does, and is interested in debugging and developing it. Would it be better to test DBG_UTIL instead of ENABLE_COMPONENT_SELF_CHECK, to at least make sure the code still compiles (in a --enable-dbgutil build) and doesn't break at run-time?SOme discussion on the mailing list needed IMHO.

Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit thisI think you should split this into three patches, one for Unix-only code, one for cross-platform code, and one for Windows-only code. That would make it easier to actually verify.I see at least one real problem in the patch for crashrep/source/unx/main.cxx: you change it to use %u for a size_t variable that isn't cast. This breaks when compiled for 64-bit, where %u is for 32-bit unsigned int, and size_t is 64-bit. There might be other similar issues elsewhere in the patch. But note that the crashrep module is not built so your changes to it won't even get compiled...That said, I wonder if it is correct of that main.cxx to use size_t for the return value of ftell(). Is there no Unix where in 32-bit code ftell() still returns a 64-bit value?

Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit thisHi Mathias,first thanks for your patch. It is great start; Well, it does some non-standard things. I suggest to re-shufle it a bit :-)1. You already mentioned that you were unsure about    downloading the files inside configure. I suggest to   do it using the download script.   You might already see the many @FILENAME@ entries in   ooo.lst.in. They are optional. If you do not define such    variable in configure, it will be empty in the generated    ooo.lst file and it will not be downloaded.2. If you use download, it will get the files into the   $TARFILE_LOCATION instead of $SRC_ROOT/moz/zipped.      I suggest to modify the related makefiles in "moz"    module to find the .zip archives in $TARFILE_LOCATION   Note that this approach follows the current trends.   In the past, we copied many 3rd party tarballs into   the related build subdirectories. We do not longer   do it. We already updated most makefiles to unpack the    tarballs directly from the $TARFILE_LOCATION.   3. I suggest to do not copy the dlls in configure because    it is not typical. Instead, I suggest to define variables   that will point to the files. Then you could copy the   files in the makefile that need to use the dlls.4. Please, do not remove the TABs from configure.in from    lines 4469-4515. These lines are copied into "Makefile"    that is later tested. TABs are important in Makefiles,   so your change breaks this test.Thanks a lot for working on it. Feel free to ask if you are in doubts.

Patch Set 1: Do not submitHmm, I am confused by all the changes:1. In the dmake fix, it does not make sense to save   the number of read items and just increment it.      Instead, it would make sense to check if it really   did read the item, for example:      if (fread( (char *)&flhdr, sizeof(flhdr), 1, f ) != 1) return (-1);   2. In the lpsolve fix, it is not a good idea to redirect all   error messages to /dev/null. It would hide real build   errors as well.      Instead, it would be better to fix the lpsolve code   to do not produce warnigns at all.3. The concat-deps.c is strange as well. It is a similar   problem like in dmake.      IMHO, we need to return an error if it does not write   the whole item => you need to modify the function   print_fullpaths to return integer instead of void.   Then you could use something like:      if (fwrite(token, token_len, 1, stdout) != 1) return EIO;      Of course, you need to handle the print_fullpaths return   value where it is called.

Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit thisI am sorry for the late response. I am busy with preparing the tag for 3.6.3-rc3.Hmm, I still do not like your solution. In short:1. It would be better to squash all the commits into one. It is easier to review. Also it would help if you later investigate the git history. You could use     git rebase -i origin/master   and follow the instructions2. You patch hides potential errors using thatif( function_call(...) ) ; construct . It means that the application could proceed random data. Instead, it should propagate the errors. For example, it should return (-1) in dmake if it was not able to read the data. I wrote this in the first comment already.

Patch Set 2:I am still not convinced this is a good idea. We are mixing two kinds of dependencies there: build time and run time (i.e., a library does not need any resource file for build). There are other kinds of resources that are needed at run time, e.g., dlopened libraries. IMHO the only approach that would really work is to postpone running the tests _after_ the build phase of a module.

Patch Set 2:the difference between build.pl and tail_build implementations of module.all is that with build.pl all dependent modules are built completely while for tail_build only the target module is built completely, and from the others only the directly needed targets are build, so adding dependencies to solenv/gbuild/Module.mk doesn't help.but i still don't like the patch :)just look at how many places load a "fps_office" resource...i think there are some more options:1. move the failing tests to subsequentcheck, that would be much simpler2. go though all resource loading calls and add explicit resource dependencies to each Library_foo.mk that contains a call.   i guess these are loaded via ResMgr::CreateResMgr or possibly via ResMgr::SearchCreateResMgr as well; 94 calls3. put in some hack to be used only by unit tests that loads all resources from a different path, and add to each test some rule that copies all needed resources to a test specific directoryhmm i don't like 3. much either...

Patch Set 2:oh wait there is another option which i don't like:4. re-create the module level dependencies from */prj/build.lst in tail_build, so that modules are always built completely.i think this would limit parallelism too much (but it would have the advantage that it would also limit parallel linking so we get less OOM problems :) )

Patch Set 2: AbandonedAll right, abandoning.I don't think moving the tests to subsequentcheck would be welcomed.Also re-introducing modules in gbuild in definitely not right.So I choose 2. and maybe I will add some explicit deps somewhere sometime if I will be annoyed again by that they are missing.

Patch Set 1:So, I've done a little more research..Note that this was not meant as cleanup.I've done make sw.all or maybe it was also make writerfilter.all and this patch helped me to build that way.Original motivation is failing tinderbox because of missing deps."you are assuming that for every resource target there is a library with the same name; this is not actually the case; for example see extensions/AllLangResTarget_upd.mk"I wish it to be true, it is in most cases but sometimes it's not. But what bad can happen ? There will be new target, which will be, hopefully, ignored."furthermore i don't actually know whether even if there _were_ a library for every resource target, this approach would work, because i don't know how these resource files are loaded: are they always loaded from exactly one library, or can it happen that there are 2 libraries that load the same resource file?"Sure, it's not perfect. There are also resource files opened with the same library. So there still are going to be missing dependencies.I think I did not remove any dep and created a few more, some of them useful and some of them not but they should not hurt.So, I think the patch improves the situation.Would be better to rename resources and use it correctly but...Thanks

Patch Set 1: Do not submitI think this change is wrong.
